Title: sandalwood: Get set for Chandan Shetty, All.OK as film music composers
Content: You’ve grooved to their songs at parties and festive occasions and now’s the time to hear their songs resonate across movie halls. Independent artistes Chandan Shetty All.OK and ViRaj Kannadiga are all set to make their silver screen debuts as composers with the upcoming Kannada films Pogaru Bengalur Boys and Omelette , respectively.Amid enjoying life as a newly-wed, Chandan Shetty has also been busy composing music for the Dhruva Sarja-starrer Pogaru. “In the Indie scene, you release a single every now and then, which is a song, that you compose, sing and feature in the video. But when you are working on a film, there are multiple factors that come into play — the hero, heroine, story, situations or a context a song fits into and so on and so forth. You brainstorm with lyricists, the director and the rest of the team to ensure the best output and rope in the most suited singers for the same. That has been a great learning,” says Chandan.Foregoing his characteristic EDM, hip-hop style, he has experimented with new genres for Pogaru. “The protagonist, played by Dhruva, is far from the conventional hero character, and is more rugged than romantic. So, we needed songs that enhanced the massy, local flavour of the narrative. I have used traditional percussion instruments to create that ambience. There are some dance numbers to watch out for,” he explains.Kempirve-fame director Venkat Bharadwaj’s Omelette will not only mark musician ViRaj Kannadiga’s filmi debut as composer, but it will also be his first onscreen outing. “I am composing the title track — a youthful rap number that provides a quirky, fun take on life by drawing parallels to an omelette,” says ViRaj.He shares that his biggest takeaway from the experience has been learning how to cater a song to the requirements put forth by the filmmakers. “While the title track does not directly relate to the story, the experience has taught me to make music for specific requirements. As an independent artiste, you tend to pursue only the ideas that interest you. But in movies, the compositions have to be in sync with what the filmmakers are trying to convey,” he explains.Musician All.OK is no stranger to film music, he has, after all, sung playback earlier. But with the upcoming film Bengalur Boys, he turns composer and is excited about showcasing his prowess with diverse musical genres. “While there will be a rap song, we will also showcase nouveau genres like Chill-hop, Techno, and House, which haven’t been explored that often in Sandalwood . The film’s story is youthful and we want the tracks to reflect the same. I am also looking at featuring new artistes on the album and using it as a platform to introduce talent,” says All.OK.Independent artistes coming into film is a good sign, he adds. “Artistes like Anirudh and Hiphop Tamizha are the perfect examples. They were successful artistes and then went on to make a name as composers too. Even rapper Eminem composed for a mainstream Hollywood project, which he won accolades for. So, independent artistes coming into film brings newness to the field,” he says.

Title: Nandaa’s role is not that of a regular villain in this film
Content: Nandaa, who wowed Kollywood buffs with his double act in the recent release Vaanam Kottatum , has bagged yet another interesting role — he will play the antagonist in Atharvaa ’s film, which is being directed by Ravindra Madhava The debutant director says, “When I approached Nandaa for the film, he didn’t ask me if he was playing the protagonist or the antagonist. His question was, ‘Why should I do this character?’ I told him he’ll understand it when I narrate the script. So he listened to the story and also his character, and agreed to be part of the film.”So, what’s his role like? “He is not a regular villain ,” says Ravindra. “Who’s this guy? Why’s he doing what he’s doing? That’s the mystery element in the film, and the hero’s character has to decode it.”Nandaa will start shooting for his portions once shooting resumes after the lockdown period in Kollywood.“We had just started shooting for the film with Atharvaa (who plays a constable) and Lavanya Tripathi (who plays an IAS aspirant) a few days ago, but because of the Coronavirus pandemic, we halted work. Nandaa was supposed to have joined us now—we were planning to shoot his portions and also do some set work for the film — but we will resume filming only next month I guess,” Ravindra signs off.

Title: Meet the Corona crooners: Baba Seghal, Anoop Seelin and Rashmi Shaarvi
Content: The coronavirus now features in compositions by musicians:Baba Seghal, Indi pop artistRapper and musician Baba Sehgal recently released a new song, titled Namaste, which is based on the ways to deal with the novel coronavirus.The lyrics of the song are based on different ways to deal with COVID-19 and how people around the globe are adopting Indian salutation namaste to greet each other amid the outbreak of the highly contagious virus. Through his song, Baba asks people to not panic and stop travelling to shoot the virus.Anoop Seelin, music directorComposer Anoop Seelin and the team of the upcoming film Inspector Vikram have come up with a fun, peppy COVID-19 pandemic awareness song titled Hey Guys Corona. This, incidentally, is the cover of their song Hey Guys from the film. “I’ve sung this track as well. This came as idea from our team when we saw how the seriousness of the matter has taken over the world and how the videos online, especially those with quirk and humour, were providing some kind of relief. We took just one day to come up with this track,” says Anoop.Rashmi Shaarvi, singerBengaluru-based singer and techie Rashmi Shaarvi’s has penned her version of events surrounding the conronavirus pandemic and sung it to the tune of Camila Cabello ’s Havana, which has promptly gone viral since its release. Terming it a lighter take on Corona, the lyrics of Rashmi’s song details how the virus originated in China, has everyone freaking out, obsessed with sanitisers and masks that have now become the latest fashion trend, while also highlighting the need to maintain basic hygiene to keep the virus at bay.

Title: None of us participants knew the extent of the pandemic: Sanjjanaa Galrani
Content:
Sanjjanaa

When Sanjjanaa Galrani took off to be a part of the Hindi reality show Mujhse Shaadi Karoge, she was prepared to fight it out and emerge winner. But with the Covid-19 pandemic shutting all film and TV production in most parts of the country, her plans were derailed. The actress, who was cooped up in the house as part of the show for a month without access to her phone or other tech gadgets, tells us, “None of the participants knew the extent of the pandemic until Paras (Chhabra) updated us about what was happening outside. Honestly, it was scary to hear about the partial shutdown. Then, earlier this week, policemen come to the set and told us to stop production. In the next few hours, the finale of the show was conducted and then all of us packed up and got ready to return home. I took an 11 pm flight the same night, reached Bengaluru and headed home. Ever since, I have been practising social distancing and catching up on all the episodes of the show. ”While her stint on the show was short-lived,says that she got what she set out to achieve. “Those 32 days (her duration in the house) were a really good, learning experience. When I joined the show, no one really knew me in Mumbai. But when I was heading home this week, a lot of people outside the set and at the airport were calling out to me. It made me immensely happy that people now know me nation-wide and that the hard work has paid off.”

Title: Director Fazil: After the first climax was shot, I felt the film won’t run, so re-did it with a new script
Content: I have often had bold, independent women in my films, be it Girly of Nokketha Doorathu Kannum Nattu or Maya Vinodini of Ente Sooryaputhrikku. The period between 1985 and 95 was a time of change in Malayalam cinema, and the atmosphere, I remember, urged me to think of brave themes for films too. Even 10 years earlier, I might not have make many of my films that I did during this time. The 90s was also a time when women were slowly showing a boldness in real-life too and so, the timing of Ente Sooryaputhrikku was just right.As everyone knows, this is the first Malayalam film of Amala Akkineni. I knew her even before she joined movies, as a talented dance student of Kalakshetra. She had an interest in acting too and so, I had her in mind for a role. When I developed the script of Ente Sooryaputhrikku, I felt she is the right fit for the character of Maya Vinodhini and roped her in. As she isn’t a Malayali, as an incentive for her, I made the film in Malayalam and Tamil.I remember we could pick exactly the right actors for each of the roles in the film. As K S Vasundhara Devi, the Carnatic singer who is the mother of Amala’s character, I could think of nobody else by Srividya . She is the daughter of singer M L Vasanthakumari and had an aura about her that was just right for the character. Suresh Gopi , who played Maya’s love interest Dr Srinivasan, wasn’t the superstar that he later became. Ente Sooryaputhrikku is a women-oriented film and what I wanted was a male protagonist who wasn’t a full-blown hero. Suresh wasn’t too busy at that time. He used to do all kinds of roles and it was a period of growth for him. I felt he is the perfect fit for Dr Srinivasan and he proved it with the performance. Same goes for all the other characters.An episode from the shoot that remains etched to my mind is the climax shoot of Ente Sooryaputhrikku. In the first version of my script, the final scene, in which she murders the villains, wasn’t there. My script had Maya declaring the truth about her parents in a speech and we had shot it too. But when I saw the film with that particular climax after the shoot, I felt it won’t have a good run in theatres… this version doesn’t give the film a strong pre-climax or climax. That got me worked up. I spoke to Amala and asked her for an extra 20 days of shoot. I wrote an altogether new climax scene and as one would say, she gave a thattupolippan prakadanam as well. And that’s what the film had in theatres. The new climax was well worth it.- As told to

Title: Pruthvi Ambaar: Pruthvi Ambaar turns scriptwriter for romantic thriller
Content: Popular actress Sana Khan, who has worked in several blockbuster films and hit television shows, has taken to social media to declared that she is quitting the world of showbiz in order to serve humanity and follow the path of her Creator.

Title: Meet the sparrow warriors of Tamil Nadu
Content: The humble tiny bird, house sparrow, whose chirping was hitherto an integral part of our lives has been missing from our homes and neighbourhood. The bird, which co-existed with human beings for so long, is now unable to cope with the decline in nesting spaces, felling of trees, and mindless construction activities, and their population has been dwindling at an alarming rate.But what’s heartening is that people are gradually realising the fact and are working on war footing to save these tiny birds from extinction. Here are a few sparrow warriors from namma Tamil Nadu who have been tirelessly working to bring back the sparrows…I was always interested in birds and animals. As I grew up, I realised that some animals and birds that I used to see often as a child, were missing now, and especially, the sparrows. So, I started the Sparrow Conservation Movement – Refuge for Feathered Guests in 2012. I began experimenting with boxes as sparrow nests. I first made a box with used cardboard boxes. This was followed by boxes made of clay and plywood. We finally picked the right bird box, which was 9 inches tall, 4 inches wide, with a 32mm opening. I make these boxes whenever I find the time. I have given away more than 1,000 boxes free till now. Sparrows spend a lot of time in the nest while laying eggs and hatching them. The young ones stay inside until they take their first flight, which is usually in 21 days. One you put up the sparrow box, stop taking pictures and checking if there are eggs. If you do that, the sparrows will fly away. — B Pandiarajan, Sparrow Conservation Foundation, CoimbatoreOur living room in Perambur had a small enclosure that was left open for the sparrows. It’s my mother who pointed it out to me that their numbers have been dwindling. When I made a few nests and put them up there they were occupied by sparrows the very next day. For me, every day is a sparrow day. At my mother’s place in Besant Nagar, we put up a nest in 2016. We have already had at least three generations of sparrows there. Lack of food, water, and shelter has been a major setback for the sparrows. Sparrows help in keeping the mosquito population in check. Sparrows can avoid a lot of vector-borne diseases as well. My mission this year is to make 10,000 feeders. I have been creating awareness about sparrows among school kids and teaching them to make feeders using discarded plastic bottles. At homes, the least we can do is to keep bird feeders and water bowls—Sadhana Rajkumar, Sparrow Conservationist, ChennaiOn every World Sparrow Day, we reach out to the public to spread awareness about the bird. We started this as a practice in 2012 and for the last eight years, we have been distributing around 500 boxes every year. But only 10 per cent of the boxes are in good condition as people tend to buy these boxes out of excitement, but fail to provide a conducive environment for the birds to live. We provide three types of artificial nests — mud pots, shoe boxes, and wooden boxes. People still don’t know the importance of the bird in the ecosystem. The change in the building structures is one of the primary reasons for the dwindling of sparrows. People are increasingly putting up nets to escape from mosquitoes. This prevents the entry of sparrows into the houses.- M Rajesh, professor, sparrow lover, MaduraiAlong with Dr Priyatharshini Rajendran from Lady Doak College and K Renuka Devi, I have been doing research on house sparrows. We have visited 13 blocks in Madurai and had found 2,571 sparrows in the preliminary survey. We chose 168 villages out of the 420 villages in Madurai last year for our research and were shocked to find that only 109 villages had sparrows. The primary reasons behind the decline are the decrease in the nesting space and change in the building structure. Today, most of the buildings are air-conditioned and do have not have ledges or vents for sparrows to come and sit. Food availability, too, has become a major concern as the pesticide used in the farms, kills the worms and insects, which are the primary food for sparrows. Sparrows are omnivores but feed the young ones with different kinds of food based on their age.- P Merlynna Ester, sparrow researcher, Madurai1.Nest to be fixed inside the verandah, balcony or in a sheltered car park.2. See that squirrels, cats and crows do not have easy access to the nest.3. The nest has to be fixed at a height of 10 feet.4. The opening of the nest should preferably be facing the south or west. (Basically, there shouldn’t be any direct sunlight falling on it).5. The nest should have a percher, so that the adult birds find it easy to feed their young ones.6. Do not try filling the nest with cotton and coconut fibre.7. Do not touch the box once it has been fixed.8.Place water bowls and bird feeders in their vicinity.

Title: Is Murugadoss directing Vijay in #Thalapathy65?
Content: With Master ready to hit screens soon, there’s a strong buzz about Vijay’s next already. Rumours have been rife about how the actor is teaming up with AR Murugadoss again after Sarkar , and it could be for a sequel to their previous hit Thuppakki, with Harris Jayaraj also being part of the crew. A source from the industry now tells us that #Thalapathy65 might be helmed by Murugadoss, though a few others have also narrated scripts to Vijay The source says, “Murugadoss and Vijay have kept in touch and the director had narrated a script to the actor recently. Both are keen to work together again, and Vijay’s next film after Master could be with Murugadoss. Things are at a nascent stage and discussions are on to finalise the finer details. The film may, or may not be a sequel to Thuppaki. Master is in its post-production stage, and the team is keen that the Lokesh Kanagaraj directorial hits screens first before making any official announcement about the actor’s next film.”

Title: With no live gigs, musicians use time to compose and record
Content: As the world prepared to battle the Coronavirus pandemic, mass gatherings were among the first to be cancelled, given the high contact transmission rate of the virus. Singers across the globe either voluntarily postponed tours or just went with the tide. The silver lining of the Covid-19 shutdown is that your favourite singer and band may soon have loads of new tunes for you. Behram Siganporia , frontman of Bengaluru-based band Best Kept SecretShows are cancelled, but we’ve been busy as we now have a chance to record some of our songs. The shutdown has given us time to work on an album that has been in process for a while now. We have been composing music and finishing the songs that were half way through.All.Ok, rapper, BengaluruI’m using this time to record my latest track, which is a motivational rap number. The song is a soothing melodic rap number — it will be a new genre for my audiences to listen to. Titled Good Morning, the track keeps with my motto of #GoodVibesOnly. It’s the kind of song that you can listen to, right after you wake up in the morning. It’ll energize you, making you ready to face whatever the day has to offer. I plan to release the track in April, depending on how soon things fall into place.Ashwin Gopakumar, member of the band When Chai Met Toast, KochiThis is a crucial time for everyone, and as a band, it has been hard on us both musically and financially. But on the bright side, it has allowed us to sit down and write more music. We were looking at releasing a full-length album this year, which has been a work in progress as we were also busy with shows. Now that we have nowhere to go, our sole focus is the album.Raftaar, rapper, MumbaiI believe that the shutdown is a blessing in disguise for many artistes. This is an opportunity for independent musicians and digital personalities to get more active. People are indoors and have plenty of time to search the web for new content, so artistes should make the most of this situation.Benny Dayal, playback singer , MumbaiI have not been heading to the studio as often as I would have liked to, but I am playing it safe and doing my bit by staying indoors. I am using the time off to be productive by working from home though, and composing new songs along with my band.Bruce Lee Mani, vocalist and guitarist of Thermal and a Quarter, BengaluruWe were all set for a seven-city album launch tour till mid of May, but that’s been called off. We are now focusing on how to make the most of this online. Of course, this is not going to generate much revenue, but we cannot complain because the whole world is in such a state.(With inputs by Tanvi PS)

Title: Coronavirus in Haryana: Two women sent to isolation wards in Ambala and Yamunanagar
Content:
Representational Image

AMBALA: Health department personnel on Thursday sent a 60-year-old woman to isolation in Yamunanagar when she showed symptoms similar to coronavirus infection after returning from Vaishno Devi pilgrimage.

“The woman does not have any foreign travel history but a while ago she traveled within the country. She showed some symptoms like cold and cough; therefore, we isolated her at a ward in civil hospital and sent her swab sample for examination at the BPS Medical College for Women in Sonepat. We are expecting her reports by Friday,” Yamunanagar civil surgeon Dr Vijay Dahiya said.

In Ambala, a 28-year-old woman with travel history to Chennai (nearly a month ago) has been isolated and her samples have been sent for inspection to PGIMER in Chandigarh.

“The woman had returned from Chennai nearly a month ago and on Thursday, she visited city hospital with some symptoms and voluntarily asked the doctors to take her samples for coronavirus test,” Ambala civil surgeon Dr Kuldeep said.

Two of Kurukshetra test negative

Meanwhile, swab reports of two Kurukshetra residents have been found negative of coronavirus infection.

“Two Kurukshetra residents, who were isolated on Tuesday, have tested negative for Covid-19 and on Thursday, they were discharged from the hospital,” civil surgeon Dr Kuldeep said.

Title: Expressing the severity of COVID-19 outbreak, Suniel Shetty shares 'can’t remember any instance when such fear & worry has gripped the human race'
Content: After the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Forensic Medical Board ruled out the murder angle in Sushant Singh Rajput’s death report, an audio tape of Dr Sudhir Gupta has been leaked wherein he reportedly claims that the late actor was ‘murdered’. When ETimes reached out to Sushant Singh Rajput’s family lawyer Vikas Singh for his reaction on the same, he stated, “To be honest, I tweeted my stand yesterday but I would like to speak to him before I take a final call. He is not answering my phone, what if he changes his stand, one doesn’t know. I will wait till I can talk to him.”

Title: Coronavirus Shutdown: Revellers defy advisories for 'lockdown parties'
Content: The novel coronavirus has forced many cities around the world to go under lockdown. However, not everyone is practicing social distancing. Even though 'stay home' is probably the most oft repeated and important advisory to stop the spread of coronavirus, from American spring breakers in Miami to 'lockdown parties' in countries across Europe, many are defying rules, with no regard for safety.In stark contrast to these revellers are the Italians, who have been living under a strict lockdown and warning others to not make the same mistakes they did. In one video, the quarantined residents are giving their past selves and other countries messages to not take the situation lightly.For many in Europe, it’s time for "lockdown parties", "end of the world drinking sessions" and "corona speakeasies". This has been seen mainly in Berlin, known for its non-stop partying culture, apart from other parts of Germany. There have been reports of closed bars taping up windows and locking doors, only allowing guests who have registered, or who deliver a specific knock on the door. The Berlin police have warned that if this continues it will "trigger a police operation".Last week, in pubs across Belgium, thousands of people gathered for one last drink before the pubs were shut down because of coronavirus. Similar lockdown parties were reported in France as well.The government has banned mass gatherings in New Zealand, but that hasn’t stopped the party crowd. Students from University of Otago held a large St Patrick's Day party and to make matters worse, the venue was just metres from a school which was forced to close due to a confirmed case of coronavirus. Students posted pictures on social media, with one even reportedly captioning a picture as, "on our way to catch corona".The Dunedin university students are pushing ahead with plans for the annual Hyde Street party on April 4 , which is traditionally attended by thousands of students.Despite advice to follow social distancing, hundreds of spring breakers were seen flocking to Florida. Pictures and videos showed that the beaches were packed with college students. While some said that "they should have more to do than sit at home", many Americans agreed that it was a dangerous and "dumb" thing to do. In a widely shared CBS video, spring breakers were giving their reasons to come out and party. "If I get corona, I get corona... at the end of the day, I’m not going to let it stop me from partying," said one, while another added, "We’re just trying to roll with it. We’re just living for the moment." Another video by a travel company shows more than 200 spring breakers having fun on a cruise ship near Nassau, Bahamas.A restaurant chain in Washington, DC has said that it will defy the mayor's orders to limit gatherings and said that its outlets will remain open. While it promised that it will take "stricter safety precautions to protect our guests", the management said that it will not bow down to pressure from any group trying to shut them down. Their statement also read, "It is not our burden to bear, nor is it our staffs’ burden to bear."For a group of British tourists in Spain nothing, not even corona, comes in the way of getting some sun at the beach. In a video from the seaside resort town of Benidorm, Spain, the group was seen defying lockdown and taunting police officers who were trying to get them back inside. Some were filmed chanting "we've all got the flu, na na na na!"

Title: Jamie Lever comes up with a song on coronavirus
Content: With coronavirus fear gripping the world, people have been going all out to express courage and fortitude. From sharing preventive tips and hand-washing videos to breaking into impromptu singing from balconies, they are doing everything possible to spread awareness and cheer. And now, stand-up comic Jamie Lever has come up with a song on corona. She tells BT , “When this outburst happened, my friend Rohan said, ‘Let’s make a song on this’. Instantly, I was reminded of the song ' Kolaveri D ' and I started humming, ‘Why this, why this corona disease’ and ‘Virus corona, jaldi humko chhodo na’. By the end of the night, I had the entire song ready. The next day, we contacted our musician friends and they said, ‘Chalo, we are free, we’ll come. In two hours, we shot the entire piece. People have loved it.” Does she plan to jam with her actor dad Johnny Lever as well? “I made him do a comedy video (on a mobile phone video platform) on his dialogue from the film, ' Awara Paagal Deewana ', and he liked that. He also loved the corona video,” she replies.

Title: Alumnae got nostalgic at this reunion in Lucknow
Content: It was a nostalgic moment for the alumnae of Sarojni Naidu hostel, Allahabad University where they gathered to recall their college years. Organised at a prominent city guest house, the reunion had 60 pass-outs in participation from batches 1964 to 2012.(L) Raini Sangal (R) Sakshi Singh and Meenakshi Parihar (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Dr Ranjana Kakkar, who was the superintendent of the hostel for almost seven years, graced the occasion as the chief guest and inaugurated the event by lighting the lamp. A special cultural program was also organised in which the present students danced and sang.(L) Sunita Aditya (R) Amrita Srivastava (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Arachna Pandey and Jagriti (R) Bandana Kumar (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Divya Gupta and Durgesh Nandani (R) Dr Anamika Srivastava (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Dr Ranjana Kakkar (R) Dr Upma Chaturvedi (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Jyotisha Singh (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

Title: #CoronaPandemic: Youngsters have a tough time selling social distancing to their parents
Content: When Bengaluru-based techie Anubhav Kumar called his parents on Monday evening and did not get a response for a few hours, he started panicking. His parents live in Greater Kailash, and the 32-year-old wanted to make sure they were doing okay amid the coronavirus scare . "I received a call from my dad two hours later saying they were at the mall, shopping," reveals Anubhav, adding, "I was aghast. When people are supposed to be practising social distancing, my very educated and aware parents were out in a public place. When I tried to admonish them for it, they said I was fear-mongering." The Kumars' case isn’t isolated. Millennials say that they are having a hard time convincing their parents to stay at home and take the virus threat seriously. With the number of COVID-19 cases in India crossing 170, most cities have shut educational institutions, cinema halls, and even monuments, while offices are encouraging people to work from home. Since the virus spreads through contact, isolation and social distancing are among the best methods to prevent its spread. But many people are finding it hard to explain the gravity of the situation to their parents.Zeeshan Khan, an IT consultant working in Gurgaon, tells us, "My father was going for his morning walks and my mother – a lawyer – was refusing to work from home. Till Tuesday, she was going to office. For them, stay at home advisories are a result of hype and ‘we should not panic about an illness that has affected just a few people’. Trying to explain to them that cases could rise anytime was futile."There have also been arguments at many homes because of the travel plans. "I fought with my parents on Tuesday morning. They had a flight to Rajkot that night. My mother had a work engagement and my dad was accompanying her for some sightseeing. They were just not getting why I was reacting the way I was, and were more fixated on: 'Agar cancel karaaya toh we will lose Rs 20,000'. I said I would pay for it and convinced them to stay back," says 26-year-old Aakriti, who works in Noida.People say that their parents think they are overreacting by staying at home and practising social distancing. Priti Jain, a Delhi University student, says, "My parents and extended family think we are being too sensitive about this kyunki ‘yeh sab China aur Europe mein ho raha hai, toh hum ghar mein kyun rahein?'." Girish Ahuja, a 30-year-o ld corporate professional from Gurgaon, adds, "They feel we are overreacting and panicking over something inconsequential. My father said something that was both politically incorrect and worrying. He told me, 'Every few years there is a new virus from China and the far east and it always blows over. So why should we worry?'" Kaushik Sharma, whose septuagenarian parents are vacationing in Himachal, says, "Their generation believes they are tough, and while I don’t argue with it, they were tough when they were young. But age is a factor now. They say they survived several diseases when medicine wasn’t as advanced as it is today so they can survive this, too. At 60, you don’t have the same immunity you had when you were 25-30, but they refuse to slow down. It was amusing at first but now it’s just ridiculous. My parents are still hosting friends and even planning to take a vacation because, in their words, 'flights are cheap now'."Many youngsters find themselves in the difficult position of having to school their parents, and while they may be up for the challenge, the parents aren’t ready for it. Gurmeet Singh, a Rohini-based MBA student, explains, "I kept trying to explain to my parents why taking a vacation right now was a bad idea, but they wouldn't listen. Funnily enough, when my uncle told them the same thing the next day, they relented. I guess they still think I’m their kid so they know more than me."And this dynamic means that arguments and advices aren’t well received. "The worst thing is that you can’t argue. People have died. I have friends living overseas who tell me how bad things there are. We have to avoid reaching that state and hence, we need to stay at home. So I do get annoyed when they take it lightly and sometimes I lose my temper. The moment that happens, the conversation shifts to how I am being disrespectful. It's a vicious circle," 32-year-old management executive Vishakha Singh sums it up.

Title: Restaurant review: Rajdhani
Content: This column is dedicated to you. Yes, to you who is reading this. Wishing you health, safety and a positive mindset. I write this while in productively happy and complete self-quarantine. I’m back to a regular routine of yoga, walking, reading, painting, sculpting, cooking, meditating, listening to music, praying and writing. Today, I review this Vashi restaurant. I lunched there with my well-travelled #foodieblinddate couple — businessman Hari Ramnath and lifestyle writer Gita Hari, who curates Sattvik Tambrahm recipes for food promotions at five star hotels. Committed vegetarians, their ‘favourites’ list has Gujarati-Rajasthani thali right at the top. Our review follows.Simply done up, spacious room. A few dolls depicting folklore. Dhoti and turban-wearing waiters bustle around.In our thali meal, it was the traditional Gujarati winter specialty, Surti undhiyu, bursting with plump purple yam, raw banana and steamed chickpea muthia that was authentic and came up tops. The Gujarati daal and kadhi passed the acid test of the perfect kiss of sweetness. Mellow with ghee Kathiyawadi khichdi, delicious with sweet churma, the Rajasthani dal baati delighted. As did the mildly spiced rajma udad masala.Inattentive service! We had to keep requesting for repeats. Also, (Gita Hari took meticulous notes) we were not served all the farsans in the menu. Salad of papaya marcha dahi papdi chaat was left out. It was the same with the desserts. Insipid Mewari paneer and greasy aloo chips. Cold phulka, puris, rotla and chilla.We had great expectations. Over the years, Rajdhani has built up a reputation for excellent food and service (see the box to know how my #foodieblinddate Jyoti Kasliwal guided me to the most superlative thali meal in Rajdhani Lohar Chawl area in the early 90s). Though some of the dishes on the winter thali menu delighted, many were lacklustre, some not served at all and others served cold. Service left a lot to be desired. We are all fans of the thali and, in Gita Hari’s words, request Rajdhani to “buckle up and reboot!”Satara Plaza, Ground Floor, 7, Palm Beach Road, Vashi, Navi MumbaiContact: 022 27843333Timings: 12 pm - 3.30 pm;7 pm - 11 pmAverage meal for two: Rs.1000 (delivery available)With several businesses temporarily shutting because of the novel coronavirus , either voluntarily or in accordance with local regulations, we suggest that you call the restaurant and confirm if it is open before visiting.

Title: Due to proximity to Italian borders, we are taking extreme measures: Celina Jaitley
Content: For the past few years, actress Celina Jaitley has been enjoying a quiet life away from the limelight in Austria, with her entrepreneur-hotelier husband Peter Haag and sons Winston, Viraaj and Arthur. However, the Coronavirus outbreak has left the family rattled, especially due to their proximity to Italy, one of the countries that’s heavily hit by COVID-19.Celina tells BT, “Due to proximity to Italian borders, everyone here is taking extreme measures to follow the government’s directions. Even as I am worried about the way the virus is spreading, I am relieved that our estate is located high on the Alps.”Celina says that she’s thankful for her husband’s foresight. “We were prepared well in advance — even prior to Austria’s chancellor announcing major restrictions on movement in public places on Sunday, banning gatherings of more than five persons, urging Austrians to self-isolate and putting further limits on who can enter the country. As of now, we can only leave the house for urgent work, to buy necessary food supplies or to help others. Austrians are taking care of themselves and the roads and malls are all deserted. It is fascinating to see how cooperative people are,” she shares.While city-dwellers have no option other than self-isolation, Celina feels fortunate that she gets to enjoy the greens around her estate. She says, “Life on the Alpine mountains is blessed. Though we are under curfew, we have beautiful mountains, brooks, orchards, gardens and a winter garden within our property. I am enjoying my solo time in the alpine woods.”The former Miss India, who has been a part of films like No Entry, Golmaal Returns and Thank You among others, is also using this forced break to teach her children about India. She elaborates, “I am taking great pleasure in homeschooling the boys and teaching them Sanskrit and Hindi, besides their school curriculum. My sons are fascinated by Indian culture and I am also educating them about ancient and modern Indian history. As far as their school is concerned, study material and assignments are being sent via email. Children have access to their teachers online, too.”She signs off saying, “This time alone and with the family has truly helped me get over from my parents’ untimely demise last year.”

Title: Maniesh Paul: I make sure that the humour is clean when I’m on stage
Content: "Hosting is not easy, it is an art that I have also mastered over the years," says actor and host Maniesh Paul . Maniesh, who is currently hosting Sa Re Ga Ma Pa Li'l Champs on the small screen, shares that he tries to experiment with something new each time he hosts a show. "I always think of creating something new. While hosting a kids’ show, I try to make sure that my humour matches up with the children’s. They should also learn from what we are doing on the show," says Maniesh, adding, "I like to do something which people enjoy. Yeh hota hai ki aap sabka toh mazak uda rahe ho par apna nahi uda rahe. Toh mujhe achha nahi lagta. I make sure that we all are equal, aur aapka mazak udd sakta hai toh mera bhi udd sakta hai. I feel that my audience definitely connects with what I do. That is why I try to do something which is relatable."There is one thing though that he makes sure is always taken care of when he is on stage. "I try and make sure that the humour is clean when I am on stage,” he says. While a lot of actors have forayed into the world of hosting, Maniesh feels that it is definitely not an easy job. “Sabka different game hai, hosting asaan nahi hai. I have also learnt it over the years. It is not just about reading a script from a teleprompter, but it is an art that you really need to understand. It is not about ki writer ne likh diya aur aapne bol diya, usmein bahaut cheezein aapko involve karni padhti hain," he says.But what does he think of the sub-plots on reality shows where hosts are often made to flirt with one of the judges on the shows? Does it bother him, we ask? "Mera bada clear hai ki aap mujhe kisi se bhi flirt nahi kara sakte. Meri understanding saamne wale ke saath samajh aani chahiye. For instance, when I hosted Indian Idol , I never flirted with Neha (Kakkar), angle hi different tha. Now I am doing Sa Re Ga Ma Pa, I am not going to flirt with Alka (Yagnik) ji, unka stature aur (show ka) angle alag hai," he says.

Title: #CoronaPandemic: Youngsters have a tough time selling social distancing to their parents
Content: When Bengaluru-based techie Anubhav Kumar called his parents on Monday evening and did not get a response for a few hours, he started panicking. His parents live in Greater Kailash, and the 32-year-old wanted to make sure they were doing okay amid the coronavirus scare . "I received a call from my dad two hours later saying they were at the mall, shopping," reveals Anubhav, adding, "I was aghast. When people are supposed to be practising social distancing, my very educated and aware parents were out in a public place. When I tried to admonish them for it, they said I was fear-mongering." The Kumars' case isn’t isolated. Millennials say that they are having a hard time convincing their parents to stay at home and take the virus threat seriously. With the number of COVID-19 cases in India crossing 170, most cities have shut educational institutions, cinema halls, and even monuments, while offices are encouraging people to work from home. Since the virus spreads through contact, isolation and social distancing are among the best methods to prevent its spread. But many people are finding it hard to explain the gravity of the situation to their parents.Zeeshan Khan, an IT consultant working in Gurgaon, tells us, "My father was going for his morning walks and my mother – a lawyer – was refusing to work from home. Till Tuesday, she was going to office. For them, stay at home advisories are a result of hype and ‘we should not panic about an illness that has affected just a few people’. Trying to explain to them that cases could rise anytime was futile."There have also been arguments at many homes because of the travel plans. "I fought with my parents on Tuesday morning. They had a flight to Rajkot that night. My mother had a work engagement and my dad was accompanying her for some sightseeing. They were just not getting why I was reacting the way I was, and were more fixated on: 'Agar cancel karaaya toh we will lose Rs 20,000'. I said I would pay for it and convinced them to stay back," says 26-year-old Aakriti, who works in Noida.People say that their parents think they are overreacting by staying at home and practising social distancing. My parents are still hosting friends and even planning to take a vacation because, in their words, 'flights are cheap now'."Many youngsters find themselves in the difficult position of having to school their parents, and while they may be up for the challenge, the parents aren’t ready for it. Title: Happiness is infectious. Let us spread this infection, say Tolly celebs
Content: As we go through one of our biggest crises in decades as a race, the occasion of International Day of Happiness today becomes all the more significant. This year the theme is — happier together. The message of solidarity, inclusiveness and sensitivity is not lost upon some of the creative souls of Kolkata, who shared their happiness mantra with CT. Read, share and be inspired.You can find happiness anytime, anywhere. It’s all in the mind. There’s too much hatred and disturbances all around, so one must try to embrace happiness with open arms. I try to be happy with whatever I have and not think about what I don’t. It is also important to forgive yourself at times. Being with positive-minded people, pets, my family and friends makes me happy. But then, it’s a collective endeavour. Like, a project can be successful only if all the actors work towards it. Whenever I hear the word “action” on the set, there’s a smile on my face. Likewise, I try to entertain as many people as possible with my acting skills.I believe happiness is a sign of an enlightened mind. And dance is the reflection of a happy soul. I have learnt to nurture happiness in me. That is the main source of energy, which I put into my art. Today, it is difficult to have a peaceful, content life. But we must still try. Mother nature is the greatest dancer. I’ve observed her closely and realised that nature’s happiness comes from unconditional love for her creation. My life, too, revolves around creative art forms, like dance, music, painting and more. We must remember that happiness is infectious. Let us spread this infection and bring down the darkness around us.I believe the secret to happiness is freedom, and the secret to freedom is courage. You need courage to let go of unpleasant memories. Try not to compare your success or failure with others. Be appreciative, love with grace and gratitude. True happiness is when what you think, what you say and what you do are in harmony. We, as filmmakers, are blessed that we can tell stories and can make millions experience a sense of happiness through our narratives. I have grown up watching such films. So, I ensure that my stories give my audience a sense of happiness and encouragement to explore life — and seek happiness within.Happiness is a relative term and perhaps cannot be explained at times — one can become ecstatic or also even shed "tears of joy". I think happiness is a state of mind that gives an individual a sense of fulfilment and positivity. I believe music has the ability to bring people from diverse backgrounds under one roof — irrespective of religion, ethnicity, age or financial status, and elevate them to a mental state devoid of any stress. Hence for that duration, the only vibes that prevail among them are togetherness and love for each other. It has been proven that music can help people overcome loneliness, jealousy, hatred, criminal activities and in some cases, even physical pain. The only feeling that prevails is — unadulterated happiness.Be it on stage or behind the camera, when I am painting or while preparing for a new project — I am the happiest when I’m working. I’ve been brought up in a beautiful environment, where there was a community feeling, love and respect. These values have shaped me as a person. For me, happiness is to make sure that everyone around me is happy. I try and find the good in people, as I believe our purpose here is to be happy — not individually, but as a community.

Title: Ministry ignores NCBC dissent, insists on adding ‘salary’ in creamy layer calculation
Content:
NEW DELHI: In what signals a deepening confrontation between the government and the top OBC oversight panel, Union social justice ministry has reiterated its proposal to redefine “creamy layer” by including “salary” in its calculation, ignoring the demand of the National Commission for Backward Classes that it be reconsidered.

Sources said social justice ministry sent back to the NCBC its Cabinet note which states that “salary” should be part of “gross income” of an OBC family which determines whether it falls in the “creamy layer”. It is a big departure from the 1993 Office Memorandum which lays down that “agricultural income” and “salary” will not form part of the “wealth test” which defines “creamy layer”.

“Creamy layer” is the affluent category among OBCs which is ineligible for 27% Mandal reservations and inclusion of “salary” would more easily put an OBC household in that segment. This implication has rendered the proposed change controversial and politically sensitive.

The ministry’s note raised the hackles of the NCBC, which is the oversight body on policies for OBC welfare. As reported by TOI online on March 9, the commission asked the ministry to redraft its note by dropping the proposal for inclusion of “salary” in “gross income”. It argued that such a move would work against the interests of the OBCs who are so categorised on the basis of social and educational backwardness, and not economic backwardness.

But what conveys a clash between the two arms of OBC welfare on the issue, the ministry is learnt to have ignored the dissent conveyed by the NCBC and has underscored that “salary” should be made part of “gross income”.

The OBC panel had also recommended that income ceiling for “creamy layer” should be increased to Rs 16 lakh “net income” annually as against the ministry’s proposal to peg it at Rs 12 lakh gross income from the present Rs 8 lakh. “Net income” means income after the deduction of income tax. The income ceiling is revised every three years and was last done in 2017.

Sources said social justice ministry had asked the NCBC to give its views by Monday but the deadline has not been heeded.

The contentious revision is rooted in the recommendations of an expert committee which was constituted in March 2019 to revisit and simplify the 1993 OM. As reported by TOI, the expert committee suggested that Income Tax Act be made the benchmark to calculate the creamy layer for all OBCs. The I-T Act includes “salary” and “other sources” but leaves out “agri income”.

The government argues that its proposed initiative would simplify the 1993 OM which has been a source of controversies. Confusion over the 1993 OM arose after the Centre over last six years started including “salary” in the gross income of OBCs from PSU background while continuing to exclude it in case of OBCs working in state and central governments.

Title: Revenue from sale of rail tickets sinks by Rs 450 cr in March
Content: NEW DELHI: The railways revenue from sale of tickets has fallen by nearly Rs 450 crore between March 1 and March 18 as compared to last year due to less booking and high rate of cancellation of tickets due to the coronavirus outbreak. Different zones have temporarily cancelled over 200 trains and railways also announced suspending concessional booking of all tickets including that of senior citizens to discourage non-essential travel.Railway ministry officials said the concessions have been suspended to avoid overcrowding of trains. The railways have appealed to people to avoid non-essential travel. “Out of the 53 category of concessions now only 15 categories can avail it. This is for a temporary period due to Covid-19,” said a railway ministry official.An official statement said in order to contain the spread of Covid-19 virus and to minimise the travel related risks to elderly citizens, Indian Railways has withdrawn concessional booking of tickets to senior citizens for unreserved and reserved segment form Friday morning till further notice. “For railway tickets already purchased before 00:00 hrs March 20, 2020, in case of travel, no difference in fare shall be collected,” it said.Meanwhile, in Mumbai, both the Central Railway and Western Railway announced suspension of the services of air-conditioned local trains from Friday in view of the coronavirus outbreak. Ordinary train services would replace them.The IRCTC also cancelled all the three “private trains” it runs amidst the virus scare. Lucknow – Delhi Tejas Express, Ahmedabad-Mumbai Tejas Express and the newly launched Kashi Mahakal Express have been cancelled till March 31. The Kashi Mahakal Express was flagged off last month by Prime Minister Narendra Modi.These trains were introduced as a first step towards allowing private operators to run trains on the Indian Railways network. As per the proposal, nearly 150 trains by private operators would be allowed on 100 identified routes.Sources said they are staring at increasing revenue fall from passenger segment in the next couple of weeks as cancellation of tickets is on the rise and there are few fresh bookings.Parl panel chief issues clarification over reports railways was pulled up about Covid-19 repliesA day after media reports claimed that members of a parliamentary panel pulled up the railways and its chairman for not giving satisfactory replies on measures taken to contain the spread of Covid-19, its chairman issued a press release saying the committee appreciated the preparedness of the railways and other ministries.“The railway committee felt that though the representative of ministry of railways were called at a short notice, they came prepared with information about various measures taken to prevent the spread of coronavirus at railway stations and trains. The committee appreciated the preparedness of Ministry of Railways, Civil Aviation Tourism and External Affairs in tackling the coronavirus threat,” said a statement issued by chairman of the parliamentary panel on transport, tourism and civil aviation, T G Venkatesh.Venkatesh is a BJP MP.Railway Board chairman V K Yadav had told the panel that nearly 63% tickets had been cancelled in March because of coronavirus outbreak. Reports had claimed that the panel members were angry about the arrangements made by the railways to tackle the virus.

Title: Central Vista revamp: Govt proposes Shram Shakti Bhwana site for creating new office block for MPs
Content:
NEW DELHI: The government has proposed to create office space for MPs where the Shram Shakti Bhawan is now located and it would be linked to the proposed new Parliament through a tunnel, according to some of the MPs who went through the latest presentation on the revamp of Central Vista on Thursday.

Sources said a detailed presentation about the project with particular focus on new Parliament was made before General Purposes Committee of the Lok Sabha. “We were told that there will be adequate office space for MPs in the new scheme of things. The planners said that the current Parliament has developed several problems and hence there is a need for a new Parliament. While MPs had no objection to the facilities that have been proposed for them in the new Parliament, some did not like the architecture, which seems to be “similar to that of Gujarat High Court”, said an MP, who did not wish to be named.

TOI has learnt that the government has prepared the roadmap to first vacate the plot occupied by the Indira Gandhi National Art Centre (IGNCA) where three new office blocks will come up. “In the first phase, offices in Udyog Bhawan , Nirman Bhawan and another building will be shifted so that redevelopment on these plots can start,” said a source,

Officials also said a decision is yet to be taken whether the Jawahar Bhawan, which houses external affairs ministry would be demolished as well for building a taller structure. There are also discussions whether Nirman Bhawan should be razed or the existing building should be revamped from inside.

Title: Covid-19: Italy reports 3,405 deaths, 150 more than China’s, despite fewer infections
Content: ROME: The death toll in Italy from the coronavirus overtook China’s on Thursday in a stark illustration of how the crisis has pivoted toward the West. Italy, with a population of 60 million, recorded at least 3,405 deaths, or roughly 150 more than in China — a country with a population over 20 times larger.Italy tallied 902 deaths in the last two days alone: 475 on Wednesday and 427 on Thursday. The total number of cases rose to 41,035 from a previous 35,713, up nearly 15%, a faster rate of growth than seen over the last three days, the Civil Protection Agency said.Italy reached the bleak milestone the same day that Wuhan, the Chinese city where the coronavirus first emerged, recorded no new infections. The worldwide toll crept towards 10,000 as the total number of infections topped 220,000, including nearly 85,000 people who have recovered.A visiting Chinese Red Cross team criticised Italians’ failure to properly quarantine themselves and take the national lockdown seriously. The head of the delegation, Sun Shuopeng, said he was shocked to see so many people walking around, using public transportation and eating out. “Right now we need to stop all economic activity and we need to stop the mobility of people,” he said. “All people should be staying at home in quarantine.”Health authorities have cited a variety of reasons for Italy’s high toll, key among them its large population of elderly people. Italy has the world’s second-oldest population, and the vast majority of its dead — 87% — were over 70.Spain has been the hardest-hit European country after Italy, and in Madrid a four-star hotel began operating as a makeshift hospital for coronavirus patients. The Madrid Hotel Business Association said it has placed 40 hotels with room for 9,000 people at the service of the Madrid region. Spain on Thursday announced that virus deaths had jumped by nearly 30% over the past 24 hours to 803. The number of people who have contracted the disease has meanwhile grown by around 25% to 17,395.The British government, which was slow to react to the virus, has shifted gears and is now drawing up legislation giving itself new powers to detain people and restrict gatherings. The bill is expected to be approved by parliament next week.Meanwhile, the WHO warned that the virus is spreading quickly in Africa. “About 10 days ago we had about five countries” with the virus, said WHO’s Africa chief Matshidiso Moeti . Now 35 of Africa’s 54 countries have cases, with the total close to 650. It is an “extremely rapid evolution”, she said. Iran’s supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei planned to pardon 10,000 more prisoners to combat the virus. The country’s toll from coronavirus jumped to 1,284 on Thursday, with the total number of infections rising to 18,407. “Based on our information, every 10 minutes one person dies from the coronavirus and some 50 people become infected with the virus every hour in Iran,” Iran health ministry spokesman Kianush Jahanpur tweeted.

Title: Micro review: 'Impossible Causes' by Julie Mayhew
Content: 'Impossible Causes' by Julie Mayhew is a dark murder mystery in an eerie secluded island.Set in Lark, an Island off Europe that's only accessible for a few months in a year, the story has a confined setting. The small secretive island only has a population of 260 people and Viola, her mother and a teacher Benjamin Hailey come to live here. It's a very religious place and the community is turning a blind eye to the girls who are supposedly dappling in witchcraft. However they don't seem too happy when Viola seems to fall in with them and after a murder takes place..the secrets of the island start to reveal themselves along with the newcomers' past.The story is excellent, detailed and well thought out. The parallel timelines in the story can get a little confusing to read however, but the story is worth it and will keep you hooked. The element of magic only adds to the mystery of the tale. It's a great book for all mystery lovers.

Title: Coronavirus cases in India: Punjab man is 4th Covid-19 victim, 54 cases reported in 2 days
Content:
More on Covid-19

India recorded its fourth death due to Covid-19 on Thursday even as fresh cases surged in the country, with more than 50 recorded in the past two days. The country’s fourth coronavirus victim was a 70-year-old man from Punjab , who had returned from a two-week trip to Germany via Italy.As many as 27 new cases were reported on Thursday from 14 states, taking the total number of cases recorded in India so far to 198. There has been a spike in the number of new cases in the past two days, with 54 being reported from the states. The health ministry has confirmed 173 cases so far.The virus travelled to new territories with Gujarat and Chhattisgarh reporting their first cases on Thursday.The latest Covid-19 casualty, a native of Punjab’s Nawanshahr district, was a patient of hypertension and diabetes. He died on Wednesday morning. Test reports of his samples received on Thursday confirmed that he was suffering from Covid-19.Government officials said he had gone on a two-week trip to Germany via Italy and landed at Delhi on March 6 and left for Punjab the same day. After the man’s samples confirmed the virus, authorities completely blocked his village. “We have quarantined around 56 villagers, including 18 from his family, and relatives who came in contact with him,” Nawanshahr civil surgeon Dr Rajinder Bhatia said, adding that those quarantined include the doctor, nurse and ward body who attended on him. “He reported typical symptoms of heart attack with chest pain and died in around 25 minutes,” said Bhatia.The number of states reporting Covid-19 deaths has gone up to four now, the other three being Karnataka, Maharashtra and Delhi.With Gujarat reporting two confirmed cases and Chhattisgarh one, the number of states and Union territories affected by the dreaded virus rose from 18 to 20 on Thursday.A 32-year-old man in Rajkot and a 21-year-old woman in Surat tested positive for the virus, principal secretary, health, Jayanti Ravi said. The Rajkot man had landed in Mumbai from Mecca on March 7 along with 10 others and they reached the city by Bandra-Jamnagar Saurashtra Janta Express on March 8. Sixteen persons who were in contact with him, including his relatives, have been quarantined at a special facility set up in the city.Rajkot district health officer Manish Bhanderi told TOI: “In all, there were 68 people in the coach. Of these, 15 were residents of Rajkot while 45 others have either returned to Mumbai or de-boarded before Rajkot. We have contacted these 60 people and they are not ill. However, five passengers are incommunicado while three had given the number of their booking agents.”The second case in Gujarat is of a 21-year-old girl who had landed in Mumbai from London on March 13 and reached Surat on March 14. The girl, who studies in London, was admitted in the isolation ward of the New Civil Hospital on March 16 after she complained of severe cough, fever and cold.“We have shifted eight of her close contacts, including parents, to a special quarantine facility,’’ Banchhanidhi Pani, Surat municipal commissioner, told TOI. On Thursday, prohibitory orders were imposed in Surat, banning gathering of four or more people in public places under Section 144 of CrPC.Of the 23 fresh cases in the country on Thursday, three each were reported from Telangana and Maharashtra, two each from Delhi, Gujarat, Uttarakhand, Andhra and UP, and one each from Haryana, Kerala , Tamil Nadu, Punjab, Karnataka, Odisha and Chhattisgarh.Maharashtra continues to top the list with 48 cases. The three new cases reported from the state on Thursday include a 22-year-old woman with a travel history to the UK, a 49-year-old woman from Ulhasnagar who had travelled to Dubai and a 51-year-old from Ahmednagar who had been to Dubai with his wife. The wife has tested negative. State health minister Rajesh Tope said two Covid-19 patients were critical and on ventilator support while other patients were doing well.At 28, Kerala has the second highest Covid-19 cases in the country while UP ranks third with 19 cases.

Title: Covid-19: Govt bans all international flights to India from March 22 to 29
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: In further restrictions to curb the spread of Covid-19, the government on Thursday imposed a blanket ban on commercial international airlines from operating to India for a week from March 22. The government has already imposed a temporary ban on foreigners, by suspending most visas, from entering India.“No scheduled international commercial passenger aircraft shall be allowed to land in India from March 22, 2020, for one week,” the government said in an advisory.The Directorate General of Civil Aviation told airlines, both Indian and foreign, that no passenger flight will take off from any airport outside the country for any airport in India after 5.30am IST (0000 hours GMT) on Sunday (March 22).The government also directed Metros, railways, buses and airlines to decrease frequency of services and consider alternative seating to ensure social distancing. “Effective disinfection and crowd management be ensured in places like railway stations, Metro stations, bus stands, and airports,” the advisory said.These flights must reach India before 1.31am IST on Monday, allowing a maximum travel time of 20 hours — good enough for even the longest non-stop to India which is San Francisco-Delhi at 16-17 hours. After 1.32 am Monday, no international commercial passenger aircraft will be allowed to disembark passengers, whether Indian or foreign, on Indian soil.Passenger flights from abroad to India can resume from 5.30am IST on March 29, the DGCA circular said.Apart from the travel restriction, the government also advised that children below 10 years of age and those above 65 years stay at home. “State governments shall issue appropriate directions so that all citizens above 65 (other than for medical assistance), except for public representatives or government servants or medical professionals, are advised to remain at home,” the advisory said.The decisions were taken at a meeting of the group of ministers headed by health minister Harsh Vardhan . The health ministry reported 148 Indian nationals and 25 foreign nationals had tested positive for Covid-19 till 5 pm and this included 20 cured and four deaths.The government directed Metros, railways, buses and airlines to decrease frequency of services and consider alternative seating to ensure social distancing. “Effective disinfection and crowd management be ensured in places like railway stations, Metro stations, bus stands, and airports,” the advisory said.The government maintained that these were preventive measures and there was no evidence of community transmission so far. On Wednesday, TOI had reported out that of 820 random samples of people with influenza-like illness , there were no positives for Covid-19, indicating that community spread was not yet happening.“These are all preventive steps. There is no reason for panic in the community. There is a need to be prepared. There is no community transmission but the community needs to take precautions,” health ministry joint secretary Lav Agarwal said.The ministry said the department of pharmaceuticals and the ministry of consumer affairs had been asked to take action against anyone charging exorbitant prices for masks, sanitisers and other health-related materials.To discourage unnecessary travel and to prevent the vulnerable category of senior citizens from undertaking unnecessary travel, concessional booking of all tickets except for patients, students and Divyangjan category for unreserved and reserved segment have been suspended form midnight of March 20.Meanwhile, on March 21, air India Dreamliner with 236 capacity will go to Rome to evacuate Indians stranded there, civil aviation ministry said.With India banning international flights from March 22, fares have shot up for flights from foreign destinations. According to travel portal ixigo, the average one-way fare on London-Mumbai was Rs 32,219 on March 13 which shot up 34% to Rs 43,183 for March 20. Similarly, one-way fares for London-Bengaluru shot up 63% from Rs 28,528 (March 13) to Rs 46,558 (March 20). Paris-Delhi rose 16% from Rs 30,470 on March 14 to Rs 35,310 on March 21.“Average one way airfares for March 19 to 21 for Sydney-Delhi are an average of Rs 40,870. Emirates one-way Sydney-Delhi for March 20 is going as high as Rs 79,797. Average one-way airfares for March 19 to 21 for San Francisco-Delhi is Rs 44,525; Toronto-Delhi is Rs 58,123 and Melbourne-Mumbai is Rs 34,805 with flights on this route like Cathay Pacific going as high as Rs 59,363 for March 20,” said an ixigo statement.

Title: Covid-19: 14-hr ‘janata curfew’ on Sunday, no need to hoard, don’t cut wages, PM Modi says
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday rallied the nation for the fight against coronavirus , calling on citizens to observe a “janata curfew” by staying indoors on Sunday between 7am and 9pm as an expression of resolve to emphasise the need to reduce public interaction to the very minimum.In his much-awaited televised address, the PM minced no words in underlining the gravity of the threat and said there was no room for complacency as the seeming normalcy could be deceptive. “We have been tracking the trend of Covid-19 and have seen how the number of cases in other affected countries exploded after the initial trickle,” he said, making it clear that India should brace for the long haul.Modi was also forthright in stressing that the world was yet to find a cure for the pandemic and no medicine or vaccine was available. However, he said, the risk could be averted if people showed “resolve” and exercised “restraint”, emphasising on the cruciality of “social distancing” for citizens to protect themselves and others from being infected.“There is only one mantra — if we are healthy, then so will the world. Keeping away from crowds, staying at home, social distancing, is very necessary and effective,” he said before he buttressed his pitch for “social distancing” with the call for “janata curfew”.“If you feel nothing will happen and go to markets and walk around the streets, then you are endangering yourself and those close to you. I appeal that for a few weeks, step out only if it is very necessary. Work from home,” he said.The PM warned that optimism over low incidence so far might be misplaced and cautioned against the risk of smugness. “The whole of humankind is in danger and even during World War I and II, so many nations were not affected. In the last few days, there has been an atmosphere (mahaul) that we are safe, but complacency is not right. It is very necessary for every citizen to be alert,” he said.The warning against complacency and that the seeming normalcy could be deceptive comes at a time when the country is anxiously waiting to see whether it has been able to dodge “community transmission” of the disease when it spreads to people who have not been abroad or in contact with such people.The PM also asked citizens to record their appreciation for frontline workers like doctors and nurses, those at hospitals and airlines, railway and bus staff, media and home delivery riders by clapping, ringing bells or banging steel plates at doors and windows of their houses at 5pm on Sunday. “They are the last sentinel between Covid-19 and India... thank them by clapping, ringing bells or thalis, salute them,” he said.In his televised address, Modi warned there was no sure-fire cure, medicine or vaccine that offered protection against Covid-19 even as he urged people to put off non-essential visits to the doctor and reschedule surgeries that could be postponed.He appealed to employers not to remove people off the rolls and to maintain salaries as he said the disease and its economic impact would be hard on the middle, lower middle and poor classes. He said the government was trying to prevent the pattern experienced by some countries where Covid-19 cases spiked, posing a serious challenge to healthcare systems.“Some nations took necessary decisions and isolated their people. But the role of citizens is central. For a country like India, which is still in the developing stage, the danger posed by coronavirus is not ordinary. When big and developed nations have been hurt, it will be wrong to say it will have no effect on India,” he said.Describing Covid-19 as a “vaishwik mahamari (global pandemic)”, the PM said the restrictions announced by the Centre and states should be followed. He made a special appeal that senior citizens remain at home for the next few weeks and recalled the blackouts imposed by authorities during wartime and the drills during peace time. A “janata curfew”, he said, will be a test of self-restraint and will prepare people for forthcoming challenges.Modi asked the NCC NSS , youth organisations, civil society, sports and religious organisations to spread the word about the janata curfew. “This is a ‘kasauti’ (challenge) for India, to see our preparedness,” he said.Taking note of reports of hoarding, the PM said there was no need for panic buying. “Do not hoard. In the last two months, every citizen has faced this danger. This danger is so big and global that no one nation will be able to help another and we need to resolutely face the challenges,” he added.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Sensex loses 581 pts, ends at 39-mth low
Content: MUMBAI: Thursday was another day of volatile trades on Dalal Street with the sensex see-sawing over 2,600 points, but again closing deep in the red. Banking & financials , along with Reliance, weighed on the benchmark index as, globally, the coronavirus case count rose and more economists saw a bigger chance of an economic recession over the next few quarters.The day’s session was also impacted down by the weakness of the rupee that breached the psychologically important 75-to-the-dollar mark as foreign funds continued to sell.The sensex opened deep in the red and slipped below the 27k mark to a 40-month low in early trade. But then, it rallied nearly 10%, or 2,657 points, to an intra-day high at 29,371. But in late selling, the sensex gave up all gains to close 581 points, or 2%, lower at 28,288 — a 39-month closing low.On the NSE, the Nifty closed 205 points or 2.4% off at 8,263. India VIX, the volatility index that is also considered to be a measure of fear among market players, jumped 12.5% to 72 — its highest level in over a decade.According to Motilal Oswal Financial Services head (retail research) Siddhartha Khemka, Indian markets continued to slide southward as the number of coronavirus cases in India as well as globally rose. Although several governments, central banks and regulators have announced steps to support the economy and the businesses, these have not been too successful.“With rising cases of coronavirus, volatility is likely to continue in coming days and any bounce could be sold into. In such times, traders should refrain taking long positions as all the global markets are in a strong bear grip,” he said.End of the session data on the BSE showed that foreign investors were net sellers at Rs 4,623 crore on Thursday, taking the total outflow for the month from stocks alone to over Rs 55,000 crore, or about $7.5 billion. So far in the month, over 1,200 of the BSE stocks have hit the 52-week low level, including sensex heavyweights like RIL, TCS, ITC, HDFC Bank and HDFC.Market players said that for D-Street investors, Friday could bring some respite since, in early trades on Wall Street, the Dow Jones and the S&P 500 indices were holding on to their previous closing levels and showing a steady trend.

Title: Coronavirus shutdown: Vicky Kaushal goes into 'Rocky Balboa' mode as he workout at his home!
Content: From the Mumbai Police filing FIR against social media trolls to Rhea Chakraborty finding more support as her custody gets extended, here are all the top headlines of the day. Our new segment Bolly Buzz goes beyond the usual mix of news and gossip to give all its readers a roundup of all the newsmakers of the day.

Title: Rupee breaches 75 against dollar first time ever
Content: MUMBAI: The rupee hit a new low on Thursday — losing below 75 against the US dollar for the first time — as foreign institutional investors stampeded out of emerging markets.The rupee opened weak at 74.96, in line with the gap opening in equity markets and crashed to 75.30 against the dollar, losing more than a rupee against its previous close of 74.23 before firming up to close at 75.12.“The FIIs have sold nearly $10 billion. The speed of the sales does not look like they are taking a view on companies; the sales appear to be triggered by trading algorithms or exchange-traded funds,” said Harihar Krishnamoorthy , treasurer, First Rand Bank .According to Krishnamoorthy, while the rupee cannot defy the trend in FII sales, several factors could favour it once these sales stabilise. If low oil prices are sustained, there could savings of as much as $50 billion on imports. Gold imports, which have been a drag on the currency, have also come down, and, thirdly, spending on foreign travel under the liberalised remittance scheme will also drop.“Nearing close of the session the rupee hit a new low of 75.30, but because there was heavy intervention (by Reserve Bank of India ) it recovered to 75.12,” said K N Dey, managing partner, United Financial Consultants . “This will continue for some days and the rupee will hit new lows. Whatever measures the RBI takes—dollar-rupee swaps or intervention—these are financial medicines. But until the disease is addressed, global markets will continue to be volatile,” said Dey.He added that RBI also may not want to exhaust its dollar reserves to defend the rupee as it would amount to subsidizing the FIIs’ exit from Indian markets. “Also, the Chinese yuan has weakened by 2.5% to 7.14 against the dollar. They are managing the currency to cover up for lost exports,” said Dey.Given that all emerging market currencies are weakening, there is no advantage in keeping the rupee artificially strong. “Exports are already getting hit. Many of the companies we advise are seeing order cancellations. The crisis will end only when the disease comes under control,” said Dey. “In the last 40 years of my career, I have not seen such a disaster in the economic markets,” said Dey.

Title: Pooja Bhatt raises her voice against animal cruelty amid COVID-19 scare
Content: Bollywood director and actress Pooja Bhatt took to the social media on Thursday to raise her voice against the exploitation and neglect which animals are subjected to as the concerns grow over the COVID-19 pandemic.The 48-year-old shared an Instagram picture of the circular released by the Animal Welfare Board of India which requests people "to not leave the animals or inflict cruelty due to the COVID-19 pandemic.The circular further clarifies that dogs and cats do not harbour or spread the novel coronavirus and any offence perpetrated aginst animals is punishable under the law.The caption of Bhatt's post read: "Animals DO NOT spread #covid_19 Please refer to this circular issued by the Animal Welfare Board of India and please do spread the word. Due to various misconceptions and false information floating around, people are abandoning animals, harming them and getting rid of them in very cruel and unethical ways. We need to be informed not ignorant. Let's not make any more animals pay the price for our lack of knowledge please".The actress's initiative was lauded by her Instagram followers as evident by the several positive and supportive comments.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Tirumala, Jagannath temples to be closed from Friday
Content:
More on Covid-19

TIRUPATI/BHUBANESWAR: For the first time in living memory, the Sri Venkateswara temple in Tirumala will be shut to devotees for a week starting Friday while the Shri Jagannath temple in Puri will remain closed till April 1 as part of a countrywide coronavirus-induced lockdown in public places.Daily rituals will be conducted inside the sanctum sanctorum of two of India’s holiest and most-visited shrines behind closed doors, officials said. In Gujarat, the Sommath, Dwarka and Ambaji shrines will be indefinitely shut from Friday.The Tirumala Tirupathi Devasthanam, which administers the Venkateswara temple, said 50 other sub-shrines across the country will also be closed for a week. This is the first time in 128 years that public worship has been suspended at the 2,000-year-old Tirumala temple. According to temple records, the last such shutdown was in 1892 for unspecified reasons.“Unless some tough decisions are taken, the (Covid-19) pandemic will impact the lives of more citizens. Based on a collective decision taken in consultation with the Andhra Pradesh government, the devasthanam has decided to close the temple from Friday,” Anil Kumar Singhal , executive officer of the managing trust, said.The temple administration on Thursday closed entry to the ghat road at Alipiri in Tirupati. The two pedestrian routes leading to Tirumala, along the Alipiri and Srivari Mettu routes, were sealed, too.In Puri, the decision to shut the 12th century Shri Jagannath shrine was taken after the Odisha government ordered the temporary closure of all religious places in the state — temples, mosques, churches and gurdwaras — till April 1.Servitors will be allowed to perform their daily rituals and pay obeisance to the sibling deities of Jagannath, Balabhadra and Subhadra, subject to the temple authorities ensuring that all health precautions are taken.“We have adopted strong measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Daily rituals will remain unaffected,” Krishan Kumar, chief administrator of the Shri Jagannath Temple Administration, said.Sources said nearly 70 servitors perform around 20 daily rituals at the shrine from early in the morning till evening. Till April 1, bhog (food) will be prepared in the temple kitchen only for rituals.On a normal day, thousands of devotees partake of bhog after it is offered to the deities.Kumar said the temple administration would look into ways to compensate the servitors for the financial loss they would suffer because of the shrine being closed to devotees.On March 15, the authorities had announced that devotees would need to fill in and submit self-declaration forms before entering the premises for darshan. (Inputs from Ahmedabad)

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Mantras, rumours get three arrested across country
Content:
More on Covid-19
