Aid growing coronavirus scare, authorities have started cracking the whip on rumour mongers across the country, from Kishtwar to Kanpur and Kashi to Narsinghpur At Kishtwar in J&K, police on Thursday arrested one person for spreading rumours on social media regarding the death of a man due to coronavirus in the town. Even Doda district administration directed police to register an FIR against a man who flooded social media with rumours about the “same death”.In UP’s Varanasi, a man landed behind bars on Thursday for claiming that his ‘mantra’ could cure Covid-19 patients as well as prevent the infection. This comes just days after the arrest of one ‘Coronawale Baba’ in Lucknow.Sanjay Tiwari, a self-proclaimed astrologer and resident of Samneghat, had been distributing pamphlets that read, “Mantra lijiye aur coronavirus se mukti payiye (Learn this mantra to get rid of coronavirus).”In Narsinghpur district of Madhya Pradesh , a 30-year-old man was arrested and sent to jail for allegedly spreading a hoax that one of his friends has tested positive for coronavirus.

Title: Dia Mirza takes up 'Safe Hands Challenge'; shares a video on her Instagram
Content: From the Mumbai Police filing FIR against social media trolls to Rhea Chakraborty finding more support as her custody gets extended, here are all the top headlines of the day. Our new segment Bolly Buzz goes beyond the usual mix of news and gossip to give all its readers a roundup of all the newsmakers of the day.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Patna University to launch awareness drive
Content: PATNA: Patna University (PU) decided to launch an awareness drive against coronavirus (Covid-19) on Thursday by educating people about ways to prevent the disease and maintain proper hygiene. The decision was taken at a meeting of the National Service Scheme (NSS) programme officers held under the chairmanship of vice-chancellor (VC) Rash Bihari Prasad Singh “Big hoardings and banners depicting precautionary measures against the spread of coronavirus will be put up in every college. Hand-washes and sanitizers will also be distributed among PU teachers and employees as well as the people residing in the neighbouring localities,” the VC told this newspaper.The PU central dispensary has started manufacturing sanitizers and is trying to set up an isolation ward for the Covid-19 suspects. “All the medical officers working at the dispensary are keeping a watch on the university staff. Almost all students residing in different PU hostels have already left the campus,” Singh said.He added, “Regular sanitization of all staircases and furniture will be done. Besides, all colleges, institutes and postgraduate departments of PU will keep their washrooms clean and make soaps and hand sanitizers available for the staff.”PU NSS programme coordinator Atul Aditya Pandey said orders for preparation of hoardings and banners had already been issued and they would be displayed in a day or two.

Title: Bihar: 20-year-old strangles sister to death in Bhagalpur
Content:
Representative image

BHAGALPUR: A 20-year old youth strangled his sister to death after he found her talking on a cell phone. The incident occurred at Jagdishpur village under the Jagdishpur police station area on Wednesday afternoon.

The incident came to light when the accused himself informed the police control room by calling on 100. On getting information, Jagdishpur police station SHO Sanjay Kumar Satyarthi rushed to the spot and arrested the youth and initiated a probe.

Police sources said that Suraj is an intermediate dropout, while his deceased sister Nitu Kumari, was a student of Class XI at Project Girls School, Jagdishpur. The body of the deceased has been sent for postmortem.

Police sources said the incident occurred when both were alone at home. Suraj’s father Ratan Lal Jha, who works as a typist at Bhagalpur civil court, was in Bhagalpur and his mother Soni Devi had also gone out for some work. Ratan and Soni rushed home on being informed about the incident.

Jagdishpur police station SHO Satyarthi said, “According to Ratan, his son Suraj is mentally disturbed and used to stay at home most of the time. He strangled his sister in a fit of rage.”

“We are investigating the case from all angles. We are all also cross-examining the family members and local residents about the incident,” the SHO said.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Patna churches restrict entry
Content: PATNA: Churches across the city have restricted the entry of people to prevent the spread of the Coronavirus , which has claimed thousands of lives across the world, including three in India so far. Several churches have also suspended Sunday mass.Father Prem Prakash, head of St Joseph Pro-Cathedral at Bankipore , confirmed that all mass gatherings have been postponed. “Mass outside the church has also been cancelled for the time being. Only small events with not more than 10-15 people will be conducted till the pandemic exists,” he said.Amar Aaron, secretary of Baptist Church said, “Keeping in mind the current situation, we have started a two-time church service for offering prayers and conducting mass. We have also instructed people not to make a gathering of more than 30-35 people at one time in the Church premises.”Pastor Pramod K Sebastian of India Pentecostal Church of God at Rajendranagar, said all events, including services, mass and prayers have been partially cancelled. “We have instructed people to restrict themselves from offering prayers at the church if they are sick. Besides, we are not conducting any special gatherings. In order to reduce the number of people, we have cancelled all services except on Sunday,” he said.Authorities at small churches, on the other hand, are not taking any special measures. “Since the crowd is already very limited, we are not limiting entry. However, programmes and events are not being conducted,” said Anand Kumar, defence committee member at Khagaul ’s Union Church.Parish priests and other church authorities pointed at dwindling number of devotees offering prayers in the past two weeks owing to the state government’s instructions to avoid public gathering. “Around 250-300 people attend Sunday morning prayers every week, but due to the outbreak, only 50-60 devotees visited the church last Sunday. Even the 40-day long ‘Chalisa’ that is going in the Church, where prayer service is held at 5pm on every Wednesday and Friday, is not witnessing a huge crowd,” Fr Prem Prakash said.Worshipers, too, said they have limited their visit to church. Fairfield Colony resident Atul Symon said, “Earlier, my family and I used to visit the church at least five times a week, however, due to the outbreak we have limited our visit. Besides, we make sure we maintain distance from other devotees.”

Title: Bihar: Many posts lying vacant at special vigilance unit
Content:
The SVU was set up soon after Nitish Kumar came to power.

PATNA: The very purpose of setting up the special vigilance unit ( SVU ), an ambitious project of CM Nitish Kumar to nail the senior corrupt government officials, seems to have been defeated with probe into most of the cases virtually stalled due to important posts, including those of SPs, lying vacant for long.

At present only two SPs — Kumar Amar Singh and Arun Kumar Sharma — are posted at the SVU, whose contract of service is also likely to end in the next couple of months. Altogether six SP posts are still lying vacant. However, the process of appointment on the vacant posts has not been initiated.

Notably, only retired CBI officials are eligible for the posts of SPs in the SVU, which works under the vigilance department of the state government. In addition, there is no full-fledged IG to monitor the investigation and ensure timely disposal of the cases.

Amit Raj is currently holding additional charge of IG, SVU. He is, in fact, posted as IG, prohibition, which functions under Crime Investigation Department (CID). Repeated attempts to contact Raj for his comments, however, proved futile.

Earlier, Ratn Sanjay Katihar was holding additional charge of IG, SVU, before his transfer to weaker section in the CID in the same capacity.

The SVU was set up soon after Nitish came to power and one of the most sincere and upright IPS officers of the state — A K Upadhyay — was appointed as its first IG. Soon after its inception, a disproportionate assets case was lodged against former DGP Narain Misra , who was accused of accumulating huge wealth through illegal means and by abusing his official position.

The SVU proved its worth when a case of disproportion assets (DA) was lodged against a senior IAS officer S S Verma. In both the cases, the SVU got approval from the special vigilance court to confiscate the property of the accused under Bihar Special Courts Act, 2009. Schools were opened for children belonging to the most backward community in the confiscated buildings.

The novel initiative of Nitish-led NDA government in the state received wide acclamation and drew the attention of national media. Thereafter, five more cases were registered against senior public servants, including former state drug controller, Y K Jaiswal, MVI Raghuvansh Kuer, revenue officer Y P Singh, joint director (agronomy) Baidyanath Rajak and former SSP of Muzaffarpur Vivek Kumar (IPS).

According to authoritative sources, altogether 19 DA cases have been lodged at the SVU police station in Patna . “In most of the cases, the investigation is either stalled or is proceedings at snail’s pace due to staff crunch mainly in the rank of SPs, who happen to be the investigating officer as per rule,” a senior officer said.

On the contrary, the Sikkim police have initiated the process of setting up an anti-corruption cell on the pattern of the SVU in Bihar. The posts in different ranks were advertised there about two months back. A K Singh, who was earlier the joint director, CBI, Patna, has been assigned to accomplish the task.

Highly placed sources at the state police headquarters said no vacancies have been advertised in Bihar since 2018. A senior home department officer said the files were sent to the CM’s secretariat twice but nothing happened.

He further said, “Now efforts are on to fill the vacant posts with the state police officers. If this happens, it will meet the same fate as other state probe agencies.”

Title: SHO suspended for liquor party at Vaishali ‘dhaba’
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

PATNA: An FIR was lodged against eight people, including the owner of a roadside dhaba, with the Sarai police station in Vaishali district on Thursday following the seizure of liquor during a raid conducted by the officials of the Prohibition department from Patna.

Altogether seven people were arrested from the dhaba located on NH-77 under the Sarai police station area during the operation late on Wednesday evening. The raid was carried out on the directive of DGP Gupteshwar Pandey, who had earlier received a complaint about liquor being served at the dhaba.

Vaishali SP Gaurav Mangla said on Thursday that the Sarai police started investigation into the matter after the complaint was formally transferred to the district police by the prohibition department officials. “Whosoever is found involved in the case will not be spared,” he said.

The SP said the owner of the dhaba was absconding after the raid. “The owner is among the eight people named as an accused in the FIR registered with the Sarai police station in the district,” he said adding that the DGP visited the Sarai police station on Wednesday evening.

“Those found in sale, manufacture and smuggling of liquor will face harsh legal action,” he said adding that nobody including a politician, bureaucrat or police official is above law.

Sarai police station Dharmaveer Mahto was put under suspension and departmental proceedings were initiated against him for dereliction of duty. Confirming action against the SHO, Vaishali SP Mangla said, “Two other sub-inspectors found on unauthorized leave are also facing departmental proceedings.”

Authoritative sources said the SP and the SDPO (Sadar) Raghav Dayal rushed to the Sarai police station soon after being informed about surprise inspection by the state police chief. “I visit only those police stations against which complaints of serious nature are received from people,” DGP Pandey said.

Title: Government’s bid to promote organ donation in Bihar
Content:
Bihar deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi

PATNA: Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi on Thursday said committees comprising trained doctors would be set up at all government medical college and hospitals in the state to formally declare a person who succumbs to accident injuries as “brain dead” so that his or her organs could be donated with the consent of family members.

Modi said the need to set up the committee was felt to prevent the delay in the start of the process for organ donation of the accident victim, who suffers brain death during treatment at the hospital.

Modi said the decision was taken as a follow-up to the case of a boy, Rohit Kumar (17) from Muzaffarpur, whose family members donated five of his vital organs to help people needing organ transplant at Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences (IGIMS) here. Modi also announced Rs 1 lakh cash reward from the funds of Dadhichi Dehdaan Samiti for the family of Rohit for their response to the campaign for organ donation.

Rohit, who had met an accident at Muzaffarpur on March 6, was rushed to IGIMS the next day. The accident had also caused brain haemorrhage. After he died on March 17, a committee of doctors gave the family a certificate of Rohit as being the case of brain death the next day. In between, the process for the donation of the vital organs of the deceased was also started.

Modi said it was the second case of brain death in the state. The first case was reported in September 2018.

Modi said 7,155 persons died due to severe accidents last year in the state, but if there had been proper awareness about organ donation, it would have helped hundreds of people. “Organs have been donated in 153 brain death cases in Maharashtra, 117 in Telangana and 93 in Tamil Nadu since September 2018,” he said.

Modi also asked the health department principal secretary Sanjay Kumar to make operational the eye banks established at Jawaharlal Nehru Medical College Hospital, Muzaffarpur and Anugrah Narayan Magadh Medical College Hospital, Gaya . He also asked Kumar to take steps for the opening of eye banks in all the other medical college hospitals.

Title: Three trains cancelled over fear of coronavirus, low occupancy
Content: DEHRADUN: The Railways on Thursday cancelled operations of three trains operating in the state from March 20 to March 31, in view of the growing threat of coronavirus as well as low occupancy.A communique from the Railways said that the cancelled trains are 12401/02 Kota-Dehradun Nanda Devi Express, 01701/02 Jabalpur-Haridwar special train, and 12091/92 Dehradun-Kathgodam Naini Jan Shatabdi “All passengers having tickets in these trains will not be charged any cancellation fees. They will get a 100 per cent refund,” said an official of the Indian Railways

Title: Covid-19 scare: Exempt us from going to colleges, demand Patliputra University teachers
Content: PATNA: Patliputra University Teachers’ Association ( PPUTA ) on Thursday submitted a memorandum to governor-cum-chancellor of universities Phagu Chauhan , urging him to ask the state government to exempt teachers of the postgraduate (PG) departments and constituent colleges located in Nalanda and Patna districts from going to colleges every day at a time when all institutions have been closed for students till March 31 by the state government due to Covid-19 scare.PPUTA president A K Singh Thakur said university and college teachers have been asked to ensure their presence in the colleges every day as per the state government directive issued on March 13. “The state government has closed all colleges for students to prevent spread of Covid-19. There is no rationale behind making presence of teachers mandatory in the colleges when classes are suspended,” Thakur said, adding most colleges have no separate rooms for teachers to sit and spend at least five hours every day.General secretary of the association Hridya Narayan Singh said some teachers were forced to sit in a congested staff room in the colleges which could be harmful for them in view of the Covid-19 scare. “Most colleges in rural and semi urban areas have not adopted any precautionary measure against Covid-19. It would be much better if teachers are exempted from coming to colleges daily,” he said.

Title: Companies get 45 days more for Q4 results, 1 month for FY20
Content: MUMBAI: To partially ease the hardships that companies are facing due to the spread of coronavirus , markets regulator Sebi on Thursday eased compliance requirements for listed companies.These included allowing an additional 45 days to file their fourth quarter results and a further one month for annual results . Companies usually get 45 days to file their quarterly returns, but have now been given time till June 30, 2020 to file the same.Sebi also gave an additional three weeks to companies to file their quarterly shareholding pattern, a circular said. For filing year-ending results, the time has also been extended by a month till June 30. Usually, listed companies get 60 days from the close of the financial year to file their annual results, the circular said.The markets regulator also gave an additional month, till May 15, to file the quarterly governance reports. Additionally, it relaxed the time-gap between two board meetings of a company. However, according to listing regulations, the board of directors and the audit committees of the companies have to meet at least four times a year.“The development arising due to the spread of the virus warrants the need for temporary relaxation in compliance requirement of listed entities,” Sebi said in the circular. These relaxations would be effective immediately.There have been some unusual restrictions on travel due to the spread of coronavirus. Also, a large portion of the corporate workforce has been forced to work from home due to the same reason.Sebi has also given one more month to companies to file their half-yearly compliance certificate relating to transfer of shares and yearly secretarial compliance report.Companies can file compliance certificate on share transfer facility till May 31 and secretarial compliance report by June 30. Companies will also get till May 15 to submit the report on investor complaints.

Title: Patna high court first to hold hearing via videoconferencing
Content: PATNA: The Patna high court, which has been at the forefront of initiating precautionary measures to contain the Coronavirus threat, on Thursday created a history of sorts by conducting a hearing via video-conferencing.Advocate general Lalit Kishore, who was present at the hearing, called it a red-letter day for the Patna high court. “This is for the first time that a hearing via video-conferencing took place at any high court in the country. This facility would be expanded later to other courts too in the state. The Chief Justice’s efforts in making this happen must be praised,” Kishore said.The novel hearing was conducted at the court of Justice Chakradhari Sharan Singh, who sat in a separate room, while the lawyers appearing in the cases were present in the courtroom where a large TV was installed.The HC had already started functioning with an alternate roster for all judges for taking up hearing of only bail matters and urgent cases as a precautionary measure to avoid large gathering of advocates and litigants.Senior advocate Yogesh Chandra Verma, who argued in the first four cases before Justice Singh’s bench, said it is for the first time that such a system was adopted for conducting hearing across any high court in the country.“It became possible due to the efforts of the Chief Justice Sanjay Karol. The situation arising out of the coronavirus infection acted as a catalyst. The system worked smoothly,” he said.Verma, who is also the chairman of the coordination committee of all three associations of the lawyers at the high court, said library of respective associations inside the HC premises have been closed and lawyers urged to arrive in smaller numbers.The advocate general, who is also the chairman of the Bihar State Bar Council , said he has issued orders for closure of bar council building inside the high court premises till March 31. “All bar council members who have their chambers inside the building, were urged to keep them closed as precautionary measure,” Kishore said.He said instructions have also been issued to remove all typing shops located inside and outside the high court premises after few crows were found dead inside the periphery couple of days back. “I have been informed that one of the dead crows was found to be infected with bird flu after tests. Administration has been alerted to inspect poultries located nearby the high court premises,” he added.

Title: Coronavirus scare drives up interest in rental cars
Content: CHENNAI: With the Covid-19 scare keeping people away from public transport, self drive and rental car companies are seeing a sharp jump in subscriptions and enquiries. Car rental companies like Eco-Rent-a-Car and Revv have seen a sudden spurt in demand, others like Zoom has quadrupled rentals while Drivezy are launching new services to ride the wave. Work from home, fear of virus spreading while using public transport and schools being shut are all factors that are pushing greater demand for car rental companies.B2B car rental company Eco-Rent-a-Car, for example, has seen its individual cab segment attract fresh enquiries even as the tourist segment dwindles. “Since Monday a lot of our corporate clients are providing individual cabs to their employees rather than have them travel by public transport. So the private cab segment has suddenly seen a surge in demand. Some of these corporates are asking for 25 cabs a day or 35 cabs a day,” said Aditya Loomba, joint MD, of the company.Currently the individual cab business for Eco-Rent-a-Car is up to 350 cars a day while travel and tourism which used to be 200 cars a day is now down to almost zero. “But we have not increased our rates and offer discounts too in some cases,” he added.Others like Revv have seen a 30%-40% increase in subscriptions said co-founder Anupam Agarwal . Drivezy on the other hand has actually reduced the price of the monthly bike subscription to Rs 6,000-Rs 7,000 per month for a period of 3-months. “Keeping in mind the concerns of customers who may hesitate to travel by public transport, we are rolling out the monthly car subscription service in all our operational cities,” said Ashwarya Singh, CEO and co-founder Drivezy India “Customers can now rent a car for themselves and their family members for a month or more and these cars will be sanitised and sent after a full maintenance check-up.”The demand spurt is also leading to a mark up in tariff. Self-drive rental Zoom Car has nearly quadrupled its tariffs on self drive cars in select cities. For example, a self drive KUV in Madurai earlier this month for 150 km drive was just Rs 1,249 with fuel.The same for the upcoming weekend is Rs 4,375. While the company did not wish to reply to TOI queries, a call to the customer service showed that the company followed dynamic pricing, like airlines: the greater the demand the higher the prices.

Title: Set up units to treat 300-500 people: Rajasthan govt to collectors
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: With three new cases of novel coronavirus (Covid-19), the health department has directed all the district collectors to establish quarantine facilities having capacity from 300 to 500 beds. “It has been decided to establish quarantine centres for housing personnel with potential exposure to Covid-19. All districts need to identify quarantine facilities that can house 300 to 500 people. For divisional headquarters, at least 500 people and rest districts at least 300 people,” says the order issued by the health department to all district collectors.

The department directed the collector to identify the place for quarantine in the outskirts of the city areas away from the human habitats. Keeping the comfort of those to be quarantined, the department directed the district collectors to ensure that the place should be well ventilated and should have adequate scope for natural lighting. Also, the quarantine facilities should have a room for accommodating 5 to 10 beds at 1 to 2 metre apart with separate washroom.

The facility should have a clinical examination room, medical station, catering facilities, laundry services and waste management. Also, ensure that the facilities should have landline and internet services so that people who are kept in quarantine at the place should remain connected with their near and dear ones.

Also, psychiatrics and psychologists will also be deployed along with public health specialists, nurses, catering staff and sanitary staff. CCTVs should be installed for surveillance. For smooth administrative functioning and an administrator, not below the rank of sub divisional magistrate should be identified as the nodal officer for each quarantine centre, who will directly report to the higher authorities.

All staff need to be oriented on Covid-19 and on infection prevention and control practices including use of personal protection equipment, mask and gloves. Dedicates ambulance service will remain available on round-the-clock basis.

Title: Valsad collector tops in CM Dashboard ranking for 165 days
Content:
Surat: With speedy implementation of various developmental works in the district, Valsad district collector C R Kharsan ranked first for 165 days, the highest number of days , in the newly launched CM Dashboard programme. The programme, which was launched by chief minister Vijay Rupani in September last year in the state, helps the CM monitor progress of developmental projects of district- level activities of various schemes on real-time basis.

The CM dashboard covers various public-oriented schemes, such as revenue, agriculture, health, education as well as energy, roads and buildings. Review and evaluation of daily, weekly and monthly activities of different schemes operated by the central and state governments can be monitored directly with the help of the CM dashboard.

Valsad collector C R Kharsan remained in the toppers’ club for 190 days. Moreover, of the 190 days, he remained on first rank for 165 days.

“CM dashboard covers 61 indicators-services of Valsad district which include 108 emergency services, civil supplies, applications to convert agricultural land into non-agricultural, inspecting police stations and jails, issuing caste certificates and law and order among other. We have set up a system to help the common people and deliver public service very fast. This work gets reflected on the CM dashboard system,” explained Kharsan, while talking to TOI.

“We are committed to do our work in an effective manner and will continue our efforts to remain on the top while delivering public services,” he added.

Title: Ahmedabad News - Times of India
Content:
Ahmedabad: A resident of Chandlodia, an accountant with a private firm, on Wednesday filed a complaint at Navrangpura police station alleging that an online swindler cheated him of Rs 70,411 using the ruse of returning interest earned on an equated monthly instalment (EMI) paid 10 years ago.

Pradeep Gajjar, a resident of Nandanvan Awas Yojana and an employee of a private firm in Navrangpura, in his FIR stated that he had received a call from an unknown number on March 2. The caller told him he was calling from a private finance firm from which Gajjar had got a consumer loan for a refrigerator.

The caller told Gajjar that he had paid Rs 4,275 extra towards his EMIs and the firm wanted to return it. The man asked Gajjar for his credit and debit cards details. Gajjar gave him these and after a while received a one-time-password (OTP). At the caller’s instruction, Gajjar shared the OTP with him and the caller told him the money would be deposited after a while.

When Gajjar went to his bank and got an account statement, he learned that Rs 70,441 had been debited from his account.

Title: Closure of MDMA hall to impact diamond trading in Surat
Content:
Surat: The trading in the world’s largest diamond cutting and polishing centre Surat will be affected after the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) closed down diamond trading hall of Mumbai Diamond Merchants Association (MDMA) at the Bharat Diamond Bourse (BDB) in Mumbai on Thursday.

Industry sources said that the MDMA hall has been shut down by the Maharashtra police as a precautionary measure in wake of the rising coronavirus cases in Mumbai. The trading activity has been suspended till further notice.

A senior functionary of BDB seeking anonymity said, “There will be no trading of diamonds till further notice. The decision was taken by the BMC to prevent the diamond traders from gathering in large numbers at the hall.”

Sources said that this will impact diamond trading in Surat’s diamond markets.

Kirti Shah, diamond exporter said, “The diamonds are sent to BDB for trading and dispatch to the foreign countries. The diamond merchants in Mumbai won’t be able to trade diamonds which in turn will impact Surat traders also.”

President of Surat Diamond Association (SDA), Babu Kathiriya said, “The closure of MDMA hall means that the merchants won’t be able to trade diamonds at BDB. Except for the diamond offices, the trading will be affected in Mumbai. At present, there is hardly 30% trading in the markets of Surat as the export of polished diamonds was down due to coronavirus outbreak.”

Title: Rumours of SUMUL closure triggers panic milk buying
Content:
Surat: Residents in the Diamond City were on the tenterhooks after rumours on the social media regarding the shutdown of the Surat District Co-operative Milk Producers’ Union Ltd (SUMUL) due to coronavirus pandemic.

Since Wednesday evening, social media was flooded with messages that the milk chilling plants of the SUMUL dairy would stop collecting milk starting from March 21. The messages circulated in the name of SUMUL urged the residents to stock up on the milk and milk powder.

Residents started frantic inquiries with their milk suppliers. Panic buying was also witnessed in many parts of the city on Thursday.

Later on Thursday, SUMUL authorities issued a statement stating that all the milk chilling plants are operational and that there was no closure. The dairy added that the messages were circulated by their opponents and that the authorities have started the process of registering police complaint against those responsible for spreading the rumours.

Talking with TOI, marketing head of SUMUL dairy, Manish Bhatt said, “There were rumours regarding the closure and shortage of milk in the market. The messages were circulated by some with vested interest who want to malign the image of SUMUL dairy. We will be filing a police complaint against the mischief mongers.”

Bhatt added, “We have started the thermal screening of the farmers bringing milk at our collection centres across the district.”

He said that all dealers across have been asked to communicate to their customers that the dairy will be operating as usual.

Title: CII chief calls for direct transfers to poor by govt
Content:
Mumbai: Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) president Vikram Kirloskar has called for the government to transfer a portion of savings on oil imports to accounts of the underprivileged and use part of the import savings in infrastructure to boost demand.

Speaking to TOI, Kirloskar said, “There are some estimates that the savings could be as much as $50 billion. The fund transfer can be a small amount that can help them get on with life and also generate demand.”

According to Kirloskar, small businesses are the most vulnerable and CII has requested the government to address the small-scale sector as soon as possible. “We are also talking to our members, asking them not to lay off people and spread the pain to everyone. We are asking them to help small businesses they deal with as it is hard to tell what will happen because of the virus ,” said Kirloskar.

According to the industry body chief, there is a need to restart a business with full safety measures in place. “People still have to live and go on with their lives. Businesses will be able to sustain only as long as money runs out,” he said.

He said that the airline and transportation sector needs to be protected as they are vital to the economy for recovery after the crisis. “We are talking to the RBI. Other central banks have reduced rates and increased liquidity. There could also be a moratorium on loans so that people do not get into NPAs. We have to find a way of using the liquidity with banks to support the small and medium sector,” he said.

Kirloskar called for a collaborative approach with the government supporting small businesses by releasing payments quickly and lowering taxes to help them tide over the current situation.

Title: Now get corona covered for Rs 459 with Star Health
Content:
Chennai: Billionaire investor Rakesh Jhunjhunwala and PE firm Madison Capital backed Star Health on Thursday announced that it has rolled out a ‘simple no questions asked Corona’ cover. “The benefit policy covers the age group from 3 months to 65 years and it is paid straight when the patient walks out of the hospital after a positive diagnosis. The insured has to show that he tested positive for Covid-19 and get the money,” said V Jagannathan, executive chairman of Star Health. Interestingly, claims under this policy do not ask for submission or take into account the recent travel history of policyholders before the purchase or during the time of claim. The COVID-19 insurance cover comes assuring a sum insured of Rs 21,000 and Rs 42,000 is promised for a premium of Rs 459 and Rs 918 respectively. Interestingly, claims can be applied after a mere 16-day waiting period, with the incubation period for the novel coronavirus standing between two and 14 days.

Star Health has designed a simple and straight health insurance policy which promises to pay the beneficiary after he/she is certified as ‘Positive Diagnosis and Hospitalisation’. All existing Star Health policyholders are already covered for expenses incurred for treatment and hospitalization of Coronavirus under present health covers.

Jagannathan said, “The very objective of this policy is to cater to an audience that is not insured yet and of lower income. Many still do not know the importance of having a health insurance cover. Customers can buy this policy from our online platform and agents. Soon, if our bancassurance partners are interested we may sell these to their customers as well.”

Title: Patna: 19-year-old boy accused of raping minor girl
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: Hours after a 19-year-old boy, Gyan Vishnu Arya, was sent to jail on Thursday on charges of raping a 14-year-old girl who was later found seven-month pregnant, the survivor reached the Women’s police station and claimed that she got pregnant after being raped by her maternal cousin in August last year.

Arya, who was living in a rented accommodation atn East Lohanipur under the Kadamkuan police station area here, was arrested on Tuesday night. The girl’s mother had lodged an FIR against Arya with Kadamkuan police station, accusing him of raping her daughter.

However, the rape survivor recorded her statement before a woman police officer posted at Women’s police station, alleging that it was her maternal cousin Deepak Kumar who had raped her in August last year and made her pregnant. The girl, however, said Arya had also raped her some days back.

SHO Arti Kumari Jaiswal said according to the rape survivor, Deepak is aged around 18 years. “The incident had taken place at the house of the girl’s maternal grandparents in Alamganj,” Jaiswal said, adding efforts were on to arrest Deepak.

However, SHO (incharge) of Kadamkuan police station Rakesh Kumar said the girl’s mother had accused only Arya of repeatedly raping her daughter. “During interrogation, Arya admitted that he had met the girl. However, he has denied raping the girl,” Kumar said, adding the girl’s statement before judicial magistrate was yet to be recorded.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Talati’s aide caught taking Rs 71,000 bribe near Surat
Content:
Sleuths of anti-corruption bureau (ACB)’s Navsari branch caught a person taking a bribe of Rs71,000 on behalf ... Read More

SURAT: Sleuths of anti-corruption bureau (ACB)’s Navsari branch caught a person taking a bribe of Rs71,000 on behalf of talati cum mantri of Simadi village of Surat’s Kamrej taluka on Thursday

Kishan Lakhani was caught in Sarthana area of the city when he took the bribe on behalf of Dharaben Thesia, who is on the run.

The complainant had won the contract to construct village panchayat office and to carry out renovation of an anganwadi. He had completed the work amounting to Rs10.60 lakh in August 2019. Thesia had demanded a bribe of Rs71,000 for clearing the remaining amount.

“Complainant did not want to pay the bribe and contacted us. Accused Thesia had asked the complainant on phone to give Rs71,000 to Lakhani for clearing the remaining payment. We laid a trap and caught him,” an ACB officer.

Title: Three arrested for firing near anti-CAA protest site in Gaya
Content:
Representational image

GAYA: Three alleged criminals have been arrested by the police for firing near an anti-CAA protest site on the outskirts of Gaya town. The firing took place near Bara village of the Chakand police station area late on Wednesday evening.

The trio was overpowered by anti-CAA protestors and handed over to the police. Senior police officers claimed the arrested men were robbers and the incident has nothing to do with anti CAA-NPR-NRC protests.

The incident caused tension in the area and soon a large group of protest sympathisers gathered from adjoining villages. However, the tension subsided following prompt police intervention to prevent rumour-mongering.

Gaya SSP Rajiv Mishra confirmed that the firing took place near the dharna site, but clarified that it had nothing to do with the protest. “The pistol used in the firing has been seized,” Mishra said.

The SSP added that the trio were highway robbers and one of them, an auto-driver from Chatra in Jharkhand , had bought a pistol from Munger about 10 days ago.

“He bought the pistol for Rs 20,000 and planned a robbery along with his two accomplices. The Jharkhand native drives auto rickshaw in Gaya town. He also smuggled liquor and along with two others consumed it and lay in wait at a shed. As a biker approached the point, they opened fire. The biker managed to dodge the criminals. And nearby protesters rushed and overpowered the trio,” the SSP said.

Anti-CAA protests are also going on in Shantibagh of Gaya town and Hamzapur area of Sherghati, one of the four sub-divisional headquarters of the district from nearly two months now.

Title: Work-from-home poses a security challenge
Content:
Kozhikode: With Covid-19 forcing many organizations to adopt work- from-home to enable social distancing and ensure business continuity, cyber security experts advised increased vigil as remote work over unsecured networks could increase the risks of cyber threats to critical assets and data of firms.

Experts said that many home networks had unsecured endpoints, including unsecured Wi-Fi and poorly-configured modems which could make corporate networks vulnerable to cyber-attacks.

"With many people now working from home, many organisations lack the capabilities to provide secured virtual private network (VPN) access or endpoint detection and response (EDR) tools. On the network security front, it means the firm’s network perimeter now has expanded further to homes and other unsecured locations. This makes it easier for malicious persons to hack user endpoint-devices by exploiting possible vulnerabilities in home network infrastructure like unsecured home Wi-Fi and poorly-configured modems," said Vinod T, who heads cyber security at UL Technology Solutions.

Also cyber security experts said that cyber criminals have already started exploiting Covid-19 concerns among people through phishing campaigns in the form of e-mails offering Covid-19 information to trick recipients to click on the link which inserts a malware into the user device. The attacker then can control the user’s device remotely and gain access to office network or create a ransomware attack.

"Simple precautions that can be taken by employees and IT team is to ensure the use of a strong password policy, keeping modem, routers and other devices up-to-date with the latest firmware patches and turning off WPA & UPnP, instead use WPA2 which uses a stronger form of cryptography. Network security administrators should conduct quick vulnerability assessment to identify loopholes," said Vinod, adding that employees should be trained on how to detect and handle phishing and other forms of social engineering attacks.

Experts say that VPNs ensure that the internet traffic is encrypted and safe between office network and the remote machine. Hence if the employee is working on sensitive data, he or she should use VPN provided by the organization.

Title: Brick kiln owner shot by two in Varanasi
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: Ramlal Patel (72), a brick kiln owner, was shot near his residence in Ramaipur Pindra area under Phoolpur police station on Thursday morning .

According to sources, Patel was on way to a a temple in his neighbourhood on Thursday morning when two motorcycle-borne miscreants shot him and fled. Patel suffered three bullet injuries on head and face and died on the spot.

Angered over the killing, hundreds of local blocked Varanasi-Lucknow highway and started demonstration. SP (rural) Martand Pratap Singh , along with heavy police force, reached there and tried to pacify the situation. The stir ended only after SSP Prabhakar Chawdhary reached there and assured to work out the case at the earliest. The body was sent for postmortem.

The SP said that Patel and his elder son used to run brick kiln. The family claimed to have no enmity with anyone, however, property dispute is being suspected to be the cause of killing, he said adding that an FIR against unidentified miscreants had been lodged.

This was second murder in less than 24 hours. On Wednesday, three masked miscreants sprayed bullets on a trader in Brahmaghat area under the limits of Kotwali police station.

Title: Surat IMA launches Covid-19 helpline numbers
Content: SURAT: In order to help people suffering from coronavirus fears and Covid-19 positive patients, the Surat branch of Indian Medical Association (IMA) has set up an action committee and issued round-the-clock helpline numbers where people can take doctors ’ advice on issues related to coronavirus.“We have issued an advisory for common people as well as doctors. People have little information about the coronavirus and they are panicky due to its fast spread. However, we want to tell people not to panic and take precautions with the help of doctors,’’ said Dr Parul Vadgama, president, IMA’s Surat branch. TNN

Title: No positive case for second consecutive day
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: No new Covid-19 case was reported in Kerala for the second consecutive day on Wednesday, while the number of persons, placed under observation, crossed 25,000. Also, 237 persons were admitted in designated isolation facilities. Till date, 2,550 samples were sent for testing, of which 2,140 tested negative. At present the situation is not out of control. We are taking extra precaution to meet an emergency, said chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan In certain countries, the virus has moved to the second and third phases. Hence, we are getting ready to meet any such eventuality. Everyone in the state has the responsibility to prevent a community spread, said the chief minister.Vijayan, in his video conference with religious heads of the state, urged them to reduce the numbers for Friday prayers at mosques and Sunday mass in churches. He also urged temples to curtail festival rituals. He requested the public to keep away from Kodungallur Bharani fest for the safety of the society. “Pathanamthitta administration has been an exemplary model in regulating persons at religious functions, prayers and rituals to 10,” he said. The chief minister also requested all marriage halls and convention centres to refund the money paid for marriages that were postponed or cancelled. On the reports that private hospitals were sending people with fever to government hospitals, Vijayan said “We asked IMA to intervene and ask hospitals not to take such steps,’’The chief minister also flayed the letter given by a doctor from IMA to the chief justice of HC claiming that over 2 lakh people are under risk and they might lose lives due to corona. It was taken up with IMA’s leadership and they had made it clear that it was not given with their permission. The state leadership came out against the letter.

Title: Veritas raises Rs 350crin series E
Content:
Chennai: Private lender Veritas Finance, has raised Rs 350 crore as Series E investment with participation from new investor, Kedaara Capital, besides existing investors like Norwest Venture Partners (NVP), Lok Capital Growth Fund and an anchor investor from the family of P Surendra Pai. Norwest Venture Partners, India has doubled their investment in the company by allocating an additional Rs 200 crore in this round. The NBFC has proposed to use the additional capital to further penetrate into existing markets to augment the capital required by MSMEs for business expansion, working capital and for asset creation backed by transformative technology, robust credit appraisal systems and quality customer service.

D Arulmany, MD and CEO, Veritas Finance said, “The significant role that informal micro enterprises play in building the economy can never be ignored and their vital contribution has been recognized by everyone. However, several reasons, starting from their unorganized nature of these enterprises, their size, location, banking habits etc., have hindered them in accessing debt and they continue to face challenges.”

Veritas Finance has a loan book of Rs 1308 crore as on February 29, 2020, with presence across eight states and one union territory. ENDS

Title: Sensex swings 2,600 pts, closes at over 3-year low
Content: Mumbai: Thursday was another day of volatile trades on Dalal Street with the sensex see-sawing over 2,600 points, but again closing deep in the red. Banking & financials, along with Reliance, weighed on the benchmark index as, globally, the coronavirus case count rose and more economists saw a bigger chance of an economic recession over the next few quarters.The day’s session was also impacted negatively by the weakness of the rupee that breached the psychologically important 75-to-the-dollar mark as foreign funds continued to sell.The sensex opened deep in the red and slipped below the 27k mark to a 40-month low in early trade. But then, it rallied nearly 10%, or 2,657 points, to an intra-day high at 29,371. However, in late selling, the sensex gave up all gains to close 581 points, or 2%, lower at 28,288 — a 39-month closing low. Investors were left poorer by Rs 3.8 lakh crore with the BSE ’s market capitalisation now at Rs 109.2 lakh crore.On the NSE , the Nifty closed 205 points or 2.4% off at 8,263. India VIX, the volatility index that is also considered to be a measure of fear among market players, jumped 12.5% to 72 — its highest level in over a decade.According to Motilal Oswal Financial Services head (retail research) Siddhartha Khemka, Indian markets continued to slide southward as the number of coronavirus cases in India as well as globally rose. Although several governments, central banks and regulators have announced steps to support the economy and businesses, these have not been too successful.“With rising cases of coronavirus, volatility is likely to continue in coming days and any bounce could be sold into. In such times, traders should refrain taking long positions as all the global markets are in a strong bear grip,” he said.End of the session BSE data showed foreign investors were net sellers at Rs 4,623 crore on Thursday, taking total outflow for the month from stocks alone to over Rs 55,000 crore, or about $7.5 billion. So far in the month, over 1,200 of the BSE stocks have hit the 52-week low level, including sensex heavyweights like RIL, TCS, ITC, HDFC Bank and HDFC.Market players said that for D-Street investors, Friday could bring some respite since, in early trades on Wall Street, the Dow Jones and the S&P 500 indices were holding on to their previous closing levels and showing a steady trend.

Title: Coronavirus pushes city’s textile processing sector into doldrums
Content:
Surat: Textile dyeing and printing mills in the country’s largest man-made fabric (MMF) hub in the city seem to have become casualty of Covid-19 in the country.

Faced with weak demand for polyester fabrics in the domestic market and also dwindling exports, processing of finished fabrics has come to a grinding halt. Consequently, textile dyeing and printing mills are now operating at less than 50% of their capacity and most have chosen to implement closure for three days a week. Most of the migrant workers have no option, but to leave for their hometown. Textile processing sector in the city employs over two lakh workers.

There are about 315 textile mills in Pandesara, Sachin, Palsana and Kadodara where about 2.5 crore metres of polyester fabrics are processed every day. Following outbreak of coronavirus in the country, textile mills now get less than one crore metres of fabrics for processing due to weak demand in domestic market and sharp decline in export orders from Europe, the United States and UAE.

Industry sources said majority of textile mills are doing job work for textile traders. About 2.5 crore metres of fabrics are processed on job work to the tune of Rs80 crore per day. In the last one week, orders have reduced by almost 50% in textile mills thereby causing them a loss of Rs40 crore.

South Gujarat Textile Processors’ Association (SGTPA) president Jitu Vakharia said, “If coronavirus epidemic worsens, we will have to shutdown our mills. Textile mills are processing one crore metres of fabrics per day against 2.5 crore metres. Demand for polyester fabrics in the country has declined sharply due to coronavirus.”

Kamal Vijay Tulsiyan, a textile mill owner in Pandesara, said, “The situation has turned from bad to worse in the last few days. Domestic demand for fabrics has gone down and exports are also declining. Textile mills have become casualty. It is getting difficult for us to sustain jobs of workers.”

Vinod Agarwal, another textile mill owner in Sachin, said, “We may be forced to shutdown the mills in the coming days if coronavirus situation worsens. In just few days, the job orders have decreased by almost 50%”

PHOTO QUOTES

Binay Agarwal, chairman of Swastik Polyprints: When the country is grappling with coronavirus, fabric purchase will become last priority for people. We are in an unprecedented situation. Domestic and export demand has decreased and we are forced to keep our mills shut for three days a week.

Pramod Chaudhary, chairman of Pratibha Group: We will have to shutdown the mills if coronavirus situation worsens in the country. Traders have almost stopped giving job orders to textile mills as domestic and export demand has decreased. We are operating at less than 50% of our capacity.

FOR GRAPHICS

Unsavoury Development

Total textile mills: 315

Total workers employed: Two lakh

Production loss: 50%

Production of finished fabrics: 2.5 crore metre per day

Total production loss: Rs40 crore

Title: Very soon, get yourself screened for corona at just Rs 500
Content:
Chennai: Pay Rs 500 and get tested for Corona virus. A Chennai-based medical devices firm Neuberg Diagnostics, part of the Trivitron group, has indigenously developed a testing kit for testing Corona infections. The company has been working for a month to get the testing equipment ready. Even as the kit is available and the company is ready to offer tests for Rs 500 (as against $1,100 in the US) in a private lab, there are a couple of factors that are delaying the process. To use the kit, Neuberg has to wait for clearances from the National Institute of Virology. “It has been mandated that one has to test 1,000 positive samples (while India has less than 200 positive cases). We have synthetic samples to test and get the clearances in the next two weeks,” said GSK Velu, CMD, Trivitron

Second, India doesn’t allow private labs to test for COVID infections. “The government is still in talks with the ICMR on this. We have written to the ICMR asking them to approve tests in private labs. With Neuberg Labs, we can test up to 3,000 – 4,000 per day in our National Accreditation Board for Testing and Calibration Laboratories (NABL) – approved labs.

Velu further said their team developed the kit with the learnings from Shandong Yingsheng Biotechnology Co. Ltd, a Chinese company which developed a testing kit for testing COVID infections.

“We had signed a JV with the company in November 2019. Soon after, Wuhan got infected with the Coronavirus and Shandong Yingsheng developed a testing kit on an emergency basis. We began developing this for testing in India at Trivitron in partnership with Institute of Genomics and Integrative Biology,” he added. ENDS

Title: 90 under home quarantine and three in isolation ward in Bharuch
Content:
cap

Bharuch/Surat: Over 90 people are under home quarantine and three persons have been kept in isolation ward of Bharuch Civil Hospital as suspected patients of coronavirus, district collector Dr M D Modiya said on Thursday.

District health team traced 146 people who had returned from abroad in the past 20 days. All were examined but no one has tested positive for coronavirus. These travellers had come in contact with 447 people and they too were examined and found to be normal, Modiya said.

"Bharuch being an industrial district, a meeting with industries associations of Ankleshwar, Jhagadia, Dahej and Vilayat was held on Wednesday. They were asked to brief workers about government directives with regard to coronavirus. We have also requested religious leaders to create an awareness about cleanliness. Teams of officials have been deputed to ensure that cinema theatres, gyms and swimming pools are not operational,” he said.

Dr V S Tripathi, chief district health officer, said, "Situation in Bharuch is normal. About 90 people are under home quarantine and two, who recently returned from Saudi Arabia, have been kept in isolation ward of Bharuch Civil Hospital. The samples of the couple were sent to a laboratory but they have tested negative for coronavirus. They will be discharged soon. A businessman, who returned from New Delhi, had himself approached 108 staff expressing fear that he has contracted the infection. He was also kept in the isolation ward at Bharuch Civil Hospital on Wednesday. His examination revealed that he too is not suffering from coronavirus.”

The district administration has set up a special ward with 45-beds and ventilators in Bharuch town. A physician has been transferred from Valia community health centre to this ward to run its operations, Modiya said.

Title: Covid-19 threat: Passenger footfall, flight operations hit at Patna airport
Content:
Six flights cancelled

PATNA: The global outbreak of coronavirus has severely hit passenger movement at the Jayaprakash Narayan International Airport. Many airlines are virtually running “ghost” flights as the departure and arrival gates at the city airport remain empty.According to the executives of different airlines, a number of people have cancelled or rescheduled their flights in view of the Covid-19 threat. SpiceJet officials told this newspaper on Thursday, “The rate of rescheduling a flight, especially an international one, is quite high.”Meanwhile, harried flyers are queuing up at ticket counters of different airlines to get their tickets rescheduled or cancelled. One of them, Nihal Singh, who has to travel to Abu Dhabi via Delhi on April 3, said, “The airline has asked me to keep tabs on online booking portals in order to reschedule my ticket.”Abdullah, who works as a sales executive at a private firm in Oman and hails from Vaishali, claimed, “Although my office is shut, I have been asked to report on April 22. There is no ticket available for Oman from April 15 to 25.”Precautionary measures at airport: The Patna airport is taking all precautionary measures for containing the spread of Covid-19. The entry of visitors to the terminal building has been stopped with immediate effect and security stepped up.The airport tweeted on Wednesday night, “We remain committed to preventing the spread of #COVID-19. Airlines, CISF, State Health Services and AAI teams are working together. Mandatory screening of all passengers with international travel history is being ensured.”Another tweet read, “Screening of domestic passengers has also started.”Besides, three teams, comprising 16 workers each, have been formed to sanitize the airport premises round the clock. Each of them is working in three shifts of 8 hours every day. They clean the seats, floor, counters and desk thoroughly.Mohd Jilani, who works as a welder in Dubai, said, “The medical team at the airport did my thorough check-up for at least 25 minutes.”Niharika Sinha, who returned home from Delhi on Thursday, thanked the airport officials for being on their toes. She said, “All the passengers arriving here were screened. It is good that the airport is not crowded.”Altogether six flights on the Patna-Delhi and Patna-Ahmedabad routes were cancelled on Thursday due to the outbreak of Covid-19.Budget carrier GoAir cancelled five flights — four Delhi-bound (G8-143/273, G8-135/136, G8-231/132 and G8-133/134) and one Ahmedabad- bound (G8-515/516).GoAir executives said, “The step is temporary as the flights have been cancelled as a precautionary measure. Customers will get a full refund. Those, who have to travel due to some urgent work, will get alternate flights.”Air India also cancelled one Delhi-bound flight (AI-409/410) on Thursday.

Title: Purnea University OKs new courses
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

PATNA: Purnea University unanimously approved as many as 36 proposals related to academic development and introduction of new courses at its fifth syndicate meeting held under the chairmanship of vice chancellor (VC) Prof Rajesh Singh on Tuesday. The syndicate members also approved the academic calendar for the session 2020-21 beginning from July month.

Prof Singh said on Thursday that the syndicate members resolved to complete all admission and registration procedure latest by July 15 and all classes would start from July 16 at both undergraduate (UG) and postgraduate (PG)- level. “The meeting also approved the examination schedule of the university for the 2020-21 academic session. The university will conduct all examinations in May 2021 for the current academic session and results will be published in June 2021,” he said.

The syndicate also passed the resolutions to start newly-designed hotel management and tourism and hotel management and hospitality courses in collaboration with ICFAI University of Sikkim. “The proposal is being sent to Raj Bhavan for its final approval to start these two career-oriented courses in the university with a view to providing ample job opportunities to students,” the VC said adding the meeting also approved the proposal to develop university library and give an impetus to smart class teaching and e-library facility.

Members at the meeting also approved the proposal to renovate laboratories of physics, chemistry, botany, zoology, biotechnology and bioinformatics at the degree and post-graduate level institution to cater to the needs of students and researchers.

“The university syndicate adopted a resolution to streamline vocational courses, including Master of Computer Application (MCA), Bachelor of Computer Application (BCA), MEd and BEd courses from the academic session 2020-21,” the VC said adding the syndicate also approved the proposal to set up a committee comprising senior university teachers to visit and inspect academic and administrative functioning at each college to streamline the academic ambience on the campuses of institutions falling under Purnea University.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Rush at Patna stores for essential items
Content: PATNA: Spooked by the Covid-19 scare, people are stocking up on essential commodities such as rice, flour, cooking oils and spices in the city. Wholesalers, supermarkets and small shop-owners claimed that demand for groceries and packaged food has gone up sharply.“Masks, handwash and sanitizers are among the top selling items at our store. Grocery items, including wheat flour, pulses, sugar, salt and spices, too are in high demand. Paper towels and packaged food are being sold in large quantities too,” said Vishwakarma, a senior employee at a supermarket near Kurji He added: “We have closed the sale of other items, including clothes, in order to limit the crowd. It is only opened for grocery and essential items now.”Customer care executives at an Exhibition Road supermarket reported a sudden rise in number of customers after the state government ordered closure of malls and public spaces. “We had to reorder several food items twice as the stocks were totally empty. Customers are buying more than they usually do,” said Pramod, a sales executive.Sales persons at another city supermarket said, “Huge number of customers are visiting to buy groceries items like salt, sugar, salt, rice, flour, pulses, cooking oils as well as ready-to-cook meals and packaged food items like poha and upma.”He added, “There are no limits set by the store on sale of grocery items as of now. So, residents are buying more than they need with some customers buying food items for two-three months.”Citing an example of how some customers are emptying the shelves, he said: “A family on Thursday afternoon bought 30kg of rice, 15kg of pulses and 50 packets of biscuits.”Wholesalers too said they are witnessing a huge rush. “We normally sell items worth Rs 30,000-35,000 a day. But now we are selling items worth Rs80,000-90,000 in a day,” said Bipin Rai, owner of a grocery store in Kadamkuan Residents said they are worried about the fact that there might be a lockdown in the coming days. “I have stocked up my kitchen with grocery items for the next three months because of the global outbreak of Covid-19. I have also bought other items like toothpaste, soaps, shampoos, floor cleaner and hand washes,” said Veena Sharan, a resident of Ashiana-Digha Road.

Title: Six with ‘home quarantine’ stamp deboarded from Rajadhani Express in Surat
Content: SURAT: Six passengers from Dubai and France having ‘home quarantine’ stamp on their hands were deboarded from Rajdhani Express at Surat railway station after train staff and passengers raised an alarm on Thursday.Official sources said checking staff of Rajdhani Express were alerted by passengers in B-7 coach after they found six people travelling with home quarantine stamp on their hands. The checking staff immediately alerted headquarters in Mumbai and the passengers were asked to deboard at Surat railway station at about 7.51pm.CR Garuda, area railway manager, told TOI, “The checking staff of Rajdhani Express asked the passengers with home quarantine tag to deboard at Surat station, but they refused. The train had to be halted for 12 minutes, instead of its departure time of five minutes. Finally, the passengers agreed to deboard and the health department of SMC was informed.”Garuda added, “The passengers were travelling from Mumbai Central to New Delhi. Three passengers are students in France and were going to Himachal Pradesh, while the rest included two women and a senior citizen of a family.”Garuda said the passengers were screened at Mumbai international airport where they were found negative for coronavirus . However, they were advised home quarantine for 14 days.Official sources said the six passengers were taken to a quarantine facility set up by the civic body at Samras hostel of Veer Narmad South Gujarat University

Title: ‘Kamal’ will bloom in MP, not Kamal Nath: Keshav Prasad Maurya
Content:
File photo of Kamal Nath

KANPUR: In Madhya Pradesh , ‘kamal’ (lotus) will bloom, not Kamal Nath , said deputy chief minister Keshav Prasad Maurya , while on a visit to the city on Thursday.

“Just wait and watch, you will all see ‘kamal’ (lotus) blooming and not Kamal Nath in Madhya Pradesh,” said Maurya, while addressing reporters at Merchant Chambers hall.

While attacking the opposition, particularly Samajwadi Party , Maurya said: “Those (rivals) who are pointing fingers on three years’ achievements of BJP government should compare it with their five-year rule. We are far ahead when it comes to providing jobs to youngsters or executing developmental projects.”

“Earlier, we constructed roads in the villages and localities of state toppers of high school and intermediate. Now, we have decided to construct roads in the villages and localities of ICSE and CBSE toppers. The roads constructed will be named after internationally acclaimed hockey player Dhyanchand,” said Maurya.

Title: Banks to continue IT, treasury, clearing operations
Content: MUMBAI: Banks have built contingency plans to ensure that critical IT units for the delivery of digital banking, treasury services and cheque clearing continue even if the coronavirus shutdown intensifies.However, frontline staff will continue to attend office this month as the last fortnight of the fiscal is the busiest time of the year. “We have put in place contingency plans for branches. If there is a case detected, the branch would have to be closed. We have formed branch clusters where alternative arrangements can be made if required,” said Bank of Baroda HR head Joydeep Dutta Roy There will also be directions on limiting the number of people inside a branch to ensure that there is social distancing, he added. An IBA official said the Maharashtra directive requiring 50% employees to work from home (WFH) cannot apply to banks as they come under essential services. Also, most of the tax collection is done through public sector banks.WFH is also not an option for many central office employees of the 10 public sector banks that are going through a merger process as they have to complete this by March 31.Meanwhile, non-bank lenders are allowing employees the WFH option. Edelweiss Financial Services has asked all employees to work from home for two weeks and has activated a business continuity plan for staff to operate remotely.All banks are promoting the use of mobile apps Bank of Baroda has seen a 10% pick-up in the use of digital channels in the last week. Union Bank of India has taken measures to ensure that even if public transportation is discontinued, a skeletal staff is organised to ensure that cheque-clearing operations continue.Banks have already activated a business continuity plan of splitting IT staff between the main hub and the disaster recovery centre so that operations are not hampered. Other critical areas where the banks are splitting their divisions into two locations are in treasury and forex trading to ensure that money keeps flowing even if there is a slowdown.SBI, meanwhile, said that it would pay an unspecified allowance to employees for March for purchasing sanitisers and face masks. Other public sector banks may also follow suit.There have been rumblings among PSB employees who were pushed by managers to achieve year-end targets. Bank of Maharashtra was criticised for pushing staff to achieve insurance sales, while Punjab National Bank Muzzafarnagar office had asked branches to remain open on Sunday to help achieve recovery targets.

Title: 71% of small business see demand fall: Survey
Content:
(Representative image)

BENGALURU: The impact of coronavirus is being felt across India’s startup ecosystem and small businesses as 71% have seen a fall in demand over the last weeks. As a consequence, 63% plan to cut jobs, according to results of a survey of over 8,500 such companies conducted by LocalCircles.

About 48% of the companies surveyed said that they expect to see supply chain disruptions and an increase in costs. While 41% expect to see a double whammy of both supply chain issues with cost increase and slowing demand, 11% of the respondents said they don’t expect an impact.

Up to 52% of the companies surveyed said that they plan to reduce marketing/advertising, while 41% will bring down real estate costs and 48% will cut infrastructure & technology costs. About 48% of the companies polled said they will take at least two of these measures, while 37% said there won’t be an impact on their business.

The survey results come on the back of increasing pain among segments of India’s consumption economy, with travel, hospitality and restaurants among the biggest hit. In digital companies, ride-hailing firms like Ola and Uber have already seen business come down 40-50% and even online food delivery has taken a hit of 20%.

Globally, governments like the US are considering a stimulus package of over $1 trillion for businesses, while France announced the suspension of taxes, rent and utility bills for small businesses.

Title: Varanasi: To beat sanitiser crisis, make your own at home
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: At a time when markets are running short of sanitisers due to an upsurge in its demand following Covid-19 scare, a research group at Nano-Cellular Medicine and Biophysics Laboratory , School of Biochemical Engineering , IIT-BHU has decided to impart training of preparing sanitizer using products easily available at home.

“We decided to prepare sanitizer in our laboratory and distribute among students and staff. Also, we have planned to conduct an outreach programme to train people on preparing sanitiser at home,” said associate professor Dr Marshal, who leads the research group.

Explaining the formula, he said that to prepare sanitizer mix 7 parts of Ethanol (99% pure) with 3 parts of Aloe Vera gel and then add 1% Sodium Hydroxide (1mm). To overcome the smell of alcohol, add rose water or kewra water to it. The cost of 100ml sanitizer prepared is estimated to be Rs 40.

“We are ready to cooperate with the district administration to fight against the virus,” said Dr Marshal adding that any individual can contact them to learn the process of preparing sanitizer free of cost.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak in Nagpur: Food delivery apps ensure restaurant kitchens keep working
Content: NAGPUR: District collector Ravindra Thakre’s directives led to all city restaurants closing their doors for walk-in customers, however, they are still serving food by delivering it to customers via several online applications.Thakare has also cleared the confusion on whether food delivery chains like Zomato and Swiggy could operate. He said they can continue operations as their functioning doesn’t involve crowds and, therefore, probability of contracting the virus was less. “The delivery boys deliver food directly at home and in entire operation no other person is involved,” he told TOI.This means restaurants can keep their kitchens open but cannot allow walk-in customers.While some restaurants are sending their own employees for delivery, a bulk of these establishment owners are relying on online food delivery apps.TOI spoke to several restaurant employees, and most of them blamed the coronavirus outbreak for business going down. However, some of them claimed that their delivery orders have not been affected due to recent order by the collector.An employee from a Wardha Road-based restaurant claimed they have closed the front door of the restaurant, but is allowing customers who want to have food inside the restaurant in from a small rear door. “We are also giving home deliveries and people are also using online applications to order food from our restaurants. However, orders have decreased. We have also announced a holiday for some of our staff, but are serving them food since they have nowhere else to go.”Owner of an online kitchen restaurant told TOI that since the outbreak of coronavirus orders for food have decreased. “Customers have reduced orders in the recent past. They are also avoiding junk food, due to which business is slack,” he said.Employee at a restaurant franchise located in Sadar claimed, though, business has not been affected after the establishment closed for walk-ins. “Several orders are coming through online food delivery applications. The closure of restaurants has not affected us as now a days people anyway prefer to eat at home rather than at a restaurant,” he said.The owner of a restaurant on Manewada Road revealed that they are also allowing customers to pick up food from the restaurant along with online applications. “The business is slow due to the recent incidents, and we are also buying materials in smaller quantity so food does not go waste. Business is down almost 50%. I hope in the coming days business will be back on track.”TOI also spoke to some of the food delivery boys, who claimed that their work has not been affected due to the recent closure of restaurants. “My work has not reduced a bit, even though restaurants are closed. I started working at around 10am and till 3.30pm I have delivered around 10 orders from different restaurants to houses in different areas,” said a delivery boy.

Title: SBI asked to defer recovery for 40 days
Content:
Ahmedabad: The effect of the Covid-19 pandemic is being felt in court orders too. A Debt Recovery Tribunal (DRT) on Thursday directed the State Bank of India (SBI) to defer its recovery proceedings for at least 40 days.

The SBI has to recover Rs 70 crore from Sysco Industries Ltd, which defaulted and the bank initiated recovery proceedings against the company by taking possession of its property. The bank had already issued notice to take possession under the Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Securities Interest (SARFEISI) Act.

Sysco’s advocate Aditya Gupta cited two orders passed by the Gujarat high court and by the Allahabad high court requesting the lower courts to defer judicial works, unless it is unavoidable in wake of novel coronavirus scare. The Allahabad HC has ordered public authorities not to take coercive action against private parties so far as taking possession of property is concerned as part of recovery proceedings.

After hearing advocate Gupta, DRT’s presiding officer Vinay Goel said, “In the light of above orders of two courts and having considered fact that although bank is to recover public money but for that life and security of public at large cannot be put to risk. So applying the ratio of orders and spirit of orders passed by the high courts, I feel fair to restrain bank from taking possession for 40 days from today and the bank would be able to proceed further after issuing fresh 14-day notice to take possession…”

The DRT further said, “It will be the duty of the counsel for the bank to inform the concerned authorities about this order and its effects.

Title: Gold ETF investments hit record high
Content: Ahmedabad: Skyrocketing prices of gold due to concerns over the Covid-19 pandemic spelled good news for investors in gold exchange traded funds (ETFs). In February, assets under management (AUM) in Gold Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) in the state hit Rs 223.68 crore – a record high, according to data by Association of Mutual Funds in India (AMFI). Analysts said that rise in gold prices last month led to an increase in the net asset value.“In February, the spread of coronavirus in China got investors across the globe concerned over its fallout in other countries. As the situation worsened, with cases and deaths being reported not just in China but other countries as well, big investors began making safe-haven investments in gold, as a result of which international price of gold rose,” said Haresh Acharya, director, India Bullion and Jewellers’ Association (IBJA).AUM in Gold ETFs in Gujarat rose from Rs 216.7 crore in January by 3.1% in February. “As prices showed a sharp rise, the net asset value of investments in gold ETFs rose significantly. The rising trend brought investors to gold, which also led to an increase in AUM,” said Acharya.Gold prices touched a record high on March 7 in the Ahmedabad market at Rs 46,100 per 10g. Owing to profit-booking and increased selling of gold by investors, prices dropped to Rs 42,800 on Thursday.Mumukshu Desai, director of a city-based financial advisory firm, said, “Gold prices are extremely volatile at this point and so are other asset classes as well. As a result, investors are maintaining status quo and not moving their funds because no asset class is delivering clear returns due to coronavirus pandemic, which has triggered severe uncertainty in global trade.”

Title: Borkar presents Rs304 crore Aapli Bus budget
Content:
The transport committee budget was presented by Narendra Borkar on Thursday

NAGPUR: Transport committee chairman of Nagpur Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) Narendra Borkar on Thursday presented a Rs304 crore budget of the department for 2020-21 before standing committee chairman Vijay aka Pintu Zalke.

Borkar revised the transport manager Rajesh Mohite’s projected income of Rs273.84 crore by over Rs30 crore. However, his budget did not reveal any concrete measures to increase the revenue.

In current financial year, Mohite had already revised the budget of ex-transport committee chairman of Rs277.84 crore to 206.19 crore. Borkar has projected a revenue of Rs86 crore from the sale of tickets while Rs184 crore funding from standing committee. The panel chief said the department will earn Rs90 lakh from bus shelters advertisements.

However, Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari ’s dream to convert all diesel-run Aapli Bus into CNG to check air pollution has hit a roadblock. Of the announced conversion of all 237 standard buses, the NMC has dropped plans to convert over 100 of them, saying these had outlived.

Borkar also announced to give cash prizes to those who give information about the nexus between Aapli Bus drivers and conductors who pocket the fare money. Though he did not disclose the reward money, Borkar has earmarked Rs10 lakh for the purpose in the next financial year.

He also announced to procure 40 more electric buses under the central government’s faster adoption and manufacturing of hybrid and electric vehicle (Fame-II). The Union government has sanctioned Rs20 crore for NMC to procure the e-buses, he said.

He assured to launch the one-day pass system from this financial year to continue old schemes for commuters.

To a query, Borkar said so far the civic body has converted 70 diesel-run standard buses into CNG and we can convert another 30 to 50.
