Borkar also admitted that from March 2017 to March 2020, the department has defaulted child nutrition cess to the regional transport department. He has kept Rs2 crore to clear the dues. “I have also suggested the standing committee chairman for book adjustment the due with the outstanding property tax of RTO,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus: Only 2.5 ICU beds for every 1 lakh population in Madhya Pradesh
Content:
Isolation ward prepared for suspected coronavirus patients at JP Hospital

BHOPAL: About 750 plus beds have been identified for the isolation of coronavirus-infected patients by the MP health department. Besides that, there are just about 2.5 intensive care unit ( ICU ) beds for every one lakh population in Madhya Pradesh , going by a 2017 assessment.

As witnessed in Italy and before that in China, where the COVID-19 outbreak has been severe, there is a requirement of minimally manual ICU care to avoid the spread of the contagion. For those with acute respiratory distress and other complications, level 2 or above ICU units are needed, explained a public health expert with the Union government.

Of the total number of ICU beds, 250 are in level 1, 1,141 are in level 2, and 425 are in level 3 facilities. This amounts to 0.34, 1.57, and 0.59 ICU beds per 1,00,000 population for levels 1, 2 and 3, respectively, according a study released in 2017 in the Indian journal of critical care medicine. The study was conducted by Dr Saurabh Saigal, JP Sharma, A Pakhare, S Bhaskar, S Dhanuka, S Kumar, S Sabde, Dr Pradip Bhattacharya and Dr Rajnish Joshi.

The health department estimates that there are 751 dedicated beds for COVID-19 treatment with 104 ventilators. All tertiary care hospitals will be treatment centres. District hospitals and others will act as screening centres.

With little over 4,000 doctors in the MP government-run hospitals, the infection risk and rate of COVID-19 infection in medical staff is very high. MP has 1,867 healthcare centres/hospitals under the health department. There are 1,420 PHCs, 324 CHCs, 72 SDH and 51 DH, according to a 2018 assessment.

There are 38,140 beds in the health department-run hospitals. Most of these, almost one-third, are for maternity/child care. Of these, 10,020 beds are in rural areas. AYUSH has 690 beds while seven defence hospitals have a total 1,402 beds. WCR railways has about 456 beds, of which 250 are in MP.

Title: 3 GMCH positive patients may be retested today
Content:
Nagpur: While the second and third tests results of Nagpur’s first coronavirus postive patients have come negative, such tests for the three more positive patients will be done after they complete seven days of admission.

The city’s first case, an IT professional admitted at Mayo hospital, was confirmed on March 11 and hence his subsequent tests were held on March 17 and 18. The results were negative.

The other three are admitted at Government Medical College and Hospital. All are doing well and have no symptoms. As per Mayo dean Ajay Keoliya, the negative tests of the first positive patients will help clinicians attending him go for his chest X-ray on a bigger machine.

Civil surgeon Devendra Paturkar said subsequent tests depend on case-to-case basis.

In case the tests on the three are held on Friday, the results would be expected by Saturday.

As per confirmed case management protocol issued by the Union ministry of health and family welfare on Covid-19, patients can be discharged after two specimens test negative within 24 hours and there’s evidence of chest radiographic and viral clearance in respiratory sample.

However, the district administration has taken additional precautionary measures to prevent the community outbreak.

Title: 100 cattle egrets, nine crows found dead in Aligarh
Content:
Agra: As many as 100 cattle egrets (birds) and nine crows were found dead under mysterious circumstances in Aligarh at two different sites -- Sasnigate and Aligarh Muslim University campus -- on Thursday morning.

On being informed, forest officials rushed to the spot and sent a sample for a forensic examination. They sent one of the carcasses for post-mortem and buried the remaining.

Amid fears of bird flu, the university directed their provosts to stop serving chicken in the hostel dining halls.

Talking with TOI, district magistrate CB Singh said the exact cause of death will be known from the autopsy report.

Aligarh’s forest divisional director Satish Kumar told TOI that preliminary investigations indicated that the cattle egret either consumed some pesticide or they were suffering from some disease. But the exact cause would be known on Friday after receiving the PM’s report.

He said one of the birds was alive when the forest team reached there and was sent for treatment. He told TOI that the birds were nesting in the area due to lot of trees.

Expressing fears over so many bird deaths, a resident of Bhojpura said, “We want the administration to get a check-up done as around 200 birds have died.”

Spokesperson of AMU Rahat Abrar said following the bird deaths, the varsity administration has decided to stop serving chicken on campus. “All provosts of the 25 dining halls have been directed not to serve chicken in the dining hall till the situation improves,” he added.

Title: Madurai corpn begins making sanitizers for its own use
Content:
Madurai: The Madurai Corporation has started manufacturing hand sanitizers required for its own use at the Sathamangalam urban primary health centre.

Assistant city health officer Dr Vinoth Raja said they are manufacturing up to 25 litres of hand sanitizers a day, which are being used in various corporation offices for employees’ and public use. They have purchased required chemicals and stocked them adequately to meet the demand.

Raja said that so far 125 people, who have returned to the city from other countries since January have been home quarantined. They are constantly monitored over phone to check if they have any symptoms. Their family members have also been sensitized. Pamphlets are being distributed door-to-door to create awareness. Water tanks have been provided at various points of the city to encourage people to wash their hands frequently. Required water is being filled up in such tanks at regular intervals. The fundamental duty of the corporation is to ensure that all public places are disinfected and they are doing it diligently. A separate Whatsapp group has been created and hospitals in the city have been asked to share photos showing disinfectant activities carried out there, Raja added.

Title: MP high court seeks count of thermal scanners
Content: BHOPAL/JABALPUR: A division bench headed by Chief Justice of MP high court on Thursday asked the state government to apprise the court on Friday morning as to how many laser thermal scanners are available in the state.It also sought response of the state government on suggestions received from members of MP State Bar Council and other advocates during hearing of the case. The state government on Thursday presented a status report on coronavirus in Madhya Pradesh . The case would now be heard on Friday.The division bench of Chief Justice A K Mittal and Justice V K Shukla is seized of a PIL filed by an advocate from Gwalior Sunil Kumar Jain, who had charged in his petition that Madhya Pradesh grossly lacks medical facilities to deal with pandemic like coronavirus.Besides, it doesn’t have adequate facility of thermal screening, sanitisers, masks at public places or isolation wards in hospitals. He said that only campaigns on TV would not help in curbing the menace, the state should be adequately equipped to handle any emergency situation.Subsequent to Sunil Jain, advocates from Jabalpur, Amit Soni and Suraj Upadhyay and Mukesh Kumar from Indore had also filed similar petitions in the high court, which were also clubbed with earlier PIL. In these PILs, the issue of black-marketing of sanitisers and masks was also raised.

Title: Ballia: Coronavirus suspect flees from hospital
Content: VARANASI: A coronavirus suspect, who had returned from Malaysia recently and was admitted to isolation ward on developing fever, cold and cough, fled from the hospital on Wednesday evening before his sample could be collected and sent to BHU laboratory in Varanasi for test. However, later the patient was traced at his home and was quarantined there itself, said chief medical officer Ballia Dr Pritam Mishra CMS of Ballia district hospital Dr B P Singh said, “A youth from Pakka Kot village had returned from Malaysia with his companions on March 14. On March 16, he complained of fever following cold, sneezing and coughing. He reached the hospital on Wednesday morning and was kept in isolation ward. However, when doctors visited the ward in the evening to collect his sample he was found missing.” We sounded an alarm and informed the district magistrate and SP, said Singh.This was the second such incident in a gap of three days. Earlier, a coronavirus suspect patient had fled from isolation ward of Mirzapur divisional hospital on March 16 night, but he was sent back to the hospital by his family.

Title: Stem cell transplant performed on 9-year-old by BHU doctors
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: A team of doctors of the department of paediatrics, Institute of Medical Sciences , Banaras Hindu University successfully carried out an autologous stem cell transplantation on a nine-year-old boy. The doctors said it is the first time that a surgery of this kind has been performed on a child in east UP region.

Talking to reporters on Thursday, professor in-charge Dr Vineeta Gupta said the boy from Sonbhadra district was suffering from relapsed Hodgkin’s lymphoma (a type of cancer affecting the lymph nodes) and hails from a poor family.

“He was admitted to an isolation room and administered high dose chemotherapy to kill the cancer cells. Thereafter, the stem cells were harvested from peripheral blood. Then conditioning chemotherapy was done after which stem cells were transplanted through central line,” she said.

“Initially, total leucocyte count of the boy reached near zero and it became a challenge for us to keep him safe from infections. Finally, on the seventh day, engraftment occurred and his count started improving. The patient was discharged around one month after admission,” Dr Gupta said.

This successful treatment has paved the way for treating children with relapsed Hodgkin’s lymphoma at IMS, BHU itself, she added.

Title: ‘Fake’ letter from SEC creates ripple, CM Jagan seeks probe
Content:
Andhra Pradesh chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy

VIJAYAWADA: The government is preparing to take action following a ‘fake’ letter addressed to the Union home ministry from the state election commissioner N Ramesh Kumar surfaced on social media platforms. In the letter, which carries the official letterhead of the SEC, Kumar has made serious allegations against the YSRC-led governement.

Although Kumar has denied having written the letter, it has created ripples across the state with the media and social media being quick to quote the contents of it.

The letter criticises the government, chief minister, other ministers and ruling party leaders. It condemns the state police for failing to maintain law and order in the first phase of the local body elections leading to violence.

The letter also seeks central forces to conduct the remaining phases of the local body elections, which were suspended due to the coronavirus scare. The letter states that SEC has no faith in the state police and administration to ensure peaceful elections. It also refers to the comments of the chief minister against Kumar and his alleged loyalties to Opposition leader N Chandrababu Naidu .

In the letter Kumar has requested the home ministry for central security forces for his and his family’s protection.

Although the commissioner has denied having written the letter, leaders of the Opposition parties, including TDP state chief K Kalavenkata Rao and CPI secretary K Ramakrishna, met Governor Biswabhushan Harichandan and sought central protection for the commissioner and Raj Bhavan’s intervention in the elections.

Meanwhile, chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy held a meeting with DGP Gautam Sawang and intelligence chief Manish Kumar Sinha and reviewed the issue. The chief minister has reportedly directed the police to find out the source and the persons responsible for it. He has reportedly expressed his displeasure over the language used in the letter which, he said, lowered the image of the government, the chief minister, cabinet and the state police, besides the entire administration.

Title: Agra Univ suspends exam papers’ evaluation
Content:
Agra: In a bid to prevent the coronavirus from spreading, Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University administration has suspended the evaluation of answer sheets of the main exams for the 2019-20 academic session. The evaluation process started on March 16.

Earlier on Tuesday, the university administration had cancelled the main exams till April 1. However, the university offices will continue to function.

According to sources, under the present circumstances, the university administration will not be able to complete the examination till April-end. The exams are expected to continue till May-end. The evaluation of answer sheets of 3.5 lakh students, eligible to appear in the exams, will also take time resulting in delay in commencement of the new session.

University registrar and examination controller Rajeev Kumar said, “The evaluation process has been suspended following the danger of the spread of novel coronavirus. The 15 days of examination schedule will be restructured. Changes will also be made in a few examination centres where reports of cheating and other malpractices have surfaced. Besides, a new schedule of the evaluation process will also be prepared. All the details will be uploaded on the varsity website.”

So far, the state government has not ordered the closure of the university. On Thursday, university staff attended office after taking precautions. The offices were sanitized and staffers worked with masks on their faces.

Title: Dadar, Ghatkopar trader bodies pledge to voluntarily call for complete bandh
Content:
On the day BMC directed shops along Mumbai’s arterial roads to stay shut on alternate days to avoid overcrowding, some traders and shopkeepers ’ associations in Dadar and Ghatkopar voluntarily came forward to give a call for a complete bandh.

In response to the BMC's directive that shops close for “social distancing,” the Dadar Vyapari Sangh declared that their establishments will remain closed till Gudi Padwa on March 25. The association has a membership of 900 shops of which 610 are in Dadar West. The Akhil Ghatkopar Vyapari Mandal, which represents 5,000 outlets, too, pledged a complete closure of their shops, hotels as well as hawkers from March 20 to 22. Association secretary Praveen Cheda said this was done to prevent crowding.

Kiran Dighavkar, assistant commissioner of BMC’s G-North Ward, said he received a representation from Dadar Vyapari Sangh that 610 of their shops would be shut till next week to keep out crowds, especially during Gudi Padwa. “We have accepted their letter and welcomed the move. However, we have also informed them from next week, even if they decide to restart their shops, they would need to follow the BMC’s directive for operating them on alternate days,” he said. — Richa Pinto

Title: HC orders continuous custody of minor in home
Content:
Madurai: Madras high court on Thursday ordered continuous custody of a minor orphan boy in a home at Tirunelveli district, in a case where few people attempted to usurp his properties.

The court gave the direction after taking cognizance of the fact that the boy was not willing for psychiatric evaluation as recommended by the court. The division bench of justice P N Prakash and justice B Pugalendhi, which heard the case, also ordered continuous custody of the boy in the home in Tirunelveli district.

The judges further directed to open a bank account in his name in order to deposit the money generated from renting his properties for his welfare. The case was adjourned to April 2 for further hearing.

A habeas corpus petition (HCP) filed by a person V Rajan Selvin, who is a relative of the boy seeking to produce him at the court. The petitioner stated that following the death of the boy’s parents, few people attempted to usurp his properties. During the course of earlier hearings, the court had passed a series of orders to safeguard the boy and his properties. The court had also appointed a senior counsel Veera Kathiravan as guardian to the boy and his properties.

During the previous hearing, the senior counsel had visited the boy and had given several suggestions to safeguard the boy and his properties. He suggested to make the boy understand the importance of education and also recommended that a psychiatrist may evaluate his condition.

Title: Puri temple administration withdraws Rs 397 crore from crisis-hit Yes Bank
Content:
BHUBANESWAR: The Shree Jagannath Temple Administration (SJTA) in Puri heaved a sigh of relief after withdrawing Rs 397 crore from the crisis-hit Yes Bank on Thursday. The money included Rs 389 crore principal term deposit and Rs 8 crore interest.

Uncertainty had loomed over the fate of the Rs 545 crore temple money deposited in the Yes Bank following the recent moratorium imposed by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) on heavy withdrawals from the private bank. The moratorium was lifted by the apex bank on Wednesday.

“We have been informed by the Yes Bank about the remittance of the Rs 397 crore (Rs 389 principal deposit and Rs 8 crore interest) from their bank to a designated account of the Jagannath Temple corpus fund with the State Bank of India’s (SBI) main branch in Puri. The maturity period of the Rs 389 crore deposit ended on Wednesday. The temple has another term deposit of Rs 156 crore in the Yes Bank. It will credit the remaining Rs 156 crore and interest upon maturity on March 30 to the temple’s SBI account,” the SJTA’s chief administrator Krishan Kumar said.

Hours after Rs 397 crore was credited from Yes Bank to the temple’s account in SBI, the ruling BJD and opposition BJP tried to hijack credit for the safe return of the temple deposit. Putting all speculations to rest, Yes Bank has transferred Rs 397 crore to the SBI account of the Shree Jagannath Temple Administration. The Odisha government has ensured the safe return of Lord Jagannath’s wealth considering the worsening condition of the private bank, said BJD’s official twitter handle (@bjd_odisha).

Significantly, state finance minister Niranjan Pujari had earlier written to Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman and sought her intervention in the matter. Later, a team of BJD MPs had met Nirmala Sitharaman in Delhi and urged her to facilitate the smooth withdrawal of the temple funds from the Yes Bank.

BJP thanked the Centre. “We express our gratitude to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, who had earlier assured all depositors, including the Jagannath Temple administration, of the safety of their deposits. The PM and FM took immediate steps to bail out Yes Bank after which the temple administration managed to withdraw the money,” BJP state general secretary Prithviraj Harichandan said.

BJP demanded action against those who had deposited the temple money in Yes Bank.

Title: Coronavirus in Odisha: In an unprecedented move, Jagannath Temple to close its doors to devotees till April 1
Content: BHUBANESWAR: The Jagannath Temple in Puri will be shut for devotees from Friday to April 1. The state government has also asked all collectors to enforce restrictions on entry of people in all religious places — temples, mosques, churches & gurdwaras — till April 1.The state government has ordered the closure of the temple to prevent the outbreak of Covid-19. Servitors will continue to perform the daily rituals of the sibling deities of Jagannath, Balabhadra and Subhadra, but only if they observe precautions.This is the first time the 12th-century shrine will be closed to devotees in living memory. “We have adopted the strong measure to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus . Daily rituals will remain unaffected,” chief administrator of Shree Jagannath Temple Administration (SJTA), Krishan Kumar, said.Temple sources said nearly 70 servitors were needed to perform around 20 daily rituals at the shrine from early in the morning till evening. The temple administration said the daily preparation of mahaprasad for devotees would remain suspended till the shrine reopened. Only bhog for the deities would be prepared.Kumar said the SJTA would look into ways to compensate the servitors for the financial losses they would suffer because of the ban on devotees.Servitors supported the temple administrator’s move. “We welcome the decision as the novel coronavirus has triggered global panic,” said Shyama Mahapatra, a servitor.The SJTA had on March 15 announced that it would compulsorily secure self-declaration forms from devotees before allowing them access to the shrine. The administration had also decided to streamline darshan and allow devotees to stand at least two metres apart in queue for darshan. “We decided to intensify the measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Once the temple is closed, tourists will also cancel their visit to Puri,” another district official said.Chief secretary Asit Tripathy on Wednesday asked all religious institutions, including managements of temples, boards, trusts and governing institutions, to take measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19.

Title: Bhopal: Suspected patient’s report awaited
Content: BHOPAL: Arguments over Covid-19 testing protocols took precedence between AIIMS Bhopal and state health department officials as first swab sample of suspected patient in MP Nagar was rendered unusable. A second swab sample was taken on Thursday.Test result was not known, till the filing of this report. The patient and his family continue to be under isolation. Does the Covid-19 suspect qualify to get tested or not, was the argument between MP health department and AIIMS Bhopal laboratory.AIIMS Bhopal took the call on Tuesday. The first swab sample was never tested. All through till Thursday afternoon, health department spokesperson Sapna Awasti told reporters – ‘the test was negative’.The health department officials could not be contacted despite repeated attempts. It was after, AIIMS Bhopal reiterated, test on the suspect’s samples was never conducted. MP health department was told the patient did not meet the criteria of Covid-19 test.The top state government officials pulled up the district health officer Dr Sudhir Dheriya and Integrated Disease Surveillance program (IDSP) in charge Dr Rashmi Jain for failing to take appropriate steps to lock down the hotel and quarantine others. By afternoon, IDSP officials were at AIIMS Bhopal, pressuring AIIMS Bhopal to carry out the testing. By then, the first swab sample was unusable.Another team from JP hospital was rushed to MP Nagar hotel. Another swab sample from suspected Covid-19 traveller was taken. The patient and his family members who have been placed under quarantine since Tuesday. In all this, AIIMS Bhopal and health department failed to adhere the first objective of ICMR testing issued on March 17 — ‘To contain the spread of infection/community transmission of Covid-19 by improving access’ has been diluted’.AIIMS Bhopal identified the patient to be asymptomatic, but IDSP argued the patient had undertaken international travel and came in contact with individual with Covid-19 positive, before reaching MP. In the recent past, private medical professionals have criticised the government for slow testing. Till now, test of only 41 have been conducted at NIV Pune out of 510 people suspected for Covid-19 and placed under isolation across MP.One french national and another grade four government employee was tested in JP hospital for Covid-19 on Thursday. The reports of both are awaited.

Title: Varanasi: Kashi soothsayer lands in jail for Covid-19 cure mantra claim
Content: VARANASI: Just days after the arrest of one ‘Coronawale Baba’ in Lucknow, a man in Varanasi landed behind bars on Thursday for claiming that his ‘mantra’ could cure Covid-19 patients as well as prevent the infection.Sanjay Tiwari, a self-proclaimed astrologer and resident of Samneghat under Lanka police station, has been distributing pamphlets that read, “Mantra lijiye aur coronavirus se mukti payiye (Learn this mantra to get rid of coronavirus).”The pamphlets, which also carry his mobile number, said that infected patients would be cured after reciting the mantra, while others chanting it would not get the infection.Pictures of the leaflets went viral on social media after which Lanka police swung into action. “Tiwari was rounded up from his Samneghat residence and has been booked for disrupting public order,” said inspector (crime) Mohit Yadav Five days ago, Lucknow police had arrested one Ahmed Siddiqui from Wazirganj following his claim that a ‘tabeez (amulet)’ he had prepared could treat coronavirus infection.

Title: CRPF personnel deployed at SEC office in Vijayawada
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

VIJAYAWADA: Police suspect the letter, said to be written by state election commissioner N Ramesh Kumar, to be a fabricated one and a deliberate attempt to create unrest in the state. The cops have launched an informal probe into the issue to dig out the facts behind the issue which has created controversy in the state.

Meanwhile, security has been beefed up and CRPF personnel have deployed at the election commission’s office in Vijayawada . DGP D Gautam Sawang is also learnt to have spoken to his Telangana counterpart and requested him to provide additional security to Ramesh Kumar in Hyderabad. As the said letter made scathing allegations against the police — its authenticity, though, is questionable as Ramesh Kumar has denied writing any such letter — Sawang asked the CRPF’s southern region IG to deploy some personnel at the SEC office to not give any room for further allegations.

Ramesh Kumar’s personal security has also been doubled from 1+1 to 2+2. The contents of the letter appear to be political statements and the language used is definitely not by a senior bureaucrat, police sources said, adding that it appears to be a deliberate attempt to malign the image of the government and police. A case would be registered and a formal investigation launched if a complaint is filed as it amounts to forgery of a senior official holding a constitutional position.

Title: UMTC wins bid, to prepare DPR for Port City’s metro rail project
Content:
Representational image

VIJAYAWADA: Urban Mass Transit Company Limited (UMTC) will prepare the detailed project report for the 79.91 kilometre first phase Vizag metro rail project. UMTC emerged as the successful bidder by quoting a price of Rs 5.33 crore.

A new DPR will be prepared for nearly 33.5km of the project, including the alternative analysis report. UMTC will also offer transaction advisory consultancy services for the bidding process management for the project, which will be taken up in a public-private partnership model and selection of a developer on a success fee basis. The state government on Thursday authorised the Amaravati Metro Rail Corporation to enter into an agreement with the UMTC for availing their services.

Speaking to TOI, AMRC managing director NP Ramakrishna Reddy said UMTC would prepare the DPR in six months. “We will initiate simultaneous bidding process for the metro rail project in the fourth month after the start of the preparation of the DPR. The bidder for the second phase project (60-km) will be finalised by the end of this month. We have received two bids for the preparation of the DPR for the first phase project,” said Reddy.

The length of the first phase project was increased to nearly 80 km from the initially planned 42.5-km project following the state government’s decision of extending the highway corridor to Bhogapuram International Airport. The other side of the highway corridor will also be extended till Steel Plant Junction from the earlier plan of ending it at Gajuwaka. The proposals of the second phase 60-km project included trackless trams. The tram corridors include NAD Junction-Pendurthi, Steel Plant-Anakapalli, Old Post Office-Rushikonda beach, Rushikonda beach-Bheemili. At a time when the state government is planning to make Vizag the executive capital, the metro rail project is expected to boost public transport network of the city.

Title: Two students held with brown sugar worth Rs 2.7 crore
Content:
Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The special task force (STF) of the state Crime Branch on Thursday arrested two students from Balasore district and seized brown sugar worth over Rs 2.7 crore from their possession. The seized brown sugar, weighing 2.73 kilogram, is the highest-ever haul of narcotics in a day in the state.

The STF personnel said the two accused, in their 20s, are 3rd-year Btech students of separate private engineering colleges in Balasore district. “We have found that the two were active members of a big drugs smuggling racket in Odisha. The drug smuggler is on our radar. Efforts are being made to arrest him,” STF’s deputy inspector general J N Pankaj said.

The accused students were supplying the brown sugar to other drugs dealers in Khurda, Bhubaneswar and Balasore. The STF sources said each of them was earning at least Rs 50,000 every month from illicit drug dealing. Their criminal antecedents, if any, are being examined.

“We strongly suspect that the accused procured the narcotics substance from Murshidabad, Kolkata and Khargarpur in West Bengal . Investigation is under way,” Crime Branch’s additional director general of police Soumendra Priyadarshi said.

On March 12, the STF personnel had seized 1.75 kilogram brown sugar worth over Rs 1.7 crore and arrested three persons, including a Btech graduate. They have already seized 6.76kg of brown sugar worth over Rs 6.7 crore so far in the last three months. “The magnitude of the 6.76kg seizure of brown sugar in the last three-and-a-half months by STF alone is highly significant as different agencies of Odisha Police together had seized nearly 2.5 kg brown sugar last year,” Priyadarshi said.

Title: ‘Bilaa Dhakhala’ of Gandipet: Court nod to Telangana's fight for title
Content: HYDERABAD: Keeping the state’s hopes alive on a 540-acre prime land at Khanapur abutting Gandipet , a Rangareddy local court has dismissed the objections of some private persons claiming a portion of the land parcel. They also urged the court not to allow the state to make any belated claims over the land.Rangareddy principal district judge Yara Renuka said: “The state is very much within its rights to lay claim over the land and the court will decide as to who could possess the title over this Rs 10,000 crore worth land after hearing both sides.”The state was earlier told by the high court to fight for its title before a civil court and hence it filed a plea before the PDJ court of Rangareddy seeking declaration of title and also recovery of possession.The peculiarity of the land parcel is it did not possess any survey number at all. Advocate-general BS Prasad, who argued before the district court laying the state’s claim, said, “It is known as Bilaa Dhakhala land, meaning a parcel of land that was left unsurveyed with an express purpose to accommodate the expansion of Osmansagar, which is adjacent to the land in question. This area falls under full tank level (FTL) area of Osmansagar and the state never accorded any pattas to any private parties over this land. State has an exclusive right over this land.”Showing adjacent survey number 65, some private parties were claiming over 150 acres of the 540 acres and some fraudulent documents too were created for the purpose, the AG alleged.There was one pattadar with title over five acres of land lying adjacent to the land and his rights were recognised in a 1954 survey. The survey number pertaining to his land speaks about only five acres, but fraudulent papers were created showing the survey number as the basis for claims over 150 acres, the AG said.Several private parties who were in possession of over 150 acres have argued that the state should not be allowed to raise its claims at a belated stage. The AG argued that the state noticed illegal entries made in the revenue records in 2001 under two survey numbers and they were shocked to see that the illegal claimants had been claiming more than 1,850 acres of land with the support of fictitious documents even though the land available on the ground was not more than 950 acres. “We have not allowed any Bilaa Dakhala land to be converted into private patta land till now,” he said raising doubts about the veracity of the documents being shown by private parties.

Title: To check hoarding, Nainital administration conducts raids at shops
Content:
Representative image

NAINITAL: In an effort to prevent hoarding and black marketing of masks and hand sanitizers, the Nainital district administration has constituted a team and conducted raids in 21 shops across the district against shopkeepers and pharmacists. This comes after several residents had complained of a sudden shortage of both masks and hand sanitizers.

Though no trader or pharmacist was found to be hoarding, the administration has asked them to keep a record of the inventory and to not charge any extra amount. “We will continue to conduct such raids across the district. It is important that traders understand their responsibility and not turn this epidemic into an opportunity for profiteering. However, if anyone is found to be violating the rules, they will be prosecuted accordingly,” said Nainital district magistrate Savin Bansal.

Title: Pondy ropes in women SHGs to make masks to meet shortage
Content:
Puducherry: The Puducherry government has roped in women self-help groups to make masks to meet the shortage of the product in the market in the wake of Covid-19 infection. The government has also decided to rope in women SHGs to manufacture hand sanitizer to meet its growing demand, said district collector cum magistrate T Arun.

Briefing reporters on the initiatives undertaken to prevent the incidence and spread of Covid-19 infection on Thursday, Arun said the government has commenced the work to make 10,000 masks per day with the help of three women SHGs. "We plan to make one lakh masks in the next 10 days and distribute them to the health and family welfare staff members engaged in the prevention and spread of Covid-19 in the territory. Later the mask will be distributed to the police personnel, anganwadi staff members and accredited social health activists," he said adding that the government will soon rope in women SHGs to manufacture hand sanitizer too.

The government has made exclusive arrangements to screen the people, who have undertaken foreign trips recently and monitor their health condition. The government has directed all hotels to obtain self-declaration from the guests, who have travelled to China, Korea, France, Germany, Spain, Italy and Iran or also self-declaration from people who came in contact with people with travel history to these countries in the last one year.

Earlier in the day, Arun in a circular to the lieutenant governor, chief minister and his cabinet colleagues, chief secretary, development commissioner, all secretaries and the heads of all departments cited the Union personnel, public grievances and pensions ministry's office memorandum and directed them to avoid routine meetings/gatherings unless such activities are in connection with the maintenance of essential services like law and order, corona prevention and other urgent matters.

Meanwhile, chief minister V Narayanasamy said all the special poojas at the famous Thirunallaru Sri Saneeswara Bagwan Temple in Karaikal have been cancelled till March 31 as a precautionary measure to prevent the incidence of Covid-19 infection. He appealed to the devotees to avoid visiting the temple and play a proactive role in the prevention of an outbreak of Covid-19 infection. Thousands of devotees used to congregate on Saturdays at the temple to attend special poojas.

Earlier, he along with health minister Malladi Krishna Rao visited Mahe, where a 68-year-old woman, who returned after visiting Saudi Arabia, tested positive for coronavirus. They reviewed the preparedness of the government machinery in the prevention and spread of Covid-19 infection.

Title: Dehradun residents self-quarantine as a precautionary measure
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: Residents of Shivalik Luxury Apartment situated at Raipur road have self-quarantined themselves as a precautionary measure against coronavirus and are trying their best to avoid visitors. The flat owners alleged that a garbage pile outside their apartment is a health hazard and its removal is all the more crucial in view of the Covid-19 threat.

Talking to TOI, Colonel P Goyal, a resident, said, “The space outside the apartments was left for provision of road widening as per the MDDA guidelines. We didn’t expect that people from the vicinity would start dumping garbage here. We had recently requested the mayor, Sunil Uniyal Gama , to resolve our problem, after which the area was partially cleaned.”

In the past, the flat owners had also installed barbed wires to deter people from dumping garbage but soon the wires and the pillars were stolen. VV Bhatt, a resident, said, “The garbage pile has been there unattended for long. With no choice, we have decided to keep ourselves inside our homes to avoid any possible infection. We just hope the DMC removes this dump in the wake of Covid-19 spread.”

To add to the woes of the residents, the site of the garbage dump has been encroached by illegally parked vehicles. Kishan Pal , sanitation inspector in the area, said, “We had recently cleaned the dump outside the apartment. Since the higher officials at the DMC are monitoring the cleaning drive, the site will be cleaned again.”

Title: Coronavirus scare in Maharashtra: Refund money of cancelled safaris, says tourist body
Content: NAGPUR: In the advent of coronavirus outbreak , the Indian Association of Tour Operators (IATO), the national apex body of tourism industry with a membership of over 1,600, has demanded refund of money towards safari bookings made between April 1 and June 30, 2020.In a memorandum to state PCCF (wildlife) Nitin H Kakodkar, the IATO demanded refund of bookings done by Indian and foreign tourists for parks in Maharashtra, mostly Pench and Tadoba.As per policy, online tickets for Tadoba can be cancelled only if booked till 15 days before the date of safari. In such cases 50% refund is granted. However, no refund is given for tickets booked between 61 to 120 days. These tickets cost between Rs4,000-8,000.Coronavirus has been declared a pandemic by World Health Organisation (WHO) and as a precautionary measure, the India government suspended all visas issued till April 15, 2020. All Indian nationals have also been strongly advised to avoid all non-essential travel.IATO president Pronab Sarkar told TOI from Delhi, “Government has cancelled visas on its own and entry of foreign tourists has been banned. The ministry of tourism too has issued directives to encourage process of refunds of foreign nationals and hence the forest department of tiger-bearing states should consider releasing refunds so that we refund money to the legitimate clients.”However, the forest departments have not yet considered refunding, barring those cancellations which will be done by default during March 18 to 31 when closure of parks was officially announced by various states.The IATO delegation, consisting of wildlife tourism consultant Himanshu Bagde and member Capt Vijay Golchha, which met Kakodkar, said, “Owing to preventive measures at global level, it is virtually impossible for tourists now to plan their travel — be it Indians or foreigners.”As per prevailing rules, tickets purchased for safari are non-refundable. However, Kakodkar has agreed to refund money towards bookings during March 18 to 31. IATO has urged Maharashtra to refund all money towards tickets which are cancelled for safari period between April 1 and June 30, 2020.“We don’t know if the situation in foreign countries will be better by April 15, or it will take more time for things to settle down. There is no indication from the government if visa requests after April 15 will be considered,” says Bagde.“As per directives from Meenakshi Sharma, director general (DG) ministry of tourism, Delhi, we have been encouraged to process refunds of foreign nationals and waive off the cancellation charges as well by rising beyond economic concerns and to set a good example of our country as a whole,” said Sarkar.“The case with domestic tourists too is the same. With schools shut now and no indication of the summer holidays, families will find it difficult to plan safaris. All planned holidays may be cancelled,” said IATO secretary Rajesh Mudgil.Meenal Dorlikar, manager of Royal Tiger Resort, says, “Maharashtra should consider refund request on priority and keeping the larger interest in mind. In Tadoba, money for vehicles and guides is deducted while online booking. When no guide and vehicle have been used why should money not be refunded?”MP parks closedClose on the heels of Maharashtra shutting its parks owing to Covid-19 crisis, MP PCCF (wildlife) Rajesh Shrivastava on Thursday issued orders to close all the national parks and wildlife sanctuaries in Madhya Pradesh. Most popular parks Pench and Kanha will also remain closed from March 20 till March 31.

Title: Covid-19: College exams postponed in Madhya Pradesh
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: College exams have been postponed in the state after the University Grants Commission ( UGC ) directed to take necessary steps in the wake of coronavirus scare.

The UGC on Thursday directed all universities and colleges to postpone examinations till March-end due to the novel coronavirus pandemic.

Similarly, evaluation will also remain suspended during this period.

Issuing the circular, the UGC stated, “All universities and affiliated colleges should postpone exams till March 31 and suspend evaluation work. Further schedule should be decided following a review of the situation.” Citing the COVID-19 threat, the professors’ association had demanded postponing of othe ngoing exams. Association president, Kailash Tyagi , said that exams should be deferred immediately. “For exams, students gather in large numbers. This makes them vulnerable,” said Tyagi. He added that even proper precautions were not being taken.

Tyagi had claimed that students are not segregated in examination halls. “Was there any screening facility at the exam centres? As per my knowledge, there was nothing like that.” The association has welcomed the decision. The MP government had ordered closure of schools and colleges last week across the state.

Title: Nainital properties to go on complete shutdown tomorrow, Musoorie hotels close doors
Content: MUSSOORIE/NAINITAL: In wake of the rising threat of coronavirus , some hotels in Mussoorie and all properties in Nainital have decided to stop accepting bookings till March 31, in an effort to stop the disease’s spread in the hills.Although the hotel association in Mussoorie refused to enforce a total temporary shutdown in a meeting on Thursday, three hotels in the hill town have stopped accepting reservations as of now. Meanwhile, all hotels in Nainital plan to ask their guests to leave. Uttarakhand hoteliers also collectively urged tourists to not visit the state for the next few weeks.Sandeep Sahni, president of Hotels and Restaurant Association of Uttarakhand , said, “In view of the current scenario, we request tourists to not visit our state for the next few weeks. While all our member hotels are observing various directives regarding hygiene, awareness and guest comfort, we feel that keeping in mind the government directives against travel and social distancing, it may be best to postpone peoples’ visits for a few days.”Speaking to TOI, Sanjay Aggarwal , a hotelier in Mussoorie, said that keeping the safety of hotel staff, guests and members of the local community in mind, he has decided to close his property till the month-end. “We are catering to the guests currently staying at our property. However, we have decided to close down temporarily,” Aggarwal said.At least two more hotels in Mussoorie have or will be shutting down temporarily. However, the owners of these properties refused to comment.Anil Sharma, the general manager of a five star resort in Mussoorie, said that business had been dismal anyway, with guests cancelling prior reservations. “We were sold out, but due to large-scale cancellations, we barely have a handful of guests with us today. We have shut down an entire block of our hotel and also closed one restaurant and sent more than 30% of our staff on leave,” Sharma said.Residents of Mussoorie said that given the current situation, all hotels should consider shutting down and the owners could utilise this time to refurbish their properties.“It is important to prevent the entry of tourists in order to prevent the spread of coronavirus, even as we may be staring at huge losses,”said Shalabh Garg, a resident.“While it is important for hotels to not accept guests from outside from the standpoint of preventing the spread of the virus, hotels that have staying power must utilise this time to take up maintenance of the property, looking after well-being of employees and if possible, look at means to digitally equip their properties,” said Mussoorie-based travel writer Hugh Gantzer Meanwhile in Nainital, hotels have decided to stop giving rooms to tourists from Friday and go on a complete shutdown on Saturday, when they plan to stop operations and ask all guests to leave.Speaking to TOI, Dinesh Sah, president of Nainital Hotel Association, said that the decision has been taken keeping in mind safety measures to prevent the spread of the virus in Nainital.“Earlier, we had asked all our member hotels to arrange for sanitisers and disinfectants. However, as the number of positive cases continue to rise across the country, we have decided to put a temporary stay on giving rooms to tourists,” Sah said.“We are also planning to go on a complete shutdown from Saturday,” he added.

Title: Coronavirus: Homes turn into offices as companies scramble to keep work flowing
Content: BHUBANESWAR: Following the state government’s recommendation to citizens to remain in home isolation and practise social distancing to keep the novel coronavirus at bay, many corporate houses and private companies have asked their employees to start working from home.To enforce this, some companies have started entire moving computer systems to the houses of employees. Others are arranging for laptops for their workers. Companies that have not yet implemented work from home are trying to ensure that employees sit at some distance from each other and have access to hand sanitisers, water and soap and a clean office environment.“The data stored in our systems/desktops can’t be moved to workers’ laptops. There is a risk to the security of our clients. So the company has started moving the desktops of the employees to their homes. This is taking some time but should be complete in a day or two,” said an employee of a multinational IT firm with an office here.Employees who have been asked to work from home said there were both advantages and disadvantages to it, but added that they were ready to do it to follow guidelines. “There is no problem in working from home. I think internet service providers — both cable or mobile — should consider upgrading net speed for free during this phase. Similarly, DTH satellite TV providers should consider providing all channels for free,” said Piyush Ranjan Rout, an urban planner with Local Governance Network, who is now working from home.Online departmental store, Grozip, has also asked all its staff, except delivery boys, to work from home. “Everyone is happy to do so and their productivity has also gone up,” said Anand Mishra, founder of the startup.Dairy manufacturer, Milk Mantra, said it had taken several initiatives to keep their employees safe from coronavirus. Around 40 per cent of its employees in the corporate office are working from home. “We are using Zoom to ensure that the work flow is smooth. We have shared a schedule to help people manage their personal and work life while working from home,” said Rashima Misra , co-founder and executive director (organisation development and brand communication).In its office, Milk Mantra is wiping all doors, work desks and laptops with sanitisers thrice a day. “At both our plants in Gop and Sambalpur , we have put up awareness posters in English and Odia. Our plants have sanitisers,” said Misra.

Title: Notice to TN in case where person was awarded death
Content:
Madurai: Madras high court on Thursday ordered notice to the state government while hearing a referred trial case where a 36-year-old man was awarded death sentence for murdering three people belonging to a family at Tenkasi in 2016.

The accused N Muthuraj alias Andavar of Nettur village is a history sheeter and there are several cases against him, according to the prosecution. On February 12, 2016, Muthuraj attempted to misbehave with Pechithaye’s 21-year-old mentally ill elder daughter. Pechithaye lodged a complaint with the police, who warned Muthuraj. Angered by this, Muthuraj murdered Pechithaye, her daughter Mari and her father Govindasamy on February 16, 2016.

Police registered a case under sections 302 (punishment for murder), 341 (punishment for wrongful restraint) and 506(ii) (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code and the case was tried before the Tenkasi additional district court.Recently, the court had convicted and awarded death sentence to Muthuraj in the triple murder case. Hearing the referred trial case, a division bench of justice P N Prakash and justice B Pugalendhi ordered notice to the state and adjourned the case to April 2 for further hearing.TNN

Title: Nagpur: Colourful classrooms with happy education experience
Content:
THE BATCH OF CHANGE: After the school is revamped, the group takes regular follow-ups about how the transforma... Read More

NAGPUR: What is the most that a group of youngsters can do with a paintbrush, colour palette and an empty unplastered wall? Well, in this case, they can double the strength of a government school, increase the attendance rate and improve the quality of teaching and learning.

Bringing colours not just to the empty walls but also lives of over 25,000 children across the country is city-based Zero Gravity Foundation. A non-profit organization operating under the umbrella of Dr Shrikant Jichkar Foundation, Zero Gravity was founded by Maitreyi Jichkar in 2008.

The young group has been working in the field of education, health care and rural development since a decade. While working in the education sector , its members came to realize that for mending impressionable minds, a lot of mending is needed in the infrastructure .

That is how their star venture the ‘Happy School Project’ started in 2011. Under this, they transform government schools through holistic infrastructural makeovers using UNICEF’s concept of ‘Building As A Learning Aid’ (BALA).

In UNICEF’s words, the concept aims at maximizing the educational utility of school buildings and the overall education experience by innovatively integrating curriculum-linked materials into the existing environment of schools. “We researched on the impact of living conditions on psychology of kids and found that poor infrastructural conditions have a damaging impact on child’s learning and can also contribute to the emergence of problem behaviour,” says Maitreyi.

Till now, the organization has transformed over a 100 schools in the country. The NGO is currently working on another 500 schools including 150 Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) schools, 50 government in Osmanabad district and some coming under Bombay Municipal Corporation.

The concepts are taken from the curriculum and incorporated in the theme of classrooms. “Whenever we approach a school, we largely focus on repair work, fixing toilets, electrical work and then painting and implementing concepts,” says Maitreyi.

What makes the initiative unique is that the concepts are not mindlessly painted on the walls. “People mostly don’t understand the logic behind how spaces and infrastructural changes impact the human psychology and learning capabilities. We take in consideration the colour psychology and then we use the right colours for the right age group. There is a lot of study that goes behind it. People often have this perception that what we are doing is picking up paints and painting,” says head architect Tanishka Acharya.

Adding that every part of the infrastructure should end up teaching something, Acharya says, “Our team of architects and designers are constantly ideating — be it converting window grills into abacus or floors into writing surfaces. If a theme of a classroom is forest, students will not just learn about types of animals but also prepositions like a monkey is ‘on’ the tree. When learning about birds, kids do it through Origami.”

After preparing the designs, the group presents it to the teachers who help them innovate more and develop teaching aids through infrastructure. “We largely focus on makeover of government schools because they are in need of this. The total strength of our government schools is going down, even when the income backgrounds are not increasing,” says co-founder of the organization Yajnavalkya Jichkar.

The young group uses different avenues to gather financial aid for the cause. “Our main funding comes from CSR of corporates. Also, we keep hosting a lot of fund-raising events by bringing people to the place we are working at,” says Maitreyi.

Once the school is revamped, the group remains consistent with the follow-ups. “After every project we have an impact measurement tool to see how things changed for teachers and students; how the concepts are helping their learning process and how are they using the renovated school infrastructure in the teaching process,” says Yajnavalkya .

In May 2019, Zero Gravity renovated a NMC school in Telangkhedi. The strength then was 57. “Today, when we recently did the survey we found that within one session, the strength of the school is 152. When we do an intervention in the school building, we encourage community to be with us in the renovation process,” says Maitreyi.

Apart from schools, Zero Gravity is also focusing on renovating government shelters. In June 2018, the group completely transformed the girls’ shelter home run by the district women and child development department at Katol Square.

The aim with which the young lot got into this project seems to have been fulfilled. “We wanted to provide basic dignity of living and learning for people coming from low income backgrounds,” says Yajnavalkya.

Title: 23-year-old youth tests negative for coronavirus in Prayagraj
Content: PRAYAGRAJ: The 23-year-old youth who was admitted to an isolation ward after showing symptoms similar to novel coronavirus (Covid-19) in Prayagraj tested negative for the infection on Thursday.The youth was rushed to the isolation ward at Swaroop Rani Nehru (SRN) Hospital after he complained of cough and sore throat. The youth had been studying in Italian — one of the worst hit nations by novel coronavirus — and had landed in Prayagraj on March 8.The youth is a resident of Govindpuri and his swab samples were sent to Lucknow’s King George ’s Medical University (KGMU) on Wednesday. The results of the test came back on Thursday.Chief medical officer (Prayagraj) Dr Girja Shankar Bajpayee said, “The man, who returned from Italy on March 8, tested negative for novel coronavirus on Thursday. No Covid-19 cases have been reported from Prayagraj district till now.”The CMO said that the department has sent four samples from the city to KGMU for testing in the past 14 days and all of them tested negative.He urged citizens to wash their hands with soap and water at frequent intervals and use tissue paperd\ handkerchieves while sneezing or coughing.

Title: Patients suffering from minor illnesses asked not to visit Jipmer
Content:
Puducherry: Jawaharlal Institute of Postgraduate Medical Education and Research (Jipmer) has discouraged patients with minor ailments from visiting Jipmer in view of “disproportionately high risk of exposure” to infections including Covid-19 on the crowded hospital premises.

In an advisory issued on Wednesday, the institute said only patients with critical ailments needing tertiary care facilities must visit the institute. The Union government has instructed all citizens to avoid crowded places in view of the coronavirus pandemic.

"Large hospitals are one such type of places. For instance, Jipmer is visited by 8,000 to 10,000 patients every day, in addition to their attendants. Also, the crowd in the hospital is more likely to include patients with Covid-19. Thus, there is a real risk of those visiting Jipmer catching Covid-19 infection. Further, the visitors to hospitals are often elderly, infirm and more vulnerable in whom the infection is more likely to be severe or fatal," said the advisory.

The institute advised patients with chronic conditions such as diabetes, hypertension, cancer and heart disease on regular continuous medications not to visit the institute to receive drugs. "They can get their regular medications from a nearby government hospital or from Jan Aushadhi Pharmacies at subsidised cost using a previous prescription from Jipmer," the advisory said.

The institute advised all patients needing an elective (non-urgent) surgical procedure to delay their visit to Jipmer until the Union government lifts the restrictions.

"Each patient needs to understand the risk of exposure to a large hospital such as Jipmer and balance this against the genuine benefit of such a visit. Jipmer regrets the inconvenience caused to its dear patients. However, it is purely the health interest of our patients that have forced us to make this decision," said the advisory.

Title: HC grants stay on order initiating action against cop
Content:
Madurai: Madras high court has granted interim stay on a single judge order directing to initiate disciplinary proceedings against the inspector of police of K Pudur police station, citing that there was dereliction and delay on his part in handing over the death and postmortem certificate in a maternal death case.

A person Manimuthu, had admitted his wife Sakthikali for delivery at the K Pudur urban primary health centre (UPHC) on September 14, 2019. However, she died due to medical negligence on the part of the UPHC.

Based on his complaint, the K Pudur police registered a case under section 174 CrPC.

Following this incident, Manimuthu moved the high court Madurai bench seeking Rs 10 lakh compensation for Sakthikali. He also sought her death certificate and postmortem report.

Taking cognizance of the fact that there was dereliction on part of the authorities in handing over the death certificate and postmortem certificate, the single judge had directed disciplinary action against Theenathayalan who is multipurpose health supervisor at GRH and Muthukumar, inspector of police.

Muthukumar had filed an appeal before the high court Madurai bench seeking to grant interim stay on the order stating that he had taken effective steps to investigate the case and there was no negligence on his part. He further noted that the judge had directed to initiate disciplinary action against him though the petitioner did not seek such a prayer.

Hearing the appeal, a division bench of justice P N Prakash and justice B Pugalendhi granted interim stay on the single judge order. tnn

Title: Rajasthan Coronavirus News: Rajasthan orders partial shutdown of government offices till end of March
Content:
CM Ashok Gehlot directs cops to enforce Section 144 strictly

JAIPUR: The state government on Thursday ordered a partial shutdown of its offices till March 31in view of the coronavirus threat looming large. Except for essential services, all other state government, semigovernment, autonomous bodies and corporations have been asked to allow 50% of the staff to work from home till the end of March.All school, college exams have been postponed till further orders. The government took the decision following a review meeting on coronavirus threat held by the chief minister on Thursday.Only during emergency situations, the staff of non-essential departments have to come to the office. But the government made it clear that it is not leave and the employees cannot leave their work stations.Jaipur: “Except for health emergency and family necessity, employees cannot leave the city in which they are posted,” said the order.CM Ashok Gehlot said the next two weeks were very critical in the fight against the deadly virus and all possible remedies have to be adopted. The chief minister sought the cooperation of the people. But the partial shutdown will not be applicable to officers above the rank of deputy secretary, joint secretary, deputy director, executive engineers.At the district level, collectors’ office and district-level offices of departments will work normally. The government said the district level offices can regulate their staff on a 50:50 ratio on rotation.The government said spas, clubs and bars would be closed and advised private businesses to encourage their staff to work from home. The labour department has been asked to check the factories for cleanliness and take all precautionary measures to prevent the spread of the virus.The chief minister said the NREGA workers need not come to the work site till March 31 and they would be paid their wages during the shutdown period.The government said that action would be taken against those who have been advised home isolation and are not following the direction under Section 188 of IPC. Additional chief secretary medical and health Rohit Kumar Singh said that at present 1,100 people are under home isolation, with 265 in Jaipur. The chief minister directed the police to enforce Section 144 strictly..Essential services and departments exempted from the shutdown include medical and health, medical education, ayurveda, energy, discoms, PHED, local self-government, municipal bodies, home and police, jail, FSL, finance, food and civil supplies.

Title: Prayagraj: KVs across India, three abroad shut till March 31
Content:
Representative image

PRAYAGRAJ: The Kendriya Vidyalaya Sangathan has suspended classes at all its schools across 25 regions in India and at an institution each in Kathmandu , Moscow and Tehran till March 31 amid the growing coronavirus threat.

A letter signed by joint commissioner (headquarters) E Prabhakar and addressed to deputy commissioners of all KV regions harps on precautions that need to be taken for the safety of students, teachers and their family members in the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic.

“All KV principals are, hereby, instructed to comply with the necessary guidelines. Schools will be closed for students and teachers while office staff and the principal may come as usual,” Prabhakar told TOI. Teachers must stay connected with their respective schools via other mediums and cooperate in case of an emergency, the letter adds.

While classes will remain suspended till March 31, ongoing exams will be rescheduled thereafter. Evolution work being conducted at over 1,200 KVs across the country will also be slated after March 31.

Title: 19 die daily of cancer, TB and AIDS in Gujarat
Content: GANDHINAGAR: An average of 19 people die of tuberculosis , AIDS and cancer every day in Gujarat . An average of 381 new cases of these three diseases have also been reported every day in the state for the past two years.Of the three diseases, tuberculosis causes the most deaths. According to the data tabled in the assembly, AIDS had the highest mortality rate, with eight of ever 100 patients dying, while the number for cancer was six and TB was four.In reply to a question by Viramgam MLA Lakha Bharwad, the government said Ahmedabad reported 10,801 cases of cancer of whom 1,062 patients died in two years. For AIDS, 3,342 new cases were added and 196 patients died in the two-year period. The district accounted for the most cancer and AIDS deaths in the state. The government also listed measures taken to control and prevent AIDS, prevent cancer and tuberculosis.A senior government officer said cases of tuberculosis were more numerous in the tribal districts of Dahod and Panchmahal where medical facilities are lacking. The officer said that in these districts and Banaskantha, malnutrition is a major issue and when a person gets tuberculosis his survival chances are low. Citing studies, he said that it has been proved that malnourished tuberculosis patients have delayed recovery and higher mortality rates than well-nourished patients.About the high number of deaths in Ahmedabad, the officer said Ahmedabad city has better treatment facilities and when patients get criticial, they are immediately transferred to the government hospitals in Ahmedabad. Moreover, the deaths recorded are from hospitals and not according to the victim’s address. For cancer, of the 2,250 deaths in the state in two years, 1,062 or 47% were in Ahmedabad city, he said.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Uttarakhand closes malls across state
Content: DEHRADUN: The state cabinet on Thursday decided to shut shopping malls across the state till March 31 in wake of the novel coronavirus outbreak.In the meeting, which was held at the secretariat, it was also decided that each MLA will give a fund of Rs 15 lakh from his MLALAD Fund to chief medical officer of his/her district for preparedness and preventive measures.The health officials have been directed to keep a special watch in Rishikesh and Tehri Garhwal, which witness a high number of foreigner footfalls.If required, the state has decided to use the rest houses of Garhwal Mandal Vikas Nigam (GMVN) and Kumaon Mandal Vikas Nigam (KMVN) as isolation wards. A budget of Rs 60 crore has been reserved to tackle the situation.Sharing information, minister of urban development and state government spokesperson Madan Kaushik said, “The cabinet has decided that each legislator will give Rs 15 lakh from his MLA Local Area Development fund to the CMO of their respective district. The CMOs have been authorised to take decision as per requirement. If the need does not arise in the constituency of a particular legislator, the CMO has the right to use the fund in another MLA’s constituency area.”The chief secretary — who is also heading a task force on Covid-19— will review the situation on a daily basis, whereas CM Trivendra Singh Rawat will take stock of the development every second day. “Any decision will be taken on the basis of the day’s development,” added the minister.

Title: Sudden rainfall brings down temperature in Hyderabad
Content: HYDERABAD: The city witnessed its first summer rain on Wednesday with many areas recording up to 45mm of rainfall in just two hours.Timulgherry received the highest rainfall of 44.8mm followed by 34.8mm in West Marredpally , 28.3mm in Nacharam and Kapra, among others.Hailstorm also occurred at many places such as Uppal, Tarnaka, Karkhana, Bowenpally, Dilsukhnagar, Diamond point in Secunderabad , among other areas.The Indian Meteorological Department , Hyderabad, attributed the unseasonal thunderstorm activity to a confluence zone over Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu and its neighbouring areas. An anti-cyclone is persisting over the west-central Bay of Bengal that is feeding moisture over the region.The sudden showers also led to a drop in mercury levels as the temperature dropped below 30°Celsius in the evening.Meteorologists predict that the thunderstorm activity will continue even during the weekend, after which a dry spell will follow throughout the week clearing way for the onset of summer by April first week.Sudden rains also led to waterlogging near Lake View guest house in Somajiguda. Heavy wind led to fallen trees at Road No. 2 in Film Nagar, near Shyamlal nala in Begumpet, among other places. A massive hoarding installed atop a building on SP Road towards Begumpet also collapsed.

Title: Covid-19: Several temples in Uttarakhand ban entry of devotees
Content: NAINITAL: As the novel coronavirus scare grips the country and number of positive cases continues to rise, several temples across the Himalayan state have been closed for the devotees.These include the famous Kainchi Dham Temple and Haidakhan Ashram in Nainital, the Jageshwar Dham in Almora, Patal Bhuvneshwar in Pithoragarh, Sai Baba temple and Sakya College in Dehradun along with all the temples in Pauri Garhwal district , including Neelkanth Temple in Rishikesh . Apart from these, several small and large temples have also taken suo motu initiative to remain closed till the coronavirus is brought under control.Speaking to TOI, an official of the Nainital district administration said that the decision to ban the entry of devotees in the Kainchi Dham and Haidakhan was taken keeping in mind the fact that many foreigners visit the temple and the mass gathering there can lead to transmission of the virus. “The temples are famous across the world and a number of tourists even from abroad visit them. Therefore, it has been decided to completely close them for the devotees since because of these gatherings, there are chances that people may get infected,” said the official.This comes after the administrations in several districts had already banned mass gatherings, including both Nainital and Dehradun. The district administration of Bageshwar has also asked the government to regulate the Purnagiri Mela and the Udham Singh Nagar district administration has also cancelled the Chaiti Mela in the Maa Balasundari Temple.Meanwhile, Bhagwan Bhatt of Jageshwar Dham Temple Management Committee said that the temple will remain closed till March 31. However, the aarti and essential services will continue. “We have decided to close the temple for devotees till March 31 so that there is less chance of people gathering at the temple, and therefore, transmitting the virus. However, we have decided that the aarti and other essential services will continue by priests inside the temple,” Bhatt said.Bhatt added that even the hotel owners around Jageshwar Dham have agreed that they will comply with the orders and not provide rooms to tourists till the situation returns to normal.

Title: Allahabad University may get a new name
Content:
Allahabad University

PRAYAGRAJ: After serial changes in names of Allahabad Junction and its satellite stations, Cheoki and Rambagh, the ball has been set rolling to rename Allahabad University too. Nomenclature change of the 133-year-old Central university tops the agenda of the ensuing executive council meeting of AU . A month ago, Allahabad Junction was renamed as Prayagraj Junction, Allahabad City as Prayagraj Rambag and Allahabad Cheoki as Prayagraj Cheoki.

After passage in EC, the proposal would be sent to Union HRD ministry from where it would be tabled in Parliament before approval of the President. The agenda (No. 08/60) of EC mentions a February 10 letter by Raju Saraswat, under-secretary, HRD ministry. The then UP chief secretary had requested name change of the varsity to Prayagraj University in a letter to the Centre on December 4, 2018. The HRD official in his communique also mentioned a letter by former commissioner Allahabad division, Ashish Goyal, with a similar request. The name of Allahabad district was changed to Prayagraj on October 18, 2018.

“In my opinion, names of institutions with a rich legacy should remain unchanged. Madras University and Madras High Court have retained their original names despite the city being renamed Chennai. Why should one change the name of AU”, asked Prof Ashim Mukerjee, member of EC.

Earlier, the executive council meeting was scheduled on Monday (March 16), but because of the coronavirus threat, the meeting was postponed. The next date has not been notified by varsity authorities.

Former president of the AU students’ union, Richa Singh, has requested the Kaushambi MP, Vinod Sonkar, to stop the name change of AU. “I have requested the MP to kindly spare AU and not advocate for changing its name. The institution has a proud past and a bright future,” she said.

Title: Teen’s family stands up against social media trial and vilification
Content:
Kolkata: The teenager who tested positive for Covid-19 — Bengal’s first — and his parents are traumatized and scared after their photographs were circulated on social media and a call for “action” against them went viral.

Family sources claimed that the teenager, now in Beliaghata Infectious Diseases (ID) hospital, had stepped out of his home only once on Monday to get himself examined at MR Bangur Hospital. He was advised to undergo a Covid-19 test at ID Hospital as he did not have any ‘outward symptom’.

“The teenager had completed his ISC examination in 2018-19 and secured admission in Oxford University for masters in maths — a four-year integrated course. On March 6, he attended a university valediction programme. They later learnt that another student had tested positive for Covid-19,” a person close to the family said. “Since he had a flight ticket back home, he sought the university’s directions. The university allowed him to leave. He returned to Kolkata on Sunday,” the person said.

“The family could not get him checked that evening as it was late and no symptom was noticed at the airport. He was advised home quarantine,” he added. According to the family member, the teenager’s father, a child specialist posted in a south Bengal district, had come to meet his son on Sunday for half an hour before leaving Kolkata.

“On Monday morning, he was taken to MR Bangur hospital for a check-up. The doctor was told the reasons and he had adopted all precautions. The hospital diagnosis did not reveal anything serious and his ‘outward symptoms’ were normal. But as a precaution, he was advised to undergo the Covid-19 tests,” the family member said. It was 1pm, and they were informed that the blood and swab samples collection deadline had passed for the day. So, they returned home and went to ID Hospital the next morning.

“The only error in judgement was that the mother had gone briefly to Nabanna to attend some meetings on Monday,” he said.

“WhatsApp messages, social media posts and some news websites suggesting they had been negligent are completely wrong. After the teen tested Covid-19 positive, his mother and the driver were admitted to the hospital. His father, too, was asked to report to the hospital, which he did. The family is now extremely worried about the allegations that they had deliberately withheld information,” the family member said.

Title: Olive Ridley turtle’s carcass spotted on beach in Kanyakumari district
Content:
Kanyakumari: The decayed carcass of an adult Olive Ridley turtle was spotted at the Chothavillai Beach in Kanyakumari district on Thursday.

“The carcass had no head and only two flippers were seen. Blood smears were spotted on the top of its body,” said Davidson Sargunam, an International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) member, who spotted the carcass.

“It is suspected that the marine animal would have been a victim of a fishing boat or net,” he said and added that the cause of death could be ascertained only after an autopsy is conducted by the forest department.

Olive Ridley is listed as vulnerable in the IUCN red list and Schedule 1 of the Indian Wildlife Protection Act, 1972 (amended 1991). Sea turtles are also protected under the Migratory Species Convention and Convention of International Trade on Wildlife Flora and Fauna (CITES).

Forest department personnel engaged in protecting Olive Ridley turtles and their hatchery in Rajakkamangalam said the turtles visit beaches in Kanyakumari from mid-December to mid-March for nesting.

This year only around 2,950 eggs were spotted in 29 nests with around 100 or more eggs in each nest. The first turtle nest was spotted on December 19 and the last one was spotted last week. “Around 500 have been released in the sea so far, including the 104 hatchlings released on Thursday,” a forest department personnel said.

The numbers are fast dwindling from more than 15,200 eggs collected from 154 nests from the December 2016 to March 2017 nesting season.

Title: Shops with pending dues sealed by civic body
Content:
Madurai: Officials from the Madurai Corporation have shut and sealed 16 shops, which have pending dues up to Rs 60 lakh, near Ponnagaram in the city on Thursday.

The shops were located in Padmasini Park near Girder Bridge. Officials said that one of the 16 shops alone had pending dues of Rs 45 lakh.

Based on the orders from the corporation commissioner S Visakan, a team lead by assistant commissioner (revenue) Jayaramaraja sealed the shops.

Officials said that with just 10 days left for the financial year 2019-20 to end, they are taking stringent possible actions to receive pending dues.

Teams have been set up to check pending dues of commercial shop owners, educational institutions, residents and various other outlets.

Measures like disconnecting drinking water supply and sewer lines are being taken to send a strong message. Those, who have not responded to the measures, will have to face harsher measures, the corporation officials said.

The Madurai Corporation has set an ambitious target this year to collect taxes, especially property taxes, which alone accounts to a total of around Rs 100 crore.

Title: SR withdraws concession on tickets
Content:
Puducherry: The Southern Railway, Trichy division has decided to withdraw concessions on tickets for all categories of passengers except students, four categories of differently-abled people and 11 categories of patients from March 20 to discourage passengers undertaking non-essential travel in view of the advisory issued in the wake of Covid-19 infection.

The withdrawal of concessions will be applicable to all tickets booked on or after March 20 until further order. The division has cancelled a few trains due to poor patronage following Covid-19 scare. It has cancelled Villuppuram- Secunderabad Weekly Special train (06043) on March 25 (1 trip), Secunderabad – Villupuram Weekly Special train (06044) on March, 26 (1 trip), Trichy – Trivandrum Intercity Express Train (22627) from March 20 to 31 (12 trips), Trivandrum – Trichy Intercity Express Train (22628) from March 20 to 31 (12 trips).

Title: Nagpur: Amid coronavirus scare, mayor cancels GB
Content: NAGPUR: In a preventive measure, mayor Sandip Joshi on Thursday indefinitely postponed the general body meeting which was scheduled to be held on March 20.According to Joshi, four patients from the city have tested positive of coronavirus and the state government has already declared it as epidemic. Therefore it could not be denied that there was a possibility of getting affected by the virus.
