Joshi added that, his office has also received a letter from the municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe who has urged him to prevent crowds as a preventive measure.A meeting of all party corporators including leader of opposition Tanaji Wanve, Congress corporators Praful Gudadhe, Kamlesh Chowdhary and corporators from other political parties too was convened by the mayor where all party unanimously decided to cancel tomorrow’s meeting.Meanwhile, following the state government’s notification, municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe on Thursday issued a circular asking NMC employees to be present in the headquarters and zonal offices on alternate days or on rotation basis.The notification stated that the NMC should have staff strength at 50% on any given day and the office heads should rotate the attendance on alternate days. The new arrangement will in place till March 31, it stated. However, the notification will not be applicable to employees working in health department, field duties staff etc.

Title: Nirbhaya’s mother will go down in history: Bedi
Content:
Puducherry: Nirbhaya’s mother will go down in history as an unstoppable mother, who fought for ultimate justice for her daughter, said lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi shortly after the execution of the four convicts in Tihar Jail.

"Her (Nirbhaya's mother) struggle fully exposed the irony of brutal and merciless criminals who pray for mercy to live for themselves," she said in a WhatsApp post.

Four men - Akshay Kumar Singh, Pawan Gupta, Vinay Sharma and Mukesh Singh, who were convicted to death penalty for gangraping Nirbhaya, a Delhi physiotherapy intern in December 2012, were finally hanged on Friday morning.

Six people including the four convicts and a juvenile were named as accused in the case. Ram Singh, the sixth accused committed suicide in Tihar jail and the juvenile was released in 2015 after spending three years in an observation home.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: It’s a stress test for small traders too
Content: KOCHI: With the coronavirus outbreak in the state, small businesses in the city too have been scrambling how to deal with difficult times. Tailoring shops, shops selling designer clothes, footwears, jewellery and other accessories at Convent Junction, for instance, have been witnessing fewer footfalls for the past few days. With customers keeping away, they do not have enough funds even to meet operational expenses. Even when businesses are under strain, the traders have to foot electricity bills, pay salary to staff and meet other miscellaneous expenses. “It has been really tough for us ever since Covid-19 cases began to be reported in the state. Many traders have been struggling to meet both ends meet. Under such circumstances, some traders are even planning to close their shops. It is a voluntary decision,” said an owner of a boutique at Convent Junction. He said that shop owners would follow the evolving situation around the coronavirus. “Based on the developments, traders will take a decision on how to go forward. If situation improves by the weekend, we will open the shops,” he added.Convent Junction has been a favourite shopping point for people across the state. The area attracts hordes of tourists as well. The shop owners allow customers to try out the merchandise put up for sale. Be it clothes, designer jewellery or footwear, customers touch them or check them out by wearing them. “There is body contact. Even employees help customers. It is impossible to stop people from touching the merchandise and do business. And customers from everywhere come here. If people from Covid-19 hit regions come, it will not be possible to prevent them from entering the shops. We feel it is better to close down the shops for a few days than ending up suffering in the long run. The traders have to protect their health as well as that of their employees,” said a designer jewellery shop owner.Meanwhile, on the adjacent TD Road and Jew Street, dealers in iron and steel, hardware, furnishings and electrical goods said there has been a 50% dip in their businesses. The attitude of customers has changed, and they have been spending only on essential commodities.“There is no spending. No new works or projects are being taken up. Only those works which have to be completed by March-end are progressing,” said Jithesh Shenoy, a hardware dealer on TD Road.

Title: Kochi corporation chalks out measures to contain spread of coronavirus
Content: KOCHI: With the city staring at a lockdown due to the spread of Covid-19, Kochi corporation has started a slew of measures to fight the virus outbreak. The local body will also seek the support of NGOs, Kudumbashree and the public in spreading the message to contain the disease.As part of Break the Chain campaign, facility to wash hands will be set up at 50 places in the city. “Facilities would be arranged at market, bus stations and railway stations. Wash basins, soaps and sanitizers will be provided at those places,” mayor Soumini Jain said.“A five-member squad comprising health officials of the corporation, Asha workers, Kudumbashree workers, councillors and members of NGOs will be formed in each division. They would act as a surveillance team and report the developments related to Covid-19 in the division. They would keep in touch with those returned from foreign countries, and apprise the health supervisor of their condition and requirements,” Jain said.The local body also plans to procure one lakh face masks and distribute it among vulnerable persons. “Vendors at markets, autorickshaw drivers, passengers heading to railway stations, taxi drivers, etc. are among the vulnerable population. There will be weekly meetings to review the progress of preventive measures,” the mayor said. The local body is also planning to distribute food and grocery kits to those in need. “Those families whose breadwinner is down with the disease, would require food items. We have received 70 food packets from the control room. We will be distributing it to the deserving families. If anybody want cooked food, we will explore the possibilities of providing it to them. We can tie up with hoteliers for the purpose,” she said.Infrared thermometers will be procured for testing the temperature of those arriving at different parts of the city. “Corporation will set up a helpline number and help desk for giving advice and guidance to the patients and the public. Corporation secretary should take the responsibility for setting up the help desk,” Jain added.Also, measures would be taken to see that public places like market are clean and hygienic. “If a vendor is found to be adopting unhygienic practices, his or her licence should be cancelled. Unauthorized wayside eateries will be closed down. The local body would consider extending time for payment of various taxes. As per norms, many of the taxes are to be paid by March 31. The corporation has written to the state government seeking facilities to quarantine people at Fort Kochi taluk hospital. Many of the private hospitals in the city have informed that they are ready to upgrade or arrange facilities to treat Covid-19. This would be conveyed to the state government,” said the mayor.

Title: Corona scare in Bhopal: Malls, marriages shut down
Content: BHOPAL: District collector Tarun Pithode has ordered shutdown of all malls in the city from Thursday midnight. There will be no bookings at marriage gardens, government or private rest houses and community halls in the city till April 15 in the wake of the coronavirus threat. These places can’t be booked for any purpose during the period. If required, these places can be acquired by the administration. Sanitation workers will remain present at these places 24 hours a day.The district collector has also prohibited all social, religious and cultural functions in the city, besides banning all rallies, demonstrations, sit-ins and agitations till March 31.A massive publicity campaign has been undertaken to make people aware of the coronavirus and how to prevent its spread. All the bus stops, city buses and other public places are being sanitized with special chemicals, said Pithode.The food safety officials have been asked to prevail upon hotel and restaurant owners to allow customers into their outlet only after washing their hands with soap and again wash their hands on coming out. The staff of hotels and restaurants should also be persuaded to wash their hands with soap repeatedly when they are on duty.Hotel owners have also been asked to inform the police or health officials or simply pass on the information on phone no. 104 if any person showing signs of coronavirus infection stays in their hotel or seeks a room in the hotel.Pithode directed that customers at super markets or shops should also be requested to wash their hands with soap before entry into the outlet for purchase. He has asked RTO to ensure sanitization of buses coming from outside.He asked sub-divisional officers (SDOs), other executive magistrates and food safety officials to ensure that sanitisers are kept in shops and masks are available and are not black-marketed from medical stores and other shops.

Title: Covid-19 in Odisha: Government ready with over 4 lakh beds to tackle crisis
Content: BHUBANESWAR: The state government on Thursday said it has created facilities for more than 4.22 lakh temporary hospital beds across the state to tackle a possible spurt in Covid-19 patients in case it spreads to the community even as all the 14 samples tested negative for the virus on Wednesday.The district headquarters hospitals, medical colleges and private hospitals together have 3,183 isolation beds ready at present.“The government has identified 450 buildings as treatment facilities in urban areas to accommodate 51,160 patients. Similarly, it has created 7,176 temporary medical camps across 6,798 panchayats with a capacity of 50 to 100 beds, making the total availability of space for 4,22,426 beds,” said Subroto Bagchi , government spokesperson for Covid-19.The government has given Rs 5 lakh to each panchayat for the temporary facility. A training session for 2.37 lakh panchayat representatives was held across state on Thursday to reach out to people owing to social distancing now and for treatment at the panchayat camps in case the need arises. The government has decided to supply paracetemol tablets and personal protective equipment such as masks to ASHAs and health workers who may become the first responders to patients in case of mass transmission.Of the 61 samples tested in the state so far, only one has tested positive. Twenty-three people have been kept in isolation in different hospitals for coming in close contact with the lone COVID-19 positive patient, a Bhubaneswar native who returned from Italy and who has been stable at Capital Hospital here.In a fresh advisory, the government asked people needing non-essential, non-urgent outpatient care with mild illness or needing avoidable follow up, elective procedures including dental care not to visit the hospitals, either government-run or private for the time-being to avoid possible transmission. Patient needing emergency care only may visit the hospitals, the advisory by P K Mohapatra, head, social distancing committee, Covid-19 Response, of the state government.Health secretary Nikunja Dhal said keeping in mind the evolving situation, the government’s current focus is on prevention of transmission so that health system is not overburdened.

Title: Rush at Yes Bank branches as restriction lifted
Content:
BHUBANESWAR: People thronged several branches of Yes Bank here on Thursday as the situation limped back to normal and banking services resumed after the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) lifted the restriction imposed on the bank.

However, the bank officials said the rush wasn’t as much as expected probably because of the ongoing threat of novel coronavirus. Those who had queued up at the bank’s several branches were seen wearing face masks or taking other precautionary measures for Covid-19.

Sources said most customers who visited the bank in several parts of the city had to settle their accounts. “I don’t trust this bank any more. I risked my life and came here to close my account,” said a customer at Bapuji Nagar branch.

Meanwhile, bank officials were seen pacifying the customers. “We are trying to make them understand that the situation is under control now and there money will not go anywhere,” an official of the bank’s Bapuji Nagar branch said.

Many customers were also seen making a beeline at the ATM counters, of whom some had come to withdraw all their money. “I don’t want my hard-earned money to go to waste as I have decided to clear my account,” said Partha Jena, a customer at the bank’s Saheed Nagar branch.

Several customers also opted for online banking to commission their transactions. “I have saved Rs 35,000 in my account and I just transferred all of it to my other accounts. I don’t want to use this account any more,” said Sudhanshu Mishra, another customer.

It must be noted that soon after the news spread that Yes Bank had become cash starved and the Union ministry of finance imposed restrictions on banking services earlier this month, there was a mad rush of customers in the Yes Bank branches in the city.

On March 5, the Reserve Bank of India imposed a cap on the withdrawal limit of the bank to Rs 50,000 a month. The banking services, including ATMs and POSs, mainly for Yes Bank customers were also not working owing to the crisis situation.

Title: Uttarakhand HC stays US Nagar DM’s order to merge schools
Content:
Representative image

NAINITAL: The Uttarakhand high court on Wednesday stayed the order of Udham Singh Nagar district magistrate (DM) Neeraj Khairwal, seeking to merge 398 government-run primary and junior schools in the district.

The bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Ramesh Chandra Khulbe had been hearing a Public Interest Litigation (PIL) filed by US Nagar resident Ganesh Upadhyay, who contended that the DM’s order violated the Right To Education (RTE) Act, which stipulates that the government provide primary schools within the walking distance of one kilometer junior schools within that of three kilometers.

“The RTE Act of 2009 says that it is the responsibility of the government to provide a primary school within the walking distance of one kilometer. The order was clearly against provisions of the Act and therefore, the court has ordered the DM and the government to maintain the status quo on the issue of merging the schools in the district,” Upadhyay told TOI.

According to the order issued by the DM, 398 out of 1,100 schools in the district were to be merged. The order had stated that these schools will be developed as model schools.

“The government said that these schools will be developed into model schools and that they are being merged because the number of students studying in them is very few. However, there are schools which have more than 100 students and therefore, the decision was completely wrong,” Upadhyay added.

Title: Dehradun: SDRF deployed outside isolation wards
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: A day after Congress vice-president was home quarantined for 14 days after he paid a visit to Covid-19 isolation ward at Government District Medical College (GDMC), to check movement of common public Uttarakhand deployed SDRF in hospitals where quarantine wards have been created.

ASHA/Anganwadi workers will also visit houses of those who are home quarantined in Dehradun to ensure that they are not roaming around. The decision was taken after the health department home quarantined two journalists and five Congress workers on Wednesday who had accompanied Congress vice-president to Doon hospital’s isolation ward.

Chief medical officer (CMO) Dehradun, Dr Meenakshi Joshi , had released a list of seven people, on Tuesday night, who accompanied Suryakant Dhasmana to isolation ward.

“We got to know that two journalists from Hindi dailies accompanied Suryakant Dhasmana in the isolation ward. And there were others with them. They all have been asked to remain in isolation at their homes. We will be sending ASHA or Anganwadi workers to their home for next 14 days to ensure their movement outside are restricted,” said the CMO.

Meanwhile, the director-general of health addressed a press conference on Wednesday regarding the Covid-19 situation in which she said that health department has asked all medical stores to sell medicines at MRP rates. The officials of health department also released a list of important medicines to treat flu and other similar conditions with their MRP and urged people to dial the helpline numbers issued by district administration to report black-marketing of sanitizers, masks and medicines.

“To restrict the movement of common people inside the isolation wards, we have sought the help of State Disaster Response Force (SDRF) whose personnel will be deployed outside isolation wards of each hospital across the state,” said DG health, Dr Amita Upreti.

Title: Man shot dead in Firozabad, another found bludgeoned to death in Agra
Content:
Agra: In two different cases, one man was shot dead in Firozabad and another was found bludgeoned to death in Agra.

In the first incident, the victim was identified as Harish Chandra who worked as a typist in district court premises in Firozabad. He was a resident of Tapa Khurd under Uttar police jurisdiction. On Thursday morning, the victim was shot dead by two bike-borne assailants.

Firozabad SP Firozabad Sachindra Patel said, “The deceased, charged for murder, had recently come out on bail. Our police team is working on the case to find out if Harish’s murder was an act of revenge.”

Meanwhile, a 32-year-old man was found bludgeoned to death in Itmad-ud-daula area of Agra. Resident of Lohamandi, Sachin Jain was a government ration distributor. He went missing on Wednesday evening. An FIR has been lodged based on victim’s relative’s complaint.

Title: Tension in Madurai as flyers from Dubai object to quarantine
Content:
Madurai: Tension prevailed at the Madurai airport on Thursday after 144 passengers who returned from Dubai by a SpiceJet flight refused to co-operate and be quarantined for 14 days as mandated as a precaution against Covid-19 spread. However, after health officials and police held talks with them, they were shifted to the quarantine facilities.

The passengers arrived at the airport where they were mandatorily screened by health officials for Covid-19. All of them were to be quarantined for 14 days. However, a section of them started to argue that only those with symptoms need to be quarantined while the others should get to go home. They refused to board the bus kept ready to take them to the quarantine facilities. The passengers were also reportedly not happy with the arrangements made at the facilities.

Finally, after the intervention of health and police officials, all 144 passengers were taken to the quarantine facilities at Chinna Udaipu and Austinpatti on the outskirts of Madurai, where 120 beds and 60 beds each have been set up. “Only a few among the 144 were resisting. We later ensured all of them are in quarantine,” said a health official.

Earlier in the day, residents in and around Chinna Udaipu protested near the facility stating that they fear the possible spread of Covid-19 from those quarantined. Officials held talks with the residents and allayed their fears.

“People’s irrational fear of Covid-19 is the reason for such protests. We urge the public to be aware of the facts and not believe in rumours. As for quarantine, we are already only letting those without symptoms stay in the facility. If anyone is showing symptoms, we have ambulances ready and will immediately shift them to a hospital,” said a health official.

Meanwhile, as many as 10 people were booked for triggering a panic about Covid-19 spread and staging a road roko against setting up a temporary medical camp at a private women’s college hostel at Sainathapuram in Vellore city on Wednesday night .

Residents living close to the college registered their opposition to the move fearing they would be easy prey to the Covid-19. Officials from the district administration have decided to set up the facility elsewhere.

Police detained 10 people for staging the road roko, triggering panic among other residents , police said.

Title: HC finds Dehradun DM’s response on slaughterhouses evasive, orders him to appear before court
Content:
Representative image

NAINITAL: Uttarakhand High Court ( HC ) on Wednesday ordered the district magistrate (DM) of Dehradun to appear before the court and explain how the animals are entering the state capital when there are no legally-run slaughterhouses in the district.

The bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Ramesh Chandra Khulbe, had in its last hearing, ordered Dehradun DM Ashish Kumar Srivastava to inspect all sites in the Doon valley where animals are slaughtered and file a response within two weeks. However while hearing the case today, the court termed the affidavit by Dehradun’s DM “evasive” and ordered him to be physically present in the court. “Dehradun DM has been asked to appear before the court on March 23 and explain as to why truckloads of animals are entering Dehradun when there is no legally-run slaughterhouse in Dehradun," said Kartikey Hari Gupta , lawyer appearing for the petitioner.

Dehradun DM, in his affidavit to the court, had said that he had directed the regional office of the State Pollution Control Board to submit a report stating the number of slaughterhouses running in the state. To this, the SPCB had replied saying that there is just one slaughterhouse in Dehradun. The affidavit added that even that particular slaughterhouse has also been closed by the Dehradun Municipal Corporation. Later, Dehradun DM paid a visit to the slaughterhouse on March 11. “That on 11.3.2020, the District Magistrate himself visited the slaughterhouse at Bhandari Bagh and found that a notice has been pasted on the main gate stating that the slaughterhouse has been closed till further orders of the Dehradun Municipal Corporation ," the affidavit read.

Gupta told TOI that any place where ten (or more) animals are slaughtered is termed as a slaughterhouse. “The DM cannot absolve himself from the compliance of the HC orders merely by closing government slaughterhouses. All private shops where more than ten animals are being slaughtered have to be shut as well,” Gupta said.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Rajasthan temple closed, yet hundreds march from UP for pilgrimage
Content: AGRA: Hundreds of devotees from across UP and Haryana have embarked on a pilgrimage to Kaila Devi temple in Rajasthan despite the place of worship closing its doors until March 31 and the authorities appealing to followers not to congregate there in the wake of coronavirus threat.An annual fair at the temple in Karauli district was also cancelled after the Rajasthan government banned gatherings exceeding 50 people. Neither the advisory nor the fact that no darshan is possible seems to have dampened the faith of hundreds.On Wednesday night, a long line of devotees on foot and vehicles could be seen on Roopvas Road in Agra as they made their way to Rajasthan for the annual pilgrimage that starts after Holi and lasts until Chaitra Navratri.“For more than 50 years, my family and relatives have been visiting Kaila Devi on foot. A virus cannot cannot stop us from worshipping our gods,” said Tulsiram, a resident of Mathura, who is part of a group of 60 pilgrims which is expected to reach its destination in three days. The group will cover 180 km on foot to reach the temple.Virendra Kumar, a farmer in Etmadpur block, who is headed to the temple with his wife, added, “We know the temple is shut but we will offer our prayers from outside.”A factory worker, Manoj Chaudhary, on his way to Kaila Devi with four friends said that Covid-19 was a “rich man’s disease” and unlikely to affect poor, hardworking people like him.No amount of convincing could make the worshippers turn back. Mahesh Chandra Sharma, manager of Shri Kaila Devi temple trust, said that pilgrims have been requested to visit the temple once the Covid-19 threat is over.Gram pradhans of villages on the UP-Rajasthan border, such as Davar, Jajauli, Aulenda, also tried to persuade the pilgrims to not continue their journey but in vain.Narayan Singh, husband of gram pradhan of Jajauli village, said, “At least 20% population of our village has left to visit Kaila Devi. The local administration has failed to create awareness about Covid-19 in remote areas.” Satyendra Singh, husband of gram pradhan of Aulenda village, said, “These pilgrims will infect themselves and others by their sheer ignorance.” Dharam Singh , husband of gram pradhan of Davar village, was relieved that Rajasthan police had started forcing pilgrims to return.Sub-divisional magistrate of Kiraoli block (Agra), Nandkishore Kalal, told TOI, “Our team is continuously working to create awareness among villagers to stop their movement toward Kaila Devi amid the spread of Covid-19. At the moment, we have not implemented CrPc section 144, as it might anger pilgrims, however, after interacting with government staff, they are returning home.”

Title: Telangana: Woman, 2-month-old girl fall in open pit, saved by passers-by
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A woman and her two-month-old grand-daughter fell into an open pit filled with rainwater at Budhanagar in Peerzadiguda on Thursday evening. Timely intervention by passers-by saved them.

The local municipal authorities had dug the pit near a private hospital as part of some civic works.

Two women with one of them carrying the baby were walking along the road when one of them stepped on the pit by accident . On seeing the woman struggling to get out, a few passers-by came to their rescue and first pulled out the infant so that she does not drown.

The whole incident which was captured on a CCTV camera nearby and the footage went viral on social media on Thursday night drawing widespread criticism for the contractor and municipal authorities.

Both the infant and her grandmother were taken to a nearby hospital where they were given treatment.

The contractor concerned and the municipal authorities reached the spot and closed the pit after the accident. However, a complaint was lodged at Medipally police station against the contractor, accusing him of negligence.



In Video: On cam: Woman and infant fall in pit left open, saved

Title: Covid-19 in Rajasthan: First China-like containment zone locks Jhunjhunu down
Content:
‘310 teams of medical staff were formed’

JAIPUR: In a first in the state, China-like lockdown has been imposed in Jhunjhunu where a Covid-19 positive couple and their child, who had returned from Italy, roamed freely in market places and hospitals in the city.Police have cordoned off the area within the one-km radius of the house, where the three infected people lived, and the government has deployed health department teams. The family had returned from Italy on March 8.The lockdown will help to prevent any formation of Covid-19 positive clusters.The state government has imposed the cluster containment strategy within a defined geographic area for early detection, breaking the chain of transmission and preventing its spread to new areas.Jaipur: In China’s Wuhan, many medical students from Rajasthan were stuck inside their hostel rooms during the lockdown to contain the outbreak. Taking a cue from it, the state government has quickly formulated the cluster containment plan to ward off the risk of spreading. The curfew, imposed in the one-km periphery of the house of the infected, will prevent transmission, morbidity and mortality.In 12 hours after the three tested positive, 310 teams of doctors and nursing staff were formed to reach out to at least 8,000 houses in the one-km area around the infected family’s house.While the entire area is under lockdown, health teams have so far disinfected 60 houses. Specific entry and exit points have been created and police have been deployed to prevent anyone entering the containment area. In the threekm radius, people are given entry only after proper screening. People in the five-km radius are also being screened.“We did not allow anyone to enter the one-km area except some students, who had to appear for an examination. The area has been completely sealed with the help of the police,” said Jhunjhunu district collector Umar Deen Khan.There was a check on outward movement of people from the containment zone except for availing essential services, including emergencies, and government business.

Title: Agra: Illegal user charges levied for door-to-door garbage collection
Content:
A probe has been ordered by additional municipal commissioner into complaints that illegal user charges are be... Read More

AGRA: A probe has been ordered by additional municipal commissioner into complaints that illegal user charges are being levied for collecting garbage door to door in the city in the name of Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC).

Since mid-January, AMC workers have been collecting garbage every day. They were entrusted with the task after the contracts of private companies assigned the job were cancelled. The AMC officials had directed that no user charges be collected till the door-to-door garbage collection work is regularized in all the 100 wards of the city. However, it is learnt that illegal charges are being collected from houses and business establishments. Fake receipts are also being were issued.

The matter came to the fore when people from Sultanganj, Balkeshwar and Water Works area gathered at the AMC office on Wednesday to point out that proper sanitation and hygiene was not being maintained in the city.

The people brought the “fake receipts” of the door-to-door garbage collection charges as proof. The receipts did not bear the name of the AMC or any official stamp or signature of any official. These receipts ranged between Rs 300 and 880 for one month of garbage collection.

The residents also informed the additional municipal commissioner that the men who came to recover user charges were not the ones who came to collect the garbage. The men who collected user charges claimed to be associated with the cleanliness work of the civic body.

Talking with TOI, additional municipal commissioner KB Singh said, “Presently the door-to-door garbage collection work is being done by the AMC. Our priority is to ensure standard maintenance of sanitation and hygiene in the city and not to generate revenue through user charges. For now, no charges are being collected for the service. We have taken cognizance of the complaints of illegal recovery taking place in the name of door-to-door garbage collection. An investigation has been initiated in the entire matter.”

Talking with TOI, mayor Naveen Jain said, “I have also received complaints of illegal recovery on the name of door-to-door garbage collection. AMC officials are conducting a probe in the entire matter. I have asked them to identify people involved in the illegal activity. I will ensure that an FIR is registered against such people.”

Title: ATM cash theft case: Culprit arrested, Rs 90 lakh recovered in Hyderabad
Content:
The Task Force team displays the seized cash to the media on Thursday

HYDERABAD: Meticulous planning and a bit of luck helped a culprit flee with Rs 92 lakh cash and a vehicle of an ATM cash replenishment firm. However, his luck ran out with police’s equally meticulous job — scanning footage of 500 CCTVs in 36 hours — and arresting him from his house at Nagole on Tuesday.

Task Force police arrested D Prakash, the driver of the vehicle, and recovered Rs 90 lakh stolen cash from his possession.

Prakash joined as a driver with Five Star Facility Solutions (India) Pvt Ltd in Kavadiguda in August 2019. On behalf of Five Star Facility Solutions, he worked for SIPL Company located at Diamond Point, Bowenpally, and, through them, he also worked as van driver for CMS Info Systems Limited.

“Prakash planned to steal cash transported from the bank while working as a driver. He waited for an opportunity and on March 16, he went to CMS Company’s vehicle parking place at Kavadiguda wearing a cap and covering his face with a handkerchief. Introducing himself as Rakesh, an employee of Five Star Security Service, the accused took the keys of a Bolero vehicle from the security guard. He then went to CMS office at Lower Tank Bund and contacted coordinator Anil Kumar Yadav.

The coordinator assigned gunman Ravi Kumar along with two custodians — T Ravi and V Jagannath Rao — to transport cash from SBI’s Koti branch to SBI ATMs. The crew picked up Rs 1.6 crore cash from SBI Koti and stopped at Shiva Tea point in Chilkalguda to load Rs 68 lakh cash in an ATM. “Gunman and two custodians got out of the vehicle and went to load the cash. During this time, Prakash fled with the vehicle containing Rs 92 lakh cash after informing them that he would take a U-turn,” city police commissioner Anjani Kumar said. The CMS staff alerted their colleagues and they tracked the abandoned Bolero to Lalaguda flyover.

Based on the complaint lodged by a CMS representative, Chilkalguda police registered a cheating case and 28 members of Task Force team scanned nearly 500 CCTVs in 36 hours. They saw the accused boarding an auto near Lalaguda flyover and conducted house-to-house check at Sai Nagar Colony in Nagole, where the accused disembarked with two bags.

The city police chief presented mementos to auto driver Sk Hameed and seven residents of Sai Nagar Colony in Nagole, including two persons working for police for helping Task Force team in cracking the case.

Title: Coronavirus in Kochi: Doctors can see you online, thanks to police initiative
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

KOCHI: In order to provide online medical consultation to those under home quarantine and to those who suspect that they have been infected, the city police commissionerate on Thursday launched an telemedicine platform, Swaraksha.

The platform, with the motto ‘protect and be protected’, facilitates virtual consultations between patient and doctor. According to police, this would help overcome the dilemma of patients visiting hospital on their own, and coming into close contact with others.

Swaraksha was created in collaboration with Indian Medical Association , Rotary District 3201 and a private communication service provider, police said.

As many as 25 doctors have volunteered to associate with the project. These doctors have been given dedicated mobile phones and sim cards for the purpose,” said district police chief ( Kochi City) Vijay Sakhare at a press briefing here.

Police said the link to the platform, , would be put out through social media platforms of city police commissionerate. The home page of the online service comes with a link to send a WhatsApp message, which could be text, audio or video. This message reaches the control room set up by the commissionerate exclusively for dealing with Covid-19 related matters. This control room is manned by a team of police officers and paramedics.

The control room will call to the number to verify the caller’s genuineness and later sent it to a database accessible by doctors. The control room then arranges a conference call with the doctor and the one seeking medical assistance before disengaging itself from the platform, police said.

Police officers in the city have been active on duty to fight the Covid-19 outbreak. Their main tasks include screening of passengers at help desks set up railway stations and bus stands, and ensuring home quarantine of suspected cases. They also ensure that foreign nationals are staying in quarantine.

Foreigners Outreach Cell has been set up by the city police to provide assistance to foreign nationals in transport, ticket and visa, accommodation and medical help.

Cyberdome Kochi and cyber cell are keeping a close watch on internet and social media to fight the spread of fake news. Police have also moved all meetings to videoconferencing platforms.

Title: Work from home not an option for many small firms in Madurai
Content: Madurai: Most of the businesses, especially Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises MSMEs ), in Madurai district continue to function as usual with little to no preventive measures against Covid-19. For big firms, particularly IT companies, work from home is an easy alternative, but for small traders and industries it is never an option. However, they are trying their best to survive in the hard times.SVS Foods, a popular flour manufacturer and distributor, has paid all of its 50 staff salary in advance for 15 days. “We understand that our employees would not be able to save money to buy essentials in case of an emergency so we decided to pay them in advance on Saturday. We held a meeting with all employees and briefed about the situation,” said S V Suraj Sundara Shankar, managing partner, SVS Foods. He added that a hand-washing basin has also been installed at the workplace and masks were also given to employees.Suraj further said that initially the company was criticized because such a move pointed towards creating a panic. “But, once the government started announcing preventive measures such as shutting down public places, many felt that our decision was justified. We are hoping to set an example for companies to ease the burden of employees during such hard times,” he noted.Meanwhile, Madurai District Tiny and Small Scale Industries Association (MADITSSIA) president B Muruganantham said that it is not enough to just emphasize hand hygiene and sanitization. “In smaller industries, the employees cannot afford to miss work or work from home. The Covid-19 scare has created an uncomfortable atmosphere in businesses and it is feared to have an adverse impact on economy. MSMEs need financial support to reform once the Covid-19 situation is resolved. Many other countries are supporting their small businesses even in the middle of tackling Covid-19,” he said.

Title: CRPF personnel commits suicide at his quarters in Hyderabad
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A CRPF sub-inspector committed suicide by hanging himself from the ceiling at his CRPF Southern Sector quarters in Jubilee Hills on Thursday.

Jubilee Hills police said that N Bhavani Shankar (30), who is a native of Rajasthan, was found hanging in the recreation centre of CRPF quarters. At around 6 am, when the quarters’ maintenance staff went to the recreation centre for cleaning the premises, they found Shankar’s body hanging from the ceiling.

Police suspect that Shankar might had taken the extreme step due to personal reasons. A case was registered under Section 174 (suspicious death) of CrPC .

Title: Coronavirus suspect admitted to AIIMS Rishikesh, Kenya-return man also referred to facility
Content: DEHRADUN: A 37-year-old man from Rishikesh who complained of throat pain and dry non-productive cough was brought to AIIMS Rishikesh on Wednesday. He has been kept in the isolation ward. Another foreign return from Uttarkashi, with coronavirus-like symptoms, was referred to AIIMS from Chinyalisaur’s community health centre (CHC). He didn’t reach AIIMS till the time of filing this report.Harish Thapliyal, public relations officer of AIIMS Rishikesh, told TOI that the 37-year-old patient is suffering from cough, fever, myalgia, and headache for a week now. He has also complained of changes in the consistency of stools and difficulty in swallowing food.“These symptoms were developed in the man after coming in contact with a visitor from Gurugram (where positive cases of Covid-19 have been found). The man’s examination has revealed that posterior pharyngeal (throat) wall congestion were within limits. At present, he is being managed conservatively with antihistamines, IV fluids, and cough suppressant . His throat sample is being sent for Covid-19 test,” said Thapliyal.Another man from Chinyalisaur block of Uttarkashi district who recently returned from Kenya was referred to AIIMS Rishikesh after he showed flu-like symptoms. According to sources, the man works at a hotel in Kenya.He reached Delhi airport on March 16 and came to Chinyalisaur on March 17, where he stayed alone in a rented accommodation. On Wednesday, he went to a private clinic for treatment of cough and cold. However, after getting to know about his recent international visit, the doctor there sent him to Chinyalisaur’s CHC. And from there, he was referred to AIIMS Rishikesh.Authorities at AIIMS Rishikesh confirmed that the case was referred to them but the man didn’t reach the hospital till the time of filing this report.Meanwhile, according to the health department, as many as 78 samples of suspected Covid-19 cases have been sent for testing. Among these, 28 have come out negative, one have come out positive, and reports of others are still awaited.“As many as 794 people were quarantined in Uttarakhand. Among them, 390 patients have completed 28 days of observation and 356 people are still under observation. The rest 34 patients have migrated from the state. We have 200 ICU beds in various government hospitals and we are identifying some properties in the outskirts of cities to convert them into isolation centres,” said DG health Dr Amita Upreti She added that the hill state has 220 companies involved in drug and medicines manufacturing. An analysis of these units done by health department revealed that they can produce 110 crore tablets and 44 lakh bottles of syrup in one eight-hour shift.

Title: 46% of paediatrician posts vacant
Content: Gandhinagar: Of the 261 sanctioned posts for paediatricians at hospitals in the state, 121 or 46% are vacant. In order to get qualified paediatricians, the government is mulling making it compulsory for postgraduate medical students to work in the government sector for three years.In reply to a question in the assembly, the state government admitted that districts such as Dahod, Chhota Udepur, Sabarkantha, Gir Somnath, Dev Bhoomi Dwarka, and Bharuch, do not have a single paediatrician at government hospitals. These six districts together have 32 sanctioned posts for paediatricians and all are vacant. Dang, Kheda, Morbi, Anand, Junagadh and Porbandar districts have no vacant paediatrician posts.The state government said that demands have been raised with the Gujarat Public Service Commission but it has failed to get qualified candidates. Moreover, the government has said that it is also holds walk-in interviews every Monday for paediatricians, but there are hardly any takers.A senior officer said the government is also thinking of making it compulsory for postgraduate medical students to work for three years in the government sector, failing which they would have to pay a hefty fine.The officer said that several doctors find private practice more lucrative then joining the government. He said that if a doctor checks 20 patients a day in private practice, he or she makes around Rs 10,000.

Title: Shivraj Singh Chouhan: Truth has won, Cong govt will lose floor test
Content:
Shivraj Singh Chouhan (2L), BJP State President VD Sharma (2R) and leader of the opposition in the State Assem... Read More

Bhopal: Madhya Pradesh BJP leaders have hailed the directive by the Supreme Court to conduct floor test in the state assembly on March 20. Welcoming the decision, former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan said that finally the truth had prevailed and the Congress government led by Kamal Nath will fall. Reacting to the apex court’s ruling on Thursday, he said, “Today, truth has won . We welcome the Supreme Court's decision to conduct the floor test on Friday. The Congress government has lost the majority as it cheated the people of Madhya Pradesh. This government will lose the floor test on Friday."

Slamming the Congress government, Chouhan said, "The people of Madhya Pradesh have finally got freedom from injustice after the court decision. Chief minister Kamal Nath and Digvijay Singh have been defeated as the government will lose the floor test."

Chouhan also raised objection over the decisions taken by the government in the last one week. He said the Congress government has made a mockery of democracy, as touts liquor mafia, sand and transport mafias are calling the shots during its rule. The law and order situation in the state had collapsed. "There is administrative chaos in the state, as the minority government is busy making appointments and shifting officers at will. Today, the apex court has ensured that truth and justice will now prevail in the state," he said.

BJP state president VD Sharma termed the Supreme Court’s decision as a victory of democracy, justice and truth. Welcoming the decision, he said that now the way for the formation of a public welfare government has been cleared in Madhya Pradesh. "The SC decision is important as it puts an end to Congress's autocratic rule. The conscious public was aware of the gameplan of Congress to avoid the floor test in the House. The apex court verdict will give people an opportunity to do way with the tricks played by Congress government and pave the way for development," he said.

Leader of Opposition (LoP) Gopal Bhargava also hailed the decision. He said: "Everything will be clear in the floor test on Friday”.

On Thursday, the Supreme Court ordered a floor test in the state assembly to be held on Friday. A bench of the apex court headed by Justice DY Chandrachud said the floor test would be held by raising hands in accordance with the law and should be completed by 5 pm.

Title: Madurai: Complaint filed by MKU over fake pic of PM Narendra Modi’s Twitter handle
Content:
The photo-shopped image of the PM’s twitter handle carried a request to MKU vice-chancellor Dr M Krishnan to c... Read More

MADURAI: Madurai Kamaraj University ( MKU ) registrar Sankar Natesan filed a police complaint on Wednesday after a fake image of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s official Twitter handle with a comment on the university was circulated on WhatsApp.

The photoshopped image of the PM’s Twitter handle carried a request to MKU vice-chancellor M Krishnan to close down the university in the light of the Covid-19 scare. It read, “I request the Vice Chancellor of #mku Madurai Kamaraj University to shutdown immediately, It is one of the best university of our country and we can’t risk the life of country’s best students.”

The tweet was dated March 16, the day from which schools and universities across Tamil Nadu shut down. Shankar said that an FIR has been registered under three sections, including under the IT Act. “We filed the complaint immediately when we came to know about the image and that miscreants were misusing the Prime Minister’s name,” he added.

MADURAIIt has been reported that the same image has been used by miscreants by replacing MKU’s name with those of other popular colleges in Madurai. The Nagamalai-Pudukottai police are investigating the matter. Meanwhile, police have been ordered to deal strictly with anyone spreading rumours regarding Covid-19 via social media.

Title: Yogi Adityanath regime all about misuse of power: Congress
Content:
File photo of Yogi Adityanath

LUCKNOW: Calling Yogi Adityanath ’s stint as UP CM a scar on democracy, UP Congress president Ajay Kumar Lallu on Thursday said that Yogi’s term would be remembered for brazen misuse of power.

The Congress also released a website called yogirajkareportcard.com, which, the party said, would expose the truth of the achievements listed out by the Yogi government.

Congress national general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra also slammed the Yogi government for not addressing issues affecting people.

“The BJP government presents fake numbers to pat its back. But when you ask questions regarding farmers, youth, businessmen and women, they cut corners. The people of UP have suffered a lot at the hands of this government,” Priyanka tweeted.

Releasing a booklet to list the failures of the Yogi government, Lallu said: “Three years of Yogi government have been all about brazen abuse of power, shameless communalisation of police force and weakening India’s secular fabric by spreading hatred.”

Stating that the BJP government in UP had failed the people despite promising highest standards of governance, Congress leader in Vidhan Sabha Aradhana Mishra said: “They spoke about ‘sushasan’ but have failed on every aspect including law and order.”

Title: Munna Bajrangi’s murder: CBI grills Jhansi jail staff, 4 inmates
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: A four-member CBI team on Wednesday night visited Jhansi jail, where it questioned the staff and four prisoners who were with Munna Bajrangi before the don was shot dead on July 9, 2018.

The investigators also seized the prison register to identify people who met Bajrangi in Jhansi a day before he was shifted to Baghpat jail and killed by gangster Sunil Rathi.

The CBI, following an Allahabad High Court directive, lodged an FIR against Rathi on March 7.

A senior CBI officer said Bajrangi, alias Prem Prakash, was shot within hours of being shifted out of Jhansi jail.

At least eight members of prison staff, including guards and deputy jailers, were quizzed for several hours as were four inmates who were in touch with the don for over two years during his stay in Jhansi jail.

The questioning began at 9pm on Wednesday and continued till Thursday evening. “They were categorically asked about the circumstances under which the don was shifted,” a CBI officer said.

CBI officers said the entire episode of the don being shifted from Jhansi to Baghpat and the early morning murder would be reconstructed. On the seized entry register of 2018, sources said the CBI had zeroed in on nine persons who had come to visit the don in Jhansi from July 1 to July 6 that year.

The agency had earlier quizzed staff at Baghpat jail. It has now sought permission to quiz Rathi who is currently lodged in Tihar jail.

Bajrangi was jailed in 2009 for the murder of BJP MLA Krishnanand Rai at Mohamadabad in Ghazipur district on November 29, 2005.

Title: Covid-19 outbreak: Entire education system halted
Content: NEW DELHI: It is not only CBSE’s exams for classes X and XII that have been deferred by the outbreak of Covid-19. On Thursday, the University Grants Commission also asked higher educational institutions to postpone all ongoing examinations and evaluations till March 31. It is also likely that the JEE (Main) scheduled for April for admission to IITs and similar entrance tests conducted by National Testing Agency, such as those for Delhi University and Jawaharlal Nehru University, will be pushed back.These steps will have a cascading effect on the 2020-21 academic calendar, including delay in the declaration of results, holding of entrance examinations and implementation of the admission process.On the directions of the Union human resource development ministry, Central Board of Secondary Education and the National Institute of Open Schooling postponed their exams on Wednesday, while the Council for the Indian School Certificate Examinations followed suit on Thursday. Now, UGC has written to the vice-chancellors of all universities to reschedule ongoing examinations and evaluations.Given the situation, Cambridge Assessment International Education, which provides international education programmes and qualifications, has also allowed schools to withdraw candidates from the May/June exam series while giving them a credit to use in the November or a future exam series. Christine Özden, CEO, CAIE, said the priority was safety of students and staff at Cambridge schools around the world.Delhi government also ordered the closure of all government and private schools in the national capital for teaching and non- teaching staff till March 31 to prevent coronavirus infection. So far, the schools were closed for students while exams were continuing. “All exams have been postponed till March 31. The schools will be closed for teaching and non-teaching staff too,” reiterated the Directorate of Education, adding that teachers would carry out the evaluation work for school exams from home even as the evaluation for board exams had been suspended by CBSE.While CISCE has decentralised the evaluation process and examiners will assess the answer scripts at their residences, CBSE is going to decide on the process after a review of the situation on March 31.As for the exams conducted by the National Testing Agency, a senior official of the body said, “The rescheduled dates for JEE (Main) will be decided after March 31 after taking into consideration the rescheduled dates of the CBSE board exams. Other exams may also have to be rescheduled but this will depend on the decision taken by the government on March 31.”

Title: Making way for secretariat construction, TSSPDCL to vacate stone building
Content:
Files and furniture being loaded on to a truck as the power discom prepares to shift office. The government ha... Read More

HYDERABAD: Employees of the Telangana State Southern Power Distribution Company Limited ( TSSPDCL ) started the process of vacating the stone building at Mint Compound on Thursday following state government orders in view of the proposal to construct a new secretariat building at the existing complex.

Official sources said that the Telangana State Southern Power Distribution Company Limited metro zone office will now be shifted to Rangareddy zone office at the Mint Compound and the Hyderabad Banjara Hills circle office will be shifted to Erragadda. Two more offices — Transco and CIG — are being shifted to Vidyut Soudha , they added.

The stone building was constructed about 100 years ago and the place was once used as Nizam’s Mint Compound and later the finance ministry set up the government mint and security printing press in 1980.

The government had earlier planned to use the building for security personnel guarding the secretariat. But the idea was dropped as Telangana State Southern Power Distribution Company Limited authorities said that they do not have space to shift their offices. Now, the government has reportedly instructed the discom to vacate the building as the land is required for the new secretariat as per Vaastu.

Title: Prayagraj: New rules for trucks ferrying medicines
Content:
Representative image

PRAYAGRAJ: As the city grapples with a shortage of masks and hand sanitisers in the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak, traders dealing in medicines have been directed to get trucks bringing their consignments unloaded between 1-5 pm or after 9pm to regulate traffic movement on the busy Leader Road. Senior police officials issued the directive for traders on Thursday.

Prayagraj traders and traffic police had been at loggerheads since the past one week over parking and loading/unloading of vehicles ferrying consignments for the former. The traders alleged that traffic police often misbehaved with truckers and issued unnecessary e-challans while medicines were unloaded.

President of Allahabad Chemists & Druggists Association Anil Dubey said, “A delegation of traders under the banner of Allahabad Chemists & Druggists Association, Prayag Vyapaar Mandal and Laxman Bazar Vyapaar Mandal on Thursday met senior police officials and complained about the high-handedness of the traffic police.”

Title: RBSE board exams postponed
Content:
Jaipur: To prevent the spread of coronavirus, the state government on Thursday decided to postpone the board exams of all classes. This has come as a relief to the parents who were worried about their wards being vulnerable to the epidemic. In the meeting, it was decided to postpone the board exams of classes V, VIII, X and XII of Rajasthan Board of Secondary Education (RBSE).

School education minister Govind Singh Dotasra said, “To prevent the spread of coronavirus, it was necessary to postpone the exams. Students are vulnerable to the disease. Now, people are being requested to spread the right information and to not panic.”

Similar orders were issued by the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) on Wednesday. In RBSE, for Class X, only two exams were remaining and class XII exams were supposed to go on till April 3.

CBSE and other state boards in the country have already issued orders to promote students to the next class on the basis of average marks obtained in other exams. The decision was taken due to the sudden closure of schools and interruption in exams.

Last week, private school organization in Rajasthan declared to promote students in primary sections to next class on average marking.

However, RBSE has just postponed board exams for class V and VIII but no decision has been made to promote these students to further classes. Teachers in government schools have objected to it, stating unnecessary wastage of time. “Anyway in primary sections, students are promoted without fail. Instead of postponing exams in classes V and VIII, government must promote these students to further sections to do away with the headache,” said one government teacher anonymously. Ongoing exam of all the colleges have been postponed as well where more than 6 lakh students were appearing for exams everyday. Taking precautionary measures, most universities in the state have postponed their exams.

Title: Father shoots 2 daughters dead for stealing cellphone
Content:
Agra: A 50-year-old man allegedly shot dead his two daughters with a country-made pistol in Mainpuri after he found out that they had stolen a cellphone during a 'Holi milan' programme.

The accused, Sukhdev Sharma, was arrested after he called police on Wednesday night and informed them that he had killed his daughters, Neha, 20, and Anamika,18, police officers said. The bodies have been sent for postmortem.

According to SP Mainpuri Ajay Kumar, Sharma told police that he had committed the crime as he was “humiliated” by his daughters’ act.

An FIR under section 302 (murder) of the IPC has been registered against him at Kotwali police station and two mobile phones, a country-made pistol and one live cartridges have been recovered from him, said the SP.

Sharma had been invited along with his family members for a "Holi milan” programme on Tuesday by Pawan Sharma, who works as a driver for a state minister, at his residence. Pawan had hired Sharma to work as a mason in his house. Later that day, Pawan’s mother found her Nokia mobile phone missing.

When Sharma inquired about the missing phone from his daughters, they handed it to him on Wednesday evening. A little later, Sharma went out to drink and when he got back he shot both of his daughters, police said. Sharma is survived by a son.

Title: JMC steps up fight against coronavirus
Content: Jaipur: The Jaipur Municipal Corporation ( JMC ) on Thursday swung into action to combat coronavirus.Guards at the entry gates have been provided with one bottle of sanitizer which will be used by the visitors entering the building.Every day, thousands of people visit the headquarters for several issues. Officials have now become more vigilant and are not taking any chances.TOI had reported on Tuesday regarding the crowd that gathered at the Birth and Death Registration Office at JMC headquarters. On Thursday, JMC officials posted guards at the entry gate of Birth and Death Registration Office to prevent gathering of crowd.Registrar of Birth and Death Registration Office at JMC, Pradeep Pareek said, “Guards have been appointed at the entry gates of the office and only 10-15 people are allowed at a time. Our target is not to let crowd assemble inside the premises.”People were seen waiting for their turn.

Title: Liquor sales fall, state suffers Rs 600 crore excise duty loss
Content:
Scene at the otherwise busy Crawford Market on Thursday

MUMBAI: In a matter of 14 days, Maharashtra has witnessed a sudden and unexpected fall in liquor consumption, resulting in an excise duty loss of nearly Rs 600 crore.

“There is no correlation between liquor consumption and health during the Coronavirus outbreak. It appears that people have stopped liquor consumption on their own and several shops have shut following the district administration orders,” a senior bureaucrat told TOI.

The bureaucrat said district collectors of Nagpur, Parbhani, Palghar, Pune, Buldhana, Ratnagiri and Sindhudurg have ordered closure of liquor shops while there is a complete ban on its consumption in the Chandrapur, Wardha and Gadchiroli districts.

“District collectors have imposed stringent restrictions to ensure that people do not gather in large numbers at one place. Social distancing is the key factor so that the virus does not spread any further. These orders had an adverse impact on people who visit restaurants and bars and consequently liquor consumption. We estimate liquor consumption has reduced by at least 20%,” he said.

He said the state government had set the target of Rs 17,977 crore for the current financial year and as on March 15, mobilization of excise duty was Rs 14,700 crore. Average monthly collection of excise duty on country liquor and Indian Made Foreign Liquor and foreign liquor ranges from Rs 1,200 crore to Rs 1,400 crore. “By and large, by March, we achieve the target. Now, following Coronavirus, it will not be possible to reach the target,” he said.

The bureaucrat further said ever since Covid-19, there has been adverse impact on the overall economy with people staying put indoors. Most outings as well as public events have been cancelled.

“There are no more celebrations and all events have been cancelled in view of the appeal made by the chief minister,’’ he said.

A senior excise official said reduction in consumption has resulted in a huge revenue loss, following liquor ban in Chandrapur district, hometown of former finance minister Sudhir Mungantiwar. There was a proposal to lift it but no decision was taken following public pressure.

Title: MUHS will declare exam results early to make healthcare providers available
Content:
Nashik: The Nashik based Maharashtra University of Health Sciences (MUHS) has decided to prepone the declaration of examination results of mid-level healthcare providers by at least 15 days.

The varsity’s decision comes in after the state health department’s request to expedite the evaluation of the answer scripts as it wants to increase the department’s skilled health manpower as soon as possible.

“Although the department has not specified why it wants the university to speed up the evaluation process, we are of the view that more trained health personnel in the state would be required as the number of Covid-19 cases in on the rise. There are also apprehensions about community transmission of the infection,” said an MUHS functionary.

Varsity’s controller of examination Ajit Pathak told TOI t hat the MUHS will declare the results within a month instead of the customary 45-50 days needed to evaluate the papers after completion of the exam.

The state government has been recruiting these mid-level healthcare providers since March 2019 under the Ayushman Bharat Yojana. In the state, the MUHS conducts the examination before the state government appoints the healthcare providers.

Altogether, 3,366 ayurved and nursing graduates are appearing for the exam after finishing a six-month training programme in modern medicine at different district health hospitals. Pathak said the theory exam was completed on February 29 and the practicals would get over by March 22.

“By the end of this month, we shall declare the results and hand over the list of successful candidates to the state health department,” he added.

“The pass percentage of such examination is over 80%. This means that at least 2,600 skilled health personnel would be available to the state health department in the near future,” the university sources said.

These examinees are trained to administer medicines, vaccinations, monitor the health of critically ill patients etc. They are appointed for a three-year term, but the contract gets extended if their performances are good. “The appointments of such mid-level healthcare personnel are meant for the health wellness clinics like primary health centres. But in case of need, they can also be deployed in government hospitals,” said Pathak.

Title: City reports 14 malaria, 12 typhoid, 9 jaundice cases a day
Content: Gandhinagar: The Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation may have an ambitious plan to eradicate malaria, but data tabled in the assembly tells a different story. Ahmedabad reported an average of 14 malaria, 13 typhoid, nine jaundice and eight dengue cases every day in 2018 and 2019.The state health department revealed that dengue caused 15 deaths (11 in 2019, four in 2018), while falciparum malaria cause three (one in 2019, two in 2018) in Ahmedabad in this two-year period.Data tabled in the assembly revealed that there was a 29.34% increase in typhoid cases and a 17.94% increase in dengue cases in 2019. The number of deaths due to dengue grew by 175% in 2019, from 2018. A senior AMC officer pointed out that there was a discrepancy in data tabled in the assemby and AMC data. In 2019, the city registered a 45% increase in dengue cases, reporting 4,537 cases, up from 3,135 in 2018.The officer said that the data tabled in the assembly is only from government hospitals, while the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation includes the figures from private laboratories and hospitals.The AMC officer said that in between August and December 2019, there was a 50% increase in the number of cases compared to the same period the previous year, with the city reporting 4,331 cases in 2019, against 2,889 cases in 2018.“The most dengue cases are reported in October and 62% of cases in 2019 were reported in just two months, with September and October accounting for 2,845 of the 4,537 annual total,” an AMC health department official pointed out.

Title: Forest department in Hyderabad imposes Rs 50,000 fine for uprooting saplings
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The forest department has imposed a fine of Rs 50,000 on realtors responsible of uprooting saplings along the stretch from Inorbit Mall to IKEA.

The remitters have also been asked to replace the uprooted saplings with 180 more as the plants were removed without permission.

“About 60 saplings were removed to ensure smooth flow of traffic near Salarpuria Sattva complex,” said Srikanth, a forest section officer. The amount was paid by Amit Bagla , who claimed to be a representative of the complex management.

However, city-based activist Harish Daga, who first reported the issue, said the fine was miniscule. “The number of saplings bulldozed was definitely over 100. The fine will not deter others from committing similar acts in the name of development.” He further said that a road had already been laid over the said site.

Title: Four more Agra residents cured of Covid-19, discharged from Delhi’s Safdarjung Hosp
Content:
Agra: Four city residents who had tested positive for Covid-19 have been cured of the infection and were discharged from Safdarjung Hospital in Delhi. All four returned home late in the evening on Thursday.

They included a 44-year-old footwear exporter who had returned from Italy in the last week of February, his 16-year-old son, the 48-year-old manager of his factory and his 45-year-old wife.

Earlier on Sunday, four members of the shoe exporter family, including the 65-year-old mother of the factory owner who had heavy viral load but did not test Covid-19 positive, were also discharged from Safdarjung Hospital.

Talking to TOI, the shoe exporter said, “Along with five family members, I had been quarantined on March 3. Barring me and my son, four family membersincluding my wife, parents and younger brother were discharged on March 15. Mentally, it was a tough time. Doctors in both Agra and Delhi made their best efforts to help us recover. The arrangements made by the state and central government to control spread of the disease are commendable. It is a great feeling to return home, after staying away from family and friends for 17 days.”

“Doctors have asked us to avoid social gatherings for a few days and maintain a high level of hygiene and sanitation. We will follow their directions,” he added.

The manager of the shoe factory said, “Doctors at Agra district hospital and Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital took good care of us. We were kept in separate rooms. There was no TV, but mobile phone was allowed. Isolation was a little depressing for all of us. People need not panic and strictly follow government advisory.”

Elsewhere, samples of all suspected patients sent to King George Medical University (KGMU) on Wednesday tested negative.

Satish Verma, superintendent in-charge of district hospital, told TOI, “Ten local residents who had recently returned from Europe, the Middle East and Sri Lanka, were admitted in isolation. Eleven other suspected cases were identified by the surveillance team. Blood, nose and throat swab samples of the 21 people have been sent to KGMU for lab tests. Reports are likely to be received on Friday afternoon.”

District magistrate Prabhu N Singh said, “Out of the eight Covid-19 positive cases, seven people have been cured of disease. One female Covid-19 positive patient is being treated at SN Medical College. In total, 1,222 people have been advised home quarantine. Health department teams are closely monitoring health of all these people. We have also constituted a traveler’s list tracking team. It will be conducting checkup of all the people arriving from other countries.”

Title: Jaipur Coronavirus News: School stripped of affiliation for flouting norms on coronavirus
Content:
Photo of Shakti Shiksha Academy Sr Sec School tweeted by school education minister Govind Singh Dotasra

JAIPUR: The recognition of Shakti Shiksha Academy Sr Sec School, Jaipur, was cancelled on Thursday by the orders of directorate of education, Bikaner, for keeping the school open in violation of guidelines issued to check spread of Covid-19.

In a surprise inspection on Thursday, Shakti Shiksha Academy School was found conducting examination as per schedule. School education minister Govind Singh Dotasra later tweeted that no school was allowed to function, so its recognition will be cancelled.

Due to the threat of coronavirus, the government has directed all educational institutions in the state to declare holidays but many prominent schools in the city were found to be functioning or calling the teachers to duty. A video went viral on social media in which students were seen going to Divine Public School, Jaipur. Education department officials reached the school and shut it down.

Not only were students being forced to go to schools, many private and government schools in the city were calling teachers, who were made to sit in the staff rooms though the classes were not on. When the school authorities were asked the reason for this, they said that the teachers were still getting salaries.

A private school teacher who did not wish to be identified said, “There is no work and most of our teachers sit in the staff room. We asked the administration to allow us to work from home but they said that teachers are being paid. But this is dangerous for our safety.”

In government schools too, teachers are made to come to work everyday though holidays have been declared. Many government schools have a teaching staff of more than 50 persons. The education authorities’ decision to call them to work violates government order about disallowing gatherings of above 50 persons.

School education minister Govind Singh Dotasra said that private schools were not under the government’s jurisdiction. “We cannot force private schools but they should understand the safety of teachers.” The minister added, “In government schools, the teachers may be given responsibility to spread awareness during the time of epidemic. We are thinking to divide teachers in different batches to be available in schools and avoid crowd gatherings. We cannot shut down the entire system as other departments are functioning as well.”

The situation was similar in city’s colleges. One private college, Bhawani Niketan College, Jaipur, has been calling teachers everyday for some work. When asked, the administration said that exams were going on and teachers were called for administering.

Meena Rathore, principal of the college said, “All the teachers were called due to the ongoing exams. Now, the university has declared postponement of exams, and we have followed the guidelines. The notification issued by education department was just to close down classes, but nothing was specified for the working of teachers. It is wrong and teachers must also be given relaxation for their security.”

Title: Anil Ambani quizzed by ED for 9 hrs in Yes Bank case
Content:
MUMBAI: Reliance Group chairman Anil Ambani was questioned for over nine hours by the Enforcement Directorate (ED) on Thursday in connection with a Rs 12,500-crore loan extended by Yes Bank to the Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Group (ADAG) companies, which went bad. Sources said he may be called for further questioning by March-end.

It is alleged that at the same time it received the loan, ADAG had given Rs 1,100 crore as loans to firms owned by Yes Bank promoter Rana Kapoor’s family members, a move that is suspected to be a quid pro quo arrangement.

A Reliance Group statement said Ambani met ED officials to clarify on the group’s exposure to Yes Bank. He reiterated that the Reliance Group’s entire exposure to Yes Bank is fully secured, and in compliance with laws and financial regulations.

“Ambani also clarified to the agency that Reliance Group has no direct or indirect exposure to Rana Kapoor or his wife or daughters, or any entities controlled by Rana Kapoor or his family. Reliance Group is committed to honour repayments of all its borrowings from Yes Bank through its various asset monetisation programmes,” the press note added.

The ED investigation is focusing on financial transactions and loans between Reliance Group companies, Yes Bank and companies associated with the Kapoor family. Sources said Yes Bank—then managed by Kapoor—sanctioned loans to ADAG companies till 2018 through it was in a financial crisis and some of its other loans had turned into non-performing assets (NPAs).

After that, ADAG companies were found to have given loans to Kapoor’s family companies in the form of debentures. ED alleged that Kapoor had formed 78 companies in the names of his wife Bindu and three daughters—Roshini Kapoor, Radha Kapoor Khanna and Raakhee Kapoor Tandon. Kapoor was managing all of them and allegedly received Rs 5,000 crore as bribe from companies that had borrowed nearly Rs 20,000 crore from Yes Bank that later turned into NPAs. ED has arrested Kapoor and he is now in its custody.

Title: Nagpur: Wives of cops working among masses concerned
Content:
Representative Image

NAGPUR: The family members of cops deployed at various places are concerned that the breadwinners of their home might be exposed to coronavirus infection if adequate preventive measures are not taken.

Cops are deployed among the unscreened masses on the streets, swarming litigants and others at courts, premises meant for the quarantined (MLA hostel), passengers arriving from international and national destinations and also at the government hospitals including Mayo Hospital where suspected and positive patients are present.

Cops are often spotted without masks or with only handkerchief wrapped around faces at public places. Though city police top brass has started distributing sanitizers and masks, TOI found many cops are yet to receive them.

Jyotsna Bhandarkar, wife of Tehsil police station’s senior inspector Jayesh in whose jurisdiction the Mayo hospital is located, says she can’t stop worrying. “He (Jayesh) cleans his hands and legs with disinfectants before entering the house and also takes other precautions. He is an officer but that does not make him any less human than others,” she said.

Mamta Deshmukh, wife of head constable Rajesh posted at Pachpaoli police station, says her husband has to take accused persons to Mayo hospital for medical examination on a regular basis. “We keep reminding him to follow personal hygiene and ensure his uniform and dresses are washed regularly,” she said.

Sunita Tiwari, wife of traffic constable Anil, who many times works close to the Government Medical College and Hospital , says the virus outbreak has posed a new challenge. “I try to keep my husband motivated. Many times, we remind him to carry sanitizer and mask. My husband has to speak to hundreds of strangers on the road. It’s not easy to use a mask while on the field,” she said.

DCP, headquarters, Vikram Sali said Rs1 lakh has been arranged from the welfare fund to purchase sanitizers and masks. “We have sent two reminders to the divisional commissioner’s office for a grant of Rs 20 lakh out of the Rs five crore government has sanctioned. The fund is for emergency needs of the constabulary like marriages, education and medical requirements. It would have been better had the government fund was available,” said the DCP.

Title: Cop suspended for beating a truck driver publicly
Content:
Agra: Mathura SSP Guarav Grover on Thursday suspended a sub-inspector (SI) for allegedly beating a truck driver publicly on Wednesday night for parking his vehicle on the wrong side of the road.

The action was taken after a video showing SI Mohit Kumar badly thrashing the man went viral on social media.

Talking to media, SSP Grover said the SI was suspended after the matter was found correct during an inquiry conducted by circle officer Govardhan.

“A departmental inquiry has also been marked against him. The inquiry against the SI was initiated after a video of the incident went viral on social media,” he said.

The officer further said he has directed his force not to misbehave with the public and warned of strict action if anyone is found violating his directions.

Title: Nirbhaya Case Hanging: Even on last day, Nirbhaya convicts kept hoping against hope
Content:
File photo of Nirbhaya convicts

NEW DELHI: A day before their scheduled execution, the four Nirbhaya convicts were anxious. They were eager to know about the plea filed for stay on hanging.

Jail officers had planned to keep an extra vigil on all four of them on Thursday night to ensure they don’t hurt themselves. All the staff, including the hangman, were counselled earlier in the day and their phones confiscated.

Sources said that the four convicts were also counselled. An excerpt from the Gita was read out to them and they were told about the karma.

“Pawan broke down after this and asked for forgiveness, while Mukesh kept on claiming that he was suffering for something he had not done. He blamed his past lives for this. Akshay said he had reformed himself and wanted to do something good for the society. Vinay was hopeful that the hanging would be stalled at the last moment,” a jail officer said.

On Thursday, the hangman conducted a dummy test using the actual hanging ropes.

As per schedule, all four convicts were handed at 5.30am on Friday inside Tihar jail.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Vacate hostels by 11am today: RU tells students
Content:
