Content: Pilibhit: Pilibhit district magistrate Vaibhav Shrivastav on Thursday set up a round-the-clock control room to respond to the queries of people regarding coronavirus.The helpline numbers of the control room is 7839853912 for mobile and 05882254116 for landline.Moreover, a 13-member ‘outbreak response committee’ (ORC), under the chairmanship of the district magistrate, has also been constituted to check the spread of coronavirus in district.Shrivastav said sub-divisional magistrate of Pilibhit sadar circle, Ram Swaroop, had been designated as the nodal officer for commanding the district control room, which will work 24/7.“These officials will attend all calls of public and would assist the people as per their need and urgency”, said the DM.He said the ORC has been comprised of members like chief medical officer Dr Seema Agarwal as the convener, superintendent of police Abhishek Dixt, chief development officer Shri Niwas Mishra, divisional forest officer of Pilibhit tiger reserve Naveen Khandelwal, district panchayat raj officer Pramod Yadav, executive officer of Pilibhit municipal council Nisha Mishra, district inspector of schools Sant Prakash, district information officer Narendra Kumar and the president of Indian medical association Dr Tarun Sethi.“The ORC would monitor both preventive and curative measures to combat novel coronavirus in the district,” said Dr Seema Agarwal, the chief medical officer and committee's convener.

Title: Water curbs in Panchavati, Makhmalabad
Content:
Nashik: There will be no water supply in parts of the Panchavati division on Friday due to repair works at the water treatment plant. The supply will resume on Saturday, but at a low pressure.

“There will be no water on Friday in parts of wards no 1, 4 and 6 in Panchavati division. The supply will be at low pressure on Saturday, but it will be normal from Sunday,” said the NMC. Also, there will be no water supply in Makhmalabad village on Saturday. It will be resume on Saturday, but at low pressure. The supply will be normal by Monday. tnn

Title: Centre gives Rs 1,051 crore less for GST loss compensation
Content:
Gandhinagar: The central government has given Rs 1,051 crore less compensation to the Gujarat government for its GST losses, the government informed in the assembly on Thursday. In a written response to a question by Congress MLA Imran Khedawala, finance minister Nitin Patel said the state government was supposed to receive Rs 11,474 crore as GST loss compensation between February 1, 2018 and January 31, 2019. However, the state received Rs 11,202.05 crore for this period from the central government. Similarly, the state government was supposed to receive Rs 14,451.59 crore for the period between February 1, 2019 and January 31, 2020, but it actually got Rs 13,663.20 crore as GST loss compensation during this period.

Patel said that the state government has written to the Union finance secretary and Union finance minister respectively, seeking the remaining amount.

Title: State govt’s public debt crosses Rs 2.40 lakh cr
Content:
Gandhinagar: In reply to a question in the ongoing session of the Gujarat assembly, the state government informed that according to the revised estimates of 2018-19, the public debt has crossed the Rs 2.40 crore mark.

In a written response, deputy chief minister Nitin Patel said, “In 2017-18 and 2018-19, total public debt remained at Rs 2.12 lakh crore and Rs 2.40 lakh crore respectively. During the same period, the government paid Rs17,146 crore and Rs 18,124 crore as interest payment respectively, while Rs 13,700 crore and Rs15,440 crore as repayment of principal for the years 2017-18 and 2018-19 respectively.

Patel added, “Generating public resources through debt for the state’s development is an accepted method. The state government has generated debt as approved by law.”

Title: More needed to curb Covid threat, Hyderabad IT workers say
Content: HYDERABAD: Despite the consistent rise in Covid-19 cases, many IT employees are still working out of their offices in Hyderabad. According to some employees, while a few companies asked their their staff to work from home, on Thursday, many others went about business as usual.Though companies are implementing measures to maintain high levels of hygiene at the workplace by making hand sanitizers available for everyone and screening their temperature, employees say that they are under constant risk as several offices are located in concentrated areas with thousands of employees in each building.“I don’t think just checking our temperature and providing hand sanitizers will stop the virus from spreading,” said an IT professional. Another employee said, “DLF building in Gachibowli sees huge crowds gathering at the canteen during lunch break. I think it is time all the IT companies make work-from-home mandatory for employees.”“Until last week, we wanted to run offices normally without creating a panic but we decided to give work-from-home to our employees since the past two days. While all the major companies are taking a decision based on corporate directives, small and medium companies might take time to follow, especially those who don’t have resources for work-from-home,” said HYSEA president, Ranga Pothula.

Title: Kerala CM announces Rs 500 crore for health sector to fight coronavirus
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: To tide over the economic crisis faced by Kerala due to Covid-19 situation, the government declared a stimulus package worth Rs 20 ,000 crore, of which Rs 500 crore would be exclusively set aside for the health sector Meanwhile, one more positive case was reported from Kasaragod on Thursday, taking the total number of infected persons to 25. This patient had returned from Dubai recently and was kept in isolation. Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said 31,173 persons were kept under observation, of which 237 are in designated isolation wards. Of the 2,921 samples sent for testing, 2,342 turned out to be negative.While detailing the stimulus package, Vijayan said Covid-19 threat had created a slowdown in the economy and there was a need for reviving it. The government decided to provide free ration (10kg/card) to all families in state irrespective of the APL-BPL divide for a month. The proposed scheme of providing Rs 25-meal, announced in the budget, will be implemented in April. The price of the meal will be reduced to Rs 20, considering the prevailing situation in state. In April, 1,000 canteens will be opened in Kerala, said the chief minister.For giving relaxation to those who are facing a crisis due to Covid-19 scare, Vijayan said the government is exploring the possibility of formulating a scheme to help taxi and auto drivers. The deadline for paying power and water bills will be extended for a month. Cinema theatres will be given relaxation on entertainment tax.Cooperative banks will provide moratorium for repayment of loans. Those who have repaid loans till January 31 will get an extension for repayment in the coming months, said minister Kadakampally Surendran, adding that banks won’t attach properties of defaulters.

Title: Coronavirus in Ahmedabad: Satellite girl suspected positive, NIV report awaited
Content: AHMEDABAD: Health authorities in Ahmedabad went on an overdrive on Thursday after a young girl, who had returned from the US two days ago, and belongs to Satellite area was suspected to be Covid-19 positive. Her blood samples were sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) for final verification and the results are expected on Friday.On Thursday, orders were issued by the state health authorities to the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) health officials for contact-tracing of the suspected positive case. A senior state health official told TOI that the girl is very co-operative and had responsibly observed home quarantine. “We checked her contact history and the girl had shown discipline. She has been moved to an isolation ward and her condition is being monitored closely,” said the official.Meanwhile, the state government has decided to crack the whip on persons reportedly flouting home quarantine rules and meeting people over the past couple of days. State health department officials said it has been decided to place such persons at government quarantine facilities for the stipulated period.Jai Prakash Shivahare, commissioner (health and family welfare), Gujarat, said there are increasing instances of persons flouting quarantine rules after returning from abroad. “On Wednesday alone, there were seven such cases identified by local governing bodies,” he said.The health commissioner said they are initiating a move under which such persons will not be allowed self-quarantine after a breach. “They will have to be shifted to a government-run quarantine facility and will have to spend the stipulated time there. Their family members could also be put under quarantine if needed,” said Shivahare.Deputy municipal commissioner Om Prakash said, “We deployed personnel to each of those asked to quarantine themselves at home. If they refuse to cooperate, we will seek help from the police to send such individuals to isolation at the nearest government facility.”

Title: Previous reservation roster for direct recruitment reinstated in Uttarakhand
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: A day after passing orders for ending promotion in reservation which had antagonised the SC/ST community , the Uttarakhand cabinet took a major step of going back to the previous roster for direct recruitment on government jobs.

As part of this, the first vacancy in a post will be for SC candidates and the sixth for general candidate.

On the recommendation of a committee headed by transport minister Yashpal Arya , the state in September 2019 had announced a new roster for direct recruitment according to which, the first position was given to general candidate, whereas sixth went to SC category. This led to a protest by the SC category, who termed it an attempt to sideline them in government jobs. After much hue and cry, the state government had formed a sub-committee headed by urban development minister Madan Kaushik . On the recommendation of the sub-committee, the state has reverted back to the previous order by overruling the change made last year.

“The cabinet has given its approval to the change made by the sub-committee, from now on SC will be the first vacancy and general goes to sixth slot,” urban development minister and government spokesperson Madan Kaushik said on Thursday. He added that the authorities have been asked to fill the backlog in government jobs at the earliest. The state cabinet has also given approval for the remaining part of budget session to be held at Dehradun . The budget session from March 3 to March 7 was held at Bhararisain in Gairsain area of Chamoli district . The remaining session – from March 25 to March 27 – would be held at Dehradun.

Title: Rubber factory tigress may be tranquilized this week: Foresters
Content:
Bareilly: With the installation of 27 camera traps in the defunct rubber factory , 18 km from Bareilly city, a team of experts comprising forest officials, a veterinarian, WWF-India and WTI members, are closely monitoring the movement of a stray adult tigress which has made the campus its home. Officials said once the team learns all the spots the tigress frequents within the factory, they will tranquilize it. The task will be undertaken in two days’ time.

Chief conservator of forests, Rohilkhand zone, Lalit Verma, said, “We are tracking the movement of the tigress and when we will know about all the locations it prefers to stay in, we will tranquilize the big cat. We also found the pugmarks of the tigress at the spot where a sub-adult tiger was tranquilized nearly two years ago.”

Officials said RK Singh, a veterinarian from Kanpur zoo, will tranquilizing the tigress. Besides, the forest department has placed three cages with bait in the factory to lure the big cat.

Apart from images of the tigress, the camera trap installed in the factory has captured the photos of many species showing the rich wildlife in the factory premises. The photos of nilgai, porcupine, jungle cat, hare, peacock and monkeys have been caught in the camera traps.

The Synthetic and Chemical Limited Company, commonly known as rubber factory here, spanning nearly 1,200 acres, was closed in 1999. Over the years, it has turned into a mini-forest providing a perfect habitat for big cats due to easy availability of prey, plenty of water in big tanks, dense tree cover, soft grass and suitable places to hide.

Apart from a tiger and a tigress, a leopard too lived in the rubber factory for almost two years. Forest officials suspect that it was same that leopard which was run over by a heavy vehicle on February 24 on the road outside the factory.

Title: Screening centres to come up at bus stands, rly stations
Content:
Aurangabad: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) will facilitate screening booths at the Aurangabad and Mukundwadi railway stations as well as Cidco and Central bus stands. These booths will be manned by health workers of the civic body.

They will screen the incoming passengers for Covid-19 symptoms. Municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey visited the Aurangabad railway station, Central Bus Stand and Cidco bus stand along with municipal officer of health Nita Padalkar and city engineer Sakharam Panzade.

Pandey told TOI that the centres will be established at the said centres along with Nagar Naka (toll at Pune highway) in Aurangabad.

“Each centre will be equipped with a medical officer and health workers. The centres will be responsible for conducting primary screening of people coming to the city from Pune, Nashik, Mumbai, Nagpur and Shirdi. The health department has been instructed to purchase thermometers or temperature guns with the National Urban Health Mission funds,” he said.

Pandey said that this measure will detect any possible coronavirus suspects who have not been identified in cities having international arrivals.

Padalkar said that the screening will immediately begin at all the specified points.

Meanwhile, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele held a meeting with members of traders association, cloth merchant, chemist and druggist association, Rotary Club and Lions Club on Tuesday. The AMC sought cooperation of different stakeholders in ensuring supplies of masks, sanitizers and other measures for prevention of coronavirus in the city.

Title: 90% students living in hostels have vacated, says Bamu VC
Content:
Aurangabad: Around 90% of the students living in hostels of the Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University (Bamu) have been vacated.

The state-run university with students from across Marathwada saw cancellation of classes and postponement of exams after the state government’s directive to shut down all educational institutes till March 31.

In order to stop further spread of coronavirus, the Bamu administration asked the hostel inmates to go home for the next two weeks.

Subsequently, the students have started to vacate their rooms. Speaking during a press conference organised on Tuesday, Bamu vice-chancellor Pramod Yeole said that 90% of the hostels have been vacated.

“The remaining students are either awaiting reservations on trains or are not able to go home due to some or the other reasons. There are 12 hostels on Bamu premises of which 7 are for women and 5 for men,” he said.

Owing to the movement of students, heavy rush was witnessed at the state transport bus stands on Tuesday. In addition, the Bamu administration has also shut down its libraries and reading rooms until March 31.

The VC said the university has restricted entry of visitors to the administrative building and thermal screening will soon be initiated.

Title: Will sell masks, hand sanitisers at lower prices, say Pilibhit chemist association
Content: Pilibhit: Following the suggestion of the district magistrate, the chemist association in Pilibhit on Thursday decided to sell masks and hand sanitizers at prices lower than the retail cost.In a meeting called by the association’s district president, Raghvendra Nath Mishra, a consensus was formed to add only 10% margin to the distributor cost of the two products in order to cover expenses like inward freight, taxes and transport etc.Mishra said, “We are forsaking our profit in the national interest in the backdrop of novel coronavirus outbreak.”DM Vaibhav Shrivastav’s suggestion came after the city magistrate, Arun Kumar Singh, along with the drug inspector, Babita Rani, raided two medical stores on Wednesday evening following complaints of overpricing of masks and hand sanitizers.However, the owner of one the medical stores, where the raid was conducted, claimed that he was selling the masks and sanitizers at a discount.“I was selling sanitizers for Rs 150, even though the retail cost of it is Rs 175. It seems that the city magistrate had some misunderstanding. I will approach the official and clear his misconception,” said Kohali.However, the city magistrate said the administration is probing the matter and a final action would be taken soon.Reacting to the raids, the association’s district president, Mishra said, “We could have announced a strike across the district in protest against the action of the city magistrate and his misconception about the overpricing. But we decided not to hit the streets in view of the public interest. However, we will be forced to take a harsh decision in case the two medical store owners are not given clean chit soon.”Notably, the Centre had on March 13 declared face masks and hand sanitizers as essential commodities for the next 100 days to boost supply and prevent hoarding of these items.The Centre also invoked the Disaster Management Act to ensure the price regulation and availability of surgical and protective masks, hand sanitizer and gloves.

Title: 3 fined Rs 1,000 for spitting in public
Content:
Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) on Thursday slapped a fine of Rs 1,000 each on three people for spitting in public places.

The action was taken by divisional offices of the NMC on the very first day after civic chief Radhakrishna Game issued a circular for slapping fines on erring citizens found spitting in public places in view of the outbreak of Covid-19.

The municipal commissioner has given powers to divisional officers (Dos), divisional sanitation inspectors (DSIs) and sanitation inspectors (SIs) to impose fine on those who are found spitting at public places.

Accordingly, an NMC squad caught two people in Nashik Road area and one person in Nashik East division for spitting in public places. “We recovered a fine of Rs 3,000 from them,” a civic official said.

“We have decided to intensify the drive against spitting. We have made a team of our officials and employees who will be deployed in civil clothes at crowded places like bus stands, markets etc. They will impose fine of Rs 1,000 on those found spitting in public places,” he added.

Apart from this, the NMC has also directed to shut down box cricket venues in the city and a fine of Rs 5,000 will be imposed on those flouting this norm.

Title: Quarantine at pvt facilities: Govt to bear expenses
Content:
Gandhinagar: Following the uproar created by those who flew in from overseas and complained of sub-standard quarantine facilities at government hospitals, the state government on Thursday said that it will bear the costs for quarantine of passengers who prefer to remain under observation at private hospitals or even hotels.

State deputy chief minister and health minister Nitin Patel, in the state assembly, said that the state government will bear the costs for international passengers opting for quarantine at private facilities such as hotels or the like. Patel said the government is working out a mechanism through which it can bear these costs.

“Considering representations made by persons advised to remain quarantined, the government has decided to keep them at the private hotels before they are allowed to go for home quarantine,” Patel said.

Title: Overflowing sewage in Kanak Chowk poses threat to two-wheelers
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: The rains have gone but overflowing sewage at Kanak Chowk, near Parade Ground, continues to pose a deadly threat to motor vehicles, especially two-wheelers. The sewage has given rise to craters not only on main roads but also in the interior ones, which witness a heavy traffic flow throughout the day.

Speaking to TOI, Sunil Verma , a commuter , said, “The water overflowing from the sewerage is dangerous for car owners and pedestrians but especially lethal for two-wheelers. Moreover, the overflowing sewage is forcing people to drive on the wrong side in one-way roads, which may lead to accidents . I hope authorities get it fixed soon.”

KL Dhyani, another commuter who owns a shop on EC road, said, “The roads are in extremely poor condition and show utter lack of maintenance. It will possibly remain like this for years unless a serious accident takes place.”

As a temporary fix, the civic body has filled the craters with bricks and cement tiles. According to sources, this has only made the situation worse as the tiles and bricks make the vehicles more prone to accidents.

Darshanlal Chowk has a similar situation, where water becomes stagnant after rains. Local residents say that standing water in the place is an indictment of the civic body’s preparedness for the rainy season.

Keval Mandhani, a commuter, said “The corners of the road are no different from mini pools. Though the rains had lashed the city four days ago, the water is still here. The stagnant rain water is not only a source of infections, but can also result in road accidents.”

A PWD official meanwhile told TOI, “The maintenance of the road will be carried out soon. As of now, development works under the smart city project are underway. As soon as the area is cleared, the roads will be in good condition.”

Title: Coronavirus in Gujarat: Rajkot man, Surat woman test positive for Covid-19
Content: RAJKOT/SURAT/GANDHINAGAR: Gujarat joined the list of states battling Covid-19 cases after a 32-year-old man in Rajkot and a 21-year-old woman in Surat tested positive for the virus on Thursday.In Surat, the 21-year-old woman had landed in Mumbai from London on March 13 and reached Surat on March14. She was admitted in the isolation ward of the New Civil Hospital after she complained of severe cough, fever and cold on March 16. She was studying in London.The Rajkot man had landed in Mumbai from Mecca on March 7 along with 10 others and they reached the city by Bandra-Jamnagar Saurashtra Janta Express on March 8. As many as 16 persons who were in contact with him including his relatives have been quarantined and put under observation at a special facility set up at Pathik Ashram on Jamnagar Road.Meanwhile, top health officials confirmed that two more suspected positive cases have been reported. This includes a young girl from Ahmedabad who has returned from the US. She had quarantined herself at home but was hospitalised after she developed COVID-19 symptoms.Senior health officials said that samples of both the cases have been sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV) for final confirmation.The man started taking treatment from a general physician after he had high fever, uneasiness and breathing difficulty. However, on Tuesday night, he was admitted to isolation ward in Rajkot Civil Hospital as his condition deteriorated. His samples were sent to the government-designated laboratory in Jamnagar and later to National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, which confirmed on Thursday that he had been infected.“The man’s condition is stable. He is a tailor by profession,” official sources said. The health department is also trying to find out other passengers who travelled with this man in the same coach from Mumbai.Rajkot district health officer Dr Manish Bhanderi told TOI, “In all, there were 68 people in the coach. Of these, 15 were residents of Rajkot while 45 others have either returned to Mumbai or deboarded before Rajkot. We have contacted these 60 people and they are not ill. However, five passengers are incommunicado while three had given the number of their booking agents.”Municipal health officer Dr Pankaj Rathod said “We will personally visit all these persons and check their health status.” Municipal commissioner Udit Agrawal has urged people to inform on helpline numbers about people who have returned from foreign trips and assured that detail of the callers will be kept confidential.In Surat, the 21-year-old woman had landed in Mumbai from London on March 13 and reached Surat on March 14. She was admitted in the isolation ward of the New Civil Hospital after she complained of severe cough, fever and cold on March 16. She was studying in London.“We have shifted eight of her close contacts including parents to a special quarantine facility,’’ Banchhanidhi Pani, municipal commissioner, Surat, told TOI.Surat police commissioner on Thursday clamped prohibitory orders banning gathering of four or more people in public places under section 144 of IPC. Surat has already shut down all educational institutions, multiplexes, malls, universities, gardens and other public places.Authorities are already on their toes given the proximity of Surat to Mumbai, which is worst-affected by the pandemic.“As on Thursday, we have a total 419 people are under home quarantine and their health is being closely monitored. If these people are found violating laid down norms, they will be compulsorily shifted to SMC’s quarantine facilities,’’ Pani said.Dr Ashish Naik, deputy municipal commissioner, health, said if any of the close contacts of the woman show symptoms of nCovid-19, their samples were sent for testing to Ahmedabad.

Title: Civic body betters last year’s property tax collection by 32%
Content:
Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) property tax collection figure till March 19 has reached Rs 140 crore, 32% more than the collection figure during the same period last year.

In the last fiscal, the civic body had collected Rs 106 crore till March 19. An NMC official said the civic body had planned to touch the Rs 150 crore-mark by this time, but collection was affected owing to the Yes Bank crisis and the Covid-19 outbreak.

“The NMC had tied up with Yes Bank for online collection of property and water taxes. Taxes were also being collected at 22 civic facilitations centres across six divisions of municipal corporation by the private bank,” the official said.

“Owing to the coronavirus spread, the number of people coming to pay their taxes in the NMC’s divisional offices has also dropped,” he added.

In the last financial year (2018-19), the NMC had collected property tax amounting to Rs 113 crore. That was the first time the NMC’s property tax collection target had breached the Rs 100 crore-mark.

The current property tax collection figure of Rs 140 crore is the highest ever.

Initially, the NMC had set a property tax collection target of Rs 218 crore for the current financial year (2019-20), but later revised it to Rs 150 crore.

The NMC had also launched amnesty schemes on two occasions during the current financial year for property tax defaulters. As per the scheme, the penalty and other charges were waived up to 75% for defaulters who cleared their total tax dues.

Through these amnesty schemes the civic body managed to collect over Rs 50 crore. Moreover, it had also issued warrants to major tax defaulters and had also the properties of some defaulters for auction. This overall led to rise in property tax collection for the NMC.

The civic body has also decided to give a 5% rebate to prompt tax payers if they pay their annual property tax during the first quarter of the new financial year.

Accordingly, 5% rebate is to be given to tax payers who pay their bills in April, 3% if they make the payment in May and 2% if payment is cleared in June.

Title: Covid-19: Gated communities in Hyderabad go all out to keep virus at bay
Content: HYDERABAD: With thousands of people living in gated communities and apartment complexes, managements are putting in stringent measures to tackle the Covid-19 outbreak. From cancelling Sri Rama Navami celebrations to thermal screening of maids and drivers, they are leaving no stone unturned.At My Home Jewel, Miyapur , the management issued a circular about entry of visitors from outside. “If you or your family are visiting from any foreign country and arrive at my home jewel (sic), please reach out to management committee by sending email or calling help desk. You would be required to quarantine yourself for 14 days. Security might deny entry to several common locations in our premises,” read the letter by the management committee.It further said that “All Vasantha Navarathri Celebrations for this year stand cancelled”. The driver’s cabin was off limits, and drivers were asked to instead remain in their private vehicles.“Maids and staff members are being screened for flu like symptoms,” said Nanda Kishore, a resident adding that these measures were necessary in tough times, especially since the community houses 2016 flats. Not just here, but in Bloomfield Ecstasy in Tellapur, too, house help were being scanned.Ramana Eshwaragiri, from Bloomfield Ecstasy, said, “We have decided to stop entry of all outside visitors in the community till March 31. Only maintenance staff such as house maids, drivers are being allowed, that too after thermal screening, which is done at the gate.”In the wake of articles on currency being a carrier of the virus, Shakuntla Hooda, resident, Aparna Lake Breeze, Chandanagar , said, “In our apartment complex, online payments have been made mandatory to avoid huge gatherings at the admin office.” The community has 943 flats and like others, common areas have been cordoned.MyGate app, used by several apartment complexes, to allow entry of outsiders, has also issued “Emergency Management Plan for gated communities”. Besides suggesting closure of common spaces, it suggests to “Avoid using biometrics for access till the situation is under control. This will help in reducing the spread.” It has also introduced a ‘Collect Parcel at Gate’ feature to avoid entry of delivery boys into the premises.

Title: Sanitation workers get training
Content:
Aurangabad: The sanitation workers of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) are being trained to take necessary precautions while collecting and transporting waste. The use of mask and gloves has been made mandatory.

The AMC has roped in private agency, which collects waste generated at households and commercial establishments and transports it to the waste sites at Padegaon and Chikalthana. The agency has vehicles which go from lane to lane.

In addition, the AMC has engaged another private agency, which carries out processing of waste at Chikalthana and Padegaon sites through its ground staff. These workers are also in direct contact with waste.

According to zone 2 sanitation inspector Sachin Misal, the household waste includes dry waste, wet waste and medical waste which comes in the category of hazardous waste. “In order to ensure that sanitation workers do not contract any infection from hazardous waste, it is important that they are equipped with safety gear,” he said.

According to head of solid waste management cell of AMC Nandkishore Bhombe, it is to use safety gear for sanitation workers. “We had found that sanitation staff working for doorstep waste collection, transportation and processing were working without safety gear. Subsequently, last week we issued directives to the two agencies to see to it that the sanitation staff who come in direct contact of hazardous waste are providing masks, gloves, gumboots, safety cap and other safety equipment,” Bhombe said. He added that if the directive is violated the agencies will be penalised Rs 100 for each worker working without safety gear.

In addition, the AMC has allowed ward offices of all nine zones in the city to use Rs 1 lakh each for making purchase of personal protective equipment for sanitation workers under AMC with the approval of zone’s guardian officer.

Bhombe said that in wake of government guidelines against large assembly of people, the civic body has asked sanitation inspectors to hold trainings at their level in each zone to advice workers to take necessary precautions while handling waste.

Title: Pithoragarh-Tanakpur national highway blocked again due to landslide
Content:
Representative image

PITHORAGARH: Barely a few hours after the vehicular movement was restored on the Pithoragarh-Tanakpur road (National Highway-9), the stretch was closed again on Thursday due to landslide.

On Wednesday night, the NH-9 was blocked at Delhi Band due to landslide, cutting off Pithoragarh from Tanakpur and Haldwani.

Supply of essential commodities like fruits and vegetables to Pithorgarh was also affected. The officials had taken 19 hours to remove the boulders.

“Incessant rainfall may have led to the massive landslide. Large chunks of boulders have blocked the road again. We will try to open the stretch by Friday evening,” Vijay Kumar Jogdande , district magistrate (DM), Pithoragarh, said.

“We have informed the district administrations of Champawat and Nainital. The vehicle movement towards Pithoragarh will be stopped. We request the commuters to take an alternative route, i.e. theHaldwani-Seraghat route to reach Pithorgarh,” the DM added.

The road cutting work is being undertaken on the Pithoragarh-Tanakpur road, under the All-Weather Char Dham project. Officials say the road cutting work may have been causing frequent landslides at the Delhi Band route. “The rocks at Delhi Band are loose. Hence due to rock cutting, landslides have been occurring. JCB machines have been deployed, hope the boulder gets cleared by Friday evening,” said PL Chaudhari, assistant engineer, National Highway-9.

Title: Dehradun: Situation reversed; both sides still annoyed
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: In a short span of 48 hours, the Uttarakhand government took two major decisions. First was to part with reservation in promotions and the second was to reinstate the previous reservation roster for direction recruitment in government jobs. While the first has annoyed the SC/ST employees , the second has not gone well with the General and OBC employees. Both sides have warned strong protest and said that “the decision was against them.”

The SC/ST employees held an emergency meeting on Thursday in which it was decided to hold a state-level meeting on March 22 to discuss the format of protest.

SC/ST State Employees Federation president Karam Ram Singh said that the employees of reserved category have been cheated. He pointed out that they had left it on the state government to decide on the matter but now felt let down by the decision that was taken.

Title: Uttarakhand Kranti Dal members join AAP in Dehradun
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: Several members of Uttarakhand Kranti Dal (UKD) joined the Uttarakhand unit of Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) in Dehradun on Thursday. Among them is Raju Maurya, who had contested some elections on the UKD ticket, the latest being in the 2017 assembly elections, when he contested from the Devaprayag constituency. Maurya also held an important organisational post in UKD.

Apart from Maurya, several other members of UKD also joined AAP on Thursday. Party memberships were handed over by the AAP state in-charge Dinesh Mohaniya .

“We are glad that more and more people are joining our party in Uttarakhand. Our party is the third alternative this state needs, and people know it’s AAP alone that can deliver on its promises. The state’s education and health sectors need a facelift immediately. Anybody who wishes to join our party is welcome, but they should not be any of the 3Cs — corrupt, criminal or communal,” said Mohaniya.

The party also released a new helpline number for AAP’s membership drive, specifically meant for people of Uttarakhand. “We have released a new helpline number (7669007669) for people to gain party membership. This number is meant only for people of Uttarakhand. The previous number had a different telephone circle, which included a part of western UP. This new one will help us get to know the exact figures for Uttarakhand,” said Mohaniya.

Title: Concerns raised over land-filling at Fatorda
Content:
COLVA: Land-filling in a low-lying area at Fatorda for a proposed hockey ground has raised eyebrows over the manner in which the activity is being carried out.

Since Saturday morning, a number of trucks were seen transporting residual matter from the decades-old legacy garbage dump at Sonsoddo and is being dumped in an area behind the indoor badminton auditorium at Fatorda, while an excavator was deployed to level the ground.

A newly-printed flex board was also displayed at the location, identifying it as the ‘proposed site for hockey ground on land allotted to Goans Hockey - By directorate of sports and youth affairs.’

Former Margao municipality chairperson and member of Shadow Council, Savio Coutinho said the contractor undertaking the work is not following proper methods for land filling, and expressed concern that this could lead to pollution of groundwater resources.

When contacted, Margao Muncipal Council (MMC) chief officer Ajit Panchwadkar said the municipality had received a proposal and had written to Goa Pollution Control Board in this regard. However, they were yet to receive authorisation to carry out the work, and added that he was unaware when the land-filling activity had started.

However, sources in the Goa State Pollution Control Board (GSPCB) said that permission has been granted to MMC. On whether the disposal of waste residue is being undertaken in a scientific manner at the location, the official said tests were conducted and reports have been presented to the HC.

Title: Vadodara: Cheater priest in jail now arrested for rape
Content:
Dr Prashant Upadhyay

VADODARA: Prashant Upadhyay, priest of Shri Baglamukhi Brahmastra Vidya Mandir, was arrested on Wednesday from Vadodara Central Jail for allegedly raping a married woman repeatedly since November 2016.

Gotri police arrested Upadhyay after a local court gave a go-ahead. Upadhyay was lodged in jail in connection with two cheating cases registered against him at Warasia and Gotri police stations.

On Thursday, he was presented before a judicial magistrate’s court which remanded him to police custody till March 23.

Police said that during custody period the priest will be interrogated to find if he had raped any other women followers of his under similar pretext. He will also be questioned if any of his aides were involved in the crime too or not. Upadhyay will also be taken to SSG Hospital for his medical check-up.

A 28-year-old woman had approached Gotri police station on March 17 with a complaint that Upadhyay raped her at his house in Gotri till December last year. The woman was afraid that she will be defamed so she did not tell anyone about her ordeal for all these years. Upadhyay had promised her that she will attain a form of ‘devi’ when she had told him about his household conflicts during one of his sermon sessions.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Yogi Adityanath takes report card of his 3-year Uttar Pradesh rule to PM, home minister
Content:
The CM had released booklets on work in each constituency

LUCKNOW: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Thursday met Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Delhi and discussed the work done by his government in the three years that it has been in power in UP.

He also presented the PM with special booklets published to mark the government’s third anniversary. These booklets outline the work done by the five MLAs whose constituencies fall within Modi’s parliamentary constituency of Varanasi.

“The two leaders met at 5pm and discussed, among other things, the completion of the BJP government’s three years in UP and the way forward. Booklets detailing the work done by respective MLAs and MPs in the past three years have been published for each assembly constituency. The CM presented five of these, which come under Varanasi, to the PM,” said a government official.

Later, the CM caught about 15 minutes of the PM’s address to the nation on coronavirus outbreak as he was scheduled to meet home minister Amit Shah at 8.30pm. Sources said that he saw the first 15 minutes of the address at UP Bhawan, after which he left for his meeting but was subsequently updated in detail about the announcements made by Modi.

“In his meeting with the home minister, the CM presented him too with booklets of some constituencies. Thereafter, he held a meeting with BJP national general secretary (organisation) B L Santosh and was also expected to meet party national president J P Nadda later at night. Deputy chief minister Dinesh Sharma , who was also in Delhi on Thursday, was part of some of the meetings,” said the official.

The CM had left for Delhi at 12.30pm on Thursday, after two meetings in Lucknow on coronavirus outbreak.

In Delhi, ahead of his meeting with the PM, Yogi also met officials from Noida and Ghaziabad while keeping constant tabs on the coronavirus updates in UP and across the world.

Title: Six ejected from Rajdhani in Surat
Content:
Surat: Six passengers from Dubai and France having ‘home quarantine’ stamp on their hands were deboarded from Rajdhani Express at Surat railway station after train staff and passengers raised an alarm on Thursday.

Official sources said checking staff of Rajdhani Express were alerted by passengers in B-7 coach after they found six people travelling with home quarantine stamp on their hands. The checking staff immediately alerted headquarters in Mumbai and the passengers were asked to deboard at Surat railway station at about 7.51pm.

C R Garuda, area railway manager, told TOI, “The checking staff of Rajdhani Express asked the passengers with home quarantine tag to deboard at Surat station, but they refused. The train had to be halted for 12 minutes, instead of its departure time of five minutes. Finally, the passengers agreed to deboard and the health department of SMC was informed.” Garuda added, “The passengers were travelling from Mumbai Central to New Delhi. Three passengers are students in France and were going to Himachal Pradesh, while the rest included two women and a senior citizen of a family.”

Garuda said the passengers were screened at Mumbai international airport where they were found negative for coronavirus. However, they were advised home quarantine for 14 days.

Official sources said the six passengers were taken to a quarantine facility set up by the civic body at Samras hostel of Veer Narmad South Gujarat University.

Title: Five loan sharks booked for suicide abetment
Content:
Rajkot: Five loan sharks were booked on Wednesday night for allegedly driving a 34-year-old man to commit suicide.

Police said the accused, Amit Khakhar, Ashish Gadhvi, Himanshu Ahir, Ram Bharwad and their unidentified accused, were booked for the suicide abetment of Baiju Anadkat.

Anadkat had ended his life by consuming pesticide at Aji Dam-3 near Padadhari of Rajkot district on March 5.

“The accused were booked on the complaint of Anadkat’s younger brother Prashant, who said that the accused were harassing Anadkat for the recovery of a loan, the amount of which he did not know,” said an official from Padadhari police station.

After consuming pesticide, Anadkat called up Prashant and told him that he was trapped in the viscous circle of loan and was being constantly harassed by the accused.

Title: Lucknow: LMC may mop up Rs 300 crore tax target, first in 10 years
Content: LUCKNOW: For the first time in 10 years, the possibility of Lucknow Municipal Corporation achieving its tax collection target looks real.Of the Rs 300crore target for 2019-20 fiscal, LMC has been able to collect Rs 245 crore till Monday.With the year to end on March 31, about Rs 71 crore is pending with six government departments — estate (Rs 36 crore), home (Rs 5 crore), Lucknow Development Authority (Rs 14 crore), public works (Rs 6 crore), revenue (Rs 5 crore) and Lucknow Electricity Supply Administration (Rs 5 crore). On Monday, LMC sent notices to these departments to make payment by March 31. “If we don’t receive the tax amount by the deadline, we ask the state government to intervene,” said an official. However, Lesa chief engineer, finance, IM Kaushal, who said, “We do not owe anything to LMC and will talk to its officials to the issue.” LDA vice-chairperson Shiwa Kant Dwivedi said, “The finance department has been directed to make the payment to the civic body by the end of the month.”PWD chief engineer Rajpal Singh was not available for comments. The pending amount of Rs 71 crore exceeds the target deficit amount because LMC has set a reduced amount as its goal.LMC finance officer Mahamilind Lal said, “The total amount that LMC can collect in taxes is Rs 450 crore. Earlier, we could not even achieve the reduced target. This year, there has been remarkable improvement. Hence, the target set for 2020-21 is Rs 400 crore.”“The target was kept lower in view of the collection records, lack of hands and infrastructure,” he said.

Title: Cops misled, find no quarantine breach
Content:
Ahmedabad: AMC and police officials on Thursday followed up a tip-off that two persons supposed to be in home quarantine were moving around, only to find that both were at their homes. The two concerned persons had arrived from the USA with their families on March 14, and were supposed to be quarantined at home for 28 days. They live in the same neighbourhood. On Wednesday, authorities received calls from neighbours of the two persons that they were seen outside their homes and it posed a risk to public health. Accordingly, AMC officials went to city police chief Ashish Bhatia on Thursday morning asking him to take action.

Police immediately went to the given addresses but found both persons at their homes. “They told us that they had never stepped out of their homes, but somebody called up AMC’s health officials to give false information. The AMC health officers then counselled them on the dangers of moving about,” said a police official.

Police officials said the task of apprehending quarantine patients moving outside home has been given to the city crime branch, which has formed teams for the purpose.

Title: Govt mulls tracking with bracelets, phones
Content:
Ahmedabad: Among complaints of people not respecting the home quarantine protocol, senior health officials in Gandhinagar discussed with a few municipal corporations the feasibility of using trackable wristbands — linked to a mobile phone app — for those who are supposed to be in quarantine.

Such white wristbands or bracelets were used in Hong Kong to track international passengers who entered the city and were advised to be in quarantine. These bracelets are linked to a mobile application on the quarantined person’s phone and not a GPS and will alert authorities if the person moves 65 or 100 metres beyond the phone device. “There are issues of privacy with the trackable bracelets, but on the other hand the bracelet can be pulled and removed. The trackable bracelet option is being examined right now,” said a senior health official under conditions of anonymity. Also another effective method is mobile phone number location tracking of those quarantined.

Title: MoUs inked with foreign varsities through video calls
Content:
The MoUs were signed on Thursday

Vadodara: MS University (MSU) signed five memorandums of understanding (MoU) with universities in Germany, Japan, Zimbabwe, Australia and Kyrgyzstan on Thursday to promote students and teachers exchange programs.

It was the first time that MSU inked the MoUs through Skype calls because of coronavirus pandemic.

MSU’s Institute of Fashion Technology signed the MoU with Kyrgyz State University of Construction, Transport and Architechture, Kyrgyzstan in area of clothing and textile. Similarly, another MoU was signed between the science faculty and Hiroshima University’s Graduate School of Science. Other MoUs were signed with La Trobe University of Australia, Chinhoyi University of Technology of Zimbabwe and Universität Regensburg of Germany. “The MoUs with universities from Kyrgyzstan and Hiroshima are for specific areas of studies while the other MoUs are for all faculties of the university. These MoUs will encourage students exchange program under which their credits will also be transferred and also teachers exchange program,” said professor Dhanesh Patel, director of MSU’s Office of International Affairs.

University officials said that the administration was working on these programs for long time but due to coronavirus, the MoUs could not signed in person. But with the help of video calling facilities, MSU officials could interact with heads of foreign universities and finalize the MoUs.

Title: 17-year-old youth stabbed to death for resisting robbery attempt, 1 held
Content:
Aurangabad: A 17-year old youth was stabbed to death after he resisted a robbery attempt by two suspects at a ground in the Mhada colony on Monday night.

Sources in the police said that the incident was captured on a CCTV camera installed in a nearby locality.

Taking help of the CCTV footage, teams from the crime branch launched a manhunt for the suspects and arrested one of them from his residence within eight hours of the alleged crime around 4am on Tuesday. .

The arrested suspect has been identified as Imran Amir Baig (25), a resident of Kabranagar. He is a scrap trader by profession. Police is still looking for the second suspect.

The deceased has been identified as Akshay Pradhan, a junior college student who was pursuing his studies in Aurangabad.

Police said that Akshay, along with his friend Amey Bhosle, also a 17-year-old student, was sitting at a ground in the Mhada colony around 8.30pm on Monday. The suspects, who were on a motorcycle, approached them. They tried to rob the teenagers by threatening them.

While Amey readily gave his wallet, which contained Rs 400 in cash to the suspects, Akshay resisted them. A scuffle broke out between them and the suspects stabbed Akshay with a sharp-edged weapon before fleeing.

Akshay was rushed to a private hospital, where he was declared brought dead. Amey lodged a complaint at the Jawaharnagar police station. An offence has been registered against the suspects on the charges of murder, armed robbery and voluntarily causing hurt.

Crime branch inspector Anil Gaikwad said the victim and the suspects were not known to each other. Therefore, it is an uphill task for them to identify the suspects and arrest them.

Title: Curbing spread: After ‘work from home’, it’s ‘pray from home’
Content:
Aurangabad: Religious leaders have been advised to convince members of their respective communities they lead to observe prayers at homes, instead of gathering at religious places and shrines in Auranagbad district.

The latest decision was taken by the district administration here on Tuesday, and communication to this effect has been issued to the clergy. A public notice will also be issued.

Aurangabad district collector Uday Choudhari told TOI, “We have taken the decision and accordingly are issuing an advisory to religious leaders and clergy asking them to convince their followers to hold prayers at their respective homes, instead of gathering at the religious places.”

The communication would be specially marked to those heading temples trusts, mosques, churches, gurudwaras, Baudha vihars, which witness high footfall.

Going a step ahead, the Aurangabad district administration has advised citizens to refrain from organising wedding functions or other celebrations that gather a large number of people in a common space. When contacted, Aurangabad municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey said, “We are shutting down all the marriage and functional halls from Wednesday. The orders in this regard are in being passed.”

Nanded district collector Vipin Itankar too has asked the marriage function halls to abstain from renting out their premises for social events. He even warned of stringent action against the hall managements for violating the new norms.

Authorities at the revenue divisional commissionerate too confirmed that the orders on similar lines are being issued to the remaining six districts of the Marathwada region.

Title: Goa: Road accidents up in Dec & Jan, but fewer deaths
Content:
Representational image

PANAJI: December last year and January 2020 saw over 50 more road accidents than November 2019. Statistics shared by the directorate of transport revealed that a total of 351 road accidents were reported in the peak tourist month of December 2019, and 342 in January 2020. November saw 285 road accidents.

“There is an increasing number of vehicles in the state,” said head of the Goa road safety forum, Dilip Naik . “This, coupled with the lack of stringent checks by traffic police and untrained young drivers that are liberally given licenses after a basic driving test, makes road safety a serious concern.”

Figures revealed that most deaths, yet again, were those of two-wheeler riders. A total of 20 riders each lost their lives in road fatalities in December and January. Pedestrians and pillion riders also came in the line of fire with an average of six people from this category losing their lives in these months.

However, slightly fewer people lost their lives due to road accidents in the two months. Compared to November, which witnessed 29 deaths, there were 26 deaths in December and 27 deaths in January.

Title: ‘SEC letter’ creates ripple, Jagan angry over its content
Content:
A 10-member CRPF team now provides a security ring to the SEC.

VIJAYAWADA: After a ‘fake’ letter addressed to the Union home ministry, allegedly written by Andhra Pradesh election commissioner N Ramesh Kumar surfaced online, the state government is preparing to find out the source responsible for it.

The letter, which carries the official letterhead of the SEC , makes allegations against the YSRC governement. Although Kumar has denied having written the letter, it has created ripples across the state with the social media being quick to circulate its contents.

The letter criticises the government, chief minister, other ministers and ruling party leaders. It condemns state police for failing to maintain law and order in first phase of the local body elections, leading to violence.

The letter also seeks central forces to conduct remaining phases of the local body elections, which were suspended due to coronavirus scare. The letter states that SEC has no faith in the state police and administration to ensure peaceful elections. It also refers to the comments of the chief minister against Kumar and his alleged loyalties to Opposition leader N Chandrababu Naidu .

In also requests home ministry to deploy central security forces for Kumar and his family’s protection.

Although the commissioner has denied having written the letter, leaders of the Opposition parties, including TDP state chief K Kalavenkata Rao and CPI secretary K Ramakrishna, met governor Biswabhushan Harichandan and sought central protection for the commissioner and Raj Bhavan’s intervention in the elections. The SEC was provided with 10 CRPF personnel on Thursday.

Meanwhile, chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy held a meeting with DGP Gautam Sawang and intelligence chief Manish Kumar Sinha and reviewed the issue. The CM has expressed displeasure over the language used in the letter which, he said, lowered the image of the government.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Streets deserted, face masks fly off the shelves in Visakhapatnam
Content: VISAKHAPATNAM: The outbreak of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) has led to hoarding of masks and respirators across the city despite health officials requesting citizens to not purchase them, or at least not hoard. Citizens on the other hand have been feeling a financial pinch as masks are being sold at higher prices to exploit the rising demand.P Ramadevi, a resident of Gajuwaka said that the boom in demand for masks has made sellers jack-up prices. She said that she had visited 14 shops to purchase masks for her son who is slated to go back to Australia.Meanwhile, a railway official of the Waltair division of East Coast Railway (ECoR) said that having failed to procure masks for the open market, the department made 20,000 masks which were distributed to their staff on Thursday.Ravi Kumar, Vizianagaram zone executive director of AP public transport department said that the department has ordered masks in bulk to distribute among staff, particularly the 23,000 conductors.Meanwhile, Dr PV Sudhakar, principal of Andhra Medical College (AMC) said that healthy people do not need to wear masks and health experts have not come up with such a suggestion. Dr Sudhakar said that only those suffering from fever, cold or cough should wear masks and those using masks should not touch the masks with their hands.The city, on Thursday, wore a deserted look with educational institutions, malls, theatres, temples and parks closed down. Visakhapatnam MP MVV Satyanarayana said, “The state government is taking all possible steps like provisioning thermal scanners in crowded areas. Social distancing is essential to check the spread of the virus.”

Title: Nagpur: With 2 retests negative, 1st positive patient on road to recovery
Content: NAGPUR: In a development that would bring smiles on the faces of novel coronavirus (Covid-19) patients and suspects, the second and third tests report of the first Covid-19 patient from city have been found to be negative.Moreover, reports of 20 trainee teachers at the pre-primary school where the first patient’s spouse was working and later tested positive on March 7, were also found to be negative.On Thursday, 30 suspects had reported at both the government hospitals — Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) and Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (IGGMCH) — in the city. Of these, five were asked to stay back at the isolation wards as their sample reports are awaited. However, no positive case was reported in the city on Thursday.As per confirmed case management protocol issued by the union ministry of health and family welfare on Covid-19, patients can be discharged after two specimens test negative within 24 hours and there’s evidence of chest radiographic and viral clearance in respiratory sample. However, the district administration has taken additional precautionary measures to prevent the community outbreak.The first patient, a 43-year-old IT professional, had tested positive on March 11 after he returned from the US. That time, he was suffering from throat infection and fever. The second test was performed on him after he came out of his fever on Tuesday, while third one was performed on Wednesday.“The reports of both second and third tests of his swab samples are found to be negative with no presence of virus. This is good news for all of us, particularly the city’s medical fraternity. Full credit to the doctors and nurses who treated patients and took 24X7 care of them without caring for their own lives,” collector Ravindra Thakare told TOI.He clarified that as an additional precautionary measure, the IT professional would be kept at the isolation ward of IGGMCH for 28 days from the date he was admitted.The collector added that the three positive patients at GMCH, including the first patient’s wife who is believed to have contracted the virus from IT professional, were also tested for the second time and their reports were awaited. “All of them are recuperating fast and fortunately there are no new cases since last couple of days, which is a big relief for all of us,” the collector said.Director of the school where the IT professional’s wife works, said, “All our staff members, who had come in contact with the Covid-19 patient, have tested negative. I was sure about this development as the patient displayed no symptoms when she was in the school. In all likelihood, she hadn’t contracted the infection at that point as her husband had returned just a day before.According to the medicos treating these patients, if second and third tests of a positive patient turned out to be negative then s/he could be released after 14 days of mandatory isolation period.The other two patients are the IT professional’s colleagues who were with him in the US for their company’s work and returned in the same flight from Doha. All tests are carried out at the region’s lone Viral Research Diagnostics Laboratory (VRDL) set up at IGGMCH.The doctors said the swab samples of all patients are also referred to the Indian Council for Medical Research (ICMR) laboratories for seeking experts’ guidance. While the IT professional is kept at the IGGMCH, his two colleagues and wife are admitted at isolation ward of GMCH.

Title: Face masks make mark as wedding fashion
Content:
Nidhi Sonune and Shashank Jadhav took their wedding vows on Waghodia road on Thursday

Vadodara: In big fat Indian weddings, guests shower bride and groom with flowers when they take the seven sacred ‘pheras’. But on Thursday at a wedding in Vadodara, guests were not given flowers. Instead, they and family members of the bride and groom were given face masks.

Nidhi Sonune and Shashank Jadhav took their wedding vows outside the former’s house on Waghodiya Road. As guests started pouring in, wedding organizers asked everyone to clean their hands with sanitizers and wear face mask to protect themselves in the wake of coronavirus pandemic.

“There were about 300 guests who had come to attend the wedding from Vadodara, Ahmedabad, Mumbai and our native place. So, we had decided to give face mask to everyone for protection,” said Nidhi’s uncle Shyam Sonune. He added that the family did not want to change the wedding date as they had already postponed the wedding once in the past. Earlier Nidhi’s sister, who lives in the USA, had some visa issues so the wedding date was changed to March 19.

“It is true that the government has closed down multiplexes and other places where gathering of people takes place in large numbers. But the wedding was organized right outside our house and we had taken all the preventive measures,” Shyam added.

During the wedding ceremonies, all guests, including children and the priest who chanted the mantras, obediently wore the masks. Nidhi and Shashank too, without worrying how their wedding photographs will turn out to be, did not remove the masks till the end.

Title: Open or shut: Dual orders leave Nagpur businessmen confused
Content: NAGPUR: Multiple orders led to confusion on first day of lock down to prevent spread of novel coronavirus . The district collector and Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) issued separate and varying orders.The order from collector bars street eateries, wine shops, malls, restaurants, theatres, gyms and swimming pools. The NMC has clamped down on all shops and establishments except those vending essential commodities like groceries, vegetables, medicines and petrol pumps.As TOI went around the city, barring small outlets like tea stalls or pan kiosks all others continued to run their businesses. Officials accepted that this was also due to confusion on account of two different orders issued by different agencies.On Wednesday, cops were seen asking street vendors and eateries, and wine shops to shut down till March 31. Some retailers said even other shops were asked to shut down. As retailers remained open, a small number street vendors also ventured out.District collector Ravindra Thakare told TOI that his orders specifically covered bars, wine shops, restaurants, malls theatres and was not for all commercial establishments. “Other outlets do not come under the definition of crowded areas and need not be closed,” he said.State home minister Anil Deshmukh, who personally carried out raids on eateries including one belonging to food giant Haldirams, also confirmed the collector’s stance. Deshmukh further said the private establishments have been ordered to work with half manpower.On the other hand, NMC additional commissioner Ram Joshi said that while the collector’s order covers the entire district, the civic body’s decisions are applicable in city limits.Joshi said the NMC began with issuing orders to shut down educational institutions from March 14. This was followed by an appeal to banquets and wedding halls to avoid holding functions or at least limit the number of persons to 50. On Thursday, orders were issued for a lock down to all shops and establishment except those vending essential goods like grocery medicines vegetables or petrol pumps.Joshi said the collector’s orders were issued under the disaster relief laws and that by the NMC under the British-era Epidemic Act of 1897 and the Indian Penal Code (IPC). “It must also be known that apart from other orders even the Section 144 of IPC is under force which bars assembly of more than four persons,” he said.The additional commissioner said all the orders are simultaneously in force and the civic body is also going to take a call on making lock down mandatory to banquets and halls “for which an appeal has been issued now”. “The NMC will also begin ensuring compliance of the order,” said Joshi.City police commissioner BK Upadhyay said, “We’re only asking street vendors, wine shop and bar owners to shut. We’re not asking all the commercial establishments to shut. If they are being forced shut, I will look into it.”Deshmukh, who was accompanied by Thakre, also conducted a raid on an eatery at Bajaj Nagar and stopped at a medical shop to inquire about availability of sanitisers and masks. The minister also checked if other eateries were open.TOI saw that the highest compliance was from street vendors who were intimated a day before. However, inside market areas like Jaripatka, Mominpura and Central Avenue some of the eateries had opened shutters.Even as the NMC had issued an order to close down non-essential commodity vending shops, all such outlets were seen open throughout the city. At Kamal Chowk, a team of NMC’s nuisance detection squad was seen in action but that was part of an anti-encroachment drive.Garment vendor Sameer Hirani, who operates from Poonam Chambers, wanted to know if the order also covered his shop as two pizza outlets were seen open for takeaway orders. Shops selling bakery items also opened as people were seen enjoying snacks at such places.

Title: Nagpur Lockdown: Covid-19 school shutdown to hit drivers ferrying kids hard
Content: NAGPUR: With educational institutes shut till March 31 in the wake of coronavirus outbreak, school van and auto drivers are staring at financial loss which, they say, could get extended assuming that many parents won’t send kids to school “just for a few days” in April either.Drivers say many parents have already started telling them that payment would be done till second week of March only (till the schools functioned) and not entire month.Afsar Khan, president of School Van Drivers Association, said, “The shutdown has caused us major loss as parents are expressing their reservations regarding paying for the full month. Our vehicles are financed by banks and we have to pay the EMI on a regular basis. We even have to provide for our families and it now seems a difficult task considering the Covid-19 circumstances. We are also bound to pick up and drop only school kids so we can’t shift to being a regular taxi or cab.”Another driver Abdul Salim said without his only source of income , things will be difficult. “On an average, most of us earn Rs20,000-Rs25,000 per month. My EMI itself is around Rs12,000 and the remaining is barely enough for running a household. We are thinking of approaching banks and asking for moratorium on EMIs for at least two or three months,” said Salim.Uday Ambulkar says he is already over-leveraged his financial condition. “I own an auto and a van which ferry total 45 students in various shifts. EMI for auto is Rs3,000, van Rs7,500 and without income, I will be in a bind. Till now, four parents have agreed to pay the full amount for the month and I hope others will also consider similarly,” said Ambulkar.Another enterprising driver Shyam Sontakke purchased two extra vans, to take his fleet to three, but is now worried about the fixed expenses. “I drive one vehicle myself and pay around Rs15,000 each to drivers of the other vehicles. Now, there is no way I can pay them that amount if income stops. Apart from this, banks won’t be lenient with me regarding EMIs,” said Sontakke.Driver Prakash Deotale said a negligible number of parents would understand their situation. “There are parents who don’t pay if their child is sick and does not go to school, so why will they pay when school itself is shut down. I am wondering how we will cope with this because this is the only source of income for all of us,” said Deotale.Even for big players, the going is tough. Samar Jog, owner of a large school bus fleet, said, “Though schools have shut down, our fixed expenses like salaries of drivers, cleaners and back office staff continue. Many of us have spent heavily, and rightfully so, on deep sanitization of buses to ensure safety of students. We have not discussed this issue with parents, but I feel that they must consider this special situation and not think of deducting transport charges.”

Title: HC quashes order condoning delay in prosecuting 4 booked for harassment
Content:
Aurangabad: The Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court has quashed and set aside a Beed sessions court order condoning the delay of over 15 months and eight days to prosecute and to file an appeal against a lower court judgment acquitting four people.

The petitioners — Sayyad Azim, his father Sayyad Manzur, his mother and sister — were booked in 2014 after his wife filed a complaint of dowry harassment, causing hurt, criminal intimidation and other sections of the Indian Penal Code. On July 3, 2017, Azim and his relatives were acquitted by the Judicial Magistrate First Class.

However, the prosecution approached the Beed sessions court by filing a miscellaneous criminal application in 2019. The sessions judge, Beed condoned the delay in March 2019.

The four then approached the high court through lawyer P D Suryavanshi challenging the sessions court decision stating that the date of pronouncement of the judgment has not been mentioned in the application (for condonation) intentionally.

“No reasonable ground has been shown for condoning the delay,” they claimed. The government told the HC that the police prosecutor, Beed filed appeal proposal to the district magistrate, Beed in August 2017. However, the letter informing about the sanction came only in October 2017.

While allowing the criminal writ petition, justice Vibha Kankanwadi observed “the delay appears to have been mechanically condoned by the learned sessions judge.”

The judge also observed that the “the remedy open, to the prosecution had become time barred, and no proper explanation was given by the prosecution to file an appeal even after the appeal period was over.”

Title: Maulingem locals to boycott zilla polls
Content:
Representational image

BICHOLIM: Around 1,700 villagers from Maulinguem in Bicholim taluka have decided to boycott the zilla panchayat elections to protest against the government’s apathy in resolving their problems.

The residents said that neither the local MLA nor the chief minister has paid heed to their grievances.

The village falls under the jurisdiction of the Karapur-Sarvan zilla panchayat. Four candidates are in the fray for the polls.

“No development work has been undertaken in the village during the past few years. There are no roads, no panchayat building and no jobs. We have forwarded all the files, but no work is being sanctioned,” local panch Jyoti Maulingkar said. “We want to know why our village is being ignored. The CM should answer our questions.” Maulingkar said.

Another panch member Shiva Gaonkar said, “There are problems viz power cuts, irregular water supply, land disputes, approvals for repairs and construction of houses, etc. However, getting official approval is an impossible task. ”

A resident Saju Mayekar said that local MLA Pravin Zantye has never visited the village and gives false assurances.

“We are living like tribals in this village. No one is bothered about us, or listens to the panchas,” a villager Deepak Sarnaik said.

Title: Mercury touches 30° C for first time this year
Content: NEW DELHI: The mercury breached the 30-degree mark for the first time this season on Thursday and is likely to touch 31°C by Friday, forecast by the India Meteorological Department show.Delhi’s Safdarjung station — considered the base observatory for the capital’s weather — recorded a maximum temperature of 30.7 degrees Celsius and a minimum of 16 degrees on Thursday. The maximum, however, is still close the ‘normal’ mark for the season.IMD has forecast a spell of light rain for Saturday, with some drizzle also occurring on Friday evening. “After receiving hail and more than normal rain, temperatures had fallen to around 24°C. It has now returned to the normal benchmark over the last few days and is likely to touch 31°C on Friday,” said Kuldeep Srivastava , scientist at IMD and the head of Regional Weather Forecasting Centre in the city.The hottest location in the capital on Thursday was Palam, which recorded a maximum of 31.5° Celsius.Humidity levels, meanwhile, oscillated between 48% and 98% in the last 24 hours. Met officials said in comparison to the last western disturbance , which had brought hailstorm to the city, the current one is likely to be much weaker. “There is a slight possibility of light rain on Friday evening/night, while light showers slated for Saturday. One can also expect gusty winds between 30-40 km/hr,” the official added.Delhi’s air quality remained in the ‘moderate’ range on Thursday, with the AQI increasing slightly from 151 on Wednesday to 186 on Thursday.Forecast for Friday shows the maximum and minimum temperatures to be around 31 and 17°C, respectively.

Title: SEC letter: Cops launch informal investigation
Content:
VIJAYAWADA: Suspecting that the letter was an attempt to create unrest in the state, the police has launched an informal probe to find its source.

Police sources told TOI that the director general of police (DGP) D Gautam Sawang spoke to his Telangana counterpart on Wednesday evening to provide additional security to the SEC as he left for Hyderabad. His personal security has also doubled from 1+1 to 2+2.

Sources said the letter appears to be a deliberate attempt to malign the image of state government and the police. A case would be registered and a formal investigation will be launched if a complaint is registered. The offence amounts to forgery of a senior official holding a constitutional position.

Title: IMFL worth Rs 10.39 lakh seized; two held in Rajkot
Content:
Representative Image

RAJKOT: A total of 4 ,356 bottles of Indian-Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) worth Rs 10.39 lakh were seized in two different raids and two bootleggers arrested in Rajkot on Wednesday night.

The first raid was carried out at Maikagam locality on Bhavnagar Road where a total of 3,060 IMFL bottles worth Rs 9.18 lakh were seized from a truck. Cops also arrested two bootleggers identified as Prahladram Huda and Fannaram Huda , both aged 21 years.

“The accused duo said that the liquor cache was sent by one Omprakash Rugnath in Barmer of Rajasthan. They were supposed to call Rugnath after reaching Rajkot,” said an official from Aji Dam police station.

In the second raid conducted at Gondal Road, a total of 1,296 IMFL bottles were seized from an MUV, which was abandoned at the spot by owner, identified as Dharmesh Tak. Police are hunting for the accused.

Title: Goa ZP polls: BJP’s former MLAs prop up kin in Mayem, Colvale
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

PANAJI: BJP will face a tough battle in Mayem and Colvale after two of its former MLAs have gone against the party and fielded their kin as independent candidates for the zilla panchayat elections.

Even though the zilla elections could be perceived as ‘inconsequential’, it has become a matter of prestige for both the ex-legislators in their bid to enter the portals of the legislative assembly once again.

Former BJP Tivim MLA Kiran Kandolkar has fielded his wife Kavita against BJP candidate Govind Kubal who is the sitting Colvale ZP member, whereas in Mayem, ex-BJP legislator Anant Shet has pitted his brother Premendra against the party’s incumbent ZP member Shankar Chodankar .

Other candidates who are contesting in Colvale are Satish Chodankar of Congress and Umesh Kauthankar as an independent.

Mayem will witness a five-cornered battle, with Narayan Tari contesting on the MGP ticket, Prasad Chodankar as the Congress candidate, Deepkumar Mapari of the Rashtriya Samaj Paksha, and independents Krishna Volvoikar and Rajesh Kalangutkar.

Despite several attempts, BJP senior leaders have unsuccessfully tried to convince Kandolkar and Shet against fielding their family members.

“If are they able to win the zilla polls, they will be in the reckoning to contest the assembly elections on the BJP ticket,” a political observer said. Both Kandolkar and Shet are leaving no stone unturned to win the seats. Mayem is a BJP stronghold, while in Colvale, the party has been bolstered after former Congress MLA Nilkant Halarnkar switched over last year.

In the 2017 assembly polls, BJP denied Shet a ticket and fielded Pravin Zantye who won the seat. However, BJP had retained Kandolkar as their candidate for Colvale.

While BJP is confident of bagging both the ZP seats, BJP karyakartas appear to be divided, with loyalists siding with the party and some shifting their allegiance altogether. Another political analyst said that with Halarnkar in the party fold, it would be difficult for BJP to replace him as the candidate for the assembly polls unless Kandolkar proves his might in Sunday’s elections. Similarly in Mayem, Shet has to win the seat to be a claimant for the party ticket.

Title: Can provide 10,000 beds if situation worsens in Nagpur: Division commissioner
Content:
NAGPUR: With an alarming increase in coronavirus cases across the country, the district administration is not taking any chances and has fully geared up to tackle the eventuality if the need arises.

In case the number of cases increases exponentially, the administration is ready to increase capacity to over 10,000 beds in the city, divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar told TOI. “Apart from government hospitals and temporary facility at MLA Hostel, we have identified places like hostels of government-run institutions for setting up such temporary facilities, including the Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology (VNIT) and Vanamati,” he said.

According to Kumar, the condition is not that critical currently, and is under control, but nothing can be said till March 31. “Next few weeks are critical. In case of emergency, we have decided that all routine OPD and other surgeries would be postponed and only Covid-19 patients would be treated across all government and private hospitals.
