Of course, the critical cases like accidents and delivery would be allowed during this time,” he clarified.

On the number of ventilators, which is most critical component in treating the coronavirus patients in case they develop complications, the divisional commissioner said that the city is having 1,450 of those machines if private hospitals were included. “Of them, the government hospitals have about 100,” he said.

Across the state, 700 ventilators are available at government hospitals. Of these, 450 are under Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation while 250 in rest of Maharashtra.

Stressing that those coming from abroad should strictly follow self-quarantine, the commissioner warned them of police action if they move out. “People who have opted for self-quarantine should behave very responsibly and follow the protocol. We have monitoring systems to keep a close tab on such flyers. We are also providing our own vehicles to drop the suspects to their respective homes for self-quarantine so that they don’t use public transport,” he said.

On Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court asking authorities from his office and other ones like PWD to resolve differences between them, Kumar said there were no clashes and he had only directed the officials concerned to provide the best possible facilities to the visitors, who will be quarantined. “As per the HC directives, we have provided Wi-Fi kits to all those housed in the MLA Hostel. They have also been provided with best food. Their feedback is positive.”

On HC’s directives of setting up more Viral Research Diagnostics Laboratory (VRDL) facilities in Vidarbha, the commissioner said there were no directives from the government as of now in this regard. “It’s a complex procedure as the laboratory needs to be established as per the protocol. It takes time,” he said.

Title: Hope unveiled: Blind People’s Association to make 5 lakh masks from donated cloth in Gujarat
Content:
Jagruti Choudhari, 30, can’t see but her hands deftly move on the cloth in front of her as she sews an elastic... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Jagruti Choudhari, 30, can’t see but her hands deftly move on the cloth in front of her as she sews an elastic band on both sides of the rectangle.

She’s one of the 40-odd volunteers at work on 12 sewing machines on Thursday at the premises of the Blind People’s Association (BPA). The organization has a target target of producing 5 lakh protective masks. The masks are made entirely of fine cotton cloth, sanitized, which can be distributed for free among citizens.

Bhushan Punani, executive secretary, BPA, said community members had come up with the idea to do their part to battle the Covid-19 pandemic. “While awareness campaign on health and hand sanitization has already been conducted, we decided to make the protective masks. While it’s not medical grade or can’t be compared with N95 masks, we are hopeful that this gesture will make the citizens more aware about precautions to be taken,” he said.

Makers of the masks include persons with blindness, movement disabilities, multiple disabilities and volunteers from the staff. BPA officials said that making masks is not very complicated and if citizens volunteer, they can teach those interested. Officials added that they have already received cloth in donations and will send the masks to far-flung places in Gujarat.

“Covid-19 is the top worry for citizens. As there is no cure available, prevention is the only way we can ensure it doesn’t come to our door. We are doing our bit and also appeal to the society at large to create awareness about the viral infection and on ways to prevent it,” said Meghna Patel, a volunteer at BPA who was making masks on Thursday.

Title: Result delay likely as CBSE, ICSE postpone exams, stop evaluation in Maharashtra
Content: NAGPUR: Results of CBSE and ICSE are likely to get delayed as both boards have postponed all exams till March 31 as a preventive step against coronavirus infection. CBSE made the announcement late on Wednesday evening while ICSE issued a statement on Thursday morning. Currently in Maharashtra, SSC (Std X) is the only board exam which has not yet been called off.Many CBSE and ICSE schools have declared holiday for their teachers as well till March 31.CBSE’s decision was prompted by a letter issued by the school education department at the centre under HRD ministry, which talked about taking strong proactive steps to curb the spread of Covid-19 . The letter addressed to CBSE, National Institute of Open Schooling, National Testing Agency, AICTE, NCTE and UGC talked about how a balance has to be maintained between academics and health safety.Amit Khare, secretary, ministry of HRD, wrote, “While maintenance of academic schedule and calendar is important, equally important is the safety and security of students who are appearing in various exams”.Following up on Khare’s letter, CBSE secretary Anurag Tripathi issued a statement that not only board exams but also the evaluation work has to be stopped till March 31. Tripathi said that evaluation work’s new schedule will start from April 1 unless otherwise notified by the board.ICSE’s chief executive and secretary Gerry Arathoon too issued a statement saying the council (as the board is referred to in official parlance) “in the interest and well being of students and teaching community, has decided to postpone all ICSE and ISC exams scheduled between March 19-31”.Both boards will be announcing their revised schedule around March 31 itself. JEE Main postponedNagpur: The National Testing Agency (NTA) has postponed Joint Entrance Examination (JEE-Main) which was to be held in April, because of a possible clash of dates with rescheduled CBSE board exams. Due to coronavirus preventive measures, CBSE’s board exams have been put on hold till March 31.The JEE Mains exams were scheduled on April 5, 7, 9 and 11. The admit cards which were to be issued on Friday, will now be issued after March 31.HRD secretary Amit Khare’s letter mentioned that “JEE Main may require travel by examinees to different towns and the dates may clash with rescheduled CBSE and other board exams. Therefore, JEE Main should be rescheduled and new date will be announced on March 31 after re-assessment of situation”.Local coaching classes expressed relief over the announcement saying it will be beneficial for students. Rajnikant Bondre, director of Sneha Classes said “This is a big relief for students because they were under a lot of stress wondering what will happen with their exam. This clarity by the government has soothed nerves and also given them extra time to prepare for the all important exam.”

Title: Covid-19: ‘Those pushing for polls risking public health’
Content:
Goa Forward Party president Vijai Sardesai

PANAJI: Praising Prime Minister Narendra Modi for taking the coronavirus threat seriously, Goa Forward Party (GFP) president Vijai Sardesai said, “Recognising the gravity of the marauding pandemic Covid-19, the PM has sought the support of the citizens to tackle the crisis on a war footing by calling for social distancing and ‘janata curfew’ which he said cannot be ignored by any government in the fight against the virus.”

“I am glad that the PM’s appeal is in tune with my demanded for postponement of zilla panchayat polls on Wednesday,” Sardesai said.

“Those pushing for zilla elections inspite of @PMOIndia announcement and endangering public health will be criminally liable!,” the former deputy chief minister said in a tweet. The former deputy CM further said that the Goa government must not test its political health at the cost of public health.

Title: Fake letter of two students being infected sparks panic
Content:
Vadodara railway station wore a deserted look as people stayed at home

Vadodara: With memes and videos on coronavirus flooding social media platforms, the creativity, however, is proving to be destructive as it is creating havoc for some people.

A forged letter of Parul University (PU) circulated on WhatsApp saying that two of its students were infected with coronavirus and asking others to take care has caused panic in the varsity. The letter also contained names of two students which added to the frenzy.

The university administration has submitted an application to Vadodara rural police to register an offence against the unidentified miscreant. However, the police are yet to act on the application.

“The letter on the forged letterhead had been circulated widely. I received several calls regarding it. However, I would like to assure that the letter is fake and all students of the university are safe,” said president of the university, Dr Devanshu Patel. “We have given an application to Waghodia police station to register a complaint because this is a serious issue,” Patel added.

On being contacted by TOI, police said that the investigation in the case is going on. “The probe is still on as we are trying to ascertain the source of the original message. However, we will be registering an FIR on Friday,” said A G Parmar, sub-inspector of Waghodia police station.

He added that the university has been closed till March 29 as directed by the state government to all educational institutions. Police sources said that an offence of forgery, violation of Information Technology Act will be registered and after proper deliberation the Epidemic Diseases Act might also be invoked.

Title: Rajkot: Man stabbed over trivial issue in Sihor
Content:
Representative Image

Rajkot: A man was arrested on Thursday afternoon for stabbing a dairy supervisor to death over a trivial issue in Sihor of Bhavnagar district early on Thursday morning. Police said the accused, identified as Bhopa Bharwad (30), had stabbed Bhavesh Joshi (32) four times near SR petrol pump in Sihor at 2am on Thursday.

According to the police, Joshi used to work as a supervisor at Sarvottam Dairy. Five days ago, Bharwad had come to the dairy in a pick-up van to upload milk supply and was hurling expletives at people. Joshi asked him not to use profane words near the dairy, following which both fought.

“On that very night, when Joshi and another supervisor Jayesh Jani were leaving for home, Jani had to go to the petrol pump while Joshi waited for him on his bike. In that period, Bharwad arrived at the spot in his pick-up van and seeing Bharwad alone, took out a knife and stabbed him four times before escaping from the spot,” said A D Gohil, sub-inspector with Sihor police station.

After Joshi succumbed to his injuries at the Sihor Civil Hospital , cops arrested Bharwad from his residence in Sihor.

Title: Sawant has failed on all fronts: Dhavalikar
Content:
Goa CM Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: With the completion of a year in office, chief minister Pramod Sawant did not get bouquets from his erstwhile ally Maharashtrawadi Gomantak Party (MGP), but sharp criticism, for failing miserably on all fronts including infrastructure, water supply, agriculture and Mhadei .

Sudin Dhavalikar said that he has written to Prime Minister Modi and urged him to constitute a committee of leaders of all political parties, a retired Supreme Court judge, a scientist and An environmentalist and visit the construction site on the upper Mhadei to check on the illegal constructions carried out by the government of Karnataka.

Title: Intermediate, Class X exams to be held as per schedule in AP
Content:
Vijayawada: Andhra Pradesh education minister A Suresh on Thursday announced that Intermediate and Class X examinations would be held as per schedule. While Intermediate examinations will conclude on March 23, Class X examinations will start on March 31.

Speaking to the media on Thursday, Suresh said all educational institutions will remain closed till March 31 as a precautionary measure to prevent and manage the spread of covid 19. “Except for residential schools having examinations, all other institutions including private universities, state universities, affiliated colleges and schools will remain shut till March 31. But students should be immediately sent home after completion of exams. Physical distance of a meter will be maintained between students in the examination centres. Students suffering from fever, cold and cough will write examinations in separate rooms. Even the spot evaluation will be conducted with certain precautionary measures,” said Suresh.

In addition, the minister also stated that special transport facilities are being arranged for the students to go back to their homes from residential institutions, colleges and universities. “A review meeting will be conducted to take a final call before resuming operations of educational institutions,” said Suresh.

Title: Decoy teams check alertness of cops
Content:
Coimbatore: In view of the prevailing communal tension , the city police have formed 10 decoy teams to improve patrol productivity.

The team members, in plainclothes, are roaming through the city on 10 motorcycles carrying stones, sickles and other weapons, city police commissioner Sumit Sharan said. “We selected 20 police personnel for the decoy teams. If police personnel conducting vehicle checks fail to stop them, the teams will inform senior officers and the personnel will be pulled up,” he said.

Thanks to the effective vehicle checks, the Ramanathapuram police arrested a gang from Madurai and seized deadly weapon a few days ago, Sharan said. “During the recent communal tension, decoy teams were deployed to check the alertness of our personnel. The team members used to mingle with the crowds attending public meetings conducted across the city.”

Director general of police J K Tripathy and two additional director general of police (ADGPs) were camping in the city to maintain peace and harmony.

Title: MLA, MP seek help for Guj students stranded in Phillipines
Content:
Vadodara: With no immediate solution in sight for medical students from Gujarat unable to leave Phillipines, appeals are being made by elected representatives from Panchmahal and Mahisagar districts to the state government and the Union government to intervene in the matter.

Five students from Godhra and one from Mahisagar district are among 150 students who are stranded in Las Pinas near Manila in Phillipines. They had gone to study medicine at a university there. The city is under lockdown during day and curfew at night.

The five students from Godhra include Milind Patel, Ronit Gosai, Dhwanit Valand, Rushikumar Patel and Jalpkumar Patel. Ankurkumar Pandya from Limbadiya village in Khanpur taluka of Panchmahal district too is stranded.

Godhra MLA C K Raulji and Panchmahal MP Ratansinh Rathod on Thursday wrote to the Prime Minister and Union foreign minister asking them to help the students. Raulji’s letter stated that the students were under distress. Lunawada MLA Jigneshkumar Sevak had earlier written a letter to the deputy CM and state health minister Nitin Patel and sought his assistance.

Title: Automatic mutation of flats, plots in city survey stopped
Content:
Nagpur: Citizens are being forced to run pillar to post and face red-tapism to get mutations done of their flats and plots in the records of city survey department. Despite being a great success for 31 months, the system of automatic mutations in city survey records has been stopped about six months ago.

Now, to get mutation done for flats or plots, one has to submit an application with a long list of documents and charges with the city survey. The applicants are also forced to fall in the trap of touts or face red-tapism and run pillar to post.

On January 16, 2017, the then collector Sachin Kurwe had launched a new system. Citing section 154 of the Maharashtra Land Revenue Act 1966, Kurwe had directed the stamps and registration department to send a copy of the sale deeds once in three days to the city survey department. He had directed the city survey to issue notice, complete necessary formalities, complete mutation and send ‘akhiv partrika’ to the concerned party by post, and also given an alert on the respective party’s mobile.

Kurwe used to follow up on the system once a fortnight, and resolved any issues. He was transferred in April 2018 and replaced with Ashwin Mudgal, who continued the system but failed to keep it going since pre-assembly election period.

Sources from stamps and registration department and city survey told TOI the system stopped from August 2019. “Again, people are forced to submit application and follow the entire process.”

Mudgal had been replaced with Ravindra Thakre in September 2019. Thakre has not even held any meeting about the system in last five months.

The officials of stamps and registration department and city survey are passing the buck on each other for abandoning the system. The city records around 52,000 sale deeds every year. The system was followed for other transactions too at registry office.

Superintendent of land records GB Daberao, who heads three city survey offices, said, “Nine offices of stamps and registration department stopped sending copies of sale deeds to the city survey offices, so the system came to a halt. There are no problems from our side.”

An official from stamps and registration department said, “City survey department stopped taking copies citing update of their system, which is not updated till date.”

Daberao denied the claim. “Registry offices used to send copies via posts, and even paid postage for this,” he said.

Thakre did not respond to TOI’s call and message.

Activist Suraj Lolage alleged city survey offices are again giving all types of problems to people. “Kurwe’s system was a big relief for all. Now, nothing happens on time or without touts. If Kurwe could get it done, it means all these departments are now violating norms and cheating people. State government should take action against all officials,” he said.

IAN

* After sale deeds, one had to submit application with long list of documents and charges with city survey

* Applicants were forced to work through touts or face red-tapism for mutations

* In January 2017, the then collector Sachin Kurwe started automatic mutation after sale deeds

* Nine offices of stamps and registration dept used to send copies of sale deeds to three city survey offices

* City survey would do mutation, send akhiv patrika to concerned person by post

* System continued for 31 months and benefited thousands

* System stopped since August 2019

* People against forced to pay touts, run pillar to post for mutation

Title: Around 20 int’l flights to be halted
Content:
Ahmedabad: At least 20 international flight movements are expected to be impacted from March 22 at Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) Airport in Ahmedabad, as the Union government has issued a notification barring the landing of all scheduled international commercial passenger aircraft in India.

“No scheduled international commercial passenger aircraft shall be allowed to land in India from March 22, 2020, for one week. The state governments shall issue appropriate directions so that all citizens above 65, except for public representatives, government servants, medical professionals, are advised to remain at home,” stated a notification issued by the government of India.

International passenger footfall is expected to be affected further in the days to come.

Title: Travellers from UK, Turkey take Uttar Pradesh’s tally to 19
Content: LUCKNOW: Two more positive cases of coronavirus have been reported in UP, taking the total number of cases to 19. One patient is from Lucknow and the other from Lakhimpur Kheri.State surveillance officer Dr Vikasendu Agarwal said, “Both patients have travel history. The patient from Lucknow returned from UK, the one from Lakhimpur Kheri has come from Turkey. They are undergoing treatment at KGMU.”The Lucknow patient, 24, studying in London belongs to Gomtinagar. The two fresh cases have taken the city tally to four. Health officials have identified 15 contacts of Lucknow patient and 16 of the Lakhimpur Kheri man.“The Lucknow patient came back via New Delhi two days ago but had no symptoms. He was under home isolation when his report came positive. Thereafter, he has been admitted to the hospital,” said Dr Agarwal.Talking about the patient from Lakhimpur, Dr Agarwal said: “This patient, in his early 50s, is a farmer from Maigalganj in Lakhimpur Kheri. He had gone to Turkey to represent his son whose company had given an all-expenses-paid trip to its distributors.”“He was also asymptomatic and went to Sitapur government hospital when he felt unwell. Doctors in Sitapur referred him to Lucknow’s Balrampur hospital where his swab samples were taken and sent for testing to KGMU,” he added.Health officials said district teams in both Lakhimpur Kheri and Sitapur had been alerted to trace people who had been in his contact.Authorities in Sitapur stated that the patient could have infected two doctors there.“One was a private doctor whom the patient went to see when he was unwell. Thereafter, he went to the government hospital where he came in contact with a contractual doctor. Both are being screened,” said additional CMO in Sitapur.

Title: Learning apps help beat school lockdown amid Covid-19 fears in Nagpur
Content: NAGPUR: As schools shut down till March 31 as a preventive measure for coronavirus learning apps seem to be getting a shot in the arm with some claiming spike in usage as they offer free sneak-peak offers.Akhand Swaroop Pandit, CEO and founder of online learning platform Catalyst Group, said, “Overall we have witnessed 30-40% in admissions in the last two to three days and also the number of students regularly attending the online classes has increased due to college and school shutdown.” He added that screentime too is increasing. “Daily screentime has almost doubled in the past two to three days as students are at home,” said Pandit.Vamsi Krishna, CEO and co-founder of Vedantu, said, shift towards learning apps during the current situation seems only natural. “We believe, online learning is a safe option in these risky and uncertain times. Students can study from the safety of their home and avoid travel and public places,” said Krishna.According to Shobhit Bhatnagar, CEO and co-founder of Gradeup, this could be a turning point for online education. “As schools and universities continue to go into lockdown mode around the world, the EdTech industry is gearing up for its biggest test — and an opportunity. The likes of Harvard have already begun the transition from offline to online, and I can see Indian universities and schools following suit. The biggest benefit that the EdTech industry can offer, especially in times like these, is live online classes, which provide a safe, convenient study-from-home option,” said Bhatnagar.For parents , online learning apps help keep kids engaged in a manner that provides productive screentime.Parent Komal Domkundwar said the learning apps have an advantage as they help parents track the child’s progress. “These apps help me a lot in keeping track of my kid’s past and present knowledge and I can see the score graph rising high through online studies,” she said.Another parent Ragini Sharma feels the way online learning resources are presented is very student-friendly. “I believe they enjoy it more because of the pictorial information that gets stored directly into their minds,” said Sharma.All parents agreed that a balance needs to be maintained between online and offline learning resources. Maria Rangoonwala, a parent, said, “These apps are definitely a good way to keep them occupied for a certain duration, but I would not want to depend on them too much. These apps and videos also increase the screentime for my child, which can be much longer than the desired limit.”Parent Suvarna Ghosh says a balance of both online and offline study will lead to best results. “Of course, the apps are fun and innovative. When traditional studying becomes mundane, the online resources come to the rescue. But, as parents, we know that relying on learning apps completely is not a good idea. And most important, reducing screentime has to be a priority as well,” said Ghosh.

Title: Early start at New Town quarantine centre as flyers from Gulf check in
Content: KOLKATA: There was a flurry of activities at the quarantine centre in New Town on Thursday morning as the first lot of flyers from Gulf countries checked into the facility. Passengers on buses from Kolkata airport started arriving at the centre a little after 3am. A source said 345 passengers of four aircraft were taken inside the centre during the day.Hours before their arrival, healthcare workers had stayed put at the gate in protective gear. After offloading their luggage from bus, the flyers were first made to queue up in two lines. Those who would take a connecting flight, were assessed first on their health condition and travel history. After analysing the threat perception, passengers found with no symptom were sent back to airport.Flyers, whose destination was Kolkata, were then examined. Those found even with the slightest of symptoms like normal cold were marked to be kept under observation before sending all of them inside the building. Sources said those with the slightest of symptom will be under intense monitoring and if required, there swab samples will be tested.The brand new building of the second campus of Chittaranjan National Cancer Institute in New Town came as a blessing for the state that requisitioned the eight-storey structure as its quarantine centre for flyers coming from abroad.The hospital with a capacity of 450 beds was supposed to start operations in April with OPD services and then admit patients from July. Accordingly, 250 beds were made ready for the first phase, now the government has added more beds so that 500 passengers can be quarantined.“So far, the facility is spick and span and the entire building is being cleaned thoroughly — four times a day. I hope they continue this kind of maintenance,” said a passenger quarantined at the facility.Visitors are barred from entering the building. While all health workers posted at the facility are wearing personal protective equipment, rest of the staff are wearing masks and gloves. The centre is also guarded by security personnel. “Since the hospital is yet to become functional it does not have much facility of treatment and medical equipment. But these are not required for quarantined flyers. The idea is to keep them away from moving into a crowd, observe them for symptoms and send them to a hospital with isolation facility in case they develop symptoms,” said a health department official.All those quarantined have been given masks and told to maintain distance from each other. Health department officials said apart from essentials like food, drinking water, soap, the centre does not have any mode of entertainment. “Since they have to stay for 14 days, we are planning to install television sets,” said a source.Situated just about 13 kilometres from the airport, the state had earmarked this hospital building last week as the first quarantine centre. The health department has also requisitioned another property in New Town as its second quarantine facility. The ready-to-use NBCC Square , a cluster of residential complex with commercial space near the first centre, will be used when required.

Title: Andhra government to build nine fishing harbours for Rs 2,900 crore
Content:
Andhra Pradesh CM YS Jaganmohan Reddy

VIJAYAWADA: Andhra Pradesh chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy said the government will construct nine fishing harbours in two phases with an investment of Rs 2,901 crore.

In the first phase, four harbours will be constructed with Rs 1,304 crore and five harbours will be constructed at ba cost of Rs 1,597 crore in the second phase.

The CM announced this at a review meeting held here on Thursday. He emphasised that the fishermen’s living standards should be enhanced and their equipment should be modernised. All the required infrastructure facilities should be provided to support fishing and deep sea fishing, he said.

Title: Vadodara: Pavagadh Mahakali temple to remain closed
Content:
VADODARA: The Mahakali temple at Pavagadh will remain closed for devotees from Friday. The decision was taken both by the temple trust as well as the state government on Thursday.

The temple at Pavagadh is revered by many is one of the Shaktipeeths of the goddess. Devotees throng the temple in thousands from across the country throughout the year. It was expected that the temple would witness heavy rush during the Chaitri Navratri that begins from March 25.

Shri Kalika Mataji Mandir Trust that manages the temple had on Thursday decided that the temple will be closed from Sunday to March 31. However, the state government on Thursday issued directives that all major temples should be closed from Friday itself. Sources said that the temple trust too decided to follow the directives and would remain closed for devotees and visitors.

Title: Covid-19: College teachers, students make the switch to remote learning
Content:
Coimbatore: With all higher education institutions ordered to remain closed till March 31 to prevent the spread of Covid-19, colleges in the city have taken up online teaching and assessment methods to make sure academic activities aren’t affected.

With no students on campuses and hostellers returning home, colleges have started using online tools and apps such as Google Classroom and MyKlassroom for coordinating classroom activities. Teachers also livestream lectures or record and upload them on platforms such as YouTube. Some of them also use popular social media platforms such as WhatsApp to clear doubts.

College representatives said they had used online platforms earlier for specific classroom purposes, but now have taken up using them full-time.

Sri Ramakrishna College of Arts and Science switched over to online mode of conducting classes from Wednesday. “Classes would be conducted online with live lectures, video and audio. PowerPoint presentations and other learning resources would be shared using Google Classroom. Formative assessments using Kahoot! and Hot Potatoes would be followed,” the management said.

College principal K Karunakaran said on Thursday, 80% of the students connected online for live classes. “Teachers record lectures and upload them so those students who can’t get connected for live classes can access the resources later,” he said. “We are planning to use online platforms for conducting seminars and quizzes, and are mulling to conduct remote online exams.”

Colleges of Sri Krishna Institutions also conducted online classes from Wednesday. While some teachers livestreamed lectures, others uploaded their lectures on YouTube. For clearing doubts, they used Google Classrooms and WhatsApp.

A Alagarsamy, head of the department of Social Work at the Sri Krishna Arts and Science College, said they have started using online platforms to complete the remaining portions. “All our teachers were online by 11am and started interacting with students over WhatsApp, clearing their doubts. We collect assignments in mail, post PPTs in MyKlassroom and clear doubts in Google Classroom,” he said.

Colleges such as the Government Arts College, meanwhile, have been conducting practical exams as scheduled. Principal K Chithra said they were mulling to postpone exams.

Meanwhile, the University Grants Commission has directed all higher education institutions to reschedule examination and evaluation work after March 31.

Title: 4 detained under NSA
Content:
Coimbatore: City police commissioner Sumit Sharan on Thursday detained four accused, who are currently lodged at the Coimbatore central prison, under the National Security Act (NSA) to maintain peace and harmony in Coimbatore.

The accused were A Azharuddin, 30 of Karumbukadai, S Noor Mohammed of Kurichi, K Pandi alias Sadaiyandi, 41, of Periyasamy Layout at Rathinapuri and V Akil, 23, from Rathinapuri.

Azharuddin and Noor Mohammed were arrested for attacking Hindu Munnani functionary M Anand. Pandi and Akil were arrested for hurling a petrol bomb at a mosque at Vedambal nagar near Ganapathy on February 5.

Title: Southern Railway cuts down train services
Content:
Coimbatore: To discourage people from undertaking non-essential travel, Southern Railway on Thursday announced that from Friday it would not be giving concessional tickets under passenger reservation system (PRS) and unreserved ticketing system (UTS).

It has also cancelled special train services and other train services due to low patronage. Following are the trains which have been cancelled.

A total of 10 trips of Dr MGR Chennai Central–Coimbatore Shatabdi Express (train no. 12243), on March 20, 21, 22, 23, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29 and 30 are cancelled. Ten trips of Coimbatore–Chennai Central Shatabdi Express (12244) on March 20, 21, 22, 23, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29 and 30 are cancelled.

Trivandrum–Chennai Express (12698) would be cancelled on March 21 and 28. Chennai-Trivandrum Express (12697) would be cancelled on March 22 and 29. Mangalore–Coimbatore Intercity Express (22609) would be cancelled from March 20 to 31, and Coimbatore–Mangalore Central Intercity Express Train (22610) would be cancelled from March 21 to 31 and on April 1.

Similarly, Jabalpur-Coimbatore Weekly Superfast Special (02198) is fully cancelled from March 21 and Coimbatore – Jabalpur Weekly Superfast Special (02197) is fully cancelled from March 23.

Chennai-Thiruvananthapuram bi-weekly express (22207) scheduled to leave Chennai Central on March 20, 24, 27 and 31 would be fully cancelled and Thiruvananthapuram-Chennai Central Bi-Weekly Express (22208) scheduled to leave Thiruvananthapuram on March 22, 25, 29 and April 1 would be fully cancelled.

In addition to this, as the collector of the Nilgiris has ordered the shutdown of tourist centres, the following trains are fully cancelled till March 31: Mettupalayam – Udhagamandalam Passenger, Udhagamandalam-Mettupalayam Passenger, Udhagamandalam- Coonoor Passenger and Coonoor–Udhagamandalam Passenger.

Mettupalayam to Udhagamandalam train (06171) and the Udhagamandalam to Mettupalayam train (06172) are fully cancelled on March 21 and 28.

Title: Rajkot father-son duo robbed of Rs 13.6 lakh at knifepoint in Limbdi
Content:
Representative Image

RAJKOT: A father-son duo was robbed of Rs 13.60 lakh by eight fraudsters who promised the victims of getting them gold at cheaper rate in Limbdi of Surendranagar district on Wednesday.

Police said the accused, identified as Kuldeep Gadhvi, Sohilkhan Naseemkhan, Naseemkhan Hajikhan, Abbas Ayub, Qarim Bhatti, Babu and their two unidentified aides, had allegedly looted Vasant Limbani (52) and his son Mitul Limbani (28), both residents of Gokul Palace at Guru Prasad Chowk on Gondal Road in Rajkot.

According to the police, Gadhvi, who was a friend of Vasant, told latter that he had contacts who wished to sell gold at 30 percent cheaper rate from the prevailing market rates. When Vasant expressed his desire to purchase the gold, he along with Mitul and Gadhvi went to Surendranagar and met the accused.

The accused showed the gold samples to the victims and told them that if they wanted to buy the gold, they would have to buy one kg and for that they would have to travel to Surendranagar to take the delivery.

On their return to Rajkot, the victims found that they were able to mobilize only Rs 13.60 lakh. When they told the accused about the amount, the accused informed they would be able to buy only 500 gram of gold with that amount. The accused asked the victims to come to Limbdi to take the delivery.

“At a hotel in Limbdi, the accused asked Mitul to go to a temple to take the delivery from their associate. When Mitul along with his two friends — Nitin Rabari and Nikunj Satani — left the spot, the accused asked Vasant to sit in their car and drove him to an interior road leading to Lakhtar. The accused then showed Vasant a knife and robbed him of the cash before dropping him on the road,” said S S Varu, sub-inspector with Limbdi police station.

Meanwhile, the police have registered the case and launched a manhunt for the accused.

Title: Vizag metro rail: UMTC to prepare DPR
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Urban Mass Transit Company Limited (UMTC) will prepare the detailed project report for the 79.91 kilometre first phase Vizag metro rail project. UMTC emerged as the successful bidder by quoting a price of Rs 5.33 crore – the lowest among bidders. Consequently, UMTC will be bestowed with the responsibility of updating the existing DPR earlier prepared for the proposed 42.5 km metro rail project and include the 3.85 km new section from Gajuwaka to Vizag Steel Plant.

A new DPR will be prepared for nearly 33.5km of the project, including the alternative analysis report. UMTC will also offer transaction advisory consultancy services for the bidding process management. The state government on Thursday authorised the Amaravati Metro Rail Corporation to enter into an agreement with the UMTC.

Speaking to TOI, AMRC managing director NP Ramakrishna Reddy said UMTC would prepare the DPR in six months. “We will initiate bidding process for the metro rail project in the fourth month after the start of the preparation of the DPR. The bidder for the second phase project will be finalised by the end of this month. We have received two bids for the preparation of the DPR,” said Reddy.

Title: Five major temples closed
Content:
Ahmedabad: In a bid to curb gathering of people in large numbers amidst threat of spread of COVID-19 virus, the Gujarat government on Thursday decided to close its five major temples for devotees from Friday.

The state government’s decision came nearly four days after it shut its educational institutes, and incidentally on the day when it detected two positive cases first time in the state.

The five major pilgrimages that will remain close for pilgrims are at Ambaji in north Gujarat, Somnath and Dwarka in coastal Saurashtra, Dakor and Pavagadh in central Gujarat. The administration has decided to completely restrict entry of devotees in these temples from March 20. However, the puja and other rituals will continue to take place as usual in all these temples.

The decision to close these temples was taken in a meeting convened by chief minister Vijay Rupani and DyCM Nitin Patel.

Meanwhile, for the first time in five decades, the Nadeshwari Mata temple in Jaloya village near Nadabet of Banaskantha’s Suigam taluka will remain closed for devotees for indefinite period.

Title: Vadodara: Two test negative, reports of three awaited
Content: VADODARA: Two persons admitted at the GMERS Medical College and Hospital , Gotri tested negative for COVID-19 on Thursday even as three other suspects, whose samples were sent for testing, remained under observation at the SSG Hospital (SSGH) in Vadodara.Sources said that the duo admitted at the Gotri hospital who tested negative on Thursday was a couple that had returned from Dubai. Three others under observation include persons who had travelled to Spain, USA and Sri Lanka. The person who returned from Spain has been admitted since Tuesday night, but test results are yet to arrive.Sources in the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) said that 108 persons who had travelled to the city from abroad are kept under home quarantine. These include 47 persons who were traced since Wednesday and were advised to stay in isolation at home.Meanwhile, the civic body also issued notices to 119 persons including those quarantined at home to follow directives strictly. Officials in the civic body said that this was done to ensure that they did not venture out or come in contact with others in the family. The decision to issue the notices was taken in wake of the incidents of people quarantined or advised isolation at home running away.VMC medical officer (health) Dr Devesh Patel said that those in contact with the suspected COVID-19 cases at SSGH were also advised to stay in isolation at home. “If any cases test positive, we will begin further activity as per the protocol,” he said.

Title: AP: Forest officer in ACB net
Content:
VIJAYWADA: The officials of Anti-Corruption Bureau ( ACB ) on Thursday arrested the deputy forest range officer at Tirupati , Chittoor , for amassing illegal assets (movable and immovable).

The ACB raided the houses of A Venkata Chalapathi and his relativesin Tirupati.

The ACB officials found a G+1 house, in the name of Chalapathi’s wife in Tirupati and G+5 house building in Chalapathi’s brother-in-law name. Apart from the immovable assets, the ACB officials seized 390 gms of gold ornaments, one car and three two-wheelers.

Title: Two persons murder man in Guntur
Content: VIJAYWADA: A man was murdered by two persons at Pattabhipuram in Guntur district on Thursday. The deceased has been identified as Sk Nag Kumar, while the accused are Manga Raju and Pullayya . Police suspect an illicit affair might be the reason for the murder .

Title: Coronavirus scare: Hyderabad schools reschedule educational trips abroad
Content: HYDERABAD: After the coronavirus outbreak, city schools are rescheduling educational trips abroad. The Hyderabad Public School (HPS), Begumpet rescheduled its Nasa trip for this year.The school management sent out a message to all its parents stating that each parent will have to incur loss of around Rs 91,000 if the trip is cancelled now.“65 students had enrolled for the trip that was scheduled for April-end. However, keeping in view safety of the students, we have decided to reschedule,” said Skand Bali, principal of HPS, Begumpet.Meanwhile, P Obul Reddy Public School too has rescheduled it's trip to Nasa. 70 students were expected to go to Nasa in May. Now, we have rescheduled the trip to October-end,” said Lata Shankar, principal of Obul Reddy Public School.Chirec International School rescheduled an exchange programme and a trip to CERN in Geneva while other schools such as Silver Oaks, Oakridge International School, Johnson Grammar School put their expeditions on hold.

Title: Nagpur: Rahate Colony, Bansi Nagar Metro stations ready
Content:
NAGPUR: MahaMetro will open two more Metro stations by the end of this month. The Rahate Colony and Bansi Nagar stations are ready and Commissioner of Metro Rail Safety ( CMRS ) has been invited to inspect them. The inspection is likely to take place between March 27 and 29.

A Metro spokesperson said that the stations would be immediately opened after CMRS gave the green signal. “Rahate Colony is on the Sitabuldi to Khapri stretch (Reach I) while Bansi Nagar is on Sitabuldi to Lokmanya Nagar stretch (Reach III). We expect our ridership to increase on both reaches after these stations open. This had happened after we opened the Jaiprakash Nagar station on Reach I,” he added.

Rahate Colony station should have started functioning in October of November 2019. It is four to five months behind schedule. When Reach I had become operational in March 2019, MahaMetro had promised to open the remaining stations of the stretch — Jaiprakash Nagar, Rahate Colony, Ajni Square, Ujjwal Nagar, Congress Nagar and Chhatrapati Nagar — by December 2019. Now, Metro is unable to say when all these stations will open.

According to the spokesperson, Ajni Square station was almost ready and was likely to open in April subject to CMRS inspection.

Commenting on the delay in opening stations, the spokesperson said that the contractor ILFS had gone bankrupt and left the work halfway. “We had to retender the work and award it to other companies. Two to three months were wasted in the process,” he added.

He further said that Ujjwal Nagar station was facing land acquisition problems as the land owner had moved the court. “It will be the last to open,” he said.

On completion of entire Nagpur Metro project, he said that the deadline was March 2021. “We will complete Sitabuldi to Prajapati Nagar (Reach IV) and Sitabuldi to Automotive Square (Reach II) by then,” he further said.

Title: Alleging Rs 145cr misappropriation, oppn seeks probe into laptop scheme
Content:
Bengaluru: Opposition parties on Thursday took the government to task over alleged misappropriation of Rs 145 crore in the procurement of laptops for 2019-20 as part of the Laptop Bhagya scheme, demanding an investigation into the issue. Meanwhile, the government said it will discontinue the programme from the upcoming academic year.

Opposition leader Siddaramaiah, while speaking on the budget, claimed that a Right to Information (RTI) query filed by former Congress higher education minister Basavaraj Rayareddi said the government has procured over 1 lakh laptops at a cost of Rs 28,320 per gadget.

“However, the same laptops were procured at a cost of Rs 14,920 per piece when my government launched the scheme. Notwithstanding inflation, no laptop can cost Rs 13,380 extra within three to four years,” claimed Siddaramaiah.

While BJP legislators claimed the laptops offered were of high quality, Congress alleged there’s not much difference in the configuration.

Intervening in the matter, chief minister BS Yediyurappa said the decision to procure the laptops at a higher price was, in fact, approved by the previous coalition government. “The decision was taken on June 14, 2019, when the coalition government was still in power,” said the CM.

Former JD(S) minister Bandeppa Kashempur said the issue was deferred twice and cleared during the final cabinet meeting. “However, not all cabinet decisions have to be implemented. The BJP government could have stalled the proposal and had a relook,” he said.

Both JD(S) and Congress have demanded an investigation by an impartial agency, but CM Yediyurappa is yet to respond.

Meanwhile, deputy chief minister CN Aswath Narayan, who holds the higher education portfolio, said the government would not continue with the scheme from the upcoming academic year owing to financial constraints.

“The government has spent Rs 311 crore on the scheme in the current financial year and it’s seen as a huge burden on the exchequer. We have decided to discontinue the scheme. Instead, we will focus on enhancing the quality of college infrastructure and improving standards of teaching staff, so that they can be eligible for National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC) accreditation,” Narayan told the house during Question Hour.

The Siddaramaiah-led Congress government in 2016-17 had launched the free laptop scheme to distribute the gadgets among first-year Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe students in government colleges. It was extended to students from all castes whose family annual income was less than Rs 2.5 lakh. The scheme was put on hold in 2017-18 and 2018-19 and was resumed in 2018-19 during the JD(S)-Congress coalition regime.

Narayan said about one lakh students were given laptops in the current academic year and funds have not been allocated for the scheme in the budget for 2020-21.

Title: Govt amendment relaxes land norms for ailing industries
Content:
Bengaluru: Amid a walkout by the opposition, the ruling BJP passed an amendment to the Karnataka Land Reforms Act by allowing private industries on the verge of collapse to sell land to another buyer or company.

Opposition parties claimed the amendment was anti-farmer, saying the land purchased from ryots will now be used for making profits with nefarious intentions.

Introducing the bill, revenue minister R Ashoka and law minister J C Madhuswamy said the amendment was being introduced to allow industries, under Section 109 of the Act, to sell the land only after a period of seven years. It can be sold only for the purpose for which permission was initially obtained.

“We have seen industrialists who have made huge investments but have committed suicide and some who have fled the country after being unable to repay loans. They have even left their employees high and dry,” said Ashoka, while justifying the amendment.

Interestingly, the bill comes around the same time when the family of Cafe Coffee Day (CCD) founder VG Siddhartha has decided to sell 10,000 acres of plantations and other assets to repay lenders. Under the original Act, industrialists are allowed to sell 40 units or 216 acres of land if the company is under distress.

Opposition leaders, including former industries minister RV Deshpande, contended that blanket authorisation to sell land would result in the real estate mafia entering the business and fake industrialists trying to make huge gains. “While a company would have purchased 100 acres of land for setting up an industry, it may use only 20 acres for the purpose. However, when the industrialist cites distress, he/she will seek permission to sell all 100 acres. This way, he/she will also make a considerable windfall from the sale,” said Deshpande, suggesting the government consider restricting the sale of land.

However, the government defended the bill, saying checks and balances would be in place. Not convinced by the response, opposition parties walked out of the assembly and the bill was passed amid the din.

Box: DKS differs from party line

KPCC president DK Shivakumar ruffled some feathers in the Congress legislature party after he moved a member’s amendment to the Karnataka Land Reforms Act. As the debate was raging, Shivakumar arrived in the house and was seen telling opposition leader Siddaramaiah to move an amendment. However, Siddaramaiah differed with his party colleague and asked him to withdraw it.

Later, when speaker Vishweshwar Hegde Kageri called upon Shivakumar to explain his proposed amendment to the bill, the Kanakapura MLA said: “I understand the problem of sections 109 and 79 (a) and (b) that make way for underhand dealings to deputy commissioners, assistant commissioners, tahsildars and revenue inspectors. As an educationist myself, I have faced a lot of problems in getting land converted. However, considering my party line, I would not like to speak any more about the issue,” he said.

Title: Covid-19 outbreak in Chennai: 'Going door-to-door to make sure all is well'
Content:
Corporation staff disinfect a locality in Arumbakkam.

CHENNAI: Armed with just a mask on his face, a green vest over his shirt and a register in his hands, 30-year-old M Venkatesan set off through the narrow alleys of Arumbakkam in Central Chennai, ringing doorbells and watching out for dogs before opening gates to apartment complexes and gather data on residents suffering from fever or any other communicable diseases. A domestic breeding checker (DBC) with Greater Chennai Corporation, Anna Nagar zone, he has been doing it for eight years. But on Thursday morning, his job assumed greater significance. Venkatesan is visiting residents living around a 100m radius of the house in which Tamil Nadu’s second Covid-19 positive case stayed. The 20-year-old patient, a hairdresser, was working in a local salon which has now been shut. TOI visited the spot on Thursday morning and found that the man hails from Rampur district of Uttar Pradesh and had come to Chennai on March 12 from Delhi on a train. Seven of his roommates have been quarantined at a facility in Poonamalee. Another resident living in the same complex is likely to be sent to the Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital and swab-tested for the virus. So far, the others have not shown any symptoms, the official said. From Wednesday evening, the entire area has been fogged and disinfected extensively. Health officials left the area at midnight and returned at 8am to take stock. Keenly observed by his superior, senior entomologist Thenmozhi, Venkatesan entered an apartment complex in ward 105. As he rung the door bell and announced that he had come from the corporation, a man in a vest and lungi rushed out. “How many families live here? Does anyone have fever? Has anyone visited a foreign country recently?” These were the standard questions posed to the house owner. An additional question was about whether anyone had a haircut in the nearby salon or its branch on the neighbouring street. “We have started collecting details of travel to Delhi,” said Thenmozhi. Every ward in each of the 15 zones has 80 DBCs who have to visit 80 homes from 7am to 2pm, rush back to the ward office and submit the compiled data to the sanitary inspector. “This is then sent to the zonal health officer and the headquarters,” Thenmozhi said. Every DBC has to file data regarding the number of houses visited, members, the travel list, how many doors were locked and how many rejected. Meanwhile, the man in the vest, 52-year-old Sivakumar, took Venkatesan to a house on the first floor. A youngster had returned from Germany last week. Although he did not show any symptoms of Covid-19, Venkatesan and Rajendran Prasad, a field assistant, took down his travel details. “He will be called up every day and asked about his health status. He has our contact details and has to inform if he catches a cold or has fever,” said Dr Priyadarshini, zonal health officer. While sincerity and tenacity are important skills for a DBC, the effectiveness of data collection also depends on how residents respond, Thenmozhi said. “Some people don’t share particulars. Some tell us to leave and that they would get themselves treated at a private hospital,” she said. Next stops were a general store and a grocery shop. Shopkeepers got the same advice and a pamphlet was stuck on a wall. Venkatesan spotted a small room beside the shop and found that some migrants lived on the first floor. He asked a boy from Rajasthan about his recent visits. “Nobody has returned from foreign. Nobody has fever,” the boy said. The zonal level officials held a health camp in the area on Thursday, but found that there wasn’t any alarming number of fever cases. People living in and around the area have been asked to quarantine themselves and maintain social distancing, avoid going out and maintain high levels of personal hygiene. The zonal level officials have also stepped up surveillance of fever cases in the area, the official added.

Title: Telangana students brave pandemic to appear for SSC exam
Content: HYDERABAD: Braving the current situation over the coronavirus pandemic, over five lakh students appeared for the Telangana SSC exams on Thursday.This, despite other boards such as Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) and Indian School Certificate Examinations (ICSE) rescheduling exams for classes 10 and 12 post-March 12. The SSC examination was held from 9 am to 12.30 pm.In Hyderabad district , of the 71,219 registered candidates, 70,497 were present for the first language paper held on Thursday. No cases of malpractices were booked on the first day in the 363 centres across the city. Amid heavy security outside every centre, students were seen wearing masks and carrying hand sanitisers inside the examination hall.While students were allowed to enter the examination hall by 8.30 am, they were not allowed to gather near the centre in large numbers keeping in line with social distancing norms. A centre in Bowenpally voluntarily distributed masks to all the students before entering the examination hall.Before the commencement of the exam, a two-minute instruction was given to all the students to not touch their face or sanitise their hands frequently.As a precautionary measure, the district education officers instructed the centre heads to sanitise all the benches before and after the examination.Students who had self-declared at the examination centre that they had symptoms such as cold, cough or fever were made to sit in separate rooms.According to officials, only one such case was reported in the Hyderabad district. “We came across only one such case in the Old City area where the student was allowed to sit in a separate room to appear for the exam as he had cold...Invigilators are constantly making students aware of the precautionary measures,” said district education officer of Hyderabad, Narasamma.

Title: Coronavirus concerns: Telangana MLA returns from US but not under quarantine
Content: HYDERABAD: At a time when the government is trying to keep the spread of coronavirus Covid-19 ) in check, Sirpur-Kagaznagar MLA Koneru Konappa was exempted from the mandatory quarantine . The legislator, who returned from the United States on Wednesday, was allowed by state health authorities to go to his assembly constituency and move about freely.This, as passengers coming from foreign countries are being moved to mandatory quarantine for a period of 14 days.The TRS MLA along with his wife had returned on Wednesday and reached Kagaznagar by train that afternoon itself. He attended the municipal council meeting of Kagaznagar municipality and also attended a programme along with his wife and 108 staffers at Venkateshwara Swamy temple at Ganugampuram in Asifabad district. The legislator was not seen wearing a mask and is also said to have met several people at his residence and outside to address grievances.Interestingly, municipal administration principal secretary Arvind Kumar, who came back from the USA is under home quarantine for the past six days despite testing negative for coronavirus, both the at the airport and at Gandhi Hospital. He has not been attending any official meetings.Union minister of state V Muraleedharan is under self-quarantine after he visited a medical institution in Kerala where a doctor was tested positive after his return from Spain while BJP MP Suresh Prabha is also under self-quarantine after he returned from Saudi Arabia on March 10.When contacted MLA Koneru Konappa confirmed that he had come back from the US on Wednesday morning and attended the council meeting and the temple programme. The legislator said that he was tested negative at the airport and district health officials had checked him and the report was negative. “I thought when the tests were negative there was no need for quarantine,” the MLA said.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: Telangana sees three fresh cases, 2,000 isloated in 1 day
Content: HYDERABAD: The number of people who have tested positive for coronavirus reached 16 in the state, even as authorities quarantined more than 2,000 people on Thursday. The three new cases include two people who returned from London, and one from Dubai.The man who returned from Dubai to his Secunderabad home on March 14, developed Covid-19 symptoms three days later.“He was immediately isolated and tested for Covid-19 as he had fever and cough. He was rushed to the Gandhi hospital, where two consecutive tests came out positive,” said a health department official. After contract tracing, six of his family members and friends were also quarantined, the official said.Officials said the 15th person to be tested positive was a traveller who came from London via Dubai to Hyderabad on March 10. He developed symptoms on March 18 and was admitted to a designated hospital on Thursday. The 16th case is that of a person who travelled from London to Hyderabad. The person has been admitted to a designated hospital.Of the 16 cases, one patient, the first positive case in the state, has recovered and was discharged from Gandhi hospital last week.Telangana has reported positive cases every day over the past one week, and on Wednesday evening, reported eight positive cases, including seven Indonesian nationals. Authorities also quarantined 711 people in their homes and put 1,292 people in the state quarantine centres spread across the city. The government said a testing facility at Osmania General Hospital has been added in addition to the ICMR laboratory at Gandhi Medical College. Covid-19 testing at NIMS and Fever hospital is expected to begin on Friday.

Title: Coronavirus: Will cooperate with government measures, says Asaduddin Owaisi
Content: HYDERABAD: Religious leaders from various Muslim organisations have announced that they would cooperate with the state government in their attempts to check the spread of coronavirus in the state. They said that they would be restricting religious gatherings at mosques and other places.Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi , along with representatives of various Mulsim organisations, met chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao at Pragati Bhavan on Thursday evening and also thanked him for passing a resolution against CAA, NPR and NRC in the state Assembly few days ago.Later addressing the media, Asaduddin Owaisi said combating the virus was a challenge and several measures were taken. “Whatever measures state government initiates, we will cooperate. We have cancelled all public meetings and urge Muslims to do their Friday prayers at home except some mandatory prayers,” he said.

Title: Covid-19: Those sans symptoms sent for home quarantine from Hyderabad airport
Content: HYDERABAD: The state government shifted 1,165 passengers, who arrived at Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) from 11 countries, to quarantine centres set up on the outskirts of the city since Wednesday night. After preliminary examination, six passengers who had flu-like symptoms were sent for further medical tests.Some passengers resisted attempts of government officials to shift them to quarantine centres, but they finally had to give in after counselling.Later, after chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao’s media briefing on Thursday, the authorities have decided to send passengers, who did not show any symptoms of Covid-19 , to their respective residences for home quarantine.Revenue and health officials of Rangareddy district and Cyberabad police coordinated in shifting the passengers, who arrived at the RGI Airport, to 10 quarantine centres. At a quarantine centre in Rajendranagar, some passengers picked up an argument with police and revenue officials, questioning them about the method of quarantine and lack of facilities.“We arranged stay at the hostel of an institution. All basic facilities were provided, but some passengers were not happy as they expected star hotel like arrangements. But, we have explained to them that they have to remain at the quarantine facility for 14 days,” a police officer from Rajendranagar police station said.Cyberabad police commissioner VC Sajjanar and Rangareddy collector Amoy Kumar initially appealed to the public not to visit the quarantine facilities to meet their family. However later, on the instructions of the CM, arrangements were made to send the passengers who do not have symptoms for home quarantine. “We are sending the passengers without any symptoms of illness for home quarantine,” Sajjanar said. Revenue, health and police personnel would monitor those under home quarantine.Based on a complaint lodged at Keesara police station, a case was booked against B Krishna Reddy, ward member of 12th ward in Keesara, for allegedly spreading rumours about coronavirus on a local WhatsApp group. A case was registered under Section 54 of the NDMA Act.

Title: Coronavirus in Nagpur: Social distancing now part of daily lives
Content: NAGPUR: Social distancing can be stressful and annoying as it may invite boredom, but considering the need of the hour citizens are practicing various techniques to keep themselves safe and sound.Dr Mrunalini Ballal is practicing social distancing keenly and has also involved a few hygienic habits in her day-to day-life. “It’s been over a week now I have avoided weddings and social gatherings. Whenever I am meeting my relatives or friends in the society I am greeting them with namaskar, and avoiding shaking hands. I am making sure to wash vegetables, fruits neatly and also washing the milk packets that the vendor delivers,” she said.Sarita Samatkar, an engineer, believes that social distancing must be practised consciously by citizens, and people are still seen wandering around in markets and shops. “I am staying at home and avoiding going out anywhere. Sometimes it feels frustrating that I cannot meet my friends but spending time with family helps. I am eating only home cooked food. I am not leaving home if there is no emergency,” she said.Adding to this, Varsha Kulkarni, a writer, is using some tips to avoid going out to the gym or vegetable market or cinema hall. “I have stopped going to my relatives’ place, hence they have also stopped visiting. I am not hitting the gym but exercising daily. I am not going to the market but buying vegetables from vendors,” she said.Manank Panchmatia has a positive approach towards social distancing. “Although we have our entire life ahead of us to meet strangers, currently it is important to take a step back in such a crisis. I am making good use of technology to make video calls, conference calls and Skype with friends,” he said.Advocate Vriddhi Bhagat is avoiding visits to the courts unless it’s some very important case as per notification of the bar association on social distancing. “It’s very difficult for a full-time professional lawyer to stay at home, and avoid public places, as that is our job. I am practising social distancing by cleaning at home and spending time with family, also making sure my parents and family members clean and sanitize their hands,” she said.Mrunal Naik, project head at SGR Foundation, is strictly avoiding any kind of public gathering and enjoying some time at home. “I am taking care cleanliness of self and area around me. At home, I am talking on the phone with the people who are isolating themselves to save others, so that they will not feel bad or depressed,” she said.For Dr Neha Rahate, who loves to socialize and try different food items, there is no going out now. “I have stopped going out to meet friends or to restaurants. From the hospital, I go to jog every evening and go directly back home. But I am enjoying the comfort of cooking food at home,” she said.It’s getting a bit difficult for students as they constantly need to go for tuitions and stationery shops for supplies. “I am not even visiting the library, but reading and studying only at home. Xerox shops and net cafés are also shut, but mobile phones and technology make it easy to study,” said Srujal Randive, a student.People working at airports and corporate sector are finding it a bit difficult as shops operate there day and night. “I am not able to completely isolate myself at home. But even at work, we are practising social distancing. We are not letting customers gather in huge numbers. Sanitizer is been given before placing any order and even in our shop, limited people work in shifts," said Roshan Khatri, manager at a food joint at the airport.

Title: Hyderabad: Nimmagadda back, in quarantine
Content: HYDERABAD: After securing legal relief from Serbian Supreme Court, industrialist Nimmagadda Prasad returned to the city on Wednesday night. However, he was immediately placed under quarantine Prasad is the accused number three in the chargesheet filed by CBI in the Vanpic case which also involves AP chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy. Prasad was the conduit between Ras Al Khaima, an UAE emirate, and the AP government which had agreed to set up the port-cum-industrial corridor Vanpic between Guntur and Prakasam districts.Al Khaima had invested more than Rs 500 crore for the purpose in 2008, but the project has been stalled for over a decade on account of the CBI probe. On July 27, Prasad was taken into custody by Serbian authorities at Belgrade when he went there in search of talented players for his football team. Based on the red corner notice issued by interpol on the complaint of Ras Al Khaima government, he was arrested by police of Belgrade in August 2019.Later he was released from prison but asked not to leave Belgrade by the authorities there. According to police, recently, a court in Serbia gave an order in favour of Prasad, allowing him to return to India.

Title: Short circuit leads to fire, 2 huts gutted in Guntur
Content: VIJAYWADA: Two huts were gutted in a fire mishap at Krosuru in Guntur district on Thursday. Police said an electrical short circuit resulted into the incident. Fortunately, there were no casualties and injuries , but over Rs 3 lakh property loss was reported.

Title: Covid-19: IMA stops all outside drills and night exercises
Content: DEHRADUN: To fight the Covid-19 virus threat, the Indian Military Academy IMA ) has stopped all outside drills and night exercises of Gentlemen Cadets (GCs) who are in the midst of training modules at the academy.So far, no case of suspected Covid-19 has been reported at the IMA where over 400 cadets, including from friendly foreign countries, are undergoing training in different courses. IMA sources said that the decision to rejig the training pattern was taken in wake of the Covid-19 outbreak in the country as a precautionary measure.Speaking to TOI, IMA spokesperson Lt Col Amit Dagar said, “We are following the instructions passed by the Centre and all gatherings and events have accordingly been stopped within the IMA premises. The GCs will not be taken out for exercises till further orders.”The GCs are usually taken outdoors for specialised training drills such as mountain climbing, long distance run, infantry mock battles and night patrolling drill in hills. “All the outdoor drills and exercise of GCs have been stopped till further notice. The main idea is to have minimum contact with others,” said the spokesperson.Also, GCs are being taught in small groups to minimise chances of spreading of infection. IMA sources said that all GCs have been given a special awareness lecture on Covid-19 and their health is being monitored by a team of doctors.

Title: Postpone Class X exams, demand teachers’ unions
Content:
Coimbatore: The State government should postpone the Class X board exams in view of the Covid-19 pandemic, representatives of teachers’ unions said.

With the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) and the Council for Indian School Certificate Examinations (CISCE) postponing the exams, schoolteachers demanded that the Class X board exam, which is scheduled to begin on March 27, be postponed.

State auditor of the Tamil Nadu High and Higher Secondary School Graduate Teacher Association (TNHHSSGTA) T Arulanandam said in view of the pandemic and health advisory seeking people to maintain social distancing, it would be wise to postpone the exams to April 20. “As the country is in a crucial phase, such measures are very important. We shouldn’t risk the safety of students,” he said. “The preparations for Class X exams are almost over and teachers have been assigned duty. We have represented the issue to the state.”

Tamil Nadu Teacher Association president P K Ilamaran demanded that Class X board exams be held in June. “The virus can spread easily among groups. Despite the precautions such as sanitising facilities, the best precautionary measure is social distancing,” he said.

The associations also demanded that exams for Classes I to IX students be cancelled. Representatives of other teachers’ associations from the state also echoed this.

Tamil Nadu Government Employees Teachers Association president S Arunan said the Uttar Pradesh government had announced that all government school students from Classes I to VIII would be promoted without exams in view of the Covid-19 outbreak. “Similarly, Tamil Nadu should also promote all students from Classes I to VIII. The state should also consider the situation and cancel Class IX exams and promote all students,” he said.

Title: Bizman arrested in woman abduction case
Content:
Salem: Police on Thursday arrested founder-president of Tamil Nadu Makkal Urimai Katchi Mohammed Ibrahim in a woman abduction case.

According to city police commissioner T Senthil Kumar, the Kitchipalayam police arrested Ibrahim based on a complaint lodged by B Harini, 43, of Srirangam in Trichy district.

In her complaint, Harini said her husband Badri Srinivasan, 46, was doing textile business in partnership with Ibrahim. “A few days ago, Ibrahim demanded Rs 18 lakh from my husband,” she said.

On March 12, Badri Srinivasan reached Salem to meet Ibrahim. Since then, he was missing, and his mobile phone is switched off, she said.

On March 13, Harini went to Salem in search of her husband and reached Ibrahim’s house.

She said Ibrahim locked her inside a room in his house and assaulted her using sharpened items.

Meanwhile, relatives of Harini came to Ibrahim’s house on Wednesday night (March 18) and rescued her with the help of the Kitchipalayam police.

Ibrahim was arrested on Thursday and lodged at the Salem central prison under judicial custody. Police are still searching for Badri Srinivasan, who went missing since March 12. tnn

Title: Cops threaten face mask machine maker
Content:
Coimbatore: Owners of a private company that manufacture machinery used for making face masks have complained that they are threatened to sell the machines to a particular company owned by the relative of a senior police officer.

In the petition to the Coimbatore collector on Thursday, Mahalingam and his son Manoj, owners of Sri Sastha Engineering at Singanallur, said that they are manufacturing machines used for making face mask and supplying to 30 clients across the country. There were several orders from clients due to the demand for the masks following the Covid-19 outbreak. However, one of the clients, who happens to be a close relative of a senior police officer, was threatening them not to sell the machines to any other company. tnn

Title: Family over finances, work for Tolly stars in self-isolation
Content: KOLKATA: It is a speech of former Coca Cola CEO Brian Dyson that has been one of the chief inspirations for Jeet during this phase of self-isolation after he returned from London on Wednesday. After reaching home, he took a steambath and strictly isolated himself from all his family members that include his elderly parents and the children at home.Jeet rattled off excerpts from Dyson’s speech where he had said: “You will soon understand that work is a rubber ball. If you drop it, it will bounce back. But the other four balls — family, health, friends and spirit — are made of glass. If you drop these, they will be irrevocably scuffed, marked, nicked, damaged, or even shattered. They will never be the same. You must understand that and strive for it”. Speaking to TOI, Jeet said, “This speech is always in my mind. When we decided to return to Kolkata, it was this concern that played on our mind. Besides, there was a travel advisory from the government regarding the UK. Of course, there will be a financial loss. But it is everyone’s safety that is more important.”Jeet has decided to stay at home. “I had all the protections when I touched down at the airport. I wore a mask and gloves as well. I took a steambath when I reached home and have not been in contact with any of my family members.”Anshuman Pratyush, director of Jeet and Mimi Chakraborty’s film, did not meet his elderly mother once he reached Kolkata. “My mother has a very low immunity system because of her age and a tumour in her pituitary gland. So, I haven’t met mom since coming back. She is at Belvedere Road while I stay at Tollygunje Phanri. I will meet her after 10 days,” Pratyush said.At home, he is staying inside a room where no one is allowed. He is wearing a mask when someone comes to speak to him from the other side of the door or when he receives food from any kin. His room has an attached washroom that has now become his personal washroom. “My wife, Sayantony, delivers food in disposable bowls,. which I overturn in my utensils in the room. The wash basin is acting as a basin-cum-sink where I wash my utensils. These don’t go out of the room for the next 10 days or so.”His five-year-old daughter, Myra, is a little upset for not being able to play with her father. “She has been pretty strong, barring an exceptional last night when she cried. She wanted to come to me since I was away for quite a few days. But my wife is explaining the situation to her. The good thing is that Myra has understood what we need to do to combat the virus,” he said.

Title: Covid-19 hatches up poultry industry’s doom in Bijnor
Content: LUCKNOW/BIJNOR: For Bijnor's poultry farmer Narender Deshwal, feeding 20,000 birds at his hatchery cost Rs 1 lakh daily. Now, with business hitting a rock bottom in view of coronavirus scare, his assets have turned into liability. Thanks to unsubstantiated social media shares linking non-vegetarian food to the spread of infection, the poultry business across the state has taken a severe hit, forcing the UP government to come out with an advisory allaying fears of panic-stricken chicken and egg-eaters in the state.“The coronavirus is transmitted human to human and as per World Animal Health Organization (OIE); poultry has not been found to be involved in transmission of coronavirus to humans so far," the advisory said, adding "consumption of Indian poultry and poultry products including eggs is safe. A general hygiene, however, may be followed.”The Centre in its letter dated March 5 and addressed to all the states had said that because of this misleading information, sale of eggs and chicken meat has drastically suffered and millions of poultry farmers dependent on poultry farming are under threat of losing their livelihood.Despite the advisory, the industry has suffered a jolt already.Deshwal himself was forced not only to destroy eggs but also new-born chicks as he was not even able to support their maintenance. He has already buried 36,000 chicks in the past two weeks. Now, bigger challenge is what to do with 20,000 alive birds at the moment. Two days day ago, a Bulandshahr-based poultry farm buried 6,000 birds alive to reduce losses.Owing to the fall in demand, wholesale price of chicken has come down drastically and is available at Rs 40 per kg in the market as compared to Rs 90 a kg earlier.Ali Akbar, president, UP Poultry Association , said: “To say in terms of financial loss is difficult right now but poultry industry in the state has collapsed. Hatcheries and farms are closing down. While government advisory has yet not reached all, social media messages creating scare have reached all and sundry.”Hatcheries are destroying fertilised eggs and poultry farms are culling chicks as there are no buyers. “Some are selling chicken for free,” said the association’s president.Moolchand, who runs a poultry farm at Dhampur-Nahtaur road in Bijnor, said, “I had set up a poultry farm two years ago with 30,000 birds. The earning was good. Things went wrong after the spread of coronavirus and the rumour on social media. Even the egg’s prices have come down from Rs 4.95 to Rs 2.15 per piece. On Wednesday, egg was sold at Rs 1.65 per piece.”“The government should come forward and extend helping hand,” he added.But, the government’s efforts didn’t calm the frayed nerves.As per state government’s poultry cell, UP has 650 poultry farms that are subsidised by government but there are thousands of private farms as well.Poultry industry involves lakhs of people considering that it’s a long chain of breeding farms, hatcheries, poultry farms and market. Beyond poultry farmers, others involved are labourers, transporters, maize and Soya farmers, vaccine and medicine manufacturers and suppliers.Dr Todarmal, joint director, poultry cell, animal husbandry department, UP, said, “We are telling people through various forums that eating eggs and chicken is safe. We are also studying the market.”The same chicken may be stored by meat processing units at minus 40 degrees for days and they would make money by selling it once the demand increases, he said. The demand might shoot up after Navratras.

Title: 70-year-old woman defeats a crocodile in Dev River, but loses her battle for life
Content:
