Javara Parmar, a 70-year-old resident of Goraj village

VADODARA: Javara Parmar, a 70-year-old resident of Goraj village, waded into the Dev River in Waghodia taluka at about 3 pm on Wednesday to wash her clothes, like every other day. However, that day the waters had turned hostile for the unsuspecting septuagenarian who came face to face with an adult crocodile .

Before she could act, the crocodile, which had sneaked into the river just few minutes earlier, caught hold of the woman’s legs. Then followed a terrifying struggle to save herself from the jaws with the help of some locals. The woman , however, succumbed to her injuries late on Wednesday night.

According to the locals, the crocodile caught hold of Parmar when she got into knee-deep water. While she raised an alarm, the shock made her stand still in the river while the crocodile locked its jaws and tried to drag her away, they said. But luckily two locals spotted her and immediately called others for help. But by then, the crocodile had already dragged Parmar under the water.

A video shot by a local of the entire incident went viral on Thursday showing three men jumping into the river and starting a battle to free the woman from the jaws of death.

Two men swam close to the reptile and tried to scare it away by hitting the water with sticks and then took on the crocodile directly which finally let go off its hold of Parmar. They quickly brought the woman to the riverbank. Parmar was rushed to a private hospital with severe injuries on her back and legs, but she died during the treatment.

Wildlife activists said that the river is home to many crocodiles and the locals have been warned not to wash clothes on its banks. However, locals often don’t pay heed to the warning and venture into the river.

Title: Two international students from boarding school in Mussoorie admitted to isolation ward
Content:
Representative image

MUSSOORIE: Two international students of a Mussoorie-based boarding school were admitted to an isolation ward in Coronation Hospital in Dehradun on Wednesday after they complained of fever and cough. Both the students had a history of travelling abroad recently.

The students were initially taken to Landour Community Hospital on Wednesday from where they were referred to Doon Hospital in Dehradun. They were later sent to the isolation ward at Coronation Hospital while their samples have been sent for testing.

Sources told TOI that both the students had reached the school on March 4 after travelling from Bangkok and Dubai.

Police and district administration officials also visited the school campus on Thursday to check whether any other students had showed similar symptoms.

Title: Mafsu files FIR, may get Nagpur Municipal Corporation show cause
Content:
NAGPUR: Two days after the mysterious disappearance of over 200 trees, the Maharashtra Animal and Fishery Sciences University (Mafsu) has filed a first information report (FIR) with the city police . Concurrently, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has held Mafsu responsible and will be issuing notices to the concerned officials.

Officials of Ambazari police station informed TOI that an offence has been registered under 379 (punishment for theft) of the Indian Penal Code. Under this section, the accused can be face imprisonment up to three years or fined, or both.

Cops said that they are trying to trace the contractor who felled the trees without permission. “We are also trying to find the matching timber in the local markets. Right now, the FIR has been registered against unidentified persons,” they added.

Mafsu officials have maintained their earlier stand of “not having any knowledge about tree felling” on its land near Telangkhedi temple.

However, the civic body has held the university responsible for not ensuring protection of age-old trees in its property. As per officials of NMC’s garden department, show cause notices will be issued to associate dean of the university, two professors and in-charge of the land. “Whoever cuts the trees, ultimately Mafsu is responsible for protection of the green cover on its land,” officials said.

They further pointed out that the land is over 35-40 acres. “Had Mafsu appointed few security personnel, they would have been known about the tree-felling,” an official added.

Environment activists said its nothing but “blame game and skipping of responsibility”. “Mafsu is primarily responsible but if it's neglecting its responsibility, the NMC too is at fault by not keeping a tab on illegal tree felling as the land comes in its jurisdiction. This needs diligent follow-up by the civic agencies. Unlike other large-scale tree felling cases, the matter should not be conveniently put to rest,” said environment activist Amit Heda .

TOI was the first to report on Tuesday about illegal felling of more than 200 trees at Mafsu land. Interestingly, the land is adjacent to Bharat-Van where thousands of trees have mysterious disappearance of thousands of trees in the last few trees had recently came to the fore.

As per the residents of Bharat Nagar who had complained about the felling, the activity has been going out since a long time. They also suspect a nexus between the university officials and tree contractor.

Title: Poor screening at railway station, bus stands
Content:
Coimbatore: While screening of international passengers at the arrival lounge of the Coimbatore International Airport has become more efficient, the screening of passengers arriving from other states via trains and buses continues to be on voluntary basis.

The entire screening and sanitation in railway station and bus stands seemed more for photo ops and official inspections, rather than detecting patients with Covid-19 symptoms. This despite increase in cases in other states and local transmission.

There is a Covid-19 medical check-up desk and help desk on the platforms of Coimbatore Junction.

The medical check-up desk has a paramedical staff with a forehead scanner.

The paramedical staff neither ask passengers whether they have any symptoms of Covid-19 nor inquire about their travel history.

When asked how many people come forward to get screened and of them how many were from affected states like Maharashtra or Kerala, the staff refused to comment. “Please ask the station director for any details,” was the reply.

However, the railways on its part has taken efforts to increase the number of times the station’s surfaces are disinfected, from the usual once in six hours to nearly once in two hours. It has also employed additional staff.

“The men just keep coming and spraying some liquid on all the seats. All it did was make the seat wet and we can’t sit on them now,” said a man waiting to board the Ernakulam-Bangalore train. As per disinfecting protocol, lyzol should not only be sprayed, but properly wiped and spread across every inch of the surface.

In Ukkadam bus stand, which receives many Kerala buses, women employed for disinfecting were seen chatting in a corner. Over an hour on Wednesday, at least three buses that arrived from Kerala and left were not wiped down. “But in the border, tyres and bodies were sprayed on and people ask us if there is any one with fever inside,” a bus driver said. Thus, if some does not volunteer due to fear of being quarantined, they pass through easily.

Title: Uttarakhand HC orders removal of Sai Temple in Rishikesh
Content:
Representative image

NAINITAL: A fortnight after the Uttarakhand high court (HC) ordered removal of all religious structures built on government land, the HC on Thursday ordered removal of a Saibaba temple built on government land in Rishikesh.

The temple had been given a removal notice by the district administration after the HC order, but its management committee — the Sai Sewa Samiti — had approached court against the notice. A bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Ramesh Chandra Khulbe which heard the matter refused to issue a stay on the notice and ordered the removal of the temple within two months.

Speaking to TOI, one of the officials of Sai Sewa Samiti said that the temple has existed at the spot for decades and hundreds of devotees visit it daily, and therefore, the administration should have taken a considered view before sending a notice. “The court has given the administration two months to remove the temple. However, we will go through the order and decide the future course of action accordingly,” the official said.

To recall, the HC had on March 4 ordered the removal of all temples, mosques, churches and gurdwaras built on public land. This came after the HC took suo motu cognisance of the fact that several religious structures were encroaching on public parks, streets, and other public spaces.

The abundance of illegal religious structures across Uttarakhand has been a serious public issue. In fact, the Himalayan state was the only state to not file an affidavit in the Supreme Court despite it giving clear directions in January 2018 that directed the state chief secretaries to frame policies in consultation with the government in this regard.

Title: Kerala to spend Rs 78cr from SDRF to fight coronavirus
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state government will spend Rs 78.4 crore from the state disaster response fund SDRF ) for containing and preventing Covid-19 pandemic The state government has been given the liberty to utilize the funds from the SDRF as the Centre has announced Covid-19 as a notified disaster and permitted the use of SDRF to deal with it.The funds will be used for measures for quarantining, sample collection, screening, procurement of essential equipment and setting up laboratories for response to Covid-19 outbreak.As per Centre’s regulations, the state can spend 25% of SDRF allocation for the ongoing financial year for quarantine measures, sample collection and screening and 10% of the allocation for procurement of essential equipment and setting up laboratories. The total allocation for SDRF for the state for the ongoing year is Rs 224 crore.The measures for quarantine and sample collection include provision for temporary accommodation, food, clothing and medical care for people sheltered in quarantine camps (other than home quarantine) and for cluster-containment operations. Funds can also be used for checking, screening and tracing the contacts. The cost of setting up additional laboratories, cost of consumables, personal protection equipment for healthcare, municipal, police and fire-force authorities also can be met from these funds. The funds will also be utilized for procuring thermal scanners, ventilators and air purifiers.However, the state’s attempt to seek permit from the Centre to utilize the funds also for providing financial assistance to families in case of death due to Covid-19 and for meeting the expense for the treatment of positive cases has failed.The Centre had issued an order last Saturday, in which it was said Rs 4 lakh can be provided to the family of a deceased person including those involved in relief operations or associated in response activities. It had also said the cost of hospitalization for all those persons who have been detected positive in the test of Covid-19 can also be met from the SDRF. Later in the day, the Centre issued a revised order by removing these two crucial purposes for which SDRF funds can be utilized.The state has now issued an order releasing the funds to be utilized only for those purposes that have been listed as per the Centre’s revised directive.

Title: Self-help groups come up with low cost face masks, sanitizers
Content:
Coimbatore: Low-cost face masks and hand sanitizers made by self help groups (SHG) are all set to hit the market.

The district administration has roped in 25 SHGs to make face masks that will be sold to public and government departments within two days. Experts from the office of deputy director, public health and preventive medicine at Race Course had trained members of six SHGs to make cheap hand sanitizers.

SHG members displayed some of the products they made, at the district collectorate on Thursday. They managed to sell as many as 100 face masks and some hand sanitizers.

While cotton face masks are sold for Rs 8 to Rs 10, non-woven masks are priced at Rs 17.

Collector K Rajamani said the measure will help to check shortage of the protective gear to fight Covid-19. “The SHGs are selling liquid soap, hand sanitizers, phenyl and bleaching powder. As many as 1,000 SHG members are involved in creating awareness about Covid-19,” he said. “Government as well as private firms, NGOs and commercial establishments can approach the Mahalir Thittam office at the collectorate to procure the products. They can also contact the office at 0422-2301855 for face masks and hand sanitizers.”

Title: Covid-19: Haj House in Karipur to be turned into isolation centre
Content: MALAPPURAM: State Haj House in Karipur would be converted into Covid care centre to provide shelter for people who want to be self-monitored.The decision to set up the facility in Haj House was taken a few days ago after the state haj committee responded positively to the request of district collector Jafar Malik. Committee chairman C Muhammed Faizi said the Haj House would be officially handed over to the district administration on Friday for the purpose. Revenue authorities said the centre would start functioning in a few days.Faizi said all facilities, including rooms and beds, in the haj house can be used for the Covid centre. The centre is being opened with an aim to provide shelter to foreign travelers and people from other states who want to be quarantined. Special medical squads and volunteers would be deputed at the centres for those who are under observation.The district will open two more centres apart from the Haj House.Meanwhile, the authorities in Malappuram managed to track down 3,317 people who were in contact with the two women who were tested positive for Covid-19 . According to officials, 200 people directly contacted the Vaniyambalam-based woman, while another 121 had contacted the Areekode native.Following reports that upcoming weeks would be crucial, the grassroots-level intervention by the rapid response teams (RRTs) have been strengthened in Malappuram, aiming to avoid the community spread of Covid 19 among the rural people in the district. The RRTs, which were formed in each ward across the district, have been active in the prevention activities for last four days. A senior medical official in Malappuram said that the RRTs can play a major role in preventing community spread and the team will also monitor the persons arriving from Covid affected areas of neighboruing states.The district disaster management authority will open hand wash points in 1,500 locations in the district as part of prevention activities.

Title: Damaged buildings: File affidavit on steps taken, Calcutta High Court to KMRC
Content:
Calcutta High Court

KOLKATA: Calcutta High Court on Thursday asked Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation ( KMRC ) to submit an affidavit on what steps it was taking for the houses damaged in the second phase of East-West Metro tunnelling at Bowbazar .

KMRC is implementing the East-West Metro project that is currently in its last leg of underground tunnelling between Esplanade and Sealdah. A fresh PIL has been filed by a resident of BB Ganguli Street, seeking protection for the structures, below which the tunnels are being built. The division bench of Chief Justice TBN Radhakrishnan and Justice Arijit Banerjee heard the PIL on Tuesday.

The petitioners told the court that 36 buildings had been damaged ever since tunnelling resumed on February 18. The twin Metro tunnels pass through the serpentine lanes off Bowbazar where more than 20 buildings fell and several others developed cracks during an accident last August. The HC turned down the plea.

Since September, last year, the court has been hearing a PIL filed by some residents who have objected to the tunnelling operations, especially after one of the two tunnel boring machines (TBMs) hit an aquifer on August 31, leading to subsidence and collapse of buildings. Around 700 residents had to be evacuated after the tunnelling fiasco and tunnelling work was suspended. Following a court order, the work resumed on February 18. An expert committee set up by KMRC recommended resumption of tunnelling, assuring the division bench that there was no fear of further accidents.

But now, Rajlakshmi Dhar, a resident of 122, BB Ganguli Street, has filed another PIL seeking the court’s intervention in protecting the newly damaged houses in the area. Dipankar Dhar, the counsel appearing for the petitioner, alleged that KMRC has failed to keep its promise that the tunnelling would cause no further damage to property.

Bikash Ranjan Bhattacharya, the counsel appearing for KMRC, refuted the allegation, saying all kinds of protective measures are being taken for safety of the buildings. The court then directed KMRC to file an affidavit on March 26, stating what these steps are.

Title: 5 suspected patients test negative for Covid-19
Content: Aurangabad: The swab samples of 5 coronavirus suspects sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune have come out negative.On Thursday, the district civil hospital sent swab samples of additional 23 people to the NIV on Thursday. The report of these 23 samples and that of 9 other people sent to Pune on Wednesday is awaited.Of the 23 samples sent, 20 are of those screened by the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation, 1 is of a patient isolated at district civil hospital and 2 are of positive cases admitted to a private hospital.According to the medical administrator of the private hospital where the positive cases are being treated, repeat swab test has been conducted owing to continued improving clinical and radiological parameters. “The patient continues to be on anti-viral treatment,” he said.A task force of Aurangabad branch of Indian Medical Association (IMA) carried out extensive screening of over 450 college students who came in contact with the affected woman patient before she was diagnosed with the infection.“Currently, 4 suspected patients (2 males, 2 females) having symptoms are admitted to the isolation ward of the district civil hospital. On Thursday, district civil hospital screened 40 patients,” district civil surgeon Sundar Kulkarni said.

Title: Biogas cylinder explodes in transit, 4 suffer burn injuries
Content:
Krishnagiri: Four people were injured and five shops, eight motorcycles and two autorickshaws were gutted after a truck carrying a biogas cylinder caught fire at Alasanatham near Hosur here on Thursday.

The Hudco police said the incident took place when the truck was heading to Hosur with a load of a 450kg biogas cylinder from Alasanatham. “While trying to negotiate a speed breaker, the cylinder jolted suddenly and gas started to leak. The vehicle soon went up in flames,” a police officer said.

The truck driver, whose identity is yet to be ascertained, immediately got down from the truck, which he parked on the roadside. “Within no time, the cylinder exploded and fire engulfed the five shops, one of them a hotel. Vehicles that were parked in front of the shops also caught fire,” the officer said.

Panicked, people in front of the shops started running for life. However, four of them - S Manjula, 25, of Alasanatham, Smasruth, 32, of Bihar, Aswa, 13 and Ravikiran, 9 - sustained burn injuries and they were rushed to the government hospital in Hosur. “Samsruth received 50% burns, while the rest received only minor injuries,” a doctor said.

It took nearly two hours for the fire and rescue services personnel to bring the flames under control by pressing two fire tenders into service.

Preliminary investigation revealed that a private company in the same locality had taken the cylinder for refilling to a gas agency. “The incident took place while the refilled cylinder was being transported back to the firm,” the officer said.

The Hudco police have registered a case and initiated inquiry with the private firm.

Title: Trip to Ooty turns fatal for 4 college students, 3 injured
Content:
Coimbatore: Four students of Vinayaka Mission’s Kirupananda Variyar (VMKV) Engineering College at Periya Seeragapadi in Salem and driver of the sport utility vehicle (SUV) they were travelling in were killed after the vehicle rammed a truck from behind near Avinashi in Tirupur district in the early hours of Thursday. Three other students were injured in the incident.

The Avinashi police identified the deceased as K Venkatachalam, 21, of Eduthanur village in Viluppuram district; R Rajeshkumar, 20, of Alathur in Viluppuram; V Elavarasan, 20, of Chinna Seeragapadi in Salem; P Vasanth Kumar, 21, of Sangarapuram in Viluppuram; and driver D Manikandan, of Bhavani in Erode.

According to an investigation officer, the incident took place when the students were on their way to Ooty from Salem. “To make the best use of the holidays that the state government had declared till March 31 to prevent the spread of Covid-19, the students decided to visit Ooty. They hired an SUV and started from Salem in the early hours of Thursday. When they neared Avinashi, the driver lost control over the vehicle, which rammed the truck from behind.”

While the five died on the spot, M Jayasurya, 20, of Kallakurichi in Viluppuram, C Santhosh, 21, of Jakkampatti in Dharmapuri, and M Karthik, 21, of Chinna Seeragapadi in Salem, escaped with injuries. Karthik was admitted to Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital, while the remaining two are undergoing treatment at a private hospital in Tirupur. The officer said the condition of Jayasurya and Karthik was critical.

The dead bodies were, meanwhile, the government hospital at Avinashi for postmortem, after which they were handed over to their kin in the afternoon. Preliminary inquiry revealed that the SUV driver lost control over the vehicle due to speeding. The Avinashi police have registered a case and further investigation is on.

Title: Coronavirus in Tamil Nadu: Temples cancel festivals, churches call off mass till March 31
Content:
Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams conducts a dhanvanthri yaga to prevent the spread of the virus on Thursday

CHENNAI: With two more people testing positive for Covid-19 in Tamil Nadu in the last two days, temples across the state have cancelled their annual festivals to prevent people from gathering in large numbers.

The Tamil months of Panguni and Chitharai (March-April) are famous for festivals across the state, when temple chariots are taken around temples with hundreds of devotees in attendance. “The Panguni Uthiram festival, on April 6, is being cancelled based on the health department’s advisory. Palani and other five other Murugan temples will also cancel the festival,” a Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowment (HR&CE) department official said. It is traditionally celebrated as a marriage festival at Murugan temples.

In Chennai, the Panguni fest at Mylapore’s Kapaleeswarar has been cancelled.

Undeterred by the government’s call for social distancing, a large crowd gathered at the information centre of Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams in T Nagar for a four-hour dhanvanthri yaga to beseech the Gods to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

In the Nilgiris, Protestant and Catholic churches have cancelled mass till March 31. Sources at the Catholic Sacred Heart Church in Ooty said regular mass was called off till month-end though the church will remain open for individual prayers.

“This is the Lenten period, so we were supposed to have a grand mass this Sunday. We have now been told we will be intimated about it on Saturday,” said Anthony Patrick, a parishioner at Catholic St Mary’s Church in Ooty.

Timothy Ravinder Dev Pradeep, Bishop of Church of South India (CSI), said, “More than 200 churches and 145 educational institutions and hostels fall under the Coimbatore diocese of the CSI (which includes the Nilgiris). While schools are closed till March 31, churches will have regular mass but the duration will be reduced. Awareness on hand hygiene is being created.”

Title: Made in Kovai sanitizers keep Covid-19 in check
Content:
Coimbatore: Some city-based educational institutions and brands have begun developing their own hand sanitizer as there is a huge shortage for the same in the market to break the chain of Covid-19 by maintaining hand hygiene. They seem to have taken inspiration from Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH) that has come up with a hand sanitizer called Covai Rub.

On Thursday, Sri Krishna College of Engineering and Technology (SKCET) in Kovaipudur and skincare brand Vilvah announced their own hand sanitizers. While SKCET plans to use the product on its campus itself, Vilvah would distribute its product to people at high risk of exposure to the virus free of cost. “This includes health care workers, delivery partners and scavengers in rural areas who are regularly in touch with patients,” said a statement from Vilvah.

The two are, however, aware that they could meet only a fraction of the demand. Vilvah said, “We have developed only 100kg so far, but we have received emails requesting 1,000kg. So, we want to target rural healthcare workers first and then go forward.”

J Janet, SCKET principal, said they had developed 2,000 litres of hand sanitizer, which they would fill in 100ml bottles to be placed in classrooms, library, laboratories, toilets, hostels, and halls, etc., for the use of students and staff. “The case is same with our group institutions. Our students also know they don’t need to buy sanitizer from market after they return on March 31. If we have extra, we can distribute it to the villages that we have adopted - Perur Chettipalayam and Arumugakoundanur.”

CMCH is, meanwhile, producing 10 litres of Covai Rub a day to meet their requirements. While Covai Rub contains isopropyl alcohol, glycerin and hydrogen peroxide, SKCET’s hand sanitizer contains 80% alcohol and natural ingredients like aloe vera extracts, rose petals and lavender. Vilvah’s sanitizer has 70% alcohol and other ingredients.

Title: Covid-19: For ‘wider participation’, Goa CM defers ZP elections by two days
Content:
TimesView By postponing zilla panchayat elections by mere two days for ‘wider participation’, chief minister Pramod Sawant is knowingly risking public health. On a day when Prime Minister Narendra Modi appealed to the country to exercise ‘restraint’ and emphasised on social distancing in the nation’s fight against coronavirus, Sawant with his shortsightedness has proved that people’s safety is last on his list of priorities. The chief minister seems to have forgotten that democracy is for the people and not for the politicians. Modi minced no words in underlying the gravity of the threat and said there is no room for complacency, but Sawant through his repeated actions has shown that he is unaware of the gravity of the pandemic. Even the religious bodies—church and temples—have cautioned and advised people to pray privately. But Sawant, who is guilty of addressing large gatherings, has shown scant regard to any of the guidelines. His first and foremost responsibility is the safety of the people, including children and senior citizens. By his highhandedness, Sawant is putting lives at risk. He should stop behaving selfishly and put people first.

PANAJI: The Goa government, which was adamant on going ahead with the zilla panchayat (ZP) polls on Sunday despite the central government calling for social distancing, decided to postpone the polls by two days after PM Modi called for ‘Janata Curfew’ from 7am to 9pm on March 22. They will now be held on Tuesday.“Respecting the appeal made by PM Modi for ‘Janata Curfew’ on March 22 and in the interest of wider participation of the electorate in the ZP elections, the state government, in consultation with the state election commission (SEC), has decided to postpone the ZP polling date to March 24,” CM Pramod Sawant said.While the SEC is yet to finalise counting day, which was earlier scheduled for March 23, there will be no change in the campaign period that ends on Friday.Immediately after Modi called for ‘Janata Curfew’ on Sunday over the spread of coronavirus , Sawant met with state election commissioner R K Srivastava and chief secretary Parimal Rai late Thursday night.The opposition had earlier been demanding that the ZP polls be deferred in view of Covid-19 scare.The government last month had postponed the election date from March 15 to March 22. The last ZP polls were held on March 18, 2015, and the first meeting was conducted on March 25 that year. “The five-year tenure ends on March 24. We have to constitute ZPs before that,” Srivastava had told reporters last month.A total of 203 candidates are in the running for the elections to two bodies – South Goa ZP and North Goa ZP – each consisting of 25 constituencies. BJP has fielded candidates for 43 seats while Congress has put up candidates in 38 seats. MGP, which has an informal pact with Congress, will fight the elections in 17 seats. AAP and NCP have put up candidates in 17 and six constituencies respectively. Besides, 79 independent candidates are in the fray.Forty-nine members remain to be elected to the ZPs as one from Sancoale has already been elected unopposed.Thirty of the 50 constituencies are reserved for women, ST, SC and OBC. A total of 9,500 staff were roped in for the elections that were to be held across 1,210 polling booths.The high court last month declined to stay the reservation of constituencies done by the government.Although the high court admitted the petitions, a division bench stated that it would not interfere with the election process and would hear the petitions in eight weeks, after replies were filed by the government in the matter.

Title: Fire breaks out at cocoon centre, shopping complex
Content:
Erode/Krishnagiri: Fire broke out at a cocoon centre in Gobichettipalayam in Erode and a shopping complex on Bengaluru main road in Krishnagiri town on Thursday, destroying goods worth several lakhs. However , no casualty was reported in these incidents.

K Balasubramaniam, 45, who has been running the cocoon production centre on his farmland at Balaji Nagar in Gobichettipalayam for the past 15 years, said it was around 10am when smoke emanated from the centre. “Fire suddenly engulfed the entire centre as cocoon is highly inflammable”

Balasubramaniam immediately alerted the fire and rescue services personnel in Gobichettipalayam and they brought the flames under control after an hour’s struggle.

The Gobichettipalayam police have registered a case and launched a probe into the incident. A police officer said, “We are yet to ascertain the cause of fire. The loss is pegged at Rs 10 lakh.”

In another incident, the shopping complex in Krishnagiri town caught fire around 4.30am on Thursday. Witnesses said flames started erupting from a fruits and juice stall in the complex, a portion of which was also gutted in the incident. They alerted the fire and rescue services personnel, who doused the fire after two hours of struggling.

An officer attached to Krishnagiri town police station said, “We suspect the fire could have been caused by short circuit. Wires that were installed in the juice stall were gutted. The loss is estimated at Rs 10 lakh.” The Krishnagiri town police have registered a case and further inquiry is on.

Title: Auto driver held for manhandling bus driver
Content:
Aurangabad: A 48-year-old autorickshaw driver has been arrested by city police for allegedly manhandling a city bus service driver and preventing him from discharging duty.

While the incident took place near Panchavati chowk on Tuesday evening, police managed to trace the suspect on Thursday morning.

The suspect — Ashok Ramandwal, a resident of Padmpura — has been booked under five different charges including sections 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty) and 332 (voluntarily causes hurt to any person being a public servant in the discharge of his duty) of the Indian Penal Code.

“In his complaint, the bus driver accused the autorickshaw driver of rash driving which led to an altercation. The autorickshaw driver allegedly pulled the driver out of bus and manhandled him. The accused also threatened to kill the bus driver,” a police officer said.

The suspect fled from the spot after the incident, but the bus driver and conductor managed to note down the registration number of his vehicle. “The registration number of the autorickshaw was shared with our local intelligence team that successfully traced the location of the accused. A police team reached the suspect’s home and arrested him,” the officer added.

Title: Crime branch seizes liquor stock worth lakhs, arrests 10 men
Content:
Vadodara: The detection of crime branch (DCB) seized a huge liquor cache from Makarpura-GIDC on Wednesday night. Crime branch sleuths said that the stock was for Laloo Sindhi, who runs a liquor network in the city. While the bootlegger is absconding, cops seized liquor worth Rs 5 lakh along with cash and mobile phones and also arrested 10 persons.

Crime branch had received a tip-off about Sindhi procuring a huge liquor stock which was to be distributed to the carriers for selling. “We raided the spot and caught hold of 10 persons who had come there to get their share of liquor stock,” said a crime branch official.

Crime branch officials said that they are now looking for Sindhi who has many cases filed against him under the Prohibition Act. The Bharuch crime branch officials too seized a massive liquor stock that was to be delivered to Sindhi. The cops intercepted four cars and seized liquor worth lakhs of rupees from Zuber Memon and his men.

Title: AMC imposes multi-pronged strategy against coronavirus
Content: Aurangabad: With screening for fresh arrivals in the city, launch of 24-hour helpline, designation of swab collection centres, quarantine centres and multiple treatment centres, the civic body has implemented a multi-level approach for prevention and control of coronavirus in the city.The city witnessed its first positive case on Sunday. The patient is receiving treatment at a private hospital in the city. To ensure that the virus is contained from spreading, the civic body has announced closure of schools, colleges, malls, gardens, theatres and swimming pools in the city until March 31. Pandey has also issued orders to close malls, wedding halls and gardens in city. On Wednesday, he appealed to citizens to stay indoors as much as possible for the next seven days.Following the review and directives of municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey, screening centres have started operating at the airport, railway station, Cidco bus stand and Nagar Naka. Municipal officer of health Nita Padakalkar said that 1,816 people were screened at the said centres on Thursday.Around 20 calls were received on the 24-hour helpline launched by the civic body by Thursday evening.In coordination with the district public health department, the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) and private hospitals, the AMC health department has arranged for isolation beds at district civil hospital, GMCH and private hospitals for any Covid-19 positive patients and suspected patients showing symptoms.To quarantine people coming from restricted countries, the AMC on Thursday opened a quarantine centre at Kalagram exhibition centre in Chikalthana MIDC. Confederation of Real Estate Developers’ Associations of India (Credai) Aurangabad has made provision for beds, food and sanitation at the centre.The municipal corporation has also launched 14 rickshaws to raise awareness about prevention of coronavirus on Wednesday.Canpack India Pvt. Ltd. has facilitated the service through which localities in Aurangabad, Waluj and Shendra will witness jingles about prevention of Covid 19 for the next 10 days.

Title: Last batch of 185 umrah pilgrims reach India
Content: JEDDAH: The last batch of umrah pilgrims from India left from King Abdulaziz International Airport here on Wednesday. A total of 185 pilgrims returned to Mumbai through a special Indigo aircraft, said Indian consul general Mohammed Noor Rahman Sheikh. With their departure, the final phase of the evacuation of 3,035 Indian pilgrims has been completed successfully.The last batch of umrah pilgrims for the current season were to arrive on February 27, the day when the ministry of foreign affairs decided to temporarily suspend the pilgrimage from foreign countries. In later phases, umrah pilgrimage from the Gulf Cooperation Council states as well as from within the Kingdom were also suspended.The last batch of Indian pilgrims was scheduled to return home on March 28. However, the Saudi government’s decision to suspend all international flights effective from March 15 forced all diplomatic missions and aviation companies to coordinate their efforts to send back their pilgrims before the expiry of the deadline. The general authority of civil aviation (GACA) allowed a grace period to send back some of the pilgrims who were stranded due to the disruption of flight services after the end of the deadline for departure. India and some other countries arranged special flights to send back their pilgrims.

Title: Covid-19: NRKs worried as UAE shuts doors on resident visa holders
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

KOZHIKODE: The temporary ban by the UAE government on entry of resident visa holders who are currently outside the country has in effect made the ongoing Covid-19 related travel disruptions for NRKs to the Gulf almost complete.

The decision, imposed as part of measures to contain the spread of Covid-19, is for a period of two weeks, subject to renewal. The UAE is home to 8.3 lakh NRKs and the announcement has caught many expats who had come on leave or had sent their family members home unawares. With this, all the six GCC countries, except Bahrain, now have travel restrictions in place for expats from India. Other GCC countries like Saudi Arabia , Kuwait , Oman and Qatar had already announced entry restrictions.

Karipur airport, which has international flights only to the Gulf countries, is left in an unenviable situation of being able to having flights to just one country- Bahrain. The restrictions have severely hit flight operations and passenger traffic with majority of flights getting cancelled.

Airport director K Srinivasa Rao said as of now the only flight that is scheduled to operate is the Air India Express flight to Bahrain.

The UAE had on Wednesday suspended issuance of visas upon arrival and all types of labour permits, including drivers and domestic workers, effective Thursday.

“Though expats are bound to face travel-related uncertainties on the personal front, there is no reason to worry about their jobs or visa status as the UAE government is expected to take a considerate view on the matter,” P K Anwar Naha, an NRK based in Dubai said.

The UAE government has requested all residence visa holders outside the UAE to contact the country’s diplomatic missions in their respective countries for support and to provide a way of returning.

Title: New Hussainsagar master plan envisages a tourist spot
Content:
Hussainsagar lake

HYDERABAD: The Hyderabad Metropolitan Development Authority (HMDA) has decided to prepare a fresh master plan on Hussainsagar , having failed in its previous attempts to rid the lake of pollutants and unbearable odour.

Senior officials said the government was keen to turn Hussainsagar into a national and international tourist destination. S Jeevananda Reddy of Centre for Sustainable Environment pointed out that HMDA was found wanting in its efforts to keep the lake and its surroundings clean.

“HMDA has spent Rs 350 crore on Hussainsagar cleaning, but the lake still reeks of pollution. Several commercial establishments have come up on the lakebed by violating the norms. Neither HMDA nor the Telangana State Pollution Control Board has taken action against them,” he told TOI.

However, officials said HMDA would go the whole hog to give Hussainsagar a new look replete with international standards. “The Hussainsagar area will get a distinct identity. We will make the lake area visually appealing and an enjoyable destination for tourists. Presently, the Buddha Purnima Project Authority areas (lake surroundings) have entertainment facilities,” a senior HMDA official said.

The lake area would be divided into two stretches — Indira Chowk to Buddha Bhavan and Buddha Bhavan to Sanjeevaiah Park — covering a distance of 5 km, the perimeter of the lake.

Officials said designs and concept plans were yet to be prepared for which HMDA has recently invited request for proposal (RFP) for consultancy services for redevelopment and preparation of master plan. “The consultant will give detailed design drawings for development of the lake on engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) mode,” an official said.

HMDA had taken up integration of master plans four years ago. Last year, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao had asked the municipal administration department to come up with a new master plan for HMDA. But, there has been no forward movement on that front.

Jeevananda Reddy said the government wants to convert the entire Hussainsagar lake area into a real estate venture in the name of redevelopment.

“The CM talked about making Hussainsagar water pure and potable. But, the authorities have forgotten about the cleaning work,” he added.

Title: Garlic, shallot prices soar as rumours spread they could prevent Covid-19
Content:
Representative image

ERODE: Panic buying after rumour-mongers spread messages that small onion and garlic would cure novel coronavirus has led to increase in prices of vegetables in markets across the district.

On Thursday morning, hundreds of people thronged the weekly shandy in Sathyamangalam to buy grocery and vegetables.

“Usually, only locals will come to the shandy. But this time, villagers from nearby villages have also came to the shandy due to the fear of lockdown over Covid-19,” M Saravanan, one of the vendors said.

Using the opportunity, vendors in the shandy hiked the vegetable prices.

One kilo of tomato, which was sold for Rs 5 until Wednesday, was sold for Rs 20 on Thursday. Similarly, one kilo of small onion, which was sold for Rs 30, was now sold for Rs 80. “The price of garlic has increased to Rs 100 from Rs 50,” A Raja, one of the buyers said.

According to the shandy vendors, they usually bring three tonnes of small onions for sale. “Due to sudden demand for small onions, we brought eight tonnes on Thursday,” S Venkatesh, an onion vendor said. Agents who had huge stock sold it for exorbitant price utilizing the opportunity.

“Many of my regular customers have purchased huge quantity of vegetables from my shop,” P Ganesan, another vendor added.

Meanwhile, Erode-based activist A Aadhavan urged the state government to keep the vegetable and essential commodities prices on control. “Many vendors will utilize the opportunity to increase the prices,” he lamented.

Title: BATU research center to come up in city
Content:
Aurangabad: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Technical University (Batu) has announced the setting up of a research centre on Mechatronics and cyber-security at Aurangabad . An official resolve to this effect has been passed in the recent meeting of the executive council of Batu recently.

The proposed facility will have three teachers of the rank associate professor and will promote research in chosen fields.

Ulhas Shiurkar, principal of Deogiri Institute of Engineering and Management, who is also the co-coordinator for Batu regional centre, said that the research centre on Mechatronics and cyber-security should come up at the earliest.

“It is a good initiative to promote research in the fields of Mechatronics and cyber-security. The proposed facility will be beneficial to students, teachers and local industries,” he said.

Batu authorities said that the location and other infrastructural arrangement for the proposed centre will be finalized shortly.

Notably, Batu has been recently enrolled as the institutional member in the National Cyber Safety and Security Standards. The recognition and benefits associated with it can be utilized for the proposed research centre at Aurangabad. The National Cyber Safety and Security Standard, a national level body, has vision of setting up research centres across the country in collaboration with various colleges and universities.

“Mechatronics has emerged as the multidisciplinary branch of engineering. It focuses on the engineering of both electrical and mechanical systems and incorporates streams such as robotics, electronics, computer, telecommunications, systems, control, and product engineering. Being an educational and industrial hub, Aurangabad is an ideal place for setting up the research centre,” Shiurkar said.

Title: Four admitted to CMCH’s isolation ward
Content:
Coimbatore: Four more people, including a couple, with symptoms of Covid-19 were admitted to the isolation ward of the Coimbatore Medical College Hospital (CMCH) on Thursday.

The couple from Mettupalayam returned to the city from a trip to Sweden on Monday. They developed symptoms like sore throat, cold and difficulty in breathing while under the mandatory 14-day home quarantine in Mettupalayam.

“The couple in their fifties approached us today (Thursday). As per protocol, we sent them to CMCH in a 108 ambulance,” dean of the Mettupalayam GH Dr Seralathan said. “However, both are stable and could have fever due to a general flu and pneumonia,” he added.

Later in the day, a girl in her twenties who had returned from Spain a week back, called the health department complaining of throat pain. She was then called to CMCH, taken a throat swab to test for the virus and then admitted to the isolation ward.

Another girl from Udumalpet with symptoms of Covid-19 was also admitted to the isolation ward. The girl has a travel history to Bengaluru.

In the corona observation centre, 118 people who landed from Air Arabia flight at 3am on Thursday were kept under observation for 12 hours and then sent off to home quarantine at 3pm. “We did not find anyone in the risk group among the 118 people,” deputy director of public health Dr G Ramesh Kumar said.

Hours after Chennai recorded a third Covid-19 positive case, the health department began screening domestic passengers at the Coimbatore airport. “The second Chennai case, a barber from Rampur, is a case of community transmission and local transmission, and he travelled across the country. So, we must start screening passengers travelling within states too,” a health department official said.

Meanwhile, the food safety department has requested hotels and restaurants to take extra measures to prevent spread of Covid-19. The measures include setting up a clear cleaning chart of how many times they disinfected all the surfaces in restaurants, ensure they have hand soaps or hand sanitizers next to their wash areas and toilets and have banned any employee with a cold, cough or fever from working on the premises. “Covid-19 symptoms and helpline number too have to be displayed in front of restaurant’s entrance, above hand wash area and cashier,” a press statement said.

“Star hotels should also update us if anyone from outside the state or country is staying in their hotel,” it added.

Title: Telangana pharma student rape case: Accused gets life term
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: The accused who had kidnapped and raped a pharmacy student in Hayathnagar in July last year was sentenced to life imprisonment by a local court in LB Nagar on Thursday.

Rachakonda police said that 38 criminal cases were registered against the accused, A Ravi Shanker, since 2001.

The trial in the sensational case began on February 13 and 27 witnesses were examined. Police also provided CCTV footage and produced other evidence in the court.

In July last year, the accused had approached the victim’s father who runs a hotel at Hayathnagar and claimed that he was a doctor at Osmania Hospital .

He told the victim’s father that he could help the victim land a job.

Later, he took the woman and her father for a ride in the city. When they reached the hotel, he asked the father to get his daughter’s certificates.

As the father got down from the vehicle, Ravi sped off with the victim.

A week later, Ravi abandoned the victim at Addanki in Prakasam district . She took a bus to Hyderabad and two days later, the police arrested Ravi.

Ravi has been convicted in three different cases in the past.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: ‘I don’t want to endanger kin, Kolkatans’
Content: A 26-year-old pastry chef at a Michelin 3-star restaurant Azumendi in Bilbao , who landed in Kolkata on Thursday morning, spoke to TOIWhen the flight touched down in Kolkata at 2am on Thursday, it was a relief. My journey had begun in Bilbao, Spain , at 5.45pm local time on Tuesday when I took a Vueling Airlines flight to Barcelona.From there, I boarded the 6.45pm Qatar Airways flight to Doha the same evening. At 9.25pm on Wednesday, I took the Qatar flight to Kolkata. But when we were told that everyone would be taken to a government quarantine facility, there were murmurs of discontentment. After all, none have been exposed to a government hospital and held a very grim view of it. Much of the apprehensions got allayed at the first glimpse of the New Town facility. We were called by turns and asked about our travel history and health. Those who were assessed to be fine were allowed to go home and advised to stay put there for the next 14 days. I was suffering from cold for around a month and told the doctor, who suggested that I remain under observation at the centre for a couple of days. I agreed. Not only did the facility look fine but I also knew the importance of isolation, having witnessed Spain suffer after the virus spread in the community. I don’t want to endanger either my parents, neighbours or fellow Kolkatans I have been provided a bed on fourth floor where a few others have been quarantined. Doctors in protective gear have made their rounds. Since I am a chef, I am naturally curious about food. Considering this is a government hospital, it’s been quite good. They first served breakfast and tea, followed by lunch in the afternoon. In the evening, I had coffee and then dinner. I’ve been in touch with my parents and they too are relieved to learn about the place.(As told to Subhro Niyogi)

Title: Kerala unites to prevent community spread of coronavirus
Content:
CM Pinarayi Vijayan and opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala address Thiruvananthapuram corporation council vi... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan and opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala urged people’s representatives in local bodies to set aside adifferences and take vital steps at local-level to prevent Kerala from entering the ‘ community-transmission phase ’, ‘which the state is likely to enter in a couple of weeks’ time’.

In a joint video conference, addressing all the ward members of panchayats, municipalities and corporations on Thursday, the leaders said it was the prime responsibility of local administrations and people’s representatives to ensure that people are following restrictions and ban to keep the dreaded phase at bay.

“There’s a big possibility that the virus may spread unexpectedly in Kerala (a second phase of community spread). A local-level screening system must be ensured by local bodies and people’s representatives. They should check and see if restrictions are being followed,” said Vijayan.

Chennithala said Kerala - ‘considering the experience of other countries and experts’ - may enter the ‘community transmission phase’ in the next 10-15 days, ‘during which sources might go untraced and the number of cases might double everyday’. “We should remain united irrespective of our political differences and brace up to face such a phase, and survive,” he said.

Stressing on the need to remain alert every second to keep the situation under control, the chief minister said society should stay united even if Kerala takes unusual preventive measures.

“We were able to contain the outbreak to a certain extent, thanks to our integrated prevention activities. But, continuous intervention of local bodies, political leaders and every citizen is required now to achieve a total containment,” he said.

Pointing out that almost 30,000 persons were under observation at their homes, Vijayan said their protection and requirements were major responsibilities of the respective local administration.

There shouldn’t be denial of basic requirements, and LSGs and ward members should ensure a normal life for them as they are in ‘care centres’ and not detention, he said. Vijayan directed local bodies to act tough on those hoarding food items, provisions and medicines and to ensure their availability in the market through repeated raids and inspections. “LSGs should also involve migrant workers in prevention activities after creating the required awareness,” he said.

Chennithala, in his address, called for proper preparations at panchayat (block and district) levels to contain Covid-19.

Title: Chennai metro trains to get digital information screens
Content: CHENNAI: In a few months, sleek LED screens will replace the existing tiny route map display panels and manual announcements by operators on metro trains as Chennai Metro Rail Limited is procuring digital screens which will display route information accompanied by an audio to inform passengers on the approaching station. The screens will also generate non-ticketing revenue for CMRL as there will be provision to display advertisements.CMRL has floated tenders for design, supply, installation and commissioning of the digital display screens for its entire fleet of 52 trains which includes the 10 new trains procured for the phase-1 extension line in north Chennai.A metro rail official said the screens, which will be linked to the signalling system, will be put up in all trains for operations when the 9km north Chennai line opens by mid-2020. “Each of the four cars in a train will have these screens,” an official said.According to the tender invite, the screens will have automatic visual and audio broadcasting of route-related information in CMRL two-corridor phase-1 and phase-1 extension lines as well as inter-corridor operations between corridor 1 and corridor 2.CMRL decided to opt for display systems as the existing fleet of 42 trains are designed only for the 45km phase-1 route and stations and not does not include the stations in phase-1 extension line. The 9km line linking north Chennai from Washermenpet to Wimco Nagar with the rest of the city is expected to be ready mid-2020.The CMRL official said there may be a minimum of two screens in every train car. While one will display the route map and inform commuters when the train approaches a station, the other will have information on the amenities available at the station, feeders services, intermodal facilities and landmarks around a station.The present operational fleet has dynamic route map display panels fixed above the doors inside train cars where lights fixed next to name of every station in the route blinks as a train approaches a station. This helps commuters know where the train is headed. All four-car trains have eight such panels but only four of them work while the rest are meant to show only the route map.“Since display panels are linked to the signalling system and works automatically, we will switch off these panels and link the signalling subsystem to the LED screens,” the official said.The display panels in the current fleet are also designed to show only phase-1 routes and station from Washermenpet to Airport and Central Metro to St Thomas Mount. Since the upcoming line from Washermenpet to Wimco Nagar is only an extension of the phase-1 corridors, the same trains will also be operated from Wimco Nagar all the way to Airport. But the trains are not designed to show commuters the nine stations in the extension line. Commuters also cannot get any information on feeders services or nearby landmarks until they alight at a station and reach the concourse level.

Title: Rs 1.5 crore sanctioned for GMCH to equip itself for Covid 19
Content: Aurangabad: During his visit to the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) on Wednesday, MLA Pradeep Jaiswal reviewed the preparedness and infrastructure of the state-run hospital for Covid-19 management The hospital will receive Rs 1.5 crore for necessary upgradation and equipment for managing coronavirus from the district planning committee funds.To ensure that the district is well-equipped to handle any emergencies that arise from coronavirus outbreak, the district administration has allocated funds to strengthen the health machinery in district.District collector Uday Chaudhari said that a sum of Rs 1.5 crore has been approved for GMCH Aurangabad. Funds of Rs 2.5 crore have also been approved for the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) to purchase medical equipment and make adequate arrangements for treatment of suspected coronavirus patients, he said. The AMC has sought Rs 4.5 crore from the district administration for the purpose.The district administration said that looking at the timely utilization of the amount, more funds can be released to the civic body for coronavirus prevention and control.Incidentally, the GMCH is the only tertiary care state-run hospital in the district. Apart from Aurangabad district, it caters to patients from across Marathwada and nearby districts. In the view of Covid-19 threat, the GMCH has converted its cardiovascular thoracic surgery building into coronavirus treatment ward where 22 isolated beds and ventilator support have been arranged. The hospital, however, have been asked to increase its coronavirus management beds to 100.However, the state-run hospital runs short of medicines and crucial medical equipment. Therefore, it has sought financial assistance from the state government to increase its capacity.

Title: GHMC to add 50 more wards, Act to be amended
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: Even as finishing touches are being given to the new GHMC Act, the municipal administration department is gearing up to increase the number of wards to about 200. GHMC has 150 wards presently and population of each ward is between 40,000 and 50,000.

Sources in the government said the municipal administration department is contemplating creating a division (ward) for every 30,000 to 35,000 population. “While some divisions have around 40,000 population, especially in surrounding wards like Ramanthapur , Uppal, AS Rao Nagar and Kapra , population in Saroornagar division is 49,128 and Ramnas Pura and Kishanbagh in Old City have around 49,300,” a senior GHMC official said.

Officials said some newly-created municipalities have 1,500 people in each ward in the rural areas while maximum population is about 10,000 in municipal corporations. “In some municipal corporations like Jawaharnagar or Badangpet, total population is about one lakh, which is half of one municipal division in Greater Hyderabad ,” a zonal commissioner of GHMC said.

The state government wanted to bring the new GHMC Act in the budget session in which the government would mention the guidelines for creation of wards in GHMC. But, the assembly session was abruptly adjourned due to coronavirus impact. Sources said the government is likely to place the new Act in a special assembly session which is likely to be held next month.

Municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao said on the floor of the assembly that the government would enhance the number of wards in GHMC. “There is a need to enhance the number of divisions in Greater Hyderabad. It is expected to touch 200 divisions going by the present population in Greater Hyderabad limits,” mayor Bonthu Rammohan said.

Interestingly, municipal circles in and around Hyderabad are likely to get more wards after delimitation as population in the peripheral areas is on the rise while it is stagnant in the core areas. Presently, the Old City has about 50 wards in seven circles. “Since physical boundaries of the wards are changed in the delimitation process, there will be a change in the reservations of wards. Of the total wards, 50% of them are reserved for various categories like SCs, STs, BCs and women and changed according to their population,” a GHMC election wing official said.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: Tipplers fall in line by keeping the distance outside liquor vends
Content: KOCHI: Tipplers queuing up at Bevco outlets are being asked to keep a distance of 1m from each other as a precaution against Covid-19 . Marking lines were drawn before the outlets of Beverages (M&M) Corporation Ltd, to demarcate the position of customers but many seemed unaware of the new restrictions.“There is not much rush these days. We have also taken the help of a security guard to ensure guidelines are followed,” said a counter clerk at an outlet in Kaloor. Queue positions were marked using yellow paint on the cemented floor before the store, but three customers were seen standing close one behind the other.Bevco outlets have asked customers to wear masks , wash hands and use handkerchiefs while coughing and sneezing. It has also advised people to choose hours when the rush is less for buying liquor and avoid crowding before shops after purchase.“We are asking customers to wash their hands before entering the store. Staffers are using masks and gloves as precaution,” said an employee at Consumerfed outlet in Kadavanthra.Bevco sells liquor worth around Rs 40 crore every day and is one of the key revenue sources of the cash-strapped government.

Title: Blackbuck population rising in Kodiyakarai, finds census
Content:
Trichy: The wildlife census carried out in Kodiyakarai wildlife sanctuary at Point Calimere hints at an increasing trend in the wildlife population, especially blackbucks for which the sanctuary is known. Habitat development activities have been carried out in the last one year by the forest department which will decide on future developments based on the outcome of the census.

The two-day census was carried out by the forest department at the sanctuary by roping in volunteers from some colleges and biodiversity conservation foundation (BCF), Trichy last week.

Saying that the census reports were encouraging, S Ramasubramanian, conservator of forest, Thanjavur circle said there are adequate signs of increasing wildlife population slowly after the Gaja cyclone.

Recalling the lost blackbuck population during Gaja cyclone, he said the fact that about 48 blackbuck fawns were spotted during the census is a clear sign of a breeding population in a conducive habitat. He said the sanctuary is not meant only for protection of wild animals but sometimes it can also be used for rehabilitation of captive elephants.

A total of 41 spotted deer living in captivity for over two decades in a mini zoo in Thanjavur district were translocated to Point Calimere wildlife sanctuary. They have got acclimatised to the sanctuary and are doing well, he said.

Lesser known animals like Ruddy mongoose, civet cats and fruit bats have also been spotted during the census.

“A blueprint will be developed on what all activity is required to be carried out for habitat development in the sanctuary based on the outcome of the census,” he said.

“We can conclude if a habitat is suitable or not for an animal by searching for indirect signs that they leave,” said founder director of Biodiversity Conservation Foundation (BCF) A Kumaraguru.

“In the case of blackbucks, there are effective signs of the animal utilising the space. Blackbucks are very sensitive and earmark lavatory sites and leave urinal markings apart from debarking trees with their spiral horns. We could find such indicators in many parts of the sanctuary,” said Kumaraguru.

Indian Jackal is the biggest predatory species at the sanctuary which was spotted in eight transect line, he added.

Title: Prime suspect in trader’s abduction & murder held
Content:
Pune: The city crime branch claimed to have nabbed the prime suspect in the murder of Laxmi Road-based shoe shop owner, Chandan Shewani (48), from Mahuli village in Satara district on Wednesday and seized three pistols as well as 40 live cartridges from him.

Police identified the mastermind of the murder as Parvez Hanif Shaikh (42) of Hadapsar, an ex-convict in a 2018 body offence case registered by the Sangvi police. Shaikh, having a history of arrests in 18 serious crimes, walked out of the Yerawada central prison in February last year on completion of his jail-term.

Shewani, the shoe shop owner, was accosted and abducted from Maldhakka Chowk while he was returning home in his car on the night of January 4. The following day, he was found dead with a couple of bullet wounds at Padegaon village near Lonand in Satara district. The police later arrested five suspects, including an employee from his shop, but still had no clue about the murder motive.

On Thursday, additional commissioner of police (crime) Ashok Morale said, “Shaikh plotted Shewani’s abduction for extortion, but the suspects opted for killing him as he was reluctant to part with money and was evasive about his financial status.”

DCP (crime) Bachchan Singh, ACP (crime) Shivaji Pawar and crime branch inspector Mahendra Jagtap worked on various leads to track and arrest Shaikh.

Shaikh’s role in the crime came up during the interrogation of the five arrested suspects — Afridi Rauf Khan (23) of Nana Peth, Sunil Namdev Gaikwad (49) of Kondhwa, Kiran Sunil Kadam (21) of Hadapsar, and Ajinkya Hanumant Dhumal (21) and Pritam Ambre (25), both from Saswad. Gaikwad worked at Shewani’s shop and his role was to provide updates about his employer’s activities and movements.

Morale said, “Shaikh wanted money after he left prison. One of his associates took him to Shewani for securing loan from the latter, but Shewani did not entertain him. Shaikh then came in contact with Gaikwad, who told him that Shewani had good money with him. Shaikh then planned Shewani’s abduction for extortion.”

Inspector Jagtap said, “Shaikh brought the five other aides, including Gaikwad, together and promised them good money on the execution of his extortion plot. Gaikwad was providing updates to the rest of the group members and on the night of January 4, the suspects followed Shewani’s car in a four-wheeler and accosted the victim at Maldhakka Chowk before forcing him into their vehicle.”

Title: Covid-19: All malls, theatres to remain closed in Telangana till March 31
Content:
A decision on reopening the malls and theatres will be taken after reviewing the situation at the end of the m... Read More

AMARAVATI: The government has ordered the closure of all movie theatres and shopping malls in the state till March 31 to prevent the possible spread of novel coronavirus (Covid-19). The decision was taken at a high level meeting chaired by chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy at his camp office on Thursday.

A decision on reopening the malls and theatres will be taken after reviewing the situation at the end of the month.

Coronavirus in India live updates

Deputy chief minister Alla Kali Krishna Srinivas (Nani), who also holds the charge of health ministry, said the government is confident of handling the crisis effectively as adequate measures are in place to contain the spread of the virus. “Only two positive cases have been reported in the state so far, which is mainly due to the many preventive and precautionary measures taken by the government,” he said. The minister further informed that a nodal centre has been set up inside the health university campus in Vijayawada .

“Test labs have been set up in Vijayawada, Tirupati and Kakinada , and one more will come up in Ananthapuram . Isolation wards and rooms have been set up at all district and teaching hospitals in the state. Around 80 ventilators have been kept ready at the teaching hospitals and we are procuring another 100 ventilators as precautionary measure,” added the health minister. Government officials have been asked to conduct meetings through video-conferencing mode to the extent possible, while private firms have been told to encourage employees to work from home. The government has also instructed restaurants and hotels to strictly follow handwash protocols besides maintaining cleanliness and hygiene in their premises.

All marriage and function halls have been told not to accept new bookings. “Weddings which are already planned should have limited gathering. All non-essential social gatherings, including religious congregations, should be postponed,” the minister said.

Title: Year on, Hyderabad-Bhadrachalam road awaits notification, funds
Content: HYDERABAD: Touted as Jai Sri Ram Road, the development of 234km long road from Hyderabad to Sita Ramachandraswamy temple at Bhadrachalam is pending a year after Union Road Transport and Highways Minister Nitin Gadkari had in principle agreed to notify it as a national highway.Though there is already an existing highway to the temple from the city, development of the 234 km stretch to Bhadrachalam was proposed as an alternative route to the temple for convenience of devotees. This 234 km stretch from Hyderabad to Gowrelly (ORR) via Valigonda and Thorrur was supposed to be developed up till Kothagudem from where there is an already developed highway till Bhadrachalam.It is a state highway and the state government expected central funds for its development. However, the Centre has not notified it as national highway.Interestingly, this is not the only road awaiting notification and funding. Of 3,150 km, 700 km of roads have not been notified as national highways. Officials said several letters have been written to Union ministry and TRS MPs have taken up the matter with the central government to notify the roads as national highways and start funding for its development. But the response from the union ministry has not been positive.The talk in official circles is that ever since the Parliament elections in May 2019 saw BJP getting majority on its own in Lok Sabha, the state is no more on the priority list of the Centre in terms of funding for development of highways. Also, the economic slowdown is being cited as another reason for the union ministry not being liberal in notifying the state roads as highways.

Title: Senior FDA official lands in ACB net
Content:
Aurangabad: An assistant commissioner with the Food and Drugs Administration ( FDA ) in Beed was arrested by the anti-corruption bureau ( ACB ) on Thursday for accepting bribe of Rs 35,000.

The suspect, Krishna Namdeo Dabhade (52), had sought the money from a flour-mill owner for renewal of license and covering up earlier action taken for certain violations.

“Dabhade had sought Rs 10,000 for renewal of license and another Rs 25,000 for hiding shortcomings observed at the establishment during a recent crackdown. The demand for money was put before the mill-owner on March 13 following which he approached the ACB,” an official release said.

Acting on the complaint, the ACB sleuths on Thursday laid a trap and caught Dabhade red-handed after he accepted the bribe. “Another man, Rajeshwar alias Dnyaneshwar Shewale, has been also arrested by the ACB during the crackdown. The 24-year-old runs a photocopy machine center and took the money on behalf of Dabhade,” an official said.

The suspect, who was also holding additional charge of Osmanabad, was in the limelight recently for series of actions he took against commercial establishments in Beed for different non-compliances and violations.

A section of owners of such establishments, however, suspected the motive behind the crackdown and accused of vested interest. A group of traders burst fire-cracker in the old market area of the city as the news of ACB action against Dabhade spread in the city.

“The FDA official hails from Ahmednagar district and owns property at hometown as well as in Nashik,” ACB sources said adding that all movable and immovable assets of Dabhade would be scrutinized.

Title: Covid-19: Inter, Class X exams in AP to be held as per schedule
Content: VIJAYAWADA: State education minister A Suresh on Thursday announced that Intermediate and Class X examinations would be held as per schedule. While Intermediate examinations will conclude on March 23, Class X examinations will start on March 31.Speaking to the media on Thursday, Suresh said all educational institutions will remain closed till March 31 as a precautionary measure to prevent and manage the spread of Covid-19.“Except for residential schools having examinations, all other institutions including private universities , state universities, affiliated colleges and schools will remain shut till March 31. But students should be sent home after completion of exams . Physical distance of a meter will be maintained between students in the examination centres. Students suffering from fever, cold and cough will write examinations in separate rooms. Even the spot evaluation will be conducted with certain precautionary measures,” said Suresh.

Title: Covid-19 in Chennai: Air crew worried over lack of screening
Content: CHENNAI: Chennai airport authorities screening passengers arriving from infected countries are letting pilots and cabin crew go without checks. Airline crew say they don’t enjoy the privilege because they don’t want to fall ill or pass on the virus to their families and others who they closely interact with.“Especially the cabin crew spend hours with passengers in a closed environment, but not every one of them is checked. Now passengers from certain countries are made to go into quarantine even without Covid-19 symptoms, but pilots and cabin crew cannot take such a break as they have to get back to the next flight,” said a pilot. Some of the airlines staff felt services should be curtailed. “Airlines continue to operate flights though patronage is low and people are advised not to travel. This is putting the cabin crew and the cockpit crew at risk,” said the pilot.For passengers, too, there is no uniform screening across Indian airports, where domestic flights go unmonitored. There is no uniform screening of passengers across the country. Some airports screen domestic passengers and crew. Chennai has started doing this after a couple of Covid-19 cases were reported in the city.Ground staff are equally concerned. “We are worried there could be passengers coming in with infection. We constantly look for ill people, but we are not given proper protective gear during check-in and boarding, when we come close passengers. “Many members of the ground staff have to share a sanitizer bottle. Many of us have bought masks and gloves out of our own initiative,” said an airline ground staff at Chennai airport.Airline staff feel that the Chennai international terminal should be shut as 12 airlines now operating have less than 50% load factor. However, AAI is yet to take a decision. With Sri Lanka shutting all its airports, there is a call in India to restrict port of entry of flights from abroad to two or three airports.“A small country like Sri Lanka is ready to shut down its airport to prevent flights from landing from abroad. We are yet to do it. Pilots and cabin crew are worried to fly to foreign countries affected by Covid-19,” said another pilot.An airline official advocated concerted action by airlines and the government to ensure that all crew members are safe.

Title: Alappuzha: Pipe relaying work hit following shortage of labour
Content: Alappuzha: The pipe relaying works of Alappuzha drinking water project is getting delayed due to the shortage of labourers in the wake of Covid-19 The Kerala Water Authority (KWA) has decided to replace 1,524m of defective pipeline under the project after digging the Ambalappuzha-Thiruvalla road. The pipes are being replaced as local residents and also PWD minister G Sudhakaran have registered strong protests.The mega project has over 5 lakh consumers in Alappuzha and the continuous pipe bursts have forced KWA to stop water supply for weeks. To prevent this, KWA decided to begin replacement of 1,084m-long faulty pipeline at Thakazhy and another 440m at Kelamangalam on March 18. But the works failed to begin as the skilled workers from Tamil Nadu and Karnataka returned to their hometowns following the spread of Covid-19. “The contractor has approached KWA saying that he is unable to begin work due to the shortage of skilled labourers. So, a meeting will be held on Friday to discuss this and as per the present condition, the work cannot be started in March and we have to wait till the present crisis ends,” said a KWA official.As per the pipe relaying plan of the KWA, 1,000-mm high-density polyethylene pipe will be replaced with 900-mm mild steel pipe. “The pipe relaying will be carried out by the same contractor who laid the pipeline and he will also meet the cost of the mild steel pipe. We will provide funds for restoring the road dug up for laying the pipeline,” KWA officials said.The Alappuzha drinking water project was executed with central government assistance under the urban infrastructure development scheme for small and medium towns (UIDSSMT) for providing water to five lakh people of Alappuzha municipality and nearby eight grama panchayats.However, pipelines of this project have burst more than 40 times, including 30 major bursts at Thakazhy, in the past two-and-a-half years.

Title: YSRC behind attacks on Opposition: Andhra Pradesh BJP
Content:
Andhra Pradesh BJP vice-president Vishnuvardhan Reddy

HYDERABAD: Andhra Pradesh BJP vice-president Vishnuvardhan Reddy on Thursday alleged that the ruling YSR Congress party in AP was encouraging attacks on opposition leaders. He demanded that all election work conducted so far should be declared null and void.

Addressing a press conference at the party office, he said that a BJP delegation will soon meet the chief election commissioner in Delhi and apprise him of the situation.

He added that the AP election commissioner N Ramesh Kumar stayed mum on the letter written to Union home ministry seeking security cover.

“If the letter was fake, the ruling party could have taken action against him. The election commissioner must clarify all doubts,” he said.

Title: Trichy: Deputy BDO dies of health issues after being arrested by DVAC for graft
Content:
M Jayanthi Rani

TRICHY: A deputy block development officer in Karur district , who was arrested by the directorate of vigilance and anti-corruption (DVAC) police on Wednesday for accepting bribe, died in the early hours of Thursday after developing health complications.

The deputy BDO, M Jayanthi Rani, 52, from K Paramathi panchayat union, complained of chest pain when taken to the residence of a district magistrate in the evening by the DVAC officials. She was rushed to Karur Medical College Hospital where she died without responding to treatment at 2 30 am.

Speaking to TOI, Karur medical college dean Dr Rosy Vennila said Jayanthi was having diabetes and hypertension. She developed cardio vascular complications, which eventually led to her death.
