She developed fluid in her lungs called pulmonary edema. This usually happens when a person is emotionally stressed, which shoots up blood pressure and leads to other medical complications.

According to DVAC police, Ramesh from Pavitharam village near Paramathi of Karur district had approached panchayat union office to divide his land into 17 plots for sale, which requires approval from the BDO office. Jayanthi is said to have demanded a bribe of Rs 30,000 to give the approval.

Not willing to pay the bribe, Ramesh approached DVAC police in Karur district. The DVAC team on Wednesday asks Ramesh to offer money lased with chemicals to Jayanthi and arrested her while receiving the money.

Following questioning at the DVAC office, she was taken to the residence of the district magistrate where she developed health issues.

Title: Bizman shot at over access road dispute, two arrested
Content:
Pune: A 54-year-old businessman was allegedly shot at by four men on Wednesday night over a decade-old dispute on an access road passing through a plot at Khandvenagar in Lohegaon.

The bullet grazed victim Madhukar Dattatreya Khandve’s right temple, the Airport police said, adding that Khandve was rushed to a nearby private hospital where he recorded his statement after treatment, naming two of the assailants as Abhijit Balasaheb Shejwal (26) and Suraj Balasaheb Shejwal (28), who stay in his neighbourhood.

Khandve, owner of a packaged drinking water unit, told police that he was not familiar with the other two men who accompanied the Shejwal brothers at the time of the incident, which occurred around 9.45pm in front of his house in Khandvenagar.

Later, the police arrested the Shejwal brothers and launched a search for their two accomplices. Senior inspector Gajanan Pawar of the Airport police and his team also visited the crime spot and recovered a live cartridge, an empty bullet shell and the front portion of a fired bullet from the spot.

In his FIR, Khandve stated that for the last 10-12 years, the Shejwal brothers and their two relatives had been involved in a dispute with the local residents over an access road.

The Shejwals had threatened Khandve and his son for using the road in the past, following which he and other residents had lodged complaints with the Airport police, the FIR stated. More recently, Khandve had to seek police protection for filling up huge potholes on the access road as they feared the Shejwals would obstruct the repairs.

Around 9.45pm on Wednesday, Khandve came out of his bungalow upon hearing someone ring the doorbell. On reaching the main gate, he saw Abhijit and Suraj standing with another man, the FIR stated.

On seeing Khandve, Abhijit pulled out a pistol, aimed at him and tried to fire a round, but the pistol did not fire. In a desperate move, Suraj snatched the pistol and pulled the trigger, the FIR stated, adding that the weapon did fire this time and the bullet grazed the complainant’s right temple.

Khandve raised an alarm, prompting his wife Maya, son Omkar, cousin Kishor Khandve and nephew Prateek Devkar to rush out. The assailants then fled towards Nagar Road. The victim’s relative took him to the hospital, the FIR stated.

Title: Trains cancelled, platform ticket rate increased
Content: CLEARED SKHERAurangabad: The South Central Railway (SCR) has announced cancellation of 17 trains, including four passing through Aurangabad . The platform tickets at railway stations have also been increased to keep a check on the movement of passengers.As per the official release, the Nanded-Aurangabad express (17620) will not be in service till March 27. The Aurangabad- Nanded express (17619) stands cancelled from March 23 to March 30. Aurangabad-Renigunta express (17621) will not ply from Friday upto March 27. The Renigunta-Aurangabad express (17622) also stands cancelled between March 21 and March 28, an official release said.SCR authorities said adequate counters are open for passengers to process refund. The occupancy in trains has dipped in the wake of social distancing norms due to COVID-19 spread.“The revised platform ticket fare at all important major railway stations and all suburban stations will be Rs 50, while at the small stations it will be Rs 20 until March 31,” an official release said.Stating that increasing platform tickets was aimed at discouraging non-essential travel to railway stations, SCR authorities said the step will supplement the action plan already in implementation on railways to tackle COVID-19.“Regulating entry on platforms will enable social distancing among those using the railway services, besides decongesting the premises. Rail users are requested to cooperate,” chief public relations officer of SCR, Ch Rakesh, said.

Title: Precautions yet to cover migrant workers’ shelters
Content: Trichy: While workers are toiling hard to develop the city’s infrastructure through smart cities’ mission projects, facilities such as shelters, available for them are in a sorry state. Though migrant labourers constitute the majority of the workforce, the ongoing precautionary efforts against Covid-19 are yet to cover their living conditions.Trichy Corporation is taking up Uyyakondan riverfront development project at an estimated cost of Rs 17.56 crore under smart cities mission through a private contractor along a portion of the irrigation canal passing through the city. Three parks and walking track would come up along the Aarukan Road leading to Kuzhumayee Amman temple in ward 52. At least 20-25 workers are constantly involved in developing the public parks and redevelopment of Uyyakondan canal’s banks and they are put up in a common makeshift shelter adjacent to the worksite. Most of them have a common water tank to meet their domestic needs. It is pointed out that the civic body authorities have been focussing on people gathering at public places and ignoring these shelters of the labourers.“Authorities are not checking the status of migrant workers who have come from various parts of the state to work in infrastructure projects here. It is high time the corporation focussed on the labourers and their travel history,” environmentalist K C Neelamegam said. “We are primarily focussing on locations with a significant number of floating population. If required, we will focus on the worksites as well,” an official source with the civic body said.

Title: Coronavirus in Chennai: Those near Covid-19 patient being tracked through phone numbers
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: While a group of health workers were combing through the streets of a residential colony in the city to track contacts of 20-year-old patient who tested positive for Covid-19 on Wednesday, another group of officials were using technology to track mobile numbers of passengers who travelled with him in the reserved compartment of the Delhi-Chennai train that reached Chennai on March 12 and other places he travelled within Chennai until he got himself admitted to the Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital on March 17.

A team of health department officials and police are working on cluster-based position tracking system to track down members of the public who were within the close range from a Covid-19 control room. Those who were in contact with him or who could have been exposed to the virus will be asked to self-quarantine for at least 14 days, said heath secretary Beela Rajesh. The department had already piloted this technology with one of the patients who went to Colombo from Chennai.

“A team of health department officials along with police are using data from mobile companies to track a cluster of mobile phones around. They will be called, visited and screened by our health workers. They will also be counselled about self-quarantine,” she said. However, for this the patient should have carried his mobile phone with him every time he travelled.

“We have asked the railways for the physical list of the passengers who travelled with him on train,” she said. The state will release a flow chart of his movement to inform people by Thursday, she said. Public health officials said that already at least seven of his close contacts have been sent to a government quarantine facility and are being watched by health workers.

“They will be moved to a government hospital if they develop symptoms. Samples have also been drawn from close contacts,” he said.

Title: Telangana worker returns home from Sharjah after 16-year wait
Content:
Girish (left) and Srinivas (right) hand over the air ticket to Durgaiah

HYDERABAD: After a 16-year long agonising wait in Sharjah , a much-relieved Dobbali Durgaiah finally set foot in his village home in Rajanna-Sircilla district on Wednesday. “I am extremely happy to be back home,” Durgaiah (47), who worked as an illegal labourer at various construction sites in the Gulf, told TOI over phone.

While his Eglaspur village, which was formerly in Karimnagar district , erupted in joy, Durgaiah, surprisingly, was allowed to head to the village. “The authorities conducted tests for the coronavirus upon my arrival at the Rajiv Gandhi International Airport in the morning and told me I am free to go,” he said. Initially, it was thought the health officials would shift him to a quarantine centre as a preventive measure for coronavirus.

Durgaiah said his family wanted him to return, but he could not because of legal complications. His passport was taken away by a job agent on landing there 16 years ago.

Social worker, vice-president of Indian Peoples’ Forum in Dubai Janagam Srinivas said Durgaiah was without work for the last six months. “It was a difficult period. He had the option of leaving Sharjah without penalty, but he chose to make use of amnesty now,” he said.

Though the UAE government had announced amnesty from time to time for illegal workers to return home, Rajaiah continued to stay to make a living. Help also came from Girish Pant, volunteers’ committee in-charge (overstay and seafarers), Consulate General of India, Dubai, who bought him ticket to fly back to India. “We had to go around several government offices to get clearances for Durgaiah’s repatriation,” Girish said from Dubai.

Title: Covid-19 in Chandigarh: Rumour mill churns chaos at Sector 26 mandi
Content: CHANDIGARH: While UT adviser Manoj Parida was announcing a slew of measures to control the spread of coronavirus , there was panic buying of groceries and vegetables at Sector 26 vegetable and grain market on Thursday.Residents were seen stocking ration and vegetables after rumours of city lockdown went viral on social media. To control the mad rush at Sector 26 market, SHO of Sector 26 police station Narinder Patial was forced to make a public announcement, stating there was no proposal of the UT administration to close down the mandi , grocery and chemist shops.The panic buying even led to huge traffic jams at all entry points of the Sector 26 market.Earlier in the day, Parida addressed a press conference after the city’s first coronavirus positive case was reported. He ordered closure of all sports complexes, government and private sports academies till March 31. Besides, the UT administration identified two more quarantine facilities in the city, including Parkview Hotel in Sector 24 and Panchayat Bhawan in Sector 18. The administration has already made Infosys Sarai in PGI a quarantine facility.The UT adviser also clarified that the administration would not close down any market or weekly apni mandis and that more space would be made for wholesalers in Sector 26 mandi by using the truck parking lot. There would be no retail selling at the Sector 26 grain market, the adviser added.On public transport, the UT adviser said there was no ban on movement of inter-state buses of Chandigarh Transport Undertaking (CTU) as of now. The instructions have been given for keeping adequate distance between passengers and sanitisation of buses was on, he added.Govt, pvt offices open: AdviserManoj Parida said there would be no closure of government and private offices. The UT would prepare a list of essential and non-essential services, and accordingly take a decision, he added.TASK MANAGERSThe overall responsibility for contact tracing and offering further advice of home quarantine will be of Anil Garg, additional commissioner, municipal corporation, Chandigarh. He can associate any municipal corporation employee with him for this purpose. A police team will also be provided for enforcing home quarantine. The contact list will be provided by the director, health services, after accessing the patient and family. A stamp, similar to what is being done at the Mumbai International Airport, will be marked on the back of right palm, mentioning the 14 days’ quarantine period.Two to five employees of each department trained as master trainers with the help of medical experts will be provided by director, health services. Director, school and higher education, Rubinderjit Singh Brar will be the overall in-charge for co-ordinating the training to master trainers and their training the employees of the respective departments.The overall strategy in ensuring food supply in case of extreme crisis will be of director, sports, Tejdeep Saini. He will interact with the deputy commissioner to prepare the strategy and act accordingly.Rakesh Kumar Popli, additional excise and taxation commissioner, will interact with the deputy commissioner for essential goods and supplies to the hospitals like masks, sanitisers and personal protective equipment.Uma Shankar Gupta, director, transport, will be in-charge of quarantine facilities to be created in lnfosys Sarai, Parkview Hotel (on payment basis) and Panchayat Bhawan or any other facility decided to be created.

Title: Mop-up drive launched at the epicentre of bird flu outbreak
Content:
MYSURU: Two days after culling nearly 5,300 birds including pets over bird flu scare, officials of Animal Husbandry and Veterinary Services on Thursday launched second phase of the drive — the mop-up round — to cull the remaining birds within the 1-km radius of the epicenter in Kumbar Koppal in north Mysuru.

Besies, the district administration has imposed a strict ban on transportation of fowls in the surveillance zone of within 10-km radius as precaution. According to census in the surveillance zone, there are about 15.73 lakh fowls, including egg-laying (15.09 lakh), country chickens (13,123) and poultry (51,000).

Speaking to TOI, deputy director of Animal Husbandry and Veterinary Services Ajith Kumar said, “Our SOP to to contain the spread of bird flu entails three phases. First culling, then mopping up and finally combing before declaring an epicentre a safe zone. We have culled about 4,317 poultry on day-one and on day–two about 989 birds including pets. We entered the second phase on Thursday.”

Civic agency and the health department staff will work together to disinfect the areas within 1-km radius using Sodium Hypochlorite once the culling phase is almost complete.

According to district administration, on March 17, about five rapid response teams were formed to cull the birds and next day, on March 18, additional eight teams were formed to clear the neighbourhoods of BM Sri Nagar , Metagalli, Kumbarkoppal, Ambedkar Jnanaloka and Hebbal — all in north Mysuru where about 304 poultry, 160 egg-laying chickens, 499 country chickens, 20 pets, 6 turkeys were culled 215 eggs destroyed.

Despite the resistance from owners, the operation was successful, claimed the district officials.

Random samples to be tested

Continuing the operation, authorities will collect random samples and carry out tests to rule out the possibility an outbreak at other areas in Mysuru. Everyday about 15 samples will be collected from different locations in surveillance zone within 10-km radius wherein 15.7 lakh poultry are being reared according to census.

Farmers to be compensated

Animal husbandry will provide compensation to poultry owners for loss as per government guidelines. For every egg-laying chicken, farmers would get Rs 90, for poultry Rs 70, for ducks Rs 135, for turkey Rs 160 and for eggs Rs 3.

DC clarifies

Deputy commissioner Abiram G Sankar clarified on Thursday that no order was passed by the district administration to prevent public from consuming chicken or eggs following the bird flu outbreak in Mysuru. The clarification came after rumours about a fake order went viral in social media platforms resulting in a drastic decline in sales.

Title: 6.4 tonne of tobacco seized, four arrested
Content:
Trichy: The Pudukottai police on Thursday seized 6.4 tonne of tobacco products illegally stocked in four locations and arrested four people in this connection. The arrested have been identified as Soundararajan, 40, Mohamed Ali, 47, Veeramani, 38, and Narayanan, 46, all from Pudukottai district.

This is the biggest ever haul in recent months and police team could arrest the key people who were distributing tobacco products in the district, said senior police officials from Pudukottai.

Soundararajan, the key accused, was nabbed following a tip-off that a large quantity of tobacco products has been stashed in his place. Police conducted a search at Soundararajan’s grocery shop and seized about 100kg of tobacco products.

His godown was also searched from where 2.8 tonne of tobacco was seized. He revealed the names of three more people who had stocked tobacco products. All the three were arrested and the products were seized from them. The arrested told police that they used to bring the products along with grocery items in goods vehicles.

They told police that the demand for such products prompted them to indulge in the illegal activity. Soundararajan also told police that customers had been avoiding his grocery shop as he was not selling tobacco products. This has forced him to source the banned items from outside. The state government has banned tobacco products, including pan masala and chewable tobacco since 2013.

Title: Chandigarh housing board scraps city’s costliest housing scheme in Sector 53
Content:
Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The Chandigarh Housing Board (CHB) has scrapped city’s costliest housing scheme in Sector 53 and decided to refund the amount to the applicants decided by the demand survey. However, the officers have been asked to consider framing of a new scheme with lesser cost.

CHB’s board of directors in their meeting on Thursday decided, “The proposed general self-financing housing scheme in Sector 53 needs to be made more lucrative. To reduce the land cost component, the matter may be taken up with the UT administration to increase the floor area ratio (FAR) so that more flats can be constructed. Further, the possibility of some changes in the specifications and design also need to be explored. Considering that framing a new scheme with lesser cost and further possible changes may take considerable time, the board has decided to refund the amount deposited by the applicants…”

There was a poor response to the demand survey of the scheme, as only 178 applicants came up for 492 flats. The CHB had reduced prices of flats twice and even extended the deadline for demand survey. After witnessing poor response, the CHB, on January 14, further reduced prices by 5% to 7%, and extended the date for submission of online application to February 24.

In July 2019, the CHB had proposed a 3BHK flat for Rs 1.85 crore, 2 BHK for Rs 1.6 crore, 1BHK for Rs 1.15 crore and accommodation for the economically-weaker section (EWS) for Rs 58 lakh, drawing a lot of criticism.

Thereafter, the board released a new price list on October 10: 3BHK for Rs 1.63 crore, 2BHK for Rs 1.36 crore, 1BHK for Rs 90 lakh and a two-room flat for EWS Rs 50 lakh. Then on January 14, the board decided that 3BHK will cost Rs 1.5 crore, 2BHK Rs 1.28 crore, 1 BHK Rs 86 lakh and a two-room flat for EWS would remain unchanged at Rs 50 lakh. The board official had said persons applying under the demand survey would be given preference in allotment. The scheme was proposed to be made open for all.

How much they cost

Category : Price of flats : Response

HIG (3BHK): Rs 1.50 crore: 95 applications

MIG (2BHK): Rs 1.28 crore: 33 applications

LIG (1BHK): Rs 86 lakh: 12 applications

2 rooms flat (EWS): Rs 50lakh: 38 applications

Title: NBCC may appeal NCLT order on Jaypee Infra takeover
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

NEW DELHI: NBCC , the winning bidder for Jaypee Infratech , is unwilling to take charge of the beleaguered firm’s real estate and road projects and is set to challenge the National Company Law Tribunal’s order , arguing it impacts the financial viability of its plan.

A key concern is the tribunal’s decision to get NBCC to pay Rs 350 crore to dissenting creditors — ICICI Bank, IFCI and SREI — over the next 12 months and also service all fixed deposit holders around Rs 120 crore, instead of Rs 29 crore proposed by the public sector company. NBCC is also peeved at having to bear the farmers’ additional compensation burden, something most homebuyers have done in case of other projects, sources told TOI.

At a meeting with lenders this week, NBCC chairman P K Gupta told bankers the PSU would like to take control of Jaypee’s assets only after getting clarity on these issues. This was despite lenders led by IDBI Bank pointing to the instances of Essar Steel and Jyothi Structures, where a monitoring agency was appointed to handle the affairs of the companies till the final disposal of appeals.

But NBCC sources said the cost of completing the entire realty project would be to the tune of Rs 6,500 crore, and only around Rs 3,000 crore is to come from homebuyers.

Title: Suspected coronavirus case in AP's Guntur
Content: VIJAYAWADA: A 24-year-old woman suspected to have coronavirus has been admitted to the isolation ward in Government General Hospital in Guntur , on Thursday.Sources said that the woman, along with her family, returned to Mangalagiri on March 16, following which she complained of a cough, cold and throat pain.The officials of the medical and health department in Guntur district collected samples from the woman and have sent the samples to the Viral Research and Diagnostic Laboratory (VRDL), popularly know as virology lab, at the Sri Venkateswara Institute of Medical Sciences (SVIMS) in Tirupati and are awaiting the results. The family members of the woman have also been placed under observation. Officials said that there is no need to panic as they have been taking all measures to contain the spread of coronavirus in the state. They also appealed the public to follow precautionary measures such as cleaning hands regularly to prevent the spread of the virus.Meanwhile, in a major relief to Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams , a 65-year-old pilgrim on a visit to Tirumala, who was admitted to the Covid 19 isolation ward at SVRR Government General Hospital in Tirupati tested negative for coronavirus. The pilgrim who was part of a 110-strong devotee group developed breathlessness during his stay at Madhava Nilayam in Tirumala on Thursday and was shifted to the isolation ward at SVRR government hospital in Tirupati. The 109 pilgrims who accompanied him were also placed under isolation as a precautionary measure by the TTD administration.

Title: Messages in tribal dialects on air
Content: Kozhikode: Clear and accurate communication that prompts people to take appropriate action holds the key in successfully managing public health emergencies.True to this, messages on Covid-19 , especially in the indigenous Paniya tribal dialect, are dominating the airwaves in Wayanad with Radio Mattoli , the state’s first community radio station, that started airing special programmes on the pandemic in tribal dialects.The initiative is all the more relevant because many remote tribal colonies often miss the mainstream awareness programmes due to their socio-economic circumstances and also owing to the language barrier.The over-a-decade-old community radio, under the Wayanad Social Service Society, has a listenership of around 3.5 lakh of the total of 8.17 lakh Wayanad’s tribal population, which is the largest in the state.Amrutha, one of the tribal staffers of the radio and hailing from the Paniya community, has produced the programmes and messages in her native dialect , and they include jingles and short audio clips.“We are broadcasting Covid-19 awareness messages in Paniya dialect throughout the day as special programmes and as short messages interspersed between other programmes. The special programmes on Covid-19 include Q&A sessions as provided by doctors and translated into Paniya dialect. Apart from that, we have ensured that at least three short audio clips go on air every half hour between programmes,” said Radio Mattoli station director Fr Bijo Thomas Karukappally.The messages in their own tribal dialects are expected to create awareness in many colonies where radio is still the only window to the outside world. Radio Mattoli authorities had distributed over 4,000 radio sets to Paniya tribal community, hence the reach of the messages is assured to a certain extent.District medical officer R Renuka said that they were trying to create and broadcast messages in other tribal dialects like the Kattunayikka dialect, considering the reach of the radio among the marginalized communities. “Besides, we will be providing training to tribal promoters in small batches to create awareness about the disease and the safeguards and precautions to be taken,” she added.Steps are being taken to improve the nutritional status of tribals by distributing food to needy families through Anganwadis, she said.

Title: Hyderabad: VDCC technology to smoothen ride at Vidyanagar underpass during monsoon
Content:
The underpass is prone to waterlogging during monsoon

SECUNDERABAD: The GHMC is laying Vacuum Dewatered Cement Concrete ( VDCC ) road at Vidyanagar underpass to prevent waterlogging and avoid frequent damages during monsoon. Officials said the underpass, which has been closed for the last one month, will open in a month’s time.

“The VDCC road will be laid after the shifting of utilities. The road is prone to waterlogging. Compared to regular bitumen roads, the VDCC road lasts longer as it helps prevent water stagnation and damage to the roads,” said a GHMC engineer.

The work was halted for a week following objections by South Central Railways (SCR). “As the road is being laid on the road under bridge (RUB), the SCR granted us permission to lay the road after we explained them the project,” said a GHMC official.

On Thursday, the underpass was filled with water after rain. “Even if it does not rain, the road is in pathetic condition. The work was halted for a week and resumed only four days ago,” said V Ramakanth, a resident of Vidyanagar.

Residents said that construction debris is strewn along the road, which leads to Shankar Mutt and Shivam Road. “Ever since the work began, commuters are having to take an alternative route, which is taking more time. I wanted to reach RTC Crossroads from Amberpet , as the underpass was closed I had to take a U-turn and go to Nallakunta crossroads to reach my destination. Authorities should complete the work on a war footing,” said Dayanand, a resident of RTC Crossroads.

Title: High-risk countries’ travellers under lens in Visakhapatnam
Content: VISAKHAPATNAM: The district collector on Thursday announced that travellers from 10 high-risk countries, especially Iran, Italy and China among others, would be kept under home quarantine and observation for at least fifteen days.The announcement was made during a press conference conducted by state tourism minister M Srinivasa Rao on coronavirus preparedness. The collector added that there are six suspected cases in Visakhapatnam , whose samples have been sent for testing, while the results are being awaited.Addressing the issue, the minister M Srinivasa Rao stated that the state government was taking preventive measures and precautions apart from ensuring that there were enough isolation wards to deal with suspected cases. The minister added that quarantine wards have been set up in VIMS , Chest Diseases Hospital and the ENT Hospital in the city.Regarding the other arrangements proposed, the minister said officials have been instructed to establish isolated wards in Paderu, Atchyuthapuram and Anakapalli hospitals, apart from setting up screening centres in popular tourist locales.

Title: Delhi: Peace panel to seek info on offenders
Content:
Committee chairman Raghav Chadha

NEW DELHI: Delhi Assembly ’s peace and harmony committee said on Thursday that it would ask WhatsApp, Facebook and Twitter to help it identify some “offenders” who had shared inflammatory posts on social media .

he committee was formed to check spread of rumours and hate speeches in the wake of the violence in northeast Delhi last month. It has got more than 7,700 complaints so far.

On Thursday, it recorded statements of 14 complainants who had drawn its attention towards inflammatory content, including videos and messages and also of a person accused of spreading inflammatory content on social media.

Committee chairman Raghav Chadha said that the alleged offender accepted his “crime” and apologised to the panel, claiming that he was not aware of the law. TNN

Title: Covid-19 scare: 8 flights from Chandigarh suspended
Content: MOHALI: Eight flights from Chandigarh, including an international one, have been suspended as a precautionary measure to check spread of coronavirus Indigo Airlines has suspended its Chandigarh-Dubai flight (6E55) till March 30 and the Dubai-Chandigarh flight (6E56) till March 26 with immediate effect. Chandigarh International Airport Limited (CHIAL) spokesperson said Indigo has issued a formal letter informing about the suspension.Indigo had recently regulated the frequency of the Dubai flight from daily to thrice a week and a few days later suspended it. The flight used to arrive from Dubai every Monday, Wednesday and Friday and depart every Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday.Apart from this, the spokesperson said corona threat has also affected the domestic sector, as Indigo and GoAir have called off seven flights connecting Delhi, Mumbai, Bengaluru and Ahmedabad. Indigo has cancelled its flight 6E-264 Mumbai-Chandigarh-Mumbai, 6E-755 Delhi-Chandigarh-Delhi, 6E-593 Bengaluru-Chandigarh-Bengaluru.GoAir has cancelled its flights G8-104 Delhi-Chandigarh-Delhi, G8-2507 Mumbai-Chandigarh-Mumbai, G8-109 Ahmedabad-Chandigarh-Ahmedabad, G8-138 Delhi-Chandigarh-Delhi.Sharjah flight passengers to be quarantined“All the passengers arriving at the international airport will be screened for Covid-19 by teams specially constituted for the purpose,” said deputy commissioner Girish Dayalan on Thursday. Passengers from the lone Sharjah flight or those arriving by domestic flights with passports showing visas of the high-risk seven countries would be identified and quarantined. Those who would be at high risk would be quarantined under the surveillance of the health department at the designated hospitals/quarantine facilities. The asymptomatic ones would be home quarantined for 14 days. All such people would be stamped on right hand wrist that would indicate the last day of quarantine, he added.

Title: Hyderabad: Toddler dies after choking on chocolate
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: An 18-month-old baby boy , Joshua Vivek, choked to death after a piece of chocolate he was eating got stuck in his throat in Bachupally on Wednesday evening.

“The boy was suffering from a lung problem and the candy got stuck in his throat. As he could not breathe, he died,” said Bachupally police.

The boy was rushed to a private hospital after he collapsed, but the doctors declared him brought dead.

The body of the boy was handed over to the family members after the postmortem at Gandhi Hospital. A case of suspicious death was registered.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Kerala HC stays all revenue recoveries
Content: Kochi: The high court on Thursday issued a stay on all revenue recovery proceedings and tax recovery in the state until April 6 in view of Covid-19 outbreak. Justice Amit Rawal issued a stay after considering a total of 81 cases seeking a stay on coercive proceedings following outstanding loans and taxes.The stay also includes income tax and value added tax in addition to sales tax, motor vehicle tax, land tax, building tax, and taxes collected by municipalities and corporations.When the cases came up for admission hearing, counsels brought the deteriorating financial situation due to Covid-19 outbreak and argued that interference of the court is warranted on an urgent basis. Following this, the court ordered that all coercive action for outstanding loans and taxes will be stayed.Pointing out that the chief justice has allowed each judge to decide about the precautions to be taken in view of the pandemic, the judge said in the order, “I am of the view that this present scenario of outburst of deadly coronavirus is very precarious and sensitive, as the lawyers and the staff rendering assistance to this court and the judges are vulnerable. Thus, to prevent such rampant spread by taking preventive measures, I deem it appropriate to issue general directions to the departments concerned like the banks, financial institutions, income tax authorities, authorities dealing with the erstwhile KVAT, GST, recovery of tax on motor vehicles and building tax to defer the recovery proceedings or coercive measures till April 6.”The court also clarified that its order issuing a stay will not be an impediment for defaulters to make use of any amnesty scheme or similar options nor to pay off their dues. Departments can approach the court in a particular case if modification of the order is warranted but such action should be backed by reasonable justification, the court ordered.The court has ordered that its order should be conveyed to the chief judicial magistrates, who consider the coercive proceedings under Sarfaesi Act.

Title: Encroachments by hawkers irk commuters at Central bus stand
Content:
TRICHY: The encroachments by traders and hawkers in the bus bay at the Central bus stand is hindering the movement of passengers waiting for city and suburban buses . Adding salt to injury is the laxity shown by the civic body as it has shown no concern or action to clear these encroachments that have turned the bay into an unhygienic spot, said commuters.

As the existing Central bus terminus spread on six acres cannot accommodate all city and suburban buses, two lanes of Rockins Road is earmarked for the buses to embark and disembark passengers. The platforms for passengers to wait for buses were sheltered and provided with seats.

However, a section of traders and hawkers have been encroaching the bus bay and they are using the platforms as stockyard to store their belongings and even to dump their waste. “Water receding from the waste accumulates along the bus bay’s platforms. The corporation prefers to ignore the unhygienic condition prevailing near the bus stand,” R Krishnanandam, a passenger at the Central bus stand said.

Though passengers have often complained to Ponmalai zone officials about the inconvenience caused to the public, who are in desperate need of shelter to safeguard them from the scorching weather, locals said that no solution was provided by the civic body. Corporation officials, when contacted, said necessary action will be taken.

Title: PGI, government hospitals suspend OPDs in Chandigarh
Content: CHANDIGARH: A day after the first case of novel coronavirus was reported in the city, all government hospitals have suspended OPDs till March 31. Besides, the PGI OPDs will remain suspended till further orders.The decision was taken during a meeting of the UT adviser, the DC, the UT health services director and directors of PGIMER and Government Medical College and Hospital , Sector 32, on Thursday.“All OPDs will remain closed till March 31. However, only the OPDs for gynaecology , paediatrics and trauma department will function. All elective surgeries have been postponed in all the government hospitals,” said UT adviser Manoj Parida.After the PGI reduced the OPD registration timings by an hour from Wednesday, the OPD count was 6,600 on Thursday. “The timings were reduced not only to check crowds, but also to keep the infrastructure ready with focus on coronavirus patients,” said PGI director prof Jagat Ram.Around 10,000 patients visit various OPDs of PGI. One of the most important ways to reduce spread of this infection in community, said experts, is social distancing. Hence it is imperative to discourage crowd accumulation. “With this objective, the OPD services of PGIMER, including all the centres, will remain suspended till further orders. Screening OPD for Covid-19 will continue in the new OPD block and emergency area. No elective surgeries will be performed from March 21 till further orders. All the emergency services will continue as usual. At any given time, there are 200 elective (non-emergency) surgeries performed in the PGI, a tertiary-care centre. “All minor ailments and dental services, which are not urgent, must be postponed. We have reduced the number of attendants too as one per patient. However, still the footfall is not less,” said prof Jagat.

Title: SC asks Kamal Nath govt to take floor test by 5pm today
Content:
NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Thursday ordered the Kamal Nath-led Congress government in Madhya Pradesh to a face floor test by 5pm on March 20 in the assembly by a show of hands of members, and asked police chiefs of Karnataka and MP to ensure security for the 16 rebel Congress MLAs if they choose to participate in the voting by coming to Bhopal from Bengaluru.

After a two-day hearing where senior advocates from Congress and BJP were pitted against each other and which ended at 5.30pm on Thursday, a bench of Justices D Y Chandrachud and Hemant Gupta adhered to the time-tested constitutional principles enunciated by the SC in the Bommai case to say, “State of uncertainty in the state of MP must be effectively resolved by issuing a direction for convening a floor test.”

In doing so, the bench steered clear of a carefully crafted web of warnings couched in interpretation of constitutional provisions cited by senior advocates A M Singhvi and Kapil Sibal . Appearing for Congress, the duo argued that holding immediate floor test would reward the rebel MLAs and BJP for the “constitutional sin” they had committed by engineering defections through allurement of ministerial posts to destabilise an elected government.

Congress’s arguments were vigorously countered by senior advocates Mukul Rohatgi and Maninder Singh, who joined ranks with solicitor general Tushar Mehta to defend the governor’s decision to ask the Kamal Nath government to face a floor test. They said the governor acted out of the knowledge that 22 Congress MLAs had deserted the party and that had prima facie reduced the Nath government to a minority in the House.

After hearing the parties at length till 5.30pm, the bench pronounced the three-page order and laid down conditions under which the floor test would be conducted.

Sources told TOI that the speaker is likely to initiate steps for disqualification of the 16 MLAs, which would prevent them from being given ministerial berths if a new government is formed by BJP. In the 230-member House, Congress had 114 members and BJP 109. Congress had formed government with the help of two BSP MLAs, one SP MLA and four independents.

Title: Tatkal tickets go abegging, only 3% booked in Trichy divison
Content:
Trichy: With fewer people using public transport including trains, the sale of tatkal tickets in all originating trains from Trichy division has fallen drastically. Out of the 1,374 tatkal tickets – including on air-conditioned coaches — available for 10 express trains, only 34 were sold out on Thursday for travel on Friday .

Railway division officials said the number of cancellations was more than the bookings. On normal days, booking a tatkal ticket was by no means easy. However, after the Covid-19 outbreak, the situation has changed. Ten trains including Chennai Rockfort, Mayiladuthurai - Coimbatore Jan Shatabdi, Mayiladuthurai - Mysuru express trains usually witness hundreds on waiting list, particularly during weekends. The officials said most of the trains have been witnessing poor patronage due to coronavirus forcing cancellation of several of them.

According to the available data, out of the 1,021 available general tatkal seats, only 29 were booked leaving 992 up for grabs. The entire 120 second class AC seats have not been booked, while for 3rd AC, out of 203 tatkal seats, only five passengers have utilized the quota. On Mayiladuthurai - Coimbatore Jan Shatabdi, all the 30 seats in AC chair cars remained vacant. Citing poor patronage, Karaikkudi passenger (train no. 76839) has been cancelled till March 31, Karaikkudi – Trichy passenger (train no. 76840) till April 1 and Trichy – Manamadurai – Trichy passenger (train nos. 76807/76808) till March 31, all with immediate effect.

Hyderabad – Trichy special fare special on March 23 and 30, Trichy - Hyderabad special fare special on March 25 and April 1 are also cancelled. Villupuram – Secunderabad special fare special on April 1 and Secunderabad - Villupuram special fare special on April 2 have also been cancelled.

Title: Officials spray disinfectant in farmers’ markets in Trichy
Content:
Trichy: The agriculture marketing department fumigated all the farmers’ markets (Uzhavar Santhai) in Trichy on Thursday. They have also erected flex boards to create awareness on Covid-19 and established common hand wash facilities at all the markets.

The agriculture marketing department has been operating farmers’ markets in various places including Tennur Anna Nagar, KK Nagar and Thiruverumbur in the city apart from Lalgudi, Manapparai, Musiri and Thuraiyur.

As hundreds of people visit the market to purchase vegetables on a daily basis, officials from the agriculture marketing commenced the process of applying disinfectant all over the market at Tennur Anna Nagar on Thursday.

A big flex board explaining the dos and don’t dos with regard to coronavirus has been erected at the entrance of the farmers’ market apart from facilities to wash hands before entering it.

On Thursday morning, officials from the agriculture marketing gave a demonstration to the farmers as well as the customers on how to wash hands properly.

Deputy director of agriculture marketing Murugan told TOI they would do the same thing in all markets from Friday onwards. He has also appealed to the farmers as well as the public who visit the markets to follow protocol to avert spreading of coronavirus.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: 1,300 hand sanitisation points in place across south Delhi
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

NEW DELHI: After the invocation of the epidemic clause of Section 376 of the Delhi Municipal Act, 1,374 hand sanitisation points with soap-water and alcohol sanitisers have been set up across south Delhi.

According to the latest progress report on hand sanitisation, till Wednesday, 271 residents welfare associations (RWAs), 595 eateries and restaurants, 41 banquet halls, 46 market associations, 23 malls and 398 hotels have operational points. The west zone is the poorest performer while Najafgarh leads in the drive. A health official said the Najafgarh zone was the most vulnerable due to the presence of the IGI Airport and a large number of hotels.

To strengthen the fight against novel coronavirus, the health department of South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) has issued a warning to all these entities to provide hand-washing infrastructure. “Enough time has been given and punitive actions under Indian Penal Code will be initiated now,” the official said.

Among the RWAs, 195 in the Najafgarh zone, 41 in the west, 25 in the central and just 10 in the south zone have complied with the direction. In terms of markets, too, both central and south zones are lagging with just five and six associations complying with the order.

Not all RWAs are happy with the directive. Chetan Sharma, who heads the Confederation of National Capitial Region RWAs, said these were voluntary organisations with no provision for funds. “The corporations should provide us resources and we can facilitate setting up such points. They charge taxes from us while we don’t have any provision for funds collection,” he added.

Rajeev Kakria of the GK-I RWA, said the commissioner should request, and not order, for the services RWAs provide due to SDMC’s shortcomings and inept functioning.

Under Section 376 of DMC Act, it is mandatory for all such entities, including malls, to set up proper sanitation facilities. The directions will remain applicable till March 31 for now.

“Violators will be deemed to have committed an offence under IPC 188 for causing danger to human life, health or safety and can be punished with a fine or an imprisonment of up to six months,” a senior official said.

Last time the provision was used was in 1997 to deal with the dengue outbreak when people were said “mosquito-genic” conditions on their premises could lead to severe repercussions.

Title: 30 homes gutted as major fire breaks out in Wadarwadi slum
Content:
Pune: About 30 tin-roof dwellings were completely destroyed in a major fire that broke out around 1.30am on Thursday in the Wadarwadi slum. No one was reported injured.

While the fire brigade and the police had no immediate clue about the source of the fire, residents of the slum suggested that a short circuit triggered the blaze. At least two LPG cylinders exploded, adding to the intensity of the fire that caused a major panic in the area as people ran away from their dwellings to safer areas. It all started suddenly, they said, while most of the residents were asleep.

The fire brigade had a tough time accessing the area, which is congested. They had to surround the scene of the fire three sides and use hose pipes to spray water on the blaze, which died around 5am.

“I woke up around 1.30am after hearing a blast-like sound, and found that people were running helter-skelter. I then found about the fire in the lane adjacent to the one I live in. Our homes were safe. But I ran towards the burning houses, which belonged to my relatives,” Hitesh Dhotre, a resident of Wadarwadi, told TOI.

Dhotre said that there was complete darkness in the area as power supply was cut off. “I first shifted children and elderly people to safety,” he said, adding, “Along with a few other youths, I climbed to the top of a house and started pouring water on the flames.”

He said the fire brigade too reached the spot and began dousing the fire three sides. “They brought the fire under control within an hour,” he added. .

Chief fire officer of Pune Municipal Corporation’s fire brigade, Prashant Ranpise, told TOI that the fire brigade received a call about the fire around 2am. “Three fire tenders from Aundh, Kasba and Nal Stop were immediately dispatched,” Ranpise said.

Ranpise too rushed the spot from the central office. “The area was congested. We had to park the fire tenders at a distance and reach the spot with hose pipes,” he said.

He said that fire spread due to LPG cylinders’ blasts. “At least two cylinders exploded,” Ranpise said.

The fire brigade used nine fire tenders, three Devdoot tenders and three water tankers. “We doused the fire around 5am. Our fire officer Shivaji Memane sustained minor injuries,” Ranpise said.

30 families lose everything

Parashuram Mane, whose house was completely destroyed in the fire, said he had to run away with his ailing son and family members as soon as the fire broke out. “Our neighbours alerted us as we were fast asleep. We just took an LPG cylinder with us and ran,” Mane said.

Mane said he just left with the clothes he was wearing. “I have lost everything. I am a daily wage worker. Due to the coronavirus outbreak, I hardly able get any work,” Mane said.

Another resident, Balamma Sidhallor, too lost everything. “Due to age I was not able to move fast. Someone lifted me and made me sit at a safe place. I have lost everything,” she said.

Santosh Dhotre too was busy in shifting damaged tins of his house. “I will have to work hard to build my house again,” he said.

The affected families have been shifted to the nearby Sant Ramdas school. “We have provided them with breakfast and lunch,” said a local resident.

Title: Nurses put themselves at risk to save lives
Content:
Bengaluru: Medical staff tending to positive and suspected Covid-19 patients also undergo tests at regular intervals to ensure they are safe and healthy to continue tackling the crisis efficiently and they don’t inadvertently put others at risk. Many have minimised contact with family members, waiting till test reports confirm they have not picked up the infection.

“As a precaution, I didn’t visit my hometown, which is 140km from Bengaluru, for a at least month. I travelled there to check on my parents only after I tested negative,” said a male nurse in the 15-bed isolation ward of Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases (RGICD), which is in the forefront of the coronavirus fight. He told TOI that all staff members involved in the efforts tested negative two days ago.

Nurses, along with doctors and other medical staff, are on the front line of the battle against Covid-19, interacting with patients regularly to boost their morale, apart from handling hospital tasks.

“A psychiatrist also comes here every day to counsel patients and make sure they are psychologically fit. Patients naturally get upset when they learn they have tested positive. It’s crucial to reassure them and boost their morale. For that task, we need to be confident ourselves,” another nurse said.

As on Wednesday, there were 10 patients in the isolation ward. Five have tested positive.

Recently, medical education minister K Sudhakar started a Twitter campaign, #HealthWarriors, to provide praise and encouragement to healthcare workers.

Some staff members at RGICD complained that they had not been provided with hazmat suits; they were making do with gloves, masks and caps. But the articles are sent to the incinerator after single use.

Most nurses in the isolation are contract employees, lacking job security. “For all the hard work we are putting in and the risks we are taking, we hope to get absorbed in government service. The Covid-19 crisis is recent, we have been dealing with infectious diseases like tuberculosis and H1N1 for years now. Naturally, our families are concerned about our health,” said a nurse working in the isolation ward.

When Sudhakar visited the facility recently, nurses urged him to make their jobs permanent. “The minister assured us that he would look into the matter,” the nurse said.

Title: ‘Animal husbandry must help in preventing death of ducks’
Content:
ALAPPPUZHA: Duck farmers have demanded effective intervention from the animal husbandry department (AHD) to prevent the mass death of ducks in Kuttanad and Upper Kuttanad areas.

According to duck farmers, over 10,000 ducks died within two weeks in Kuttanad. Alappuzha Tharavu Karshaka Sangham leaders on Thursday conducted a news meet here and alleged that the AHD does not have a vaccine against Riemerella — a bacteria that leads to the death in young ducks. Sangham secretary K Samuel said that though the AHD does not have the vaccine, they are claiming that they have stocked adequate vaccine against this disease. “It is misleading information. The department has failed to prevent the death of ducks due to Riemerella. If a duck is affected by the infection, it will die within four days. The department takes many weeks to find the reason for the cause of death. When they found the reason, almost all affected ducks die. It should change, and the department should have a facility to prevent the mass death of ducks as soon as possible. They should give us a proper vaccine to prevent the spread of the disease,” he said.

Farmers first felt that avian flu was the reason for the unexpected death of ducks.

AHD officials collected samples of the dead ducks and tested at Avian Disease Diagnostic Laboratory, Manjadi near Thiruvalla. The lab identified that Riemerella was the reason for the death. The mass death of ducks was mainly reported in Thalavadi and Mankombu in Kuttanad.

Title: Contract Staff at Tiruvarur MC protest
Content:
Tiruvarur: Hundreds of contract staff including conservancy workers at the Tiruvarur Government Medical College Hospital staged a protest on Thursday alleging that they had not been provided with safety gears like masks in wake of the Covid-19 outbreak.

The protesting labourers gathered near intensive care unit of the hospital and raised slogans against the hospital authorities. The protesters alleged that despite the coronavirus outbreak, the hospital authorities were disregarding their safety. While the permanent staff at the hospital were provided with masks and other safety gadgets, they were being ignored, the protesters alleged.

They also complained that the hospital was denying them benefits like provident fund. Moreover, they had not received their salaries for the last two months, the protesters said.

District secretary of CITU, Murugaiyan, along with functionaries of the trade union took part in the protest and demanded that the hospital authorities heed to the genuine demands of the contract workers. The protesting workers also stayed off from on Thursday.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: How equipped are our pvt hospitals?
Content: KOCHI: The state government has asked all private hospitals to keep rooms ready to admit patients if there is Covid-19 community outbreak . District collectors of all districts held separate meetings with private hospital managements and informed them that they need to keep the rooms ready to treat any Covid-19 patient who comes to the hospital.Now, the private hospitals are in the process of setting up isolation rooms either in a block or floor of the hospital. Depending on the total number of rooms, the hospitals are keeping 2 to 20 isolation rooms ready. They are ensuring that separate entrance and lift are made available to the isolation rooms and the area where the isolation rooms will be set up has been quarantined. Some of the 500-plus bedded hospitals have kept two-three negative pressure rooms ready.In each hospital, there is a Covid-19 crisis management team consisting of doctors and managers who prepare contingency plans. They have been trained to handle isolation wards and are provided with personal protection equipment. Just like in the ICU, in the isolation room, the hospitals plan to maintain nurse-patient ratio of 1:1. The staff in the isolation will be posted for maximum 6 hours in a day.However, many small and medium private hospitals have raised concerns of lack of adequate personal protection equipment. “Many private hospitals don’t have adequate personal protection equipment and therefore, we have written to the respective district medical officers to provide the same,” said Kerala Private Hospital Association president Dr P K Mohamed Rasheed.Incidentally, though the district collectors during the meetings have made it clear that a person who comes to them with Covid-19 symptoms should be treated in the hospital and not shifted to a government hospital, there is some apprehension. “Most of our hospitals don’t have the facility or infrastructure to treat critical cases of Covid-19. Such patients we will have to shift to government medical colleges,” added Dr Rasheed.Who will bear the cost of treatment in private hospitals is another issue. Though some private hospitals had raised doubt over the cost involved for treating patients, there was no further discussion on it.“Government authorities have informed us that they would be first utilizing the government facilities. Once that’s filled up, then we will need to admit patients and we are ready for it,” said VPS Lakeshore CEO S K Abdulla.“At the moment, there is no patient load and therefore, if government facilities are exhausted, we can admit Covid-19 patients in our hospitals,” said Dr K G Alexander, chairman, Baby Memorial Hospital, Kozhikode.Meanwhile, some of the hospitals have identified separate hostels where staff can be quarantined in case they do get infected. “We have kept a facility with 60 beds ready to accommodate our doctors and medical staff if they need to be quarantined,” said Dr M I Sahadulla, chairman and managing director, KIMS Healthcare Group.

Title: Four isolated at MGM govt hospital test negative for Covid-19
Content: Trichy: Four people, including three students from Kerala , tested negative for Covid-19 at the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial (MGM) government hospital here on Thursday. The public health and preventive medicine department has quarantined 27 foreign returnees at the makeshift quarantine facility at the central market for vegetable, fruits and flowers at Kallikudi on Thursday.Test results from the viral research and diagnostic laboratory at the government medical college hospital in Tiruvarur revealed they were not infected.The three students had got themselves admitted at the isolation ward on Tuesday after they developed Covid-19 symptoms following their visit to Kerala recently. The fourth one was a foreign returnee.The symptoms of the virus include fever, cough, sneezing and difficulty in breathing.A senior doctor at MGMGH said the decision on discharging the negative patients would be taken by the doctors after reviewing their present health condition.Of the eight admitted at the isolation ward here, four have tested negative and one was shifted to the general ward after he recovered from the symptom.With three passengers under treatment, four more also joined them early on Thursday morning. By Thursday evening, seven passengers with symptoms were being observed at the isolation ward at MGM.The makeshift quarantine facility at the central vegetable market for vegetables, fruits and flowers has seen a sudden surge in the number of passengers returning from worst-hit countries. The passengers include 12 from Dubai, six from Malaysia , one from Germany and eight who travelled to those countries.The public health department has also stated that four men and three women in the quarantine facility were above 60 years. The public health department officials said that none of them had symptoms. Since they had travel history to most affected countries, they were quarantined for a period of 1-14 days. A total of 326 passengers landed at the Trichy International Airport by two flights from Sharjah and Dubai late on Wednesday night.Trichy district administration said the passengers will be sent home based on the report from the doctor. The passengers will be provided with food and accommodation at the centre

Title: Coronavirus scare in Delhi: Rumours make people rush for bulk buying
Content:
TimesView Taking precautions at a time like this is understandable. But there is a thin line that separates being cautious from succumbing to panic. Hoarding essentials because you believe they might not be available tomorrow is certainly on the dangerous side of that line, as the PM pointed out in his address to the nation. It only adds another chaotic element to an already grim situation. There is absolutely no reason to believe that we are running out of supplies of goods of daily consumption and hence no cause for panic buying. Remember, your hoarding up for a month could well make it impossible for someone who needs rice, wheat or dal for next week to find them.

NEW DELHI: Kusum Sehgal reached her local supermarket in Malviya Nagar, south Delhi, early in the morning. Usually, she replenishes her stock of groceries and other stuff at the beginning of the month, but on Thursday, she decided not to wait for another 10 days. “We have bought some extra pulses, aata, biscuits, vegetables, non-perishables and noodles. You never know when the shops will run out of these items and a lockdown is announced,” she explained.The coronavirus scare had led to panic buying in the past few days but on Thursday local markets across the capital witnessed a rare frenzy. Anxious people were propelled by rumours of markets closing down and the spectre of shortages crowded grocery shops and pharmacies. Ignoring clarifications by the Government and traders’ associations that there was no shortage, they bought stuff in bulk.Prime Minister Narendra Modi, in his address later in the evening, assured citizens that there won’t be any shortage of supplies and appealed to them not to hoard. “Please don’t race to hoard these things. Just buy like you normally do. Panic buying is wrong,” he added.Shivam Singh, a resident of Munirka, said he was out to replenish his stock of insulin. “The government will not close chemist shops but it is better to keep your own stock as others may start hoarding leading to a shortage. You don’t know what may happen tomorrow,” he added.Defence Colony residents reported panic buying across grocery stores. “Home deliveries have been stopped by most shops as they don't have enough staff to meet the demand. Defence Store, Le Marche, Modern Bazaar etc have long queues as everyone fears a lockdown from tomorrow,” one of the residents said. Bhavreen Kadhari, a resident, she couldn’t find any milk. “I got a call from my niece who needed milk and it wasn’t available. There were long queues outside Krishna Super Marche,” she said.Harjinder Saroha of Vasant Kunj RWA said a lot of hoarding was being reported from grocery shops. “Whatsapp messages and rumours floating in social media have led people to believe that a shutdown will be announced. We are holding awareness sessions with our staff and maids,” he added. Kapil Kakkar from Jangpura Extension and Rajiv Kakria from GK-I acknowledged that people were stocking up. “Some vegetable vendors spread the scare that Azadpur Mandi may be closed down but a video from the mandi chairman cleared the air,” he added.Sanhita Mandal of C R Park said prices of some veggies had been arbitrarily hiked. Pinaki Das, who had gone out to buy some stuff at one of the local markets in the area said there was such a rush, with people scurrying around wearing masks, that he returned home.Many marts and bigger outlets reported that they were facing a shortage from wholesale vendors. Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT) clarified that so far no trade association has taken any decision to close markets. “However, if the government takes any such decision, traders will comply,” said Praveen Khandelwal, general secretary of CAIT said.Many people who reached the shops late and couldn’t get the items they were seeking tried to order on online platforms with mixed results.

Title: Budget: Kannur corp eyes infra development
Content:
Kannur: Kannur corporation deputy mayor P K Ragesh on Thursday presented the budget for 2020-21 amid protests from the LDF , which also boycotted the presentation, saying that it is being presented against the stay order of the ombudsman and also majority of the finance standing committee objected to it.

Nonetheless, UDF went ahead with the budget, with an expected revenue of Rs 409.09 crore and expenditure of Rs 378.75 crore, and it mainly focuses on infrastructure development, including roads and other facilities. The ombudsman had stayed the council meeting on March 18 but there was no stay on budget presentation, said UDF.

Apart from improving roads and bridges in the city, and also renovating footpaths, the corporation would take up renovation of the Jawahar Stadium complex, for which Rs 10 crore was earmarked.

To improve the tourism potential of Kannur, ‘Night-less Kannur’ would be launched with an aim to set up a trade and shopping complex that would function round the clock. Besides attracting tourists, it would also ensure the safety of women out at night, said the deputy mayor who earmarked Rs 10 lakh as initial fund.

To provide a platform for Kudumbashree groups and farmers’ clubs to sell their products, a temporary facility would be opened at the Stadium Corner at an expense of Rs 10 lakh. Further, a storage building for fishermen will be constructed at Adikadalayi at an expense of Rs 5 lakh.

On the environmental front, the rejuvenation of Kakkad river is a major project for which Rs 1 crore would be spent. This includes eviction of encroachments and restoring the natural flow of the river.

Other important projects: Drinking water scheme at Chelora (Rs 1 crore), children’s security (Rs 3 lakh), Vijaykiran (to improve academic standard of students from the SC/ST community and provide them special coaching for SSLC and Plus Two – Rs 8 lakh), Nanma Award for initiatives in plastic-free campaign, waste management and organic farming (Rs 5 lakh).

Title: Covid-19: Plea to close Tasmac shops dismissed
Content:
Madurai: Madras high court has dismissed a public interest litigation (PIL) which sought to close all Tasmac liquor shops in the state to prevent the spread of Covid-19. In the petition, C Sankar, a resident of Virudhunagar district, stated that the state government as a part of the precautionary measure to restrict public gatherings had ordered to close stadiums, clubs, recreation clubs, bars including Tasmac bars from March 17 to 31. He stated that though the order included the closure of Tasmac bars, the shops continue to remain open. Due to this, hundreds of people are gathering at these shops to purchase liquor which would not serve the purpose of the precautionary steps taken by the government. He stated that it is necessary not only to close the Tasmac bars but also the shops in order to prevent the spread of Covid-19.

Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench. When the petition was taken up for hearing on Thursday, a division bench of justice P N Prakash and justice B Pugalendhi dismissed the petition, citing that a similar petition is pending before the principal seat at Chennai.TNN

Title: Coronavirus scare in Delhi: Services at RTOs to be curtailed
Content:
NEW DELHI: To stop the spread of infection by the novel coronavirus by reducing crowding, many services at the 13 Regional Transport Offices (RTOs) in Delhi are likely to be suspended or curtailed soon. The transport department is planning to stop issuing learner’s licences and also reduce the number of appointments being given out per day.

“In the meeting chaired by lieutenant governor Anil Baijal, which was attended by chief minister Arvind Kejriwal and other senior ministers and officials, it was decided that all Delhi government work will be segregated into two categories, essential and non-essential,” said an official. “All non-essential activities are likely to be suspended, which includes learner’s licences,” he said.

More than four lakh learner’s licences are issued by the transport department every year and more than half of the applicants are in the age group of 18 to 24. The tests also include touching biometric scans and online tests on touchscreen computers, which might get contaminated.

“It is very likely that issuance of learners licences would be deferred as it is very difficult to sanitise keyboards, mouse and touchscreens after each applicant takes their test. That is why it is better to defer this for a few weeks,” said a Delhi government official. “A decision is likely very soon.”

The official added that the number of appointments at RTOs may also be curtailed to avoid crowding.

“In spite of the outbreak of the global pandemic, there has been only a dip of about 10% in number of applicants coming to RTOs. As the schedules for driving tests, license renewals or registration certificate transfer etc. are made in advance and paid for, applicants don’t want to miss their appointments,” said an official of a busy RTO . “We are also apprehensive for our own health.”

Title: Caller booked for abusing 41-year-old woman
Content:
Pune: A caller was booked on Wednesday on the charges of abusing a 41-year-old woman and using obscene language with her.

An officer from Hinjewadi police said the complainant was a software company employee working from home in the wake of the coronavirus spread. “On Wednesday, she received a call on her cellphone from a man posing as a private finance firm official. The caller told the woman that she would get a refund of Rs 4,000 on her purchases,” the officer further said.

As the woman was talking, she also received a message on her cellphone. “The caller then told the woman to share one-time password (OTP) sent to her to avail the refund. Hearing this, the woman became suspicious and asked the person his name, following which he introduced himself as Rakesh Sharma. When the woman asked his employee ID, the person began abusing her with obscene language,” the officer said.

The police have registered the offence under section 509 (word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman) of the Indian Penal Code.

Title: 2 held, 1 surrenders for role in blast at DMK leader’s house
Content:
Madurai: The Madurai city police on Thursday arrested two people in connection with the recent blast at the house of a former DMK, V Velusamy. One more person involved in the incident has surrendered before a judicial magistrate in the Madurai district court, after police closed in on him. The two have been identified as Malaisamy and Jayaram. The third accomplice has been identified as Yasin Mohammed Ali. Ali has been remanded in the Madurai Central Prison in judicial custody.

A low-intensity improvised explosive device (IED) went off in the house located in 1st East Cross Street in Anna Nagar on Monday. CCTV footage showed that two people, who had come on a bike had planted the bomb inside the gate and left. The bomb exploded a few minutes later. Police higher officials, including city police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham had visited the house and conducted an inquiry.

Based on a complaint from Velusamy, a case was registered with the Anna Nagar police the same day under The Explosive Substances Act. Special police teams arrested Malaisamy and Jayaram. Police inquiries revealed that Malaisamy was involved in the murder of Velusamy’s son 15 years ago. He was convicted in the case and had served life sentence. After coming out of prison a year ago, he planned to take revenge on Velusamy, who had lodged a complaint against him in connection with the murder. Police said he joined hands with Jayaram, a history-sheeter, who has been booked under many cases before. They took Ali’s help to prepare the explosive device. tnn

Title: Coronavirus in Bengaluru: Chickpet textile shops, jewellers head for shut down
Content: BENGALURU: Textile shops in and around Chikpet are likely to shut as five associations related to the trade have asked its members to close as part of the ‘break-the-chain’ strategy to contain Covid-19. Around 3,000 textile shops associated with Bangalore Wholesale Cloth Merchants Association in Chikpet will close from March 22-25.“Every shop has 8-10 salespersons who come from various parts of the city,” said Prakash Pirgal, president of the association. “Besides Karnataka, many of our customers come from other states like Kerala, Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. We have to consider interests of both sections, so we decided to close down for the time being.”Prakash pointed out that footfall has decreased by 60-70% over the past 10 days and shop owners are facing severe financial constraints.The Mysore Silk Cloth Market Council (Wholesale), which has around 550 shops under its umbrella in Chickpet, Jumma Masjid Road and Chowdeshwari Temple Street, shut shops from Thursday. The shops will remain closed till March 25.“Employees in our industry are from Bengal and Odisha. They are engaged in dyeing, printing and other activities. Embroidery is being done by a minority community from Varanasi. Taking into account all this, we decided to stay closed,” said Mahendra Jain, president.Businessman Mahipal Surana said the move is part of social distancing measures to contain the spread of the virus. “The voluntary shutdown, which comes in the run up to Ugadi festival, will affect the trading community severely. But we have to act in the larger interest of society,” Surana said.Other associations that have called for a closedown are: Bangalore Apparel Manufacturers Association (from March 20-22), Bharatiya Resham Udyog Sangh (March 20-25) and Bengaluru Jari Traders Association (March 20-24).Traders in other goods such as electrical, plywood, hardware and paper among others will remain open, but footfall has fallen drastically. “Shops are open, but there are hardly any customers. There’s at least 90% reduction in footfall,” said Mayur Khakhar of optical trade association. The associations are contemplating similar decisions.

Title: Kin of fishers stranded in Iran seek early repatriation
Content:
Kanyakumari: The Centre’s reply in the Lok Sabha on Wednesday that 255 Indians in Iran are among 276 Indians outside the country who have tested positive for Covid-19 has left the nearly 800 Indian fishermen and their relatives back home worried. They have demanded fast-tracking of their testing and repatriation. Though external affairs minister C Jayashankar had said last week that nearly 6,000 Indians are stranded in Iran, till date only less than 600 have been repatriated.

“We have been asking for help for 22 days, but not one official from the Indian Embassy has visited us,” Sahaya Ascar of Kanyakumari who is in Zero, Iran, told TOI through a WhatsApp audio message. “Minister Jaishankar said that fishermen are in the safe zone and hence the delay. My Iranian employer told me that 22 people on Kish Island are infected and at least two are dead,” said Jesu Rethnam of Ramanthurai who is one of the nearly 350 Indian fishermen on Kish Island.

“We are safe because we are confined to our boats for 22 days. What if one of us gets infected” he said. “Three days ago the embassy officials called us and asked for the list of provisions we need for our survival till we are repatriated,” fellow fisherman L John Britto, 34, of Thoothoor said. But on Wednesday the embassy officials called them to inform that they will not be able to make it. The nearly 800 Indian fishermen including more than 600 from Tamil Nadu – over 500 of them from Kanyakumari district – wondered if Government of India will reach out to them before they are infected.

Director of coastal peace and development, Kanyakumari district, father M Stephen said they had petitioned chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami, MEA C Jaishankar and minister of state V Muraleedharan along with AIADMK Rajya Sabha MPs. On March 12 Kanyakumari MP H Vasanthakumar raised the issue in the parliament and also petitioned the Prime Minister. “But all these efforts have not yielded any results,” he said.

Title: 9-year-old girl killed in road accident
Content:
Madurai: A nine-year-old girl was killed in a road accident when the share auto rickshaw in which she was travelling hit a truck near Nagamalai Pudukottai in Madurai district.

The deceased was identified as P Keerabrintha from Valandur near Usilampatti. She was travelling in the share auto along with her brother Kivin Prasanna, 11, mother P Saranya, 32, and grandmother S Gowthami, 50, towards their village from Madurai on Wednesday evening.

Police said the share auto driver, K Kodiveeran, 42, was driving the vehicle in a rash and negligent manner. He hit a truck coming in the opposite direction at Achampattu bus stop. All the occupants of the autorickshaw, including the driver suffered injuries and were rushed to the Government Rajaji Hospital.

Keerabrintha, who suffered grievous injuries, died in the hospital without responding to treatment. Based on a complaint from Gowthami, a case was registered with the Nagamalai Pudukottai police station. The truck driver identified as Arun Prakash, 34, from Chinnathukarai near Alanganallur was arrested. tnn

Title: Covid-19: NSS urges govt to postpone exams
Content: KOTTAYAM: The Nair Service Society NSS ) have urged the state government to postpone all the examinations in the state in the wake of Covid-19 scare.NSS general secretary G Sukumaran Nair in a press note on Thursday said that the students who have to write exams resort to unsafe ways to reach the examination centres and returning home. He also said that the students should remain in their homes at this juncture.The government should take emergency steps to postpone the examinations considering the seriousness of the situation, he said in the statement.Meanwhile, MG University has announced that it will not postpone its exams. Its vice-chancellor Sabu Thomas said that the exams will be held as per schedule.

Title: Covid-19 outbreak: AIIMS doctors make sanitisers to beat shortfall
Content: NEW DELHI: One of the biggest challenges healthcare workers are facing in dealing with the Covid-19 outbreak is shortage of hand sanitisers and protective equipment, such as masks. They are in short supply in hospitals as well as wholesale markets.To deal with this crisis, which may worsen in the coming days, the infection control team at AIIMS has started preparing both alcohol-based handrubs and plastic face shields in their own lab.Dr Purva Mathur, professor of laboratory medicine at the hospital, who heads the infection control team, told TOI they have already prepared about 20 litres of hand sanitisers. Larger quantities of the alcohol-based handrub can be prepared at short notice, she said.“We don’t have a crisis in our hospital at present. But this exercise is being done to prepare the hospital for a crisis situation,” she added.According to Dr Mathur, making alcohol-based hand rub isn’t difficult. It requires Ethanol, Hydrogen peroxide, Glycerol and distilled water that are easily available in the market and the process of mixing them is clearly laid out by World Health Organisation. “Fifteen years ago, when commercial hand sanitisers weren’t available, this is how hospitals used to prepare them,” Dr Mathur explained.Doctors deputed for the screening of Covid-19 patients need to cover their face with masks to reduce the risk of contracting infection. In anticipation of scarcity of the crucial personal protective equipment, the AIIMS team has also been working to develop their own indigenous mask.“We have prepared a few using transparency film and foam at a fraction of the cost of the masks available in the market,” Dr Mathur said. “In the coming days, we would be able to prepare more of these protective items,” she added.While the common people have been advised to stay home to check the spread of Covid-19 and reduce the risk of contracting the infection, healthcare workers are on the ground to care for patients. However, this comes at a high risk of catching the infection. Data shows 1,700 medical workers have been infected by Covid-19 in China and at least six have succumbed to it.Though no healthcare worker has been affected in India, the anxiety level among the staff at hospitals such as Safdarjung and Ram Manohar Lohia, where coronavirus patients are being treated, is high. Some of the doctors TOI spoke to said the lack of masks and gloves was the trigger behind it.

Title: Hyderabad: Missing man found dead
