Content: HYDERABAD: A 70-year-old man, Narsaiah , was found dead in an isolated area in Vampuguda , Jawarharnagar on Thursday. The man had been missing since March 15. On Thursday, municipal workers came across the body and informed Narsaiah’s family members. Narsaiah’s son Bhikshapati told police that his father might have died due to ill health. A suspicious death case was registered.

Title: 84 more trains cancelled, takes total number to 155
Content:
Railway officials have ramped up cleaning efforts at both stations and in trains in the wake of the novel coro... Read More

NEW DELHI: Indian Railways on Thursday announced it had cancelled 84 more trains — which would not be operating between March 20 and March 31 — owing to the novel coronavirus outbreak in the country.

Coronavirus in India live updates

Thursday’s announcement took the total number of cancelled trains to 155. Officials said that only low-occupancy trains had been cancelled, with the passenger occupancy dropping drastically over the last few days.

A railway official, working at the ticket refund office at New Delhi Railway Station, had to be admitted to Northern Railway Central Hospital in Paharganj as precaution after she allegedly hosted a few Italian nationals at her residence.

“The woman lived in the railway colony and a few Italians visited her house in the last few weeks. At present, she is a suspected case. She had also visited the railway refund office after hosting them several times,” said a railway official, who did not wish to be identified.

Deepak Kumar, CPRO, Northern Railways, said the woman had been sent to the hospital for a check-up and all others, who came in contact with her, have been asked to be in isolation. “The office is being sanitised. It has, however, not been sealed yet,” Kumar said.

A senior railway official said a large number of train tickets had also been cancelled over the last few days. “The total tally of cancelled trains all over India, due to low occupancy, is 155 pairs, including a few passenger trains,” he added.

Railways have individually informed all passengers who had booked tickets for the trains that now stand cancelled. “No cancellation fee will be charged for these trains. Passengers will get 100% refund,” the official added.

The official, however, said that EMU, DEMU and MEMU inter-state local trains are yet to be cancelled, despite the drop in occupancy rate. “Even though the occupancy rate for these trains and footfall at stations has dropped, they are still running at the moment. They may be cancelled if required,” he added.

Northern Railway said there is also likely to be a 50% reduction in railway staff, with the majority of workforce asked to focus on sanitising trains and stations. “All trains are being disinfected and fumigated prior to a journey. Instructions have also been issued to frequently disinfect and sanitise points of passenger contact, including rails, doors, windows, snack tables, lift buttons and seats,” the official added.

Title: Covid-19 threat: Church suspends Sunday Mass obligation, Way of Cross
Content: PANAJI: As a pre-emptive measure against the spread of Covid-19 , the archdiocese of Goa and Daman on Thursday dispensed the faithful from the obligation of participating in Sunday Mass. It also suspended, with immediate effect, all community devotional practices and gatherings including the Way of the Cross, ‘ Santos Passos ’, processions, domiciliary visits of the statue of Our Lady, retreats and Lenten dramas.The archdiocese has further advised that marriage celebrations with large attendance should be postponed to a safer time and funerals be conducted only with close family.Stating that this unprecedented situation called for unprecedented measures, archbishop Filipe Neri Ferrao, in a circular issued on Thursday, strongly advised children, people above 60 years, those with common cold symptoms, and those having co-existing ailments not to attend Mass. People who have travelled from any virus-hit areas after March 1, have also been advised to not attend.The circular discourages the faithful from daily Mass unless it is strictly necessary and to keep a distance of not less than one metre from one another.Priests should take sanitary precautions before distributing communion and should continue to celebrate Mass even without a congregation, the archbishop said, while also instructing the faithful to receive communion on the hand.“Wherever possible, the celebration of the Mass is to be live-streamed or recorded and then broadcast,” he stated.Ferrao also advised that churches and chapels be kept open during the day, at least for a few hours, so that the faithful can pray privately while taking all the necessary precautions.“All meetings of association and church groups are to be suspended, barring those that are necessary for urgent consultation or decision-making and for charitable activities,” the circular stated.Earlier on Thursday, the Shrine of Our Lady of Fatima at Don Bosco, Panaji , announced that its Blessed Sacrament chapel will remain closed till further notice. The shrine has also cancelled Thursday adorations and Way of the Cross. “It is Christian charity also to care for the safety of others. Let not your piety imperil the health of your neighbour,” Fr Loddy Pires, director of the shrine, said.

Title: Social distancing a challenge for micro and small scale industries
Content: Madurai: Although work from home has been announced to ensure social distancing, there are many small scale industries operating in pockets in and around Madurai that are going to find it a challenge as they have been told to close down if they employ more than 100 people or give holidays to employees partially.On Thursday, district collector T G Vinay convened a meeting including members of Rotary and Lions clubs, NGOs, residential associations and industrial organisations, on the safety measures to be taken for social distancing in workplaces. In Virudhunagar, for example, the collector has directed the fireworks industry not to employ more than 50 people at a time in an unit.Madurai District Tiny and Small Industries Association (Maditssia) former president V S Manimaran said that this was going to be a big problem for micro and tiny industries that employ over 100 employees in small places.“Almost all our industries have bank loans which have to be repaid and putting work on hold would mean difficulty in making repayments. The government should come forward to give us at least six months for repayments and make interest waivers on these loans,” he said.Many such units have people working in close quarters without even one feet distance between them in work places. “Downsizing the workforce would be a solution but only to some extent, but this too would cause problems,” said B Muruganantham, president Maditssia.Meanwhile, all of them have started stressing on the importance of handwashing frequently, especially when the workers go out for lunch or use toilets.There are a few garment industries which employ over 1,000 people and industrialists say that the government should prescribe some norms like salaries for workers in case of a total lockdown as their business and workers would stand to suffer if some sought of grant is not assured to them, in the wake of Covid-19 crisis.Sources say that random checks would be conducted in the next few days to ensure if they are adhering to the norms.

Title: Daily wagers hit hard, govt relief sought
Content: Aurangabad: Scores of unorganised workers engaged in businesses such as manufacturing, hospitality and transportation have been severely hit amid the coronavirus scare in the absence of any law to bail them out in such a situation.Some employers are reportedly paying wages to such workers although there is no work, but say that they cannot continue to do this for long. On the other hand, activists are seeking government intervention.Deputy labour commissioner N N Itkari said there are no provisions in the law for financial aid to workers who lose their employment in the wake of such an emergency. “Such a situation has happened for the first time and we do not have a backup for it. However, if the government announces relief, we can implement it.”Subhash Lomte, general secretary of Maharashtra Rajya Hamal Mapadi Sanghatna, said the government has completely ignored the catastrophe that has struck the workers in the unorganised sector.“Government’s own data states that only 6% to 7% of the total workforce is in government sector or are on the payroll of private organisations. This shows that the remaining 93-94% are in the unorganised sector. However, even as industry is hit by cessation in exports and imports due to the coronavirus outbreak, the workers in unorganised sector are worst hit,” he said.Lomte said the government should ask industries and employers to provide sustenance allowance to the such workers until the situation is back to normal and that they can be engaged in extra work later.Rakhamaji Jadhav of Jadhav Mandap and Decorators, who provides event management services for weddings and conferences, said the coronavirus scare has led to the collapse of the event management business.“March 10 was an auspicious day for weddings but the closure of wedding halls and ban on gatherings in the wake of covid-19 threat has dealt a blow to the business. I have 120 labourers on daily wage and there is no business now. I am still paying them Rs 200 a day. However, I cannot continue to pay without work for more than eight to 10 days,” said Jadhav.Prabhakar Mate, Marathwada region secretary of Bhartiya Kamgar Sena, trade union wing of Shiv Sena, said they are planning to meet the government officials and propose for some relief for the workers affected by the shutdowns and slowdown due to the virus scare.“The hotel industry has collapsed and other industries too are suffering in view of the slowdown. Just like compensation is sought for farmers when their crop is damaged, the daily wage workers should also get relief in such an emergencies,” said Mate.

Title: Covid-19: Goa government orders closure of weekly markets, shopping malls
Content:
For now, restaurants to stay open

PANAJI: Inching closer towards a lockdown, the state government on Thursday ordered the closure of weekly markets , shopping malls, pubs and operations of coaching classes till March 31. The order comes into effect from midnight of March 20-21.Director of health services Jose D’Sa issued the order on Thursday evening in the view of the novel coronavirus Though the state has not reported a Covid-19 case till Thursday, it is feared that mass gatherings could lead to the spread of the disease since Karnataka and Maharashtra have detected cases.On Wednesday, health minister Vishwajit Rane had expressed the need to shutdown shopping malls. Many pubs have already halted operations, while cinema halls are closed till March 31.A health official said that regular bazaars will continue as their closure would inconvenience citizens in buying groceries and other items.The weekly markets held in the talukas are thronged by people from adjacent villages as well as from across the border who come to shop or sell vegetables, fruits and grains, the official said.The wide range of relatively cheaper items sold at these markets are much sought after by people.This is mostly seen at the Mapusa and Valpoi weekly bazaars, he said.Authorities have not ordered the closure of restaurants, but owners have been advised to follow social distancing as a preventive measure, he added.Pernem takuka is popular for the fruits and vegetables that are sold by vendors from neighbouring Banda and Sawantwadi in Maharashtra, while vendors from Karwar in Karnataka sell their wares at Canacona.With regards to coaching classes, he said, it was brought to their notice that some coaching classes are continuing even after schools and colleges were shut down and exams were postponed.On March 14, chief minister Pramod Sawant had directed the closure of all educational institutes, pubs, clubs, gyms, casinos, cinema halls, spas and boat cruises till March 31.Sawant had also urged tourists not to visit Goa until March 31, when the state government would conduct a review of the situation, before deciding on the future course of action. The Shigmo float parade was also cancelled at some places.

Title: How Bikaner contained spread of cholera in 1927
Content: JAIPUR: Similar to what the country is doing to contain coronavirus, the erstwhile Bikaner state had done to combat cholera in 1927.It had sealed its border by framing an Act to fight the spread of the disease by restricting the entry of unwell persons and imposing a penalty on those who violated the law. The Act existed till Bikaner state still it merged with the Union of India and later in Rajasthan.The Act named ‘Khatarnak Phelne wali Bimario ka Act (Infectious disease Act 1927) was passed by the Bikaner state assembly in view of the spread of two diseases—plague and cholera — under the reign of Maharaja Ganga Singh (1880-1943). The Act says it will be applicable once the state notified the outbreak or pre-empt the spread of any infectious disease in the state or the neighbouring state.Documents at Rajasthan State Archives Bikaner suggest that how the Act helped the state preventing its people from the spread of any infectious disease till it was merged with India. “It shows the wit and commitment of the ruler who ruled the state close to 90 years ago by granting special powers to health workers and enforcement agencies to screen any suspected patient of any infectious disease,” said Mahendra Khadgawat, director of Rajasthan State Archives Bikaner.At present, the country has banned the entry of foreigners and sealed its borders as an effective tool to stop the spread. The erstwhile rulers have also on occasions formed check-posts at borders screening the entry of outsiders, health workers at public places including the railway station, bus station, kutchery (Court) and other public places. “Great emphasis has been laid on creating awareness on the infectious disease by pasting posters, banners and verbal announcements. I don’t see any parallel of this visionary Act in India during the time the country was taking on Britishers,” said Khadgawat.The country is yet to make the violators of stringent measures as a punishable offence, the former rulers have granted the special powers under the Act to run a legal case against them. Reportedly, Ganga Singh was among the first king to have introduced state assembly in then united India.

Title: In Palakkad, 2 die of suspected sunstroke
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

PALAKKAD: Two persons have died in the district of suspected sunstroke as the atmospheric temperature touched 41Celsius at Mundur.

An auto driver Santosh, 41, son of Govindan Nair of Parampil House in Mundur, who was working in his farm was found dead on Tuesday.

His body had sunburns and the family members said that he died of sunstroke while working in the open field when the temperature recorded on that day at Mundur was 41C.

Since Monday Mundur has recorded 41C. Last week, an unidentified person was found dead at Mundur with sunburns. Between March 13 and 17, temperature recorded at IRTC Mundur was 40C. It is estimated that since 2017 there have been 15 sunstroke deaths in the district.

The temperature recorded in Mundur is 41C on Thursday. In Malampuzha, the temperature stood at 38.8C and Pattambi recorded 39C on Thursday.

tnn

Title: Coronavirus in Delhi: Hospitals may pool resources for ICU needs
Content: NEW DELHI: Covid-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus, causes mild symptoms in 80% of the patients. But 20% of them suffer from complications, mainly respiratory distress, which may require ICU support. Does Delhi have enough ICU support, especially ventilators, to save them?“It depends on the number of cases that can’t be predicted. However, we are fully prepared to deal with any situation,” said Dr Randeep Guleria, the director of AIIMS, which has more than 200 ICU beds at its main hospital. “All hospitals have been advised to postpone non-emergency or routine surgeries so that the current strength of ICU beds can be utilised to meet increased demand, if needed,” he added.In addition, the National Cancer Institute (NCI) in Jhajjar, also run by AIIMS, and the Trauma Centre have earmarked 125 and 20 beds, respectively, for acute management. Of this, 45 are ICU beds with ventilator facilities. “The number of ICU beds can be scaled up further by pooling in critical-care beds from other departments. We have a plan in place,” Dr Guleria said.The Safdarjung and Ram Manohar Lohia hospitals, two other central government-run facilities, have also been asked to be ready to deal with any emergency situation. Together, they have more than 200 ICU beds.Delhi government runs 33 tertiary-care hospitals with a total bed capacity of 10,059, out of which 3.5% have ventilator facilities. Recently, the government told the high court that 63 ventilators were being procured at 15 hospitals, and it would be completed in six months.Mechanical ventilators help patients breathe, or breathe for them. They are critical in the management of severe Covid-19 cases because the infection, once it reaches the lower respiratory tract, damages the lungs. “In severe cases, complications can be limited to symptoms such as shortness of breath and low-oxygen saturation. But if this continues despite treatment, the patient may start getting restless and fall unconscious due to less oxygen in the brain,” explained Dr Arup Basu, senior pulmonology consultant at Sir Ganga Ram Hospital. “It can also affect the heart, kidneys and other body parts, leading to multi-organ failure.”A state health department official said private hospitals, which have a majority of ICU beds in Delhi, have also been alerted. “Their facilities may be utilised for acute management of Covid-19 cases,” said an official. While Indraprastha Apollo Hospital has 218 ICU beds, the Max group about 800 ICU beds, a source said.Niti Aayog, the Centre’s policy think-tank, recently held a meeting with the representatives of top private hospitals and told them to be ready to create isolation wards. The matter was also taken up in a meeting on Thursday, the source said.

Title: Nagpur: Satpuda Foundation to dedicate mobile education van in Pench
Content:
NAGPUR: Even as World Forest Day on March 21 will be a silent affair due to Covid-19, Satpuda Foundation (SF), a NGO working in Central India for tiger conservation, has announced a gift for kids of Mowgli’s Pench landscape. The SF has dedicated an education van for Pench Tiger Reserve , Maharashtra .

“The education van was planned to be handed over on World Forest Day. However, we have postponed the programme as schools are closed and social gatherings are banned to prevent infection of Covid-19,” said Kishor Rithe, founder, Satpuda Foundation.

Satpuda Foundation is working on environment education programme in Pench and other tiger reserves since 2001. This year the SF has designed a science-based conservation education programme aiming for tiger conservation. The project is funded by BC Mehta Trust in England through ‘The Fable Fund’.

“The well-equipped education van will operate in 26 buffer villages of Pench Tiger Reserve showing films on “conservation and benefits” to kids and organize interactive programmes with tribal youths to provide them livelihood opportunities and also focus on reducing anthropogenic pressure on tiger habitat by mobilizing village eco development committees (EDCs),” said Mandar Pingle, education officer working on this project.

“Satpuda Foundation has already recorded many achievements in the Pench landscape and we hope that the Fable Fund will bring measurable change in tiger conservation scenario,” said Nikita Mehta of BC Mehta Trust.

Title: Region gets highest ever representation in RS
Content:
CLEARED SKHER

Aurangabad: Marathwada has now got its highest-ever representation in the Rajya Sabha after the BJP, Congress and NCP each nominating a member from region.

Bhagwat Karad of BJP, Rajiv Satav of Congress and Fouzia Khan of NCP are from Marathwada. They have been elected unopposed to Rajya Sabha.

At present, only industrialist Rajkumar Dhoot, whose third-term as RS member is slated to end next month, was the representative from Marathwada in the upper house of the Parliament.

Karad, former Aurangabad mayor, is considered the OBC face from Marathwada. With former minister Pankaja Munde Palwe, another OBC leader from the region, facing defeat in assembly election, Karad’s elevation is being seen as BJP’s move to give representation to the community.

Satav, an ex-MP from Hingoli, did not contest the last Lok Sabha election but was granted the RS nomination. A former youth wing president of the Congress, he is known to be close to the top Congress leadership.

Fouzia Khan, who hails from Parbhani, is considered a loyal member of the NCP and served as the minister of state for school education in Maharashtra. She is hailed as progressive and well educated woman leader within the Muslim community.

Sharad Advant of advocacy group Marathwada Janta Vikas Parishad said the region should benefit from the representation in the Rajya Sabha. “The elected leaders must ensure that the issue of developmental backlog of Marathwada is addressed. The necessary advocacy on pending issues is expected from leaders,” he said.

Earlier, Janardan Waghmare (2008- 2014) and Gopalrao Patil (1994-2000), both from Latur, were Rajya Sabha member of NCP and BJP, respectively. Rajni Patil from Beed was also Rajya Sabha member from 2013 to 2018.

Title: ‘Ablution before going to mosque’
Content:
Pune: The Seerat Committee, Pune, on Thursday appealed to the Muslim community to perform ablution before going to mosques for the Friday prayers and stay at home if they have cough, cold or fever as a preventive measure against coronavirus.

The committee members, Maulana Nizamuddin Fakhruddin and Ghulam Ahmed Kadari, in a statement also urged the community and the trustees of mosques in the city to make the Friday prayer a short affair.

Community leader Akbar Pathan told TOI that people have been urged to offer “Sunnah” prayers at home and offer only the ‘Fard’ prayer in mosques before dispersing.

Title: UoH, IIIT-H renew collaboration
Content: HYDERABAD: University of Hyderabad ( UoH ) and International Institute of Information Technology , Hyderabad (IIIT-H) penned the MoU for five years to further collaborate in areas of teaching, research, conferences, seminars, exhibitions, etc. Both institutions also agreed to extend their physical facilities for mutual benefits.

Title: HC seeks DVAC report on substandard check dam
Content:
Madurai: Madras high court has sought a report from the directorate of vigilance and anti-corruption (DVAC) in a plea seeking action against officials responsible for the construction of a substandard check dam in a water channel in Virudhunagar district.

In his petition, P Vellaisamy, who cultivates crops on four acres of land at Kansapuram village near Watrap, stated that the land is dependent on the Seevaneri irrigation tank. Surplus water from the tank would flow through the Nondi Virisal channel. Since there was no check dam at the channel, the surplus water from the tank drained quickly causing hardships to the farmers. He stated that government had allotted Rs 5lakh for the construction of a check dam at the channel during 2018-19. However, since it was constructed using substandard materials, the dam was damaged within three months and is currently in a dilapidated condition. He stated that the fund allotted for the project was swindled. tnn

Title: Hyderabad: Constables injured in road accident
Content: HYDERABAD: Two police constables sustained injuries after a car rammed into the two-wheeler they were travelling on in Vanasthalipuram on Thursday. Constables Chitrapu Sanjeev Kumar and his colleague B Madhu were going towards Panama from Narayanaguda when a car hit their vehicle. Both victims sustained injuries on their hands, legs and face and were shifted to a hospital. A case was registered.

Title: Rs 100cr property tax due against 60k a/cs
Content:
Indore: Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) has identified as many as 60,000 property accounts from which it has not received tax payment for years.

Corporation officials said that total dues of Rs100 crore is pending in name of these property and their respective owners have not paid tax for last eight years.

“Eighty per cent of these accounts are of residential and remaining 20 per cent accounts are of government or commercial property,” IMC’s additional commissioner SK Chaitanya told TOI.

He said that total demand from these 60,000 accounts is estimated to be around Rs100 crore. “However, we can expect recovery of some Rs10 crore from these accounts,” he said.

He said that list of these accounts have been shared with respective zones officials for cross verification.

“Zonal officials have been instructed to verify every account of their respective areas and initiate action or close them accordingly,” he added.

While these accounts have been identified in an internal survey of the corporation, officials said that many of these accounts were supposed to be closed down as separate accounts were opened in name of the same property.

“We found that there was some plots on which residential property were constructed and new accounts were opened while old accounts were not closed,” officials with IMC’s revenue department said. The corporation has been running extensive recovery drive across city for past two months. It has even started seizing movable property of defaulters to compel them into clearing their dues.

For current fiscal, state government has fixed revenue target of Rs1160crore for the civic body.

Title: Mother, grandmother kill 5-day-old baby girl, bury her
Content:
Madurai: A woman and her mother-in-law allegedly killed a five-day-old baby girl in a village near Andipatti in Theni district on March 2, in a suspected case of female infanticide.

Police said the mother murdered the child on the insistence of her mother-in-law as it was the third girl child in the family. The accused have been identified as S Kavitha, 27, wife of Suresh, 34, and her mother-in-law Chellammal, 55.

The accused buried the child next to their house in Othaveedu in Ramanathapuram village after confirming its death. The Rajathanai police registered a case under 174 CrPc (suspicious death) and conducted an inquiry with the family members. After the duo spilled the beans, the section was changed to 302 IPC – punishment for murder. They were also booked under 201 IPC - causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender.

Police said that Kavitha and Suresh, a mason, got married 12 years ago and had two children Pandi Meena and Harini. They are staying in their relative’s house in Ramakrishnapuram.

Kavitha gave birth to a healthy baby girl at Theni Medical College Hospital on February 26. She was discharged after a couple of days. After coming home, her mother-in-law started reprimanding her and insisted her to get rid of the child. The two fed the baby sap of Calotropis, a poisonous plant. After the baby died, she was buried next to her house.

They informed the villagers that the child died due to choking when the mother was breastfeeding her. It was taken to the knowledge of child protection unit in the district. They informed the revenue officials, who conducted an inquiry.

Title: Kin of those staying abroad on edge
Content: Jodhpur: As the coronavirus is spreading unabatedly across the globe, the families whose wards or relatives are either studying or working abroad are concerned about their well-being.Though, most of them are convinced with the arrangements put in for the safety of their wards or relatives in their respective countries, but they want them to come back considering the situation turning worse.TOI spoke to some of the families, who have their wards or relatives either studying or working abroad to weigh their concerns amid the corona pandemic. An engineer in Jodhpur Municipal Corporation, Parasmal Purohit, whose daughter Kirti Purohit is pursuing medicine in a medical college in Almaty in Kazakhstan, said he has been in regular touch with his daughter.“Her classes have been suspended by the college administration and all the students have been asked to stay put in their hostel rooms, where they are being provided with their daily lessons through internet,” Purohit said.“The situation is under control till now and my daughter has not expressed any concern either. But we are concerned and would prefer her to be back, if the situation escalates there,” Purohit added.Kriparam Godara, whose brother Prashant has been working in Toronto (Canada) for the past few years, has also been in touch with his brother.“All the staff members of his company have been asked to work from home and have been advised to remain in-doors since the outbreak of coronavirus,” Godara said.Godara said the family wants him to return. “But he assured us that there was nothing to worry about as adequate safety measures have been in place in the entire country,” he added.On the other hand, parents of those who have returned heaved a sigh of relief. “I am relieved that my daughter returned from the UK amid the growing menace of coronavirus,” said Hari Mohan Sharma. His daughter has been pursuing finance in a college of UK.He said their primary concern was priority being given to locals over foreigners in many countries as far as medical and other measures were concerned.Similarly, Swapndeep Singh Chouhan, who has been pursuing a course in engineering in Aachen of Germany, returned to Jodhpur on March 8.He said after the situation started worsening there, he decided to leave for home as most of the Indian students had done. “Though, people are good there, but when it came to crisis, priority is given to locals. So instead of waiting, I decided to return after the colleges were shut,” Chouhan said.The JMC has begun physical screening of those who have returned from abroad since February 1.Commissioner Suresh Ola said about 150 people have returned from different countries and their hands were being stamped so that they could be identified easily.

Title: Cops to help PCMC keep quarantined at home
Content:
Pimpri Chinchwad: The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation will seek the help of police as well as home guards to ensure that people advised home quarantine for 14 days do not venture out in the public.

Sharing this information at a press conference on Thursday, municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar also appealed to private firms in PCMC limits to extend help to the civic body via corporate social responsibility (CSR) funds to check the spread of Covid-19.

The civic chief said the condition of the 11 positive patients in isolation was stable. “Nine of them are asymptomatic, while two have minor symptoms,” Hardikar said.

He said the number of people under surveillance or home quarantine rose to 299 on Thursday from 230 the previous day. “It is necessary for these people to stay at home for the entire 14-day period. The civic body has formed 100 field surveillance teams with 240 civic employees to ensure that home-quarantined people stay at home. We are also taking the help of 60 police personnel for this purpose. We have sought home guards from the state government to help these teams,” the municipal commissioner said.

He said the civic body had covered 22,000 households under its door-to-door survey in the buffer areas of the spots. “We are advising people suffering from cold or cough to seek doctor’s advice,” Hardikar said.

When contacted, deputy commissioner of police Sudhir Hiremath said, “We have formed 20 teams, including officers from the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation. These teams will visit residences of those home quarantined. Police will warn them of strict action if they are found roaming in their societies. The quarantined people must ensure that they stay at home. We have the list of home quarantined people.”

Title: PMPML buses disinfection at 3 depots
Content:
Pimpri Chinchwad: The civic body has deployed employees at the three bus depots of Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) for decontaminating buses.

K Anil Roy, medical officer of health said instructions have been given to the zonal offices to decontaminate buses at Nigdi, Nehrunagar and Bhosari bus depots. Two employees have been deployed at each of the 3 depots for cleaning the buses using sodium hypochloride (bleach).

A PMPML official said, “The public transport body has begun decontamination and regular washing of all the buses plying from its 13 bus depots after receiving directives during the meeting at the divisional commissioner’s office on March 13. A daily report is sent in the evening to the office.”

He said earlier 1,700 buses from 13 depots made around 21,000 trips in comparison to 1,100 buses covering 14,000 trips daily amid the Covid-19 scare.

The PMPML has provided extra manpower of 20 to 30 staffers for washing and decontamination of buses across all depots.

Title: 30% flights cancelled at Madurai airport
Content:
Madurai: Covid-19 scare has resulted in the cancellation of at least 30% of flights, both domestic and international, at the Madurai International Airport on Thursday. Officials said that while some flights were cancelled due to lack of patronage in the wake of Covid-19, some had to be cancelled as a precautionary measure as per instructions from AAI.

An official from Madurai airport said all the services between Madurai and Colombo have been cancelled, while flights to Singapore have already been cancelled. A few domestic flights connecting destinations like Chennai and Bengaluru have also been cancelled due to poor occupancy. In Tuticorin, of the six flights connecting Tuticorin with Chennai (5) and Bengaluru (1), two have been cancelled every day during the course of this week due to poor occupancy. Tuticorin airport director N Subramanian said that SpiceJet has cancelled two of its morning flights from and to Chennai from March 21 to April 30. Sources from Madurai airport said the cancellations left many passengers fuming. The airlines were opaque in letting fliers know the status of the upcoming flights. Passengers were asked to visit in person.

Title: Pune: Man sets wife ablaze over dispute due to coronavirus
Content: PUNE: The Kondhwa police on Wednesday arrested a 25-year-old unemployed man for setting his wife ablaze over a dispute of not visiting their village at Parbhani because of coronavirus, among other reasons. The man attempted to harm his wife at their Gokulnagar residence on Katraj-Kondhwa bypass road around 7.30am on Tuesday.The victim Changuna Joagdand (22) has sustained 65% burn injuries. She is recuperating at the Sassoon General Hospital. The accused Haridas Gangadhar Joagdand has been remanded in police custody till March 22.The police had initially registered a complaint of accident after the woman gave a statement that she sustained injuries because her dupatta had caught fire while heating water. A police officer said, “After her relatives visited her, Changuna changed her statement and stated that her husband had poured kerosene on her before setting her ablaze. Her statement, recorded in the presence of a medical officer, was converted into an FIR.”Senior inspector Vinayak Gaikwad from the Kondhwa police station said, “The couple had been quarrelling after Haridas told his wife that they would shift to their village in Parbhani but she refused because of coronavirus, among other reasons.”“In a fit of rage, the accused poured kerosene on his wife and threw a matchstick upon her. We have arrested Haridas on the charge of attempting to commit murder of his wife under Section 307 of the Indian Penal Code ,” Gaikwad said.Sub-inspector Nilesh Chavan from the Khadi Machine police chowky said, “The couple got married in July last year and moved to Pune around four months ago. Haridas initially worked at a fuel station but he later lost his job.”Chavan said, “Haridas started arguing with his wife about shifting to Parbhani but she refused because she was working in a mall and it was not possible for her to apply for leave. Secondly, she was not willing to leave Pune.”“The woman resisted her husband and raised an alarm after the suspect set her ablaze. The husband later doused off the fire and with the help of their landlord and shifted her to Sassoon Hospital to seek treatment,” Chavan added.

Title: Central Vista: Government proposes site for new office block for MPs
Content:
NEW DELHI: The government has proposed to create office space for MPs where the Shram Shakti Bhawan is now located and it would be linked to the proposed new Parliament through a tunnel, according to some of the MPs who went through the latest presentation on the revamp of Central Vista on Thursday.

Sources said a detailed presentation about the project with particular focus on new Parliament was made before General Purposes Committee of the Lok Sabha. “We were told that there will be adequate office space for MPs in the new scheme of things. The planners said that the current Parliament has developed several problems and hence there is a need for a new Parliament. While MPs had no objection to the facilities that have been proposed for them in the new Parliament, some did not like the architecture, which seems to be “similar to that of Gujarat High Court”, said an MP, who did not wish to be named.

TOI has learnt that the government has prepared the roadmap to first vacate the plot occupied by the Indira Gandhi National Art Centre (IGNCA) where three new office blocks will come up. “In the first phase, offices in Udyog Bhawan, Nirman Bhawan and another building will be shifted so that redevelopment on these plots can start,” said a source,

Officials also said a decision is yet to be taken whether the Jawahar Bhawan, which houses external affairs ministry would be demolished as well for building a taller structure. There are also discussions whether Nirman Bhawan should be razed or the existing building should be revamped from inside.

Title: Startup team harvests medicinal mushrooms
Content:
PALAKKAD: Pournami Agritech , an agritech startup here has successfully harvested the first of tissue culture and commercial cultivation of Cordyceps Militaris , a rare species of medicinal mushroom is known as Himalayan Gold (as it is mainly found in the Himalayan ranges) which has a multitude of health benefits and can potentially prevent a wide range of lifestyle illness.

This is the first of its kind in the state, as the three-year-old study and research brought them success in commercially cultivating this wonder mushroom which is popular for healthy food supplements that have already caught up across the world.

Cordyceps Militaris can be added to tea, coffee, cereals, juices and much more. Its medicinal use has already been documented in Tibetan and Chinese medicines.

Two young entrepreneurs, founder and chief operations officer Raghu O Nair and co-founder, Jayakrishnan K had started Pournami Agritech in Chandranagar three years ago. With extensive study and research, they could successfully commercially cultivate Cordyceps Militaris in Palakkad.

“Through our research, with the help from various other agencies and experts, we have started tissue culture and commercial cultivation of Cordyceps Militaris. It is first of its kind in Kerala. We are now planning to take this initiative in phases. In the first phase, we had our first successful harvest. In the next phase, with the help of Kerala Startup Mission, we are seeking investment for rolling out value-added nutraceutical products to make it available to a larger segment of people”, said Raghu.

“We are also planning to collaborate with various research organizations for the research and development of this rare herb. Hopefully, the world of Cordyceps will pave the way towards innovative and healthy products,” they said.

Meanwhile, the fungus was first reported from Kerala in 2013 by T Santhosh Kumar , assistant professor, Regional Agricultural Research Station, Pilicode, while conducting a research on managing the coconut root grub (Leucopholis canephora). It was later confirmed as a species belonging to the Cordyceps genus also known as caterpillar fungus.

“Preliminary studies conducted at the Regional Cancer Centre showed that the species is capable of suppressing tumour cells and inhibiting the proliferation of lung cancer (adenocarcinoma) cells. Thus, there is every possibility of using the species to develop immunity enhancement, anti-ageing and anti-fatigue functional food on a commercial basis,” said Kumar.

For more details, contact Pournami Agritech No-389, Chandranagar Co-operative House Building Society, Chandranagar, Palakkad-678008 (Mob: 9043099998)

Title: Fatehsagar Lake shut till March 31
Content:
Udaipur: In adherence to the government’s order over social distancing, UIT on Thursday issued order of closedown of Fatehsagar Lake here till 31 March. People were asked to evacuate the area urgently in the evening and vehicles parked in the area were made to retreat. Meanwhile, CMHO Dinesh Khardi told media that no positive cases have been reported in Udaipur till Thursday and only one result of the sample of a youth who returned from Kuwait, is awaited.

Collector Anandi held an emergency meeting and imparted necessary instructions on the precautionary measures to check assemblage of people at public places. On the other hand the Udaipur Municipal Corporation took steps to disinfect public places.

“We have sprayed a mixture of water and sodium hypochrorite solution at various govt premises like Hospital, Nagar Nigam Campus, busiest market streets , Collectorate Campus, Railway Station, Bus stand etc as a precautionary measure,” Ankit Singh, the UMC commissioner told TOI. The authorities have appealed to the persons who have returned from Jhunjhunu to visit the hospitals for screening.

Title: Many in dilemma over attending funerals
Content:
Madurai: Family functions, ceremonies and celebrations may have been put on hold to avoid people gathering in large numbers, but can funerals be avoided? There have been many instances in which people who have taken up self-imposed quarantine at home do not know whether to attend a funeral or not.

A 65-year-old woman from Ramnad developed a lung infection and was referred to the Government Rajaji Hospital on Monday. Though she showed symptoms similar to those of Covid-19, doctors reassured her family that with no travel history she would not have to be tested for Covid-19. However, her condition continued to deteriorate at the GRH and she passed away on Thursday. Her immediate family members had to attend her funeral, but friends and relatives were in a dilemma. “There is no doubt that funerals are occasions when one can pick up infections, but not attending them citing Covid-19 also causes strain in relations. The government is yet to make a mention about crowding at funerals,’’ said T Palanikumar of Madurai.

“Some people understand, but there are rituals and customs that are followed by relatives. If they are not performed that also causes problems within the family,’’ said K Saroja of K K Nagar. Funerals are occasions for final farewells and are of sentimental value, but it is being pointed out that precautions also need to be taken.

“Asking people to wear masks and sanitize their hands while coming to a funeral is also not possible. Self-restraint will be the best option in such situations,” said health department sources, because not many would be ready to listen to rules and regulations at funerals.

Title: Delhi cops say no breath test unless driver ‘visibly’ drunk
Content: NEW DELHI: Amid the virus scare, the traffic police has decided to stop checks for drunk driving using alcometers for the next few days unless a driver is found to be visibly drunk or endangering the lives of others on the road.An officer said most people who were stopped for checks earlier this week had refused to blow into alcometer pipes fearing infection. On Wednesday, too, there was no challan for drunk driving. According to the Delhi Police data on drunk driving, only six challans were issued on March 14 against 89 on February 14. From March 15-18, 11 challans were issued while 176 were recorded during the same period in February.Delhi Traffic Police has already issued instructions regarding novel coronavirus for the safety of its personnel and motorists. Besides extra masks and hand gloves, the traffic police personnel were also given extra straws for using alcometers, said an officer. “We had even asked our personnel to wash hands if possible or use gloves in the presence of a suspect. They have been instructed not to interact without a mask especially during an alcometer test,” said a senior officer. The cops even assured everybody that a new straw was being used for each check.But in most cases the drivers still refused to let the cops bring the alcometer close to their mouth. Considering the scare among people and the spread of the infection, “we have now decided to keep the checks limited to the drivers found to be driving dangerously,” the officer said.A spotting team will be placed at various locations across the capital to identify suspected drivers and alert another team that will be stationed a few metres ahead to flag down the violators. “A fresh straw will be placed in the alcometer and the policemen operating it will put on gloves and masks in front of every suspect to assure them before conducting a check,” said another officer.Traffic cops have also asked the liquor shops to advise buyers not to drive after drinking.

Title: Romanian held for ATM card cloning in Delhi
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: A Romanian has been arrested for allegedly duping people by installing skimming devices and cameras at unguarded ATMs in south Delhi areas. His act was exposed after an advocate from Greater Kailash-I informed police about the fraudulent withdrawal of Rs 40,000 from his debit card.

The accused has been identified as Claudiu Cosmin (29). According to police, Cosmin and his associate Danial came to India in February 2019. They would install skimming devices and cameras to steal the card and PIN details at several unguarded ATM kiosks in south Delhi areas. They stole data of at least 50 people.

“The accused managed to withdraw about Rs 15 lakh from the cards which were cloned from Greater Kailash, Malviya Nagar, CR Park, Vasant Kunj and other areas,” said Atul Kumar Thakur, deputy commissioner of police, South. Eight cloned cards, a laptop, a mobile phone, masks and other devices were recovered. Danial is yet to be arrested.

Title: Nagpur: Ex-sarpanch kidnaps two to help wife win poll
Content:
To ensure the victory of his wife in elections for deputy sarpanch post in Bokhara, a former sarpanch abducted... Read More

NAGPUR: A former sarpanch, who allegedly abducted two members of the panchayat samiti to ensure the victory of his wife in by-election to the post of deputy sarpanch at Bokhara , are now finding themselves in the dock as the cops have slapped charges of kidnapping against him and his aides.

The was held on March 16 in which Sneha, wife of former village head Ranjitsingh Chavan, defeated Javed Shaikh of the Congress party by a wafer thin margin of two votes.

Chavan was so desperate to get Sneha elected as deputy sarpanch that he scripted a reel life kidnapping drama and allegedly abducted two village panchayat members, Shakeel Anwar Shaikh and Vinod Parte, from different places and forced them to stay at a lodge at Mouda without mobile phones till the election result was announced.

Chavan was helped by his accomplices, brother Abhijeet , Shubham Dixit and Dilip Barde.

Sneha contested the election as an independent candidate and emerged victorious against Javed, who was supported by Shakeel Shaikh and his group.

The post was lying vacant after the resignation of former deputy village headwoman Varsha Tayade.

Narrating the chain of events, Shaikh, cousin of Javed, said he was about to leave for voting when Chavan, his brother Abhijeet and others came in a car to his saloon at Mankapur Chowk and asked to be with them for a meeting with Parte at his liquor bar on the ring road.

Shaikh said, “I did not oppose Chavan. After picking up Parte, we were told that there would be a meeting with the current sarpanch Lalla Bhai . Meanwhile, Chavan left us near powergrid and Shubham Dixit joined.”

Shaikh said, “My and Parte’s mobile phones were snatched. We were taken to a lodge at Mouda and locked up. There was no other way to contact others to seek help. Abhijeet also started threatening with knife which scared us.”

Shaikh and Parte were released at 5pm on March 17 after the result was declared. “We were threatened of dire consequences if we reported the matter to police. However, we gathered courage and lodged a police complaint,” he said.

He also said the sarpanch will now lodge a complaint with the authorities concerned to cancel the election.

Mankapur police have registered an offence of kidnapping against Chavan brothers, Dixit and Barde. Police have so far arrested Barde and launched a search to nab the other accused.

Title: Choreographer posts Covid-19 status on FB
Content:
Bengaluru: Choreographer Diya Naidu from Bengaluru went public on Thursday with her Covid-19 infection, saying her throat swab test confirmed it and is now waiting for the blood test result. The state government declares a person Covid-19 positive only after the second confirmatory test.

She returned from Switzerland on March 9 and was admitted to the isolation ward of ESI Hospital, Indiranagar on Wednesday night.

Diva posted on Facebook: “I am sorry to do this here. The BBMP is supposed to but seeing how unprepared we are I'm trying to make sure. I have tested positive for Covid-19 and am in hospital currently. I was barely symptomatic... In case you have come into contact with me or someone who has met me - please quarantine yourself.”

She added: “The only thing I got was total loss of smell - no cough or cold or fever or shivering - none of the typical symptoms yet.”

Several people asked Diya why she didn’t go into home isolation. But many appreciated her for going public when there is fear, stigma and discrimination of Covid-19 suspected cases and patients.

Diya told TOI on phone that when she returned to Bengaluru, no one told her about home isolation. “The focus was only on countries like Italy, Dubai, the US and the UK. I called the helpline number posted at the airport, but couldn’t connect despite multiple calls. I went to a private hospital to check if I should be tested. But the general physician told me I would be tested if I developed symptoms.”

“I went out on work for one day. I took part in a fund raising activity. I was an audience member at a public event on March 12. I have told the organisers that I’ve tested positive,” she said.

On Thursday evening, India Foundation for the Arts (IFA) sent a note stating that an audience-member at the Mir Mukhtiyar Ali Concert it had organised on March 12 has tested positive and all those present must take precautions and contact local health authorities if they experience any symptoms.

“Diya Naidu is a suspected Covid-19 patient and was admitted in our hospital for quarantine purpose. Her test results are awaited,” a doctor from ESI Hospital, Indiranagar, said.

Firm says employee is positive

Kronos Incorporated, a provider of workforce management and human capital management cloud solutions, said on Thursday that one of its employees in Benglauru tested positive.

“We can confirm that an employee from Bengaluru region has a positive diagnosis following travel outside India and hasn’t come to our office since February-end. We communicated this to Kronites in that region and the building landlord, ensuring that the employee did not come to the office,” it said.

Title: US-Kolkata ticket costs Rs 1.6 lakh ahead of flight ban
Content: KOLKATA: International flight fares shot up on Thursday after the government announced a ban on all international flights from Sunday. Though the embargo is for a week, aviation industry sources said it could be extended if the number of coronavirus cases in India rose.On Thursday evening, fares were sky-high with a one-way trip costing as much as a return journey. A French national bought a ticket to Paris for Rs 64,000 while a Swiss national had to cough up Rs 67,000 to travel to Zurich. For a German engineer, the trip to Dusseldorf was even more expensive at Rs 74,000. As the handful of foreigners who have been stuck in India scramble for a seat on the last few flights out of Kolkata before the shutdown, the fares could escalate still more.Return flights have already touched astounding levels with Indians desperate to return before the skies shut. A student studying in Purdue in the US bought an economy class ticket from Chicago to Kolkata for a whopping Rs 1.6 lakh! It’s not just west-bound flights whose fares are sizzling. A Kiwi citizen of Indian origin bought a ticket to Auckland for Rs 67,000 while another who lives in Brisbane paid Rs 74,000 for the flight home. “Airlines are making the most out of people’s desperation,” said a travel agent.At Kolkata airport though, the international flight ban didn’t come as a surprise. The advisories that led to gradual shutdown of flights from EU, the UK, Turkey, Malaysia and Philippines followed by the roll-out of compulsory quarantine on Gulf flights had hinted at the shutdown.“The daily flight count had come down from 35 to 16. The passenger count had dwindled from 4,500 a day to fewer than 1,500. Retail stores and food & beverage outlets had begun to shut. One of the two duty-free outlets had closed as well. Flights were operating half empty,” recounted an airport official, adding that the immediate challenge would be to maintain an empty facility and bear the expenses with no cash-flows.While the shutdown appeared inevitable, it is the long journey to revival that has everyone worried now. Though all airlines have assured the airport authorities they will return after the havoc caused by the pandemic is over, they are unlikely to restart operations with the usual number of weekly flights.“It has to be a slow ramp-up. Passengers will initially be reluctant to travel. Students and businessmen will be the first to fly but it will take time for leisure travellers to regain confidence. It may be several months before Kolkata airport regains the buzz,” an airline official said.

Title: Coronavirus in Kolkata: Crowded hospitals beat concept of social distancing, say doctors
Content: KOLKATA: Leaves have been declared at educational institutes, movie halls have downed shutters temporarily and family functions are being postponed to ensure social distancing in the wake of the coronavirus crisis. However, thanks to the steady flow of patients, hospitals, specially the state-run ones, continue to remain crowded. This, doctors said, could pose a threat to the whole concept of social distancing to prevent transmission of the virus.“The Karnataka government has already come up with a circular, asking only patients who need emergency care to visit government hospitals over the next two weeks. We hope the Bengal government comes up with similar restrictions to decongest hospitals,” said a senior doctor at SSKM Hospital. The hospital sees a footfall of nearly 14,000 OPD patients daily on an average. The rest of the four medical colleges in the city get 6,000 to 7,000 OPD patients each daily. Relatives accompanying them add to the crowd.“We are trying to limit the number of visitors and OPD patients. For example, for patients with common illness, we are giving them medicine for one month and asking them not to come back during this period unless there is an emergency,” said Raghunath Misra, medical superintendent and vice-principal (MSVP) at SSKM Hospital.NRS Medical College and Hospital has already started restricting the number of visitors to the hospital by allowing a patient to be accompanied by only one relative. Other measures are expected to follow. “Meanwhile, we have started our fever clinic from Thursday where all patients with flu symptoms are isolated and checked so that they do not mix with other patients. We have five ventilators in the RCU reserved in case they are needed to treat Covid-19 patients,” said Saurabh Chattopadhyay, MSVP at NRS Medical College and Hospital.The Calcutta National Medical College (CNMC) administrators will meet on Friday to find out ways to reduce crowding on the hospital premises and also chalk out a roadmap to tackle suspected Covid-19 patients. “About 80% of patients who throng the OPD in government hospitals complain of common condition like abdomen pain. If we can attend to only 20%, who really need immediate medical attention, during this crisis, the crowd will thin down significantly,” said a CNMC doctor.RG Kar has already held rounds of meeting on decongesting the hospital premises. The hospital will start segregation of patients with influenza symptoms. The authorities are also mulling planned intervention including scheduled surgeries. “The kind of crowd in government hospitals is a serious threat as far as transmission of coronavirus is concerned. Even our doctors are at risk. We have a few plans lined up to tackle the patient rush but we cannot implement them unless the directive comes from the health department,” said an administrator at RG Kar Medical College.While most of these hospitals have kept their isolation wards ready, they need uninterrupted supply of PPE (personal protective equipment) for healthcare workers who will deal with such patients. Apart from ID Hospital, only NRS so far has corona-suspected patients in its isolation ward.

Title: People rush to markets for buying veggies, grocery
Content:
Jaipur: Panic buying of essential commodities reached its peak on Thursday evening as people rushed to vegetable markets and departmental shops to stockpile items of daily use.

The departmental and grain shops reported more than usual number of buyers as people pressed the panic button and started stocking of non-perishable items in the fear of coronavirus forcing a total shut down.

The momentum reached its peak in the evening following state government announced a partial shut- down of its offices and decides to strictly impose the curfew announced on Wednesday. The address to the nation by prime minister Modi also added fuel to fire as people expected some drastic announcements.

People were also carried away by the rumours on social media and word by mouth publicity that the governments is planning a total shut down of shops and vegetable markets as well. The Lal Kothi vegetable market seen unusual rush of people to buy vegetables in the evening.

Meena Lekhyani, resident of Raja Park was seen rushing to gas agency for ordering an extra cylinder. "Everyone is talking about a lock down. I have ordered a cylinder in advance just in case if we would need anything," said Meena.

Shalu Gupta, another resident said she had bought everything in advance as there is a panic in the market. Grocery shops and vegetable vendors were busy dealing with customers. Rumours of entire market being shutting down including the vegetable market have made people more tensed.

A departmental shop owner on the Tonk Road near Municipal corporation office said, “there was steady stream of consumers since morning who were purchasing milk powder, biscuits and other grocery items in advance. It was heightened in the evening. They were all worried about a shutdown of shops and shortage of essential items.”

Similarly, a people could be seen rushing to get stock pile wheat and rice.

“I heard that supply is likely to be hit by coronavirus fear and wanted to buy sackful of wheat in advance,” said a customer. However, a shop owner said there is no need for panic as there is sufficient stock of the wheat and rice in the market.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Bus frequency won’t be curtailed as it will result in crowding, says Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal
Content: NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Thursday said that the frequency of buses and Delhi Metro trains will not be reduced even though the government wants people to travel less.Kejriwal said the issue was discussed by his government, but a decision was taken against reducing their trips. “If the frequency is reduced, there will be crowding,” he added, while urging Delhiites to stay at home as much as possible.Meanwhile, Delhi government has decided to extend the timings of the free disinfection of public service vehicles, including autorickshaws, e-rickshaws and taxis, to cut down the long queues at the bus depots where the drive is being carried out.The CM said, “We are disinfecting buses, ISBTs and metro trains daily. We were also disinfecting private public service vehicles, like autorickshaws and taxis, daily in two shifts from 10am to noon and from 4.30pm to 6.30pm at all our DTC and cluster bus depots for free. Owing to the long queues at the bus depots, we have decided to conduct the disinfection drive from 10am to 6pm. We will also double the manpower at bus depots that witness a lot of rush.”There has been a huge decline in the number of interstate buses coming to Delhi’s ISBTs and bus services from Jammu and Kashmir and Nepal have completely stopped, Kejriwal said. Delhi government is also disinfecting buses coming from other states. The government has made it mandatory for interstate buses to produce certificates of disinfection from their originating depots before being allowed to enter ISBTs in Delhi.On Wednesday, 11,081 certificates of disinfection were issued to public service vehicles at various bus depots. Though this service is not mandatory, Delhi government has advised the owners and operators to get their vehicles disinfected daily.“We have received an overwhelming response to our disinfection drive. Because of this, we have decided to extend it to the entire day. Our motive is to disinfect as many vehicles as possible,” transport minister Kailash Gahlot said. “Would request other public service vehicle owners to avail the free disinfection service being offered by Delhi government,” he later tweeted.Delhi government had initially started disinfection drive for DTC and cluster buses. The facility was later extended to other public service vehicles, like autorickshaws, Gramin Sewa, Phat-Phat Sewa, Maxi Cab and eco-friendly vehicles, free of cost.

Title: Need to turn tide on deforestation in Nagpur
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: Forests cover one third of the earth’s land mass, performing vital functions around the world. Around 1.6 billion people, including more than 2,000 indigenous cultures, depend on forests for their livelihoods, medicines, fuel, food and shelter.

Forests are the most biologically-diverse ecosystems on land, home to more than 80% of the terrestrial species of animals, plants and insects. Yet, despite all of these priceless ecological, economic, social and health benefits, global deforestation continues at an alarming rate.

The United Nations General Assembly proclaimed March 21, the International Day of Forests in 2012. The organizers are the United Nations Forum on Forests & Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), in collaboration with governments, the collaborative partnership on forests and other relevant organizations in the field.

The day raises awareness about importance of all types of forests. On each international day of forests, countries are encouraged to undertake local, national and international efforts to organize activities involving forests and trees, such as tree planting campaigns.

The theme for each international day of forests is chosen by the collaborative partnership on forests. The theme for 2020 is forests and biodiversity. António Guterres , secretary general of United Nation, says, “2020 has been referred to as a ‘Nature Super Year’ and must be the year where we turn the tide on deforestation and forestry loss.”

Over the past 25 years, the annual rate of net global deforestation has slowed by over 50%, which is a credit to the efforts of governments and other stakeholders working to sustainably manage forests. Yet, vast areas of forest continue to be lost. Our global environment is being degraded by our unsustainable choices. The way we consume natural resources is accelerating biodiversity loss and exacerbating climate change.

Forests, their sustainable management and use of resources, including in fragile ecosystems, are key to combating climate change, and to contributing to the prosperity and well-being of current and future generations. Forests also play a crucial role in poverty alleviation and in the achievement of the sustainable development goals (SDGs).

One average grown up tree sequesters 0.2 mt of CO2 per year and releases 0.118 mt of oxygen per year. Humans need oxygen for their survival at the same time trees inhale the CO2 released by the human beings.

Our ancient literature says, “Save trees, they will save you.” An ordinary person in a hospital requires 3 oxygen cylinders per day whose cost is Rs2,100 per day. If average life expectancy of a person is 65 years, every human is consuming oxygen worth Rs5 crore over his lifetime. Hence, it is too precious to lose forests.

Title: Delhi deputy CM Manish Sisodia asks colleges to focus on infra expansion
Content:
Delhi deputy CM Manish Sisodia

NEW DELHI: Deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia on Thursday met principals of 16 Delhi University colleges , which are partially funded by the government, to discuss infrastructure expansion and improvement of facilities.

A day earlier, Sisodia had met officials of 12 DU colleges fully funded by Delhi government. These colleges are yet to receive funds from the government and have been unable to pay salaries to their staff for over two months. A principal with one of the colleges said, “There is no clarity yet on when we will get the funds. The deputy CM said the file is under consideration.”

The 16 colleges included Shivaji, Motilal Nehru, Rajdhani, Kamala Nehru, Gargi and Delhi College of Arts and Commerce. These colleges get 95% of their funds from UGC and 5% from Delhi government.

Kalpana Bhakuni, officiating principal of KNC, said, “The meeting with the deputy CM focused on improving higher education. We were asked our issues and promised all support.” Rajiv Chopra, principal of DCAC, said, “The deputy CM told us that we should look at expanding the college’s infrastructure.”

However, many principals said that there was no concrete talk about governing bodies, despite it being a contentious issue between the government and the university.

Meanwhile, National Democratic Teachers Front DU Executive Council member VS Negi sent a letter to vice-chancellor Yogesh Tyagi alleging that the meeting violated autonomy of the colleges. “The university should ensure that there is no political interference in the formation of the GBs,” he added.

Many are worried about not receiving funds despite the formation of GBs. Sujit Kumar, professor at Bhim Rao Ambedkar College, who has not been paid for the past two months, said, “Salaries of staff should not be linked to GB formation. It is we who are suffering in the fight between two political parties.”

Title: Four men assault duo for tryst with criminal
Content:
Pune: Four men assaulted an 18-year-old youth and his 20-year-old friend with sharp weapons inside an eatery at Mohammadwadi Chowk in Kondhwa on Tuesday evening following a dispute over one of them staying and roaming with a criminal on record.

Police said Abhijit Kamthe from Pisoli, sustained serious injuries to his head and left hand. His friend, Pratik Pethe, got injuries on his right hand.

“Kamthe and Pethe were at an eatery when the four men reach the spot on two motorcycles around 7.30pm.They picked up a quarrel with Kamthe over the latter residing and roaming around with the criminal on record, Sagar Autade, who’s currently lodged in Yearawada Central Jail. The four men accused Kamthe of giving them ‘dirty looks’ over the past few days,” senior inspector Vinayak Gaikwad from the Kondhwa police said.

The officer said the four men were armed with sickles. “They attacked Kamthe and Pethe with the sickles and chairs before fleeing the spot,” he added.

Sub-inspector Nilesh Chavan from the Khadi Machine chowkey said “The injured victims were rushed to a private hospital in Hadapsar. We recorded their statements and inspected the crime scene after receiving information of the incident from the city police control room.”

Two of the four assailants, Tushar Dukare (21) and Pratik Tilekar (20), were arrested on Wednesday, Chavan said, adding that a search was on for the two others.

“One of the absconding suspects is a minor with a criminal record. Dukare and Tilekar were arrested on the charge of voluntarily causing grievous hurt of the Indian Penal Code, among others,” he said.

Kamthe is a helper with the Hamal panchayat. “I used to live with Autade, as he was my friend. I also know the four assailants,” Kamthe said, refusing to elaborate on the incident.

Title: Kolkata Coronavirus News: Co-flyers of Covid-19 positive teen traced, all advised home isolation
Content: KOLKATA: The state government has traced 17 passengers who had travelled with the Covid-19 positive teen in the Etihad Airways flight via Abu Dhabi to Kolkata on Sunday. It has also given Jharkhand the passenger details after it was learnt that some passengers were from the neighbouring state. All passengers have been advised an immediate medical check-up and home isolation. Meanwhile, two maids who worked for the patient’s family in their home have tested negative for coronavirus According to sources, two immigration officers who had interacted with the teenager at the airport have been asked to go on home isolation.The 18-year-old Covid-19 patient’s mother, a senior bureaucrat, his father, a child specialist, and their two drivers have already been sent to the Rajarhat quarantine facility for a fortnight’s isolation. The two maids will also be sent for a 14-day isolation. Beliaghata ID Hospital sources said the teenager has been responding to treatment and his condition is stable. “He has only complained of mild cough. He has no other problem,” a source said.The apartment owners’ association of the condominium, where the family lives, on Thursday submitted a list of nine people to the state health department who have recently returned from abroad and have made them stay in home isolation. “None of them still has any symptom but we have submitted their details to the state government,” said the secretary of the owners’ association.“No one is now owning up to have visited the patients’ apartment in the last few days or having met them. We have knowledge about few of the neighbours who had even spent some time inside their home but if they do not own up, we cannot force them,” said another member of the association.From Thursday, KMC has begun fever surveillance by visiting homes and complexes at boroughs 11 and 12, comprising areas in south and east Kolkata, covering Patuli, Garia, EM Bypass, Naktala, Baghajatin, Jadavpur, Santoshpur and areas off EM Bypass.“We have been receiving a number of calls from these areas about people who have come from outside. Some of them are suffering from fever and other symptoms of coronavirus. Hence, we have been undertaking a survey and will submit the report to the state health department,” said a senior KMC official.

Title: Soon, expect advisory on fewer guests at weddings
Content:
Pune: The Pune district collector Naval Kishore Ram has appealed to citizens going ahead with their wedding plans to curtail the number of guests to 50 and help prevent the spread of coronavirus.

He said an advisory will soon be issued to ensure that no more than 50 persons from the invite list attend the wedding. “Earlier, we had permitted 100 persons from each side to attend the wedding. We want all to follow social distancing norms. While no action will be taken for violation but we appeal to people to follow the advisory,” Ram stated.

Several couples from the city and wedding venues have proactively cancelled or postponed events lined up till the end of April. Namdev Mahabdi, manager of Siddhi Garden and Banquets, said, “We had multiple events lined up but all have now been postponed till May. Many postponed their events voluntarily while we had to ask others to move their event to a later date.”

Representatives from some venues also stated that instead of curtailing the number of guests, most people prefer to postpone events.

Title: How Delhi is closing down to shut out coronavirus
Content: NEW DELHI: The government has decided to suspend non-essential public services from Friday till March 31 but directed officials to work from home and remain connected with offices online and telephonically. Those activities categorised as ‘essential’ will, however, continue.These and other decisions were taken in a joint meeting of lieutenant governor Anil Baijal and the chief minister Arvind Kejriwal with other Delhi ministers and senior government officers at Raj Niwas.The categorisation of ‘essential’ and ‘non-essential’ services is likely to be done by Friday, the chief minister said.The joint meeting of top government functionaries and senior officers witnessed the health department making a detailed presentation on the present status of coronavirus spread in Delhi, action taken by various authorities, availability of quarantine facilities and hospital beds and proposed measures to contain Covid-19.In a statement issued after the meeting, Baijal said directions were issued to make thermal screening mandatory at public places and efforts would be made to scan every person going in public space while traffic police have been told to stop breath analyser test. Hotels that have the facility to quarantine people have also been directed to waive the tax on rooms.Neighbours and RWAs should be informed about those under home-quarantine in a residential complex and fine on spitting in public places is to be strictly enforced.Briefing the media, Kejriwal said the Delhi government was taking all relevant measures to contain the spread of coronavirus. “We have a capacity of 768 beds installed at the quarantine facilities till now, with only 57 beds that are currently occupied. We have 550 isolation beds in the Delhi government hospitals for the treatment of Covid-19 patients, out of which 40 beds have been occupied. There are 95 beds available in the central government hospitals, out of which 67 beds have been occupied by suspected Covid-19 patients. We are also mapping the requirements of all the government and private hospitals in Delhi, and we will issue directions that all the machinery and ventilator facilities in these hospitals should be in working conditions,” the CM said.“Following reports that many people are escaping from quarantine facilities, we have started stamping all those who have been advised to self-quarantine themselves. This is a very dangerous situation as they infect others who deliberately or non-deliberately come in their contact. If they don’t abide by the do's and don’ts, we will have to take strict measures against them, including filing FIR or taking them into custody,” Kejriwal said.He added that while all restaurants in Delhi shall remain closed till March 31, home-deliveries and take-aways will continue. “All educational institutions have also been shut down, including ITIs, polytechnics, universities, colleges, and schools till March 31 for both teaching and non-teaching staff,” he said.The CM appealed to people to “comprehend the intensity” of the situation and avoid stepping out of their homes, especially senior citizens. “Stay at home as much as you can. Private sector institutions should also allow employees to work from home. Senior citizens are the most vulnerable of all and they should avoid going out,” he said.Responding to reports of people hoarding eatables, Kejriwal said panic buying should be avoided. “It will only worsen the situation. Both the Centre and state governments have been working in close coordination. There has been no community transmission until now and if we continue to work like this, we will be able to control the situation,” Kejriwal said.The LG has also directed officials to explore the possibilities of running mobile vans in residential areas to sell essential commodities of daily use and medical items.

Title: Covid-19: Karimnagar in virtual lockdown for health check
Content: HYDERABAD: With eight out of 11 Indonesians who arrived in Karimnagar testing positive for Covid-19, the district administration on Thursday began an exercise on a war-footing to conduct health check-ups for people at places the group visited.On Thursday, officials targeted to cover 10,000 houses. As many as 100 medical teams fanned out into all areas in the town to identify people with fever and, if necessary, they would be sent to Gandhi Hospital in Secunderabad if they show any symptoms of coronavirus It was as if the town was on a lockdown as shops and establishments closed down after authorities urged people to stay indoors for the health checks. Minister Gangula Kamalakar went around town urging people not to venture out of their houses and avoid gatherings.The Indonesian group had visited a mosque and it has already been sanitised. The community has been asked not to gather for Friday prayers there. Kamalakar said CCTV footage was being collected to identify the places the Indonesian group had visited.In addition, the authorities, who enquired about the movement of the Indonesian group, were reportedly informed that they had visited two other places of worship. The areas around those places would also be covered for health checks. Initially, 100-metre radius of the places where the Indonesians had visited would be covered and subsequently it would be extended to a one-kilometre radius.A three-kilometre radius around the Karimnagar collectorate wore a deserted look as the area the Indonesians had visited, Mukarampura, was in its proximity. Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao said the religious preachers from Indonesia , after their arrival in India had landed in Ramagundam by train and from there, took autos to reach Karimnagar. The authorities were trying to ascertain how many local people came in contact with the group.Karimnagar police have directed people not to gather in groups in the area to prevent spread of the coronavirus. In addition to the 200-bed isolation ward at the government general hospital, isolation wards have been created at two more private health facilities.The leave of all medical personnel in Karimnagar has been suspended and they have been asked to be available round-the-clock, if the necessity arises.Meanwhile, the Indonesian ambassador to India, Sidharto Suryadipora has been informed by the Telangana government about the Indonesian nationals being admitted to Gandhi Hospital.
